DOC.HEAD: `Pizza Connection' Prosecutor to Head Probe
DOC.TEXT: The lead prosecutor in New York's ``pizza connection'' heroin trial was named Friday to coordinate the investigation in the bombing deaths of a federal judge and a black Savannah lawyer. Louis Freeh, an assistant U.S. Attorney in New York, was named to head the Justice Department investigation and prosecution of the case. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said he picked an outside prosecutor to oversee the probe because the mail bombs case spanned several jurisdictions. Freeh handled the 17-month New York trial of an Mafia ring that distributed tons of heroin and cocaine in the United States. He won prosecutions against 18 members of the $1.6 billion ring that used pizzerias as fronts to distribute large amounts of heroin and cocaine from 1975 to 1984. The reputed former chief of the Sicilian Mafia, Gaetano Badalamenti, and his associate, Salvatore Catalano, received 45-year prison terms for running the ring. In the present case, four packages containing explosives were sent to sites in Alabama, Florida and Georgia over a four-day period in mid-December. Two of them exploded, killing 11th U.S. Circuit Court Judge Robert S. Vance at his home near Birmingham, Ala., and Savannah Alderman Robert Robinson at his law office. Packages containing explosives were removed from the 11th Circuit's headquarters building in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``Hundreds of law enforcement personnel have been working on this investigation and cooperation among the various districts has been excellent,'' Thornburgh said. ``As this multi-district investigation has progressed, however, it has become evident that the naming of the a single coordinating prosecutor with overall responsibility is essential,'' the attorney general said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Security Chief Arrested After Criticizing Collor's Policy
DOC.TEXT: The army on Friday ordered the arrest of Brazil's former secret service chief after he criticized President Fernando Collor de Mello and the new government's economic reform plans, officials said. Also disciplined for similar criticism was retired Gen. Euclydes Figueiredo, the brother of former military President Joao Figueiredo. Carlos Tinoco, the minister of the army, announced the punishments in a televised interview. The presidential palace refused to comment. Both generals were punished under a military code that prohibits military personnel from making political statements or attacks on the president to the press without authorization from an armed forces minister. The confrontation underlies growing tensions between Collor and conservative elements of Brazil's armed forces. Tinoco said Gen. Newton Cruz, the former head of the recently abolished secret service, was ordered arrested for 10 days in an army barracks in Brasilia after attacking Collor in an interview published Friday in the O Estado de Sao Paulo newspaper. Cruz criticized Collor for firing 400,000 public employees earlier this week to speed his anti-inflation program. ``I think we live in a dictatorship validated by the judiciary and the Congress,'' Cruz was quoted as saying. ``If former President Jose Sarney erred by lacking authority and determination, Collor fails for his excessive aggressiveness.'' Tinoco said Cruz confirmed ``basically all of his criticisms.'' Euclydes Figueiredo was also severely reprimanded for defending Cruz's criticisms in a separate article, Tinoco said. In addition to scrapping the 29-year-old secret service, Collor has irked a number of generals by opening up classified files of political opponents to the 1964-85 right-wing military regime. Figueiredo ended military rule by turning the presidency over to Sarney, a civilian, but the military exerted great influence during the five-year Sarney administration.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Countywide Judicial Elections in Texas
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court panel Friday upheld Texas' countywide elections for judges, ruling 2-1 that black voting strength isn't illegally diluted by electing as many as 59 judges at large from one county. The three-judge panel of the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton's decision that the elections in nine urban Texas counties illegally dilute the strength of minority voters. ``While elected judges are representatives in that they are accountable to a constituency of electors, the full authority of a trial judge's office is exercised exclusively by one individual, and there can be no share of such a single-member office,'' the panel said in its decision. ``Consequently, the countywide election of district court judges does not violate the Voting Rights Act.'' Bunton, ruling last November on a lawsuit by the League of United Latin American Citizens, ordered Texas to divide the nine counties into electoral subdistricts and to hold nonpartisan elections in those districts. Bunton had directed the elections be held May 5, but the appellate court has stayed that order. The counties _ which include Dallas, Fort Worth, Houston, San Antonio, Austin and four smaller cities _ elect 172 of Texas' 390 district judges. Friday's decision ``is clearly good news for our judicial system and for the people of Texas,'' said Gov. Bill Clements. ``By its decision today, the panel ruled that Texans will retain the right to elect all trial judges who serve in their local county courthouse.'' ``As Texas' chief elections officer and a defendant in this lawsuit, I am extremely pleased with this action,'' said Texas Secretary of State George Bayoud. The League of United Latin American Citizens, a major minority rights group based in San Antonio, didn't immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. The losing side can petition the panel for a rehearing, or appeal to the Supreme Court. Appeals Judge Sam D. Johnson of Austin disagreed with the ruling by Judge Patrick Higginbotham of Dallas, who voted with Judge Carolyn Dineen King of Houston. ``I am totally at odds with the majority's application of the so-called single officeholder exception,'' Johnson wrote in his dissent. He said the majority incorrectly based its decision on a New York case involving three candidates elected from three different districts. ``The majority expands (this) beyond its logical bounds,'' wrote Johnson. Under Texas law, district judges are elected every four years. They run at-large, with all voters in a county allowed to vote in every race. Bunton said the at-large elections deny Hispanic and black voters an equal chance to elect the candidates they want. The appellate panel rejected Texas' arguments that judges are not representatives, and that Congress didn't mean judicial elections to fall under the Voting Rights Act. But it also rejected the central argument brought by the league: that each judge is part of a larger court which should have more black representatives. ``Indisputably, district judges in Texas share administrative tasks with other district judges in the same county,'' it said. ``Equally indisputably, however, the district judge in Texas does his judging alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Swamped Marinas, Flooded Campsites May Harm Tourism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 12th graf pvs, `We're looking...,' to UPDATE with request for disaster declaration in Oklahoma; SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT style error. Also moving on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TRK5
DOC.TEXT: With Memorial Day on the horizon and floods in the foreground, Lake Texoma businesses that spend millions to lure fishermen and boaters are worrying about swamped marinas and closed campsites. Intermittent rains fell over the region Friday and showers are forecast for the next few days, but some business owners hope they can recover in time for Memorial Day, the first big holiday of the season. ``You always think things won't get this bad,'' said Arnold Perkins, president of the Lake Texoma Association. ``We've had floods 10 to 15 feet above normal _ that's a bad flood. We're talking 24 feet above level now.'' Normal elevation at Lake Texoma, on the Red River at the Texas line, is 617 feet above sea level. It crested Monday at 644.76 feet, dipped to 641.4 Friday, but still sloshes window-high on mobile homes once 100 feet from its shore. A restaurant, disco and marina complex used by 5,000 to 6,000 people a day during the summer, was submerged and has been flooded for three weeks. David Hull, who leases the property, estimates damage at $2 million. About 700 concession workers have been laid off because heavy rains in the region pushed the lake to its highest levels since it was built in 1944. Some campsites, lodges and golf courses are open, but word is out that Lake Texoma has suffered its worst flooding since 1957, and that could be as big a blow to the tourism industry as the flooding itself, Perkins said. The rains in Oklahoma and Texas filled lakes to their brims, causing flooding in the two states and Arkansas as water was released downstream on the Arkansas and Red rivers. The Army Corps of Engineers said its expects a greater volume of water to move safely through the Red River flood control system than did in the disastrous floods of 1957 and 1927. Texas had a dozen flood-related deaths; Oklahoma, one. Corps spokesman Ed Engelke said the 20 camping areas around Lake Eufaula in eastern Oklahoma all have limited access because of high waters there. He said rangers must check for damage before the sites are fully accessible. Downstream in Arkansas, where the Arkansas River is receding from its crests at Little Rock and Pine Bluff, the Red River crested 8 feet above flood stage Thursday at Fulton and closed westbound lanes of Interstate 30. ``We're looking at 80 square miles of flooding,'' said Jim Barnes, head of the U.S. Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service in Little River County. ``It stretches for six miles.'' Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon asked President Bush on Friday for federal disaster assistance for 36 of Oklahoma's 77 counties because of the floods. In Texas, where severe flooding extended along the Trinity River from north Texas to the Gulf Coast, the Red has flooded 40 homes near Texarkana, where National Guard troops were in their fourth day of reinforcing levees. At Lake Grapevine near Dallas, some say it could take months for boat ramps to be reopened because of recent high waters. ``Summertime is like our Christmas. We only make it three months out of the year,'' said Terri Berthelsen, manager of the Landing Snack Shop at the marina. ``We pulled through last year on our savings _ this year we don't know what is going to happen.'' On Lake Texoma, Caney Creek Resort owner Virginia Wornom said business slowed considerably in the last week and should stay through Memorial Day and beyond, ``until people realize we haven't floated off.'' ``In the next two weeks, all the marinas should be in condition to take care of the public,'' Perkins said, but on Friday about half were either under water or inaccessible. Perkins said water covered the roads leading to his marina in Denison, Texas. His restaurant, once 5 feet deep in water, reopened Friday. He and other proprietors say they can't begin to guess at the amount of the damage until the water recedes. The Corps of Engineers has said it could be 45 to 60 days before the lake returns to a ``decent level.'' Perkins and other business owners have their eye on the holiday weekend, traditionally a huge kickoff for a season that runs through Labor Day. ``We were booked solid for Memorial Day, but we've had a lot of cancellations,'' said Marion Stone, owner of Soldier Creek Resort and Marina. ``People are not going to come to the lake.'' James Atnip, superintendent of Lake Texoma State Park, said park officials are trying to be positive, even though 270 of the 300 campsites are closed and tree limbs and other debris are scattered across the lake. ``There's not going to be a Lake Texoma this summer,'' said Mrs. Stone. ``All the beaches are under water. The water is murky. The publicity has been harmful, but we try not to mislead people.''

DOC.HEAD: Manhattan Pedestrians: Life in the Bus Lane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The pedestrian _ the most flexible, inexpensive and pollution-free unit of transportation _ is being driven into Manhattan streets by sidewalk obstructions. Obstacles range from construction scaffolding to slow-moving out-of-towners. This becomes apparent on the west side of Lexington Avenue each weekday afternoon at 5:23 when, according to scientific studies, the sidewalk between 42nd and 43rd streets is the most crowded on the planet. Almost 160 pedestrians a minute squeeze through a channel usually narrowed to 4 feet by newspaper vending machines, trash cans, street and traffic light poles, a newsstand, a table selling exotic oils and incense, a flower stand and a tank of refrigerated liquid nitrogen. Something has to give, so the pedestrians step off the curb _ a few at first, then more, until at least a third of the thousands steaming toward Grand Central Terminal are doing so in the dubious safety of the Lexington Avenue bus lane. ``The pedestrian has been losing ground in the struggle for space in Manhattan,'' according to a report by the borough president's office, ``and that is a serious problem in an environment which depends so heavily on walking for its mobility.'' Another reminder of how serious a problem came last week. Erica Moreno, 3, was walking hand-in-hand with her mother in 40th Street because a construction project had closed the sidewalk. A driver lost control of his car and smashed another vehicle into the girl, killing her. Each year, cars and trucks in New York kill more than 600 pedestrians and injure 15,000. William H. Whyte, an urban planner who has counted and studied pedestrians on Lexington and streets all over the world, says New Yorkers try to bully cars with an attitude of ``make way for me or kill me.'' But walking is vital on a crowded island where 60 percent of eligible adults don't even have a driver's license, and Whyte says pedestrians in Manhattan walk longer and faster than any place in America. They need space, however, and Manhattan's already congested streets and sidewalks have been tied up by the financial services boom of the 1980s, which brought in more workers, and the attendant construction boom, which closed down more sidewalks. Then there are tourists. A male New York pedestrian's cruising speed can exceed 350 feet a minute; visitors from less populous communities often move at 250 feet a minute, and they have been seen doing so three abreast. As a result, locals are always walking up the heels of out-of-towners. But the biggest problem is the dimension and condition of the city's pedestrian infrastructure _ the sidewalks. On Lexington between 42nd and 60th much of the pavement is cracked or buckled, sloping in spots at 20 degrees. It is full of holes and hollows, some with semipermanent puddles replenished by rain and snow in winter, and by condensate from store air conditioners in summer. At 12{ feet, Lexington's sidewalks are far narrower than Fifth Avenue's (22 feet), and they usually are further reduced by various obstacles. Traffic is reduced to one lane at the northwest corner of 60th by a subway entrance, construction scaffolding and a ``newsstand'' selling everything but washing machines. Most of the space along Lexington goes to vehicles, even though the pedestrian volume at the Lexington entrance to Grand Central is rivaled only by one approach to Tokyo's Shinjuku rail station. About 78 percent of the people moving along the avenue at peak periods are on foot; only 22 percent are in vehicles. Yet only 34 percent of the avenue's total space is given to pedestrians (20 percent of that usable), while vehicles get 66 percent. To pedestrians, the solution seems obvious: damn the motorists and widen the sidewalks. The city plans the latter on Sixth Avenue above 42nd Street, where it will narrow each vehicular lane to add 3 feet of sidewalk. Drivers and many businesses oppose such tactics, but later this year a coalition of environmental groups will ask the city to begin a broad program of sidewalk expansion and reconstruction. Until that happens there will be more jaywalking, more midblock crossing, more people in the bus lane, according to Peter Hecht of the Project for Public Spaces, who has filmed and studied pedestrian movements. Street walking, he says, ``is the pedestrian's way of saying the sidewalks are too crowded. They're voting with their feet.''

DOC.HEAD: Survivor Leads Search for Bodies of 1970 Riot Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Adam Gotner, badly wounded, survived that bloody day when police opened fire on people in the street. Twenty years later, Solidarity runs the government and he leads a search for secretly buried bodies. Dec. 17, 1970 is etched in Polish memory as a day of slaughter. At 6 a.m., Gotner and many others were walking to their jobs at the Paris Commune shipyard. Tanks and police were posted at the shipyard gates. Suddenly, the police began shooting. Gotner, then 25, felt something hit his shoulder and saw his jacket turning red. He thought of running at the tanks, ``but I realized it would be instant suicide,'' and retreated. ``All this time, for several minutes, I could hear the shooting continuing, and then it seemed I was stepping on people,'' he said. ``I had the impression I was stepping on bodies. The whole street had been covered with people going to work. In my mind, there were at least 500 dead.'' Long afterward, Gotner realized most were not dead, but either wounded or sprawling for cover. The communist authorities had declared the port and shipyard closed because of unrest over government-imposed increases in food prices, but had not told the workers. Police may have thought the men intended to occupy the shipyard. Official accounts said 45 Baltic port and shipyard workers were killed that day, 28 of them in Gdynia and Gdansk. Many Poles believe the number was much higher. A committee led by Gotner is trying to determine how many died in Gdynia, which means digging for bodies. Two excavations have yielded no conclusive results. A macabre legend grew around the ``December events'' and the authorities contributed to it by collecting bodies and burying them hastily at night, often with no relatives present. Tombstones erected later were allowed to say only that the person honored had died a ``tragic death.'' No mention of the Gdynia killings was permitted in the state-controlled press. Attempts to investigate were blocked even in 1980-81, Solidarity's first brief experience of legal existence. Censorship was eased enough to allow Andrzej Wajda to make the acclaimed movie ``Man of Iron,'' in which the 1970 Gdynia killings are portrayed as central to the rise of Solidarity a decade later. Gotner survived five bullet wounds in the chest, eventually became a Solidarity activist in Gdynia and organized a civic committee this year to build a new monument to the victims in front of City Hall. Soon after it was formed, his committee came under public pressure to investigate the killings. With the Communist Party out of power, city officials agreed. On a sunny April day at the Witominski Cemetery, gravediggers lifted the coffin of Jadwiga Sikorska from a sandy hillside and probed a little deeper. They found two sets of bones wrapped in cloth. One was too old to be from 1970; the other did not appear old enough. A representative of the prosecutor's office was present and the remains were taken to a forensic laboratory for analysis. Mrs. Sikorska's son, Jerzy, had noticed bones in the earth when he buried his mother in March and told the committee. Earlier, 70 volunteers dug up a 60-foot stretch of path in another part of the cemetery where witnesses had reported signs of newly dug graves immediately after the 1970 shootings. No bodies were found. Experts confirmed part of the path had been dug up about 20 years ago, but only to a depth of about four feet. They said there was no evidence the soil had been disturbed below that depth for hundreds of years. ``There were several hypotheses, and mine is that they were preparing to bury bodies there and then decided not to because of personnel changes in the government,'' Gotner said in an interview at his modest apartment overlooking the shipyard. He is a slender, articulate man with dark, curly hair salted with gray, and is cautious in expressing opinions about the outcome of his search. When pressed, Gotner said: ``I think it may turn out to be true that five or 10 more people were killed than has been reported.'' That conclusion would not be popular. ``Already, I have heard gossip that the fact that we have not found anything proves we are on the side of the authorities,'' he said. Several people claimed to have seen secret burials. Three witnesses who appeared reliable, including a militiaman, claim to have seen about 200 bodies. Gortner noted, however, that ``no one is coming to us and asking us to find somebody,'' despite public appeals for information. Whether the victims were more or fewer, Gotner said, ``we want to find the truth. We cannot let half-truths continue to exist if we want to build the future.'' He removed his shirt, revealing scars on the upper chest and a very deep exit wound in his back. ``If I had known I had five bullets in me, I would have died of fright,'' he said, and laughed. The laughter gone, Gotner said: ``Doing this is my responsibility to those who died at that time. I remember when I was walking and I saw someone falling down. I wanted to to help him then, but I could not.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Editor Says U.S. Press Marches In Lock Step
DOC.TEXT: The American press ought not to be described as free because its members keep playing the same tune, according to an assessment by a controversial Russian magazine editor reported in Friday editions of The Washington Post. ``All our stay in this country is described with the same epithets, the same words, the same expressions, as if it was Xeroxed,'' Stanislav Kunayev was quoted as saying. Kunayev, editor of Nash Sovremennik (Our Contemporary), was one of eight editors and writers chosen by the U.S. Embassy in Moscow for their Russian nationalist views for a month-long tour of the United States. Jewish organizations protested the visit, saying Kunayev and others in the delegation advocated anti-semitic views. The sponsor, the U.S. Information Agency, defended the choices on the grounds that everybody could benefit from a close look at a free, open society. Kunayev was interviewed at a reception at Columbia University in New York City, the newspaper reported. He was quoted as saying, ``You folks in America worry too much about the Jews. They're not that bad off.'' He called the controversy over the visit ``primitive and ludicrous'' and said, ``I don't see any reason to call the American press a free press in relation to us.'' Kunayev, who has been quoted as saying he supports the United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism, told the interviewer he opposes the form of Zionism that spreads reports of what he called ``nonexistent pogroms.'' He criticized the extremist Russian patriotic group, Pamyat, on the grounds that ``their practice helps Zionists'' but added that the group is ``a phantom which is exaggerated by propaganda.'' Viktor Likhonosov, an author, described the tour: ``By and large, there was no chance for dialogue, the way the newspapers were proceeding. ``It's particularly surprising when you know you're not the way you're represented and you think you're behaving honorably. Even during the Cold War, they received governmental people with more understanding.'' Kunayev said, ``Between all the nationalities (in the Soviet Union) we have very tense relationships, and the Jewish question is not the most important one.''

DOC.HEAD: Toughest Federal Prison Prepares for Move
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's toughest penitentiary will be losing that distinction along with some of its most hardened criminals now that federal officials have decided to build a new prison in Colorado. The changeover is still more than 2{ years away. But it will mark the end of almost three decades in which U.S. Penitentiary-Marion has served as the nation's Alcatraz, housing inmates no other prison is equipped to handle _ guard killers, escape artists and spies. ``You don't get into Marion by being a nice person,'' said Terry Finnegan, administrator at Marion, the nation's only federal penitentiary rated as level six, the highest level of security. The Federal Bureau of Prisons decided four months ago to build a complex at Florence, Colo., said Jack Crosley, assistant warden at Marion. It will include a level-six section with space for 500 inmates, and when it is finished, Marion will be remodeled and downgraded to a level five. Construction of the new prison hasn't begun but is expected to be finished in December 1992. It should be cheaper than modernizing Marion, which was built in 1963, Crosley said. The prison will be designed so that one guard can control the movements of prisoners in several cellblocks using electronic doors, cameras and audio equipment. Even with its tight security, Marion has had to resort to locking most of its approximately 360 prisoners in their cells 23 hours a day since October 1983, when two guards and one inmate were killed in a series of confrontations. Once the new prison is built, Marion prisoners won't be transferred en masse, said John L. Clark, who took over as Marion's warden in January. ``It will happen in slow transition. We will take one or two cell houses at a time so that the staff can get their feet on the ground,'' said Clark. Marion's 230 guards have mixed feelings about losing their level six status, Clark said in a recent interview. ``Right now, the staff are very proud of the unique role they play at the Marion prison,'' he said. ``It will be a change; it will take some adjustment.'' Colorado residents are undaunted by the prospect of living near the most violent federal criminals. Fremont County, about 120 miles south of Denver, welcomed the complex with $130,000 in incentives, said County Commission member Bud Chess. The county already is home to seven state prisons, Chess said. ``To the people here, it's just part of life. When you move something like that into an area where the people haven't been around prisoners, they are all shook up,'' Chess said from his office in the county seat of Canon City. The $160 million Florence prison complex will house 1,960 prisoners in security levels ranging from minimum to maximum, said Federal Bureau of Prisons spokesman Scott Burton in Washington, D.C. Clark estimated that the new prison will have about 500 beds for level six inmates. Burton said it would require a total of 650 to 750 staff members, including an undetermined number of guards. A decision is pending on whether some of the most infamous Marion inmates _ including spies Jonathan Pollard and John Walker Jr., Colombian drug lord Carlos Lehder Rivas and escape artist Garrett Brock Trapnell _ will be among those transferred, officials said. Those inmates are among seven who live in Marion's K-Unit, reserved for the most notorious prisoners, which one prison official said takes ``nearly an act of Congress'' for visitors to gain access to. When Marion is changed to level five, it will have enlarged recreation areas, a central education area, more classrooms and psychologists' rooms and an expanded library, Clark said. ``There are large parts of the institution that aren't used much or aren't used at all,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Life Along the Flooded Banks of the Arkansas River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A few of the people who own homes in the Mud Lake area near Pine Bluff, Ark., have been boating through the treetops and rooftops. ``Was the driveway rough?'' W.H. ``Buddy'' Clark joked as his visitors glided to a stop, their boat almost even with the windows of his garage. Clark and his wife, Eula, park their boat on a levee and go into town to get ice and groceries. They cook on a borrowed camp stove. They have no utilities other than water so they motor over to a neighbor's house to watch the evening news. ``If it wasn't so bad, it would almost be fun,'' Mrs. Clark said. ``Last night was a beautiful sunset. That helped.''

Jim Cunningham and his wife, Edwyle, live in Stuttgart, Ark., but they have a summer home on Swan Lake near Pine Bluff. Cunningham said each of the homeowners in the area will have to spend between $10,000 and $15,000 to get their homes back in order. Mrs. Cunningham says the soggy experience finally go to her: ``When I went to sleep last night, all I saw was snakes and water.''

Many flood victims dread what they will find when the water goes down. ``The problems are probably just starting,'' said Dwayne Ayers, who found water almost hip-deep in one level of his home near Pine Bluff. ``Paneling is buckling on the walls. The cabinets have buckled. The wallpaper is coming off the walls.''

Sewage from a backed-up manhole poured into Gary Peeler's back yard in North Little Rock, Ark. Water covered a 3-foot-high bird bath. ``You could see that yesterday,'' he said. ``Just try to find that sucker now. I'm not worried about the flood, I'm worried about the sewer lines. This isn't river water, this is raw sewage. ``Politics and the sewers are closely related,'' he said. ``They decide beforehand whether the sewage is going to go before it (the flood) happens. They can't say God is deciding anymore.''

North of Little Rock, State Rep. Lloyd George, D-Danville, had about 150 head of cattle trapped on 40 acres of dry land. ``Obviously, that's not enough for them to feed on,'' he said. The cows are hemmed in on three sides by water and by a neighbor's fence on the fourth side. It's costing him $100 a day to feed the cattle that otherwise would graze, George said. ``I'm concerned about these cattle _ if I have to keep feeding them it gets expensive,'' said George. He went on to counter some critics who say the situation has been made worse by the Army Corps of Engineers, which operates a lock and dam system along the river: ``That's not the Engineers fault,'' George said. ``The Lord made it rain.''

Gary Harper's front yard drops into the water about 10 feet from his front steps in Jefferson County, Ark., and Harper has been fishing from his yard since the weekend. ``I caught a bunch of catfish last night,'' he said.

West of Pine Bluff, the Felix Brown family had to call on a friend with a rodeo background to rescue between 160 and 170 cattle stranded on an island. The water surrounding the island ranged from 4 to 35 feet deep, Melvin Brown said. The only way they could manage to get the cattle onto boats was for friend Danny Murdock and some others with rodeo training to tie the animals' feet together. ``We toted about 40 calves in flat-bottomed fishing boats across Saturday because the water wasn't deep enough for a barge to get in there,'' Brown said. ``We tied their feet and brought two at the time.'' Brown said the cattle were ``a little skittish, and we had a few crazy ones, but you always have that with cattle and water.''

When floodwaters sloshed into A.D. Chavis' home near Pine Bluff, he was glad to have a well-equipped boat nearby. ``Me and the dog are living on the cruiser,'' said Chavis. ``We have a color TV, air-conditioning, and I just got through vacuuming.'' All is far from well, though _ Chavis spent $8,000 on home improvements since last year. Looking at the flood damage, he said: ``If I'd known about this, I would have gone on a big drunk.''

DOC.HEAD: Traffic Jams and Landfills Reach The Highest Peak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Traffic jams and landfills have come to Mount Everest, the roof of the world. A growing number of nature lovers, and the flags, clothes and oxygen tanks they leave behind, are turning parts of the majestic mountain into a garbage dump. And a crowded one at that. A long line of climbers snaked near Everest's peak Thursday, vying for elbow room on the top. Americans, New Zealanders, Swiss, Soviets, Chinese and Australians queued up to reach the 29,028-foot summit. One was the son of Sir Edmund Hillary, the first person to reach the summit. Hillary has expressed concern about damage to the fragile ecology of the Himalayas. At least 17 people reached the crowded summit over the course of the day. Some came within minutes of each other. One group came from the north side, but the others hiked from the southeast, taking the traditional route made famous by Hillary, the New Zealander who first conquered Everest with his Nepalese guide, Tenzing Norgay, on May 29, 1953. Fortunately, Thursday's climbers did not all reach the summit at once. Everest's pointy peak has room for only about 10 hikers _ backpacks and oxygen gear included. It has been one of the mountain's busiest seasons. A Japanese team of three even tried to fly over Everest, in the first attempt to buzz the peak in a hot air balloon. They crashed Wednesday and one man suffered leg injuries. In late April, the Nepalese Tourist Administration said more than 100 people were climbing the mountain from the Nepalese side. Add to that a group of 30 climbers from a ``peace group'' of Soviets, Chinese and Americans, who attacked the mountain from Tibet. This mountainous traffic jam raises questions about the effects such hikes have on the ecology of Everest and the pristine Himalayas. The mountain range, famed for its breathtaking views, pure air and fertile valleys, is being ravaged by deforestation. Population increases in the Himalayan valleys have led farmers to cut down local forests for fuel and housing. Maneka Gandhi, India's minister of state for environment, warns that deforestation will have disastrous results far beyond the highlands. Already, it contributes to flooding in Bangladesh and erosion in the Indian plains. Everest itself has been turned into a dump in some places _ littered with mountaineers' used oxygen tanks, metal food containers, flags and clothes. Climbers estimate that two tons of garbage despoil Everest's majestic flanks. Since this year's season began, the first to reach to peak were Nepalese soldiers. On April 24, five of 25 soldiers scaled Everest's heights. Then three assaults from the ``peace group'' expedition made it to the top. Among the pack Thursday was Hillary's 36-year-old son, Peter. He reached the summit at 7:30 a.m., with two other members of an eight-member team from New Zealand along with a Nepalese sherpa guide. Even at that early hour, which necessitated setting out from the 26,197-foot high Camp 4 an hour before midnight Wednesday, Hillary still wasn't the first. Five Americans had already arrived at the peak with two sherpas. The climbers were Peter George Alhams, 32, of Snow Bird, Utah; Dana Quentin Coffield, 31, of Columbia, S.C.; Glenn Porzak, 41, of Boulder, Colo.; Michael Browning, 37, of Monitou Spring, Colo.; and Brent Manning, 39, of Salt Lake City. Later in the day, six climbers from the joint American-Chinese-Soviet team scaled Everest, bringing to 20 the number from the ``peace group'' to reach the summit. Two more teams were waiting in the wings. Three Belgians turned back when the regulator of an oxygen cylinder burst. Only one expedition in the recent season set out with the express idea of cleaning the mountain. The ``peace group'' will be filling up duffle bags to be buried in a landfill near the mountain's base camp. Jim Whittaker, a top American mountaineer who is overseeing the international trip, has focused attention on the garbage problem. Whittaker was the first American to climb Everest in 1963. Edmund Hillary has also spoken out against the destruction of the Himalayan range. In a news conference in March in New Delhi, Hillary, now 70, said tourist development has destroyed much of the beauty of the Himalayas. ``The living standards are increasing, but the beautiful tracks and valleys have been littered and the forests destroyed,'' he said. Indeed, trekking traffic in the Himalayas has skyrocketed in the past decade, fueled by the desire by many Westerners for exotic vacations. The jam on Everest also has increased. Since Hillary first scaled its peak, Everest has been conquered about 240 times, sometimes by the same person. About 100 people have died making the attempt. The going price for an expedition ranges from $50,000 to $300,000, depending on its size. Each sherpa makes about $300 to $500 per climb.

DOC.HEAD: Poles Face New Shortage: Lack of Passports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Poles once blamed the Communists for shortages of everything from meat to gasoline, but their newly won freedoms have produced a unique supply problem _ too few passports to meet the demand. Now that regulations have been loosened to allow Poles to travel freely abroad, there has been a rush to apply for passports, which people can now keep at home. This has resulted in a shortage of the passport documents themselves, according to media reports. A personnel shortage also has lengthened the waiting time for passports, the pro-Solidarity daily Gazeta Wyborcza reported this week. Sometimes the wait is even longer than it took to obtain a passport when the Communists were still in power. A meeting at the Interior Ministry on Tuesday failed to solve the problem. The document shortage is blamed on the state mint, which prints passports, the newspaper said. ``While the holiday season is approaching, the lack of passports continues. The Interior Ministry did not promise any rapid improvement,'' Gazeta Wyborcza said. Negotiations are under way with a Swiss firm to produce the travel documents, but the $22 million price tag may prove too high for the financially strapped government, the newspaper said. In one Warsaw district, the wait for a passport now exceeds two months and the situation is similar across Poland, Gazeta Wyborcza said. The issuance of passports is to be transferred from the Interior Ministry, which controls the police and security forces, to the civil administration under reforms pending in parliament. But that shift, which will take three months from the time the law is enacted, is not expected to solve the shortage, the newspaper said. After martial law was lifted in 1983, Communist authorities gradually eased restrictions on travel abroad, and in many cases Poles were able to receive a passport within several weeks of filing their application. In early 1989, the then-Communist government lifted a regulation requiring Poles to surrender their passport to police after every trip abroad and then reapply for the document when they wanted to travel again. Instead, Poles were allowed to keep their passport at home, and the document remained valid for an unlimited number of trips abroad for up to 10 years. The Solidarity-led government, which came to power in August, has further eased travel regulations. The biggest problem now for Poles wanting to travel West is obtaining a visa. Poles face long lines and must undergo a careful screening process in order to obtain visas for such popular destinations as Britain and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Man Robs Bank To Pay Tip
DOC.TEXT: A man who wanted to do right by a waitress took things too far, police said, robbing a bank to come up with her tip. The man, whom police described as a shirtless transient, became concerned when he went to pay the $4 bill for his lunch at the downtown Golden Spike restaurant Wednesday afternoon. ``After he ate, he told the waitress, `I don't have enough money for a tip, but I'm going to go rob a bank and I'll be back,''' said Dolores Steggell, supervisor of the restaurant. The man allegedly walked across the street to First Interstate Bank, told the teller he had a gun and demanded all of the $20s, said Salt Lake Police Lt. Joel Campbell. He fled the bank clutching about $1,200 in his hand and entered the restaurant, where he gave the waitress a $2 tip, Steggell said. Before he was able to leave, police arrived, arrested him and recovered the money _ including the tip. John Milton Park, 31, was booked into the Salt Lake County Jail pending a federal court hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Oral Roberts University Cuts Deal to Buy PTL Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, bgn `The actual...,' to UPDATE with 6 grafs of Roberts' comment. DELETES outdated 15th graf pvs, `Officials at...'
DOC.TEXT: Oral Roberts University has agreed to pay $6 million in cash for the PTL satellite network once headed by Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker, but the ministry's court-appointed trustee said Thursday the deal is not final. The trustee, Columbia attorney Dennis Shedd, said he is still hoping to sell the network and other PTL assets as a package before the contract with Oral Roberts is approved by a U.S. bankruptcy judge. Shedd said he signed the pact with the Tulsa, Okla.-based university founded by evangelist Oral Roberts because he wants to force action by buyers interested in acquiring the entire PTL complex. He added, however, that he did not yet have such an offer although ``there are four or five groups that are seriously looking at'' the whole package. Shedd declined to identify them. ``I do have a firm deal with Oral Roberts University. However, in the contract, I expressly reserved the right to sell all the assets until the point of approval of the sale of just the network,'' Shedd said in a telephone interview. The complex includes the satellite network, the 500-acre Heritage USA Christian retreat in Fort Mill and 1,700 acres of undeveloped land in upstate South Carolina. Shedd said he made the deal ``because I have a cash offer and I think it makes good business sense to sell this asset. This asset is essentially deteriorating. ... Plus, it also works into the broader scheme to sell the whole property.'' Shedd filed legal papers in Columbia Thursday asking U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Thurmond Bishop to approve the sale to Roberts on May 31 _ in effect the deadline for prospective bidders to submit offers for the entire package. The actual contract signing, which was done by fax machine and air express service between Tulsa and Columbia, was completed Wednesday and included a $1 million down payment. ``I plan to sell it one way or the other and this is the only firm offer I have for any substantial part of the estate,'' Shedd said. Richard Roberts, son of the 72-year-old faith-healer, said university regents approved the offer this week. ``We believe it is important to provide 24-hour Christian broadcasting to a global audience assuring that God's word will be taken to every man's world,'' Roberts said in a statement. Roberts told the Tulsa World the agreement was reached about two weeks ago but that ministry officials needed seven days to raise the money for the down payment. ``We were able to raise the $1 million from our regents and from several of our very dear prayer partners,'' Roberts told the newspaper. The assets of the Bakkers' former religious broadcasting empire have been on the block since April 1988, a year after Jim Bakker resigned in a sex-and-money scandal. Bakker was convicted last fall of fraudulently raising $158 million from PTL contributors and is serving a 45-year prison sentence in a federal prison in Minnesota. The Heritage USA retreat has been shut since September, when Canadian businessman Stephen Mernick failed to close on his contract to buy the assets for $65 million. The broadcast network, however, continues to operate with a skeleton staff of about 10 employees. It broadcasts shows produced by other evangelists such as Jerry Falwell, James Robison and Roberts' son, Richard. As for the network's future, Shedd told The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer, ``My understanding is they want to operate it as a religious network.'' The contract gives Roberts all the network's satellite and cable leases and all of PTL's television production equipment, which will be moved to Tulsa. Shedd said Roberts has already given him a $1 million deposit, which will be refunded if all PTL's assets are sold as a package to another buyer. The remaining $5 million is due in cash at the closing, which is to come 10 days after Federal Communications Commission approval transferring the broadcasting license, The Observer reported. ``I think it's a good price,'' Shedd said. At the time PTL declared bankruptcy in June 1987, the satellite network was carried on 1,300 cable systems that had 12 million subscribers. According to court papers filed Thursday, that has slipped to 800 systems with 6.4 million subscribers, The Observer reported. Besides PTL, there are only four other religious satellite networks in the United States: Pat Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network (CBN), the Southern Baptist Convention's ACTS network, Paul Crouch's Trinity Network and Jimmy Allen's LIFE TV. Other evangelists such as Roberts buy time on those four networks.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Team Excavates Crash Sites
DOC.TEXT: A joint U.S.-Vietnamese team has excavated warplane crash sites in central Vietnam to search for the remains of about 12 missing American airmen, the official Vietnam News Agency reported. The report, dated Thursday and seen in Bangkok today, did not say if anything was recovered from the search in Quang Tri and Quang Binh. The 21-day project ended Thursday. It was the 10th time Vietnamese and U.S. specialists have conducted joint field searches for remains of a total of about 2,300 American servicemen listed as missing in action, or MIA, from the Vietnam War. The war ended 15 years ago in a Communist North Vietnamese victory over the U.S.-backed South Vietnam government, and many Vietnamese and American experts believe many of the remains will never be found. The U.S. government has said progress on the MIA search will determine the pace of efforts to establish diplomatic relations between the United States and Vietnam. The major barrier is Washington's demand for a political settlement of the war in Cambodia, which Vietnamese soldiers invaded in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Jazz trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie made dreams come true _ his and Soviets' _ by bebopping his way to the Soviet capital for the first time in his long career. ``I've always wanted to come to Moscow, but nobody ever asked me,'' Gillespie said. Gillespie, 72, finally got the invitation from One World for All, a charity for peace and the environment. He played East Berlin on Wednesday and travels next to Prague, Czechoslovakia. After Thursday's concert, attended by about 2,500 people who jammed the Hotel Rossiya Concert Hall, a Soviet fan said he also had waited a long time. ``I'm delighted that after 40 years of dreaming, in my life I've gotten to see and hear Dizzy Gillespie,'' said Igor Itkin. Gillespie, his cheeks puffed out as he blew into his bent-bell trumpet, was showered with flowers after each song, prompting him to remark, ``I haven't had so many flowers in my life!''

It's not easy being Zsa Zsa's sister, dahlink. Eva Gabor, whose Bel-Air mansion is just a few miles from Zsa Zsa's estate, complains she's always getting mixed up with her more notorious sibling. But convicted cop slapper Zsa Zsa also has suffered an occasional identity crisis: Witnesses testified in last fall's colorful trial that they recognized Zsa Zsa from her ``Green Acres'' TV role. Actually, it was Eva who appeared in the series with a pig named Arnold. And she reprises her role in the May 18 CBS-TV movie ``Return to Green Acres.'' ``Why should we be linked together, dahlink? That annoys the hell out of me. Because we have very different lives and what is white for her is black for me,'' the 69-year-old Eva said in a recent interview. ``Of course, she's my sister and I love her. ``But I don't necessarily approve of certain things she does, nor does she of what I do. I just think it's so unfair, and I suffer a lot for it.'' Eva Gabor went into ``serious hiding'' during her sister's legal problems, but she conceded: ``It's awfully boring to be called the `good Gabor.'''

Eight vehicles belonging to comedian Redd Foxx were going on the auction block today to help pay the $2.9 million the Internal Revenue Service claims he owes in back taxes. The vehicles, including a 1927 Model T Ford, were seized during a November 1989 raid at Foxx's Las Vegas home. Lawyers for Foxx agreed that the vehicles could be auctioned with some other items belonging to Foxx if the comedian could keep his home and other personal effects. Foxx's lawyer, Marc Risman, said the deal allows the IRS to attach part of Foxx's earnings from his show at the Hacienda Hotel in Las Vegas. ``He's paying back what he can afford to pay back at this time,'' Risman said. ``He gets a reasonable amount to live off of.''

Jane Pauley says she left NBC's ``Today'' show, where she was co-host for 13 years, because the job was in conflict with her family life. ``NBC was very serious about keeping me,'' Pauley told USA Weekend in this week's issue. ``We were in a mutual state of disbelief. They did not believe I was serious.'' Pauley, who left the morning show five months ago, has exchanged pre-dawn rising for daytime duties at NBC that include substituting for Tom Brokaw on the evening news for three weeks starting May 23. She says she is a less-stressed mother to her three children, 6-year-old twins Ross and Rachel and 3-year-old Thomas. ``They're getting a more relaxed bedtime routine,'' says Pauley. ``I'm more likely to linger over a bedtime story because I'm less anxious to get to bed myself.'' In the old days, she would rise at 3 a.m., get to the office by 5:30 a.m., spend afternoons at home preparing for the next day's show and be in bed by 8 p.m. Now she can breakfast with her kids and at night there's no homework to worry about.

A windowless warehouse auditorium in an industrial park is the new headquarters for Tammy Bakker's New Covenant Ministries, and she says the Orlando area is the next best thing to Heritage USA. This world of theme parks is the place for her, Mrs. Bakker said Wednesday even though her husband, Jim, is in Minnesota serving a 45-year federal prison term for fraud. ``This is where my husband left me, this is where he placed me, and I feel that I need to stay where he placed me,'' she said. Jim and Tammy Bakker moved to Orlando a year ago, shortly before the former televangelist went on trial on fraud and conspiracy charges in the PTL scandal involving the Heritage USA theme park in South Carolina.

Part of a superhighway has been renamed for Rosa Parks, whose refusal to give up her seat on a bus helped spark the civil rights movement in 1955. Ms. Parks, 76, who lives in Detroit, was honored Thursday when the Ohio Department of Transporation unveiled one of the signs that will be placed along the highway from Perrysburg to Toledo, a distance of about 10 miles. ``The dedication of Interstate 475 in the name of Rosa Parks will serve to remind us all of the sacrifice this great African-American woman has undertaken,'' said state Rep. Casey Jones, who sponsored legislation to rename the highway in her honor. Several streets in other cities, including Detroit and Montgomery, have been renamed in her honor, Ms. Parks said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Expectations Are Modest for Bush-Gorbachev Talks
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The tipoff was the story the other day that President Bush is willing to halt production of U.S. chemical weapons. The president is aiming for an agreement with Moscow _ provided he gets it on his terms _ to sharply reduce U.S. and Soviet stockpiles of poison gas. But the reason Bush is making the move now is that other arms control accords are proving to be elusive as the May 30-June 3 summit approaches. And Bush wants to be able to do some serious business with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to go along with five days of photo opportunities. Otherwise the two leaders could be accused of unproductive posturing. Months ago, when the summit was scheduled, it looked like an agreement could be ready to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines. Only wild optimists expected a finished treaty for Bush and Gorbachev to sign. The issues are complex. Besides, any verification system to make sure there is no cheating requires an enormous amount of work _ and trust. But considering the Soviet leader's determination to cut nuclear arms and Bush's positive response after an initial delay, the plan was to celebrate the summit with a strategic arms agreement-in-principle on key issues. Bush and Gorbachev would initial the framework accord, and up to 50 percent of the most dangerous weapons in the world would be consigned to the scrap heap after U.S. and Soviet negotiators in Geneva worked out the details. But with Gorbachev due here in less than three weeks, the two sides are still far apart. For example: they have agreed tentatively to eliminate land-based ballistic missiles with multiple warheads. But the Soviets want to extend the ban to such missiles carried by submarines. That is an area of U.S. strength, and the administration is balking. The Soviets also want to make deeper cuts in air-launched cruise missiles than the administration is willing to accept. The reason is the Pentagon plans a new missile above the cutoff range proposed by Moscow. Negotiations between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact have also slowed in Vienna on another treaty to reduce troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. The plan was to have the heads of 35 countries, including Bush and Gorbachev, sign the treaty at a European summit before the end of the year. There is still some hope of reaching that goal. But Bush's prediction last June that the treaty would be ready by now is falling flat, so he and Gorbachev are unable to announce that the major arms control accord is at the wrap-up stage. The picture could change when Secretary of State James A. Baker III holds talks in Moscow next week with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, although they failed to make serious headway only last week in Bonn. Thus, a chemical weapons accord looms as the most promising candidate for the Bush-Gorbachev summit, though it is not a cinch either. Bush wants the Soviets to agree that the two sides should retain small stockpiles of chemical weapons until all 40 nations sign and implement a global ban. The Soviets have resisted until now. Some two dozen nations are believed either to possess or be capable of manufacturing poison gas. The Soviet argument is that waiting for all 40 nations to carry out the treaty before scrapping the last U.S. and Soviet chemical weapons would indefinitely postpone ridding the world of poison gas. Still, the president's move this week probably is based on a judgment that enough is settled for him and Gorbachev to assure the people of the world that in one dangerous arena there may be cause for hope and that the United States and the Soviet Union will lead the way.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid covers diplomacy for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Fewer Nuclear Weapons Ahead
DOC.TEXT: NATO nations will have fewer nuclear weapons on their soil as a result of an alliance review of its future nuclear strategy needs, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney predicts. Cheney, speaking with reporters after a two-day NATO meeting in Western Canada, also left the door open for a unilateral alliance move to withdraw aged nuclear artillery shells from Western Europe. ``It's entirely possible,'' Cheney said. ``It wouldn't be the first time it's been done.'' The defense secretary said the North Atlantic Treaty Organization clearly is in the mood to pare its nuclear arsenal in light of the near-evaporation of the Warsaw Pact, prospects for Soviet troops withdrawals from Eastern Europe and East-West agreements to slash conventional forces. Given those developments, ``you can also take down nuclear forces,'' Cheney told reporters aboard his plane returning to Washington. ``We want to go to the lowest level (of nuclear weapons) we can ... we don't want any more nuclear weapons than necessary,'' he said. The meeting was the first alliance discussion of nuclear issues after President Bush announced he had dropped plans to upgrade short-range nuclear Lance missiles and was scrapping a move to modernize nuclear artillery. At the conference, Dutch and West German officials pressed for speedy, unilateral elimination of the 1,600 nuclear-tipped artillery shells. The weapons are designed to be used within a 10-to 20-mile range to halt an overwhelming advance of Warsaw Pact troops. Britain expressed reservations about the idea and called for holding onto some short-range, land-based nuclear weapons. But the United States did not object to the Dutch and German proposal, which was supported by other ministers, leaving it for further study under a lengthy review of NATO nuclear strategy. Cheney said the comprehensive review of NATO's nuclear force structure wouldn't be anywhere near completed by the time alliance leaders gather for a summit in London July 5-6. He said the review ``is going to take a long time'' but believed it ``would result in an overall reduction in nuclear weapons.'' ``We're likely to see fewer nuclear weapons in Europe than in the past,'' he said. Cheney appeared upbeat about the results of his third NATO Nuclear Planning Group session, which was held at the snowy Kananaskis ski resort at the foot of the Canadian Rockies. Fourteen of the alliance's 16 defense ministers _ including an observer from Iceland _ ended the session with a statement that there is a ``diminishing need'' for short-range nuclear systems in the alliance arsenal amid the changing security situation in Europe. The ministers left to a future series of NATO sessions decisions on what kind of cuts might be made in those short-range nuclear systems and how deep they might go. Cheney stressed that some U.S. nuclear weapons must remain in Europe as a fundamental deterrent and as a means of avoiding war. Conventional forces alone won't prevent an outbreak of war, he argued. He described as ``very, very shaky thinking'' the view that Europe can rid itself of nuclear weapons when NATO and the Warsaw Pact reach parity in conventional forces. ``Everybody wants to operate as though the future is here today,'' he said, repeating his oft-stated warning that although changes in Soviet military posture in Europe have begun, they are by no means complete. The short-range forces under discussion have come to prominence in light of the U.S.-Soviet treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles, which had a range of more than 300 miles. The alliance, in its statement, acknowledged that the decision to cut back on shorter-range weapons places more emphasis on air-launched nuclear missiles, which also must be upgraded in the coming decade. But NATO members made no decision on the weapons, studiously avoiding entering any kind of debate such as the one that split the alliance over the upgrade of the Lance systems. The Lance was deemed irrelevant in light of prospects for German unification, given that it was designed for use against East Germany and Czechoslovakia. The upgraded Lance could reach into the Soviet Union, and some in West Germany opposed adding a more powerful weapon to their stockpile amid lessening tensions.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Chairman Calls For Deposit Insurance Reform
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan is outlining ideas for overhauling the bank deposit insurance system but is stopping well short of advocating a substantial cutback in the 56-year-old program. In his first extensive remarks on the subject, Greenspan on Thursday suggested: _Varying insurance premiums according to the riskiness of a bank's investments. _Examining banks' books more frequently. _Seizing weak banks faster. _Requiring bank owners to risk more of their own money. Federal deposit insurance began in 1934 after the nation suffered an unprecedented wave of bank runs and failures during the Depression. However, it has been blamed for skewing incentives in the financial system and helping create the savings and loan crisis. All banks now pay the same deposit insurance premium. Current law in most cases bars the takeover of banks until they officially are insolvent, but by that time losses to the federal deposit insurance fund sometimes are steep. Greenspan, in a speech in Chicago, did not address proposals on cutting back $100,000 per account insurance, limiting insurance to one account, imposing ``deductibles'' on insurance or finding a way to let large banks fail without endangering the system. ``He is proceeding gingerly ... but in the chairman are the seeds of a most radical reform of our existing financial system,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, which represents smaller banks wary of deposit insurance changes. The Treasury Department is due to release its banking reform plan by next February. Greenspan is expected to be a major influence in its development and in congressional debate on the issue next year. The Treasury study, at Greenspan's insistence, was required by last year's legislation on bailing out the nation's troubled savings and loans. Greenspan appeared to reject the notion of simply abolishing deposit insurance and other safeguards, which some free-market conservatives advocate. ``The United States has not suffered a financial panic or systemic bank run in the last 50 years. In large part this reflects the safety net,'' he said. But protection comes at a cost, he said. The three-part safety net poses a ``moral hazard'' for bankers by allowing them to shift some of the risks of their actions onto the public. The three areas are deposit insurance, the ability of banks to borrow at low rates in emergencies from the Fed's discount window and banks' access the Fed's electronic payments wire, which guarantees payments between banks. Reform of the safety net should be considered in tandem with permitting banks to expand into securities and insurance, Greenspan said. Offering banks no new powers likely would cause commercial banking to shrink, shifting money to unprotected parts of the financial system. That, in turn, ``may create systemic risk similar to that faced in earlier years,'' he said. Some have advocated strict ``fire walls'' separating new activities from an insured bank. But Greenspan said that ``undercuts the reason for granting any additional powers to banking organizations in the first place.'' Instead ``we should probably develop additional market-simulating ways of limiting moral hazard,'' he said. ``We might also consider the desirability of returning to capital requirements that more closely simulate those that the market dictated in a world without a safety net,'' he said. Bank owners currently risk about six cents of every dollar they lend. Greenspan noted that in the 1800s, before the creation of deposit insurance and the discount window, bankers risked 25 cents to 50 cents for every dollar loaned. That encouraged them to use more caution, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bob Hope's Son Nominated to Indian Panel
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Anthony Hope, a lawyer and son of entertainer Bob Hope, is expected to be confirmed quickly as chairman of a new federal Indian gaming commission. The law that created the commission 18 months ago to watch over gambling on Indian reservations requires two of its three members to be Indians. ``Mr. Hope is not an Indian, but is an Indian at heart,'' Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, said Thursday at a hearing at which Hope's management skills were praised. Inouye said he would bring the nomination to a committee vote Monday and hoped to get it approved on the Senate floor before Memorial Day. Leonard Prescott, vice chairman of the National Indian Gaming Association said a number of tribal governments and Indian organizations had expressed concerns about Hope's inexperience in Indian affairs and gaming. ``However, we believe that his extensive management and financial background will be beneficial to the work of the commission,'' Prescott said. Hope, 49, said he grew up in the West and was familiar with the conditions on reservations. ``Although I am not an Indian, my personal and professional background make me empathetic to the condition of the Indians and capable of managing a small regulatory agency,'' he said. A graduate of Georgetown University and Harvard Law School, Hope worked in New Hampshire for George Bush's presidential campaigns in 1980 and 1988. He was on President Reagan's Grace Commission, which made recommendations on cutting government waste. Hope also was a partner in the accounting firm of Touche Ross & Co., and formerly worked for Mutual of Omaha. He ran unsuccessfully for Congress from California in 1986. The three-year commission chairmanship pays $83,600 a year. About 100 tribes use bingo or other forms of gambling to raise money. Incidents such as recent riots near the Mohawk lands in St. Regis, N.Y., and the vulnerability of the reservations to organized crime have demonstrated the need for more supervision, officials have said. Inouye said the commission would inspect gambling premises, do background checks on employees, levy fines and enforce ordinances.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Tour Boat Docks at Albanian Port
DOC.TEXT: A Yugoslav cruiser with 240 Italian tourists on board returned from Albania after becoming the first tour boat in recent history to dock in the isolated Communist nation, the Yugoslav news agency said. The Yugoslav cruiser, Dalmacija, has since returned to the port of Split, the Tanjug agency said Thursday without further detail. Yugoslavia and Albania have extremely limited cross-border trade and freighters sometimes dock on the Albanian coast. Albania signaled this week in advance of a visit by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar that it intends to open up further to the outside world. Senior Communist Party officials have reportedly told Parliament that in the future Albanians will be granted passports for travel and the death penalty will be dropped for those trying to flee across the country's tightly sealed borders. Penalties for those spreading ``religious propaganda'' will also be dropped, the officials said. Albania, a country of 3.1 million residents, is wedged between Yugoslavia and Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Cocaine Report Aimed at Political Target, Drug Director Says
With PM-Cocaine-States
DOC.TEXT: The coordinator of the government's war on drugs says he will not change strategy despite a Senate study that sets the number of hard-core cocaine addicts in the United States at 2.2 million, more than double the administration's estimate. National drug policy director William J. Bennett angrily rejected suggestions by a Senate committee chairman Thursday that the administration's focus on discouraging casual use of cocaine should be changed to give more attention to hard-core addicts. The addiction statistics in the Judiciary Committee report contrast with an estimate by the government's National Institute of Drug Abuse that there are 862,000 hard-core addicts, defined as individuals who use cocaine at least once a week. The report and the criticism by committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., touched off a day of feuding between Biden and Bennett, who said the senator was seeking ammunition for congressional election campaigns this fall. ``This is ridiculous,'' Bennett said in a telephone interview. ``What official estimate is he talking about? There is no official estimate. In the national drug control strategy we use a number larger than the one he is using. We use 4 million'' drug addicts. ``I think I know why he is doing it, though,'' Bennett added. ``What is it now, May? It's not that long until November. It's that time of year, the political time of year.'' The feud resumed Thursday night when Biden and Bennett met on the MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour on the Public Broadcasting System. Bennett told Biden sharply that ``you are trying to discredit our policy'' and ``we think this is just a bit disingenuous.'' ``I don't like this rhetoric, Bill,'' Biden shot back. ``I don't like these cheap shots about being disingenuous.'' While Bennett clung to the national drug strategy's figure of 4 million addicts, Biden pointed out that it referred to users of all kinds of drugs, not just cocaine. Bennett retorted that most addicts abuse more than one drug. Both men conceded, however, that there was no way of getting a perfectly accurate count. Dr. Edgar Adams of the National Institute of Drug Abuse told reporters at Biden's news conference that the Senate report was ``a good attempt to look at what was a very complex problem.'' He praised the report because ``it restates the fact that drug abuse is a very serious problem.'' But he said there was a 95 percent confidence level for the institute's smaller estimate and cautioned it might be hard to arrive at anything similar for the Senate version. The Senate report put the number of hard-core addicts nationwide at 2,159,000 and said nearly one in every 100 Americans is a weekly cocaine user. Some areas of the United States have ``extraordinarily high concentrations'' of addicts, according to the report. It said one out of every 40 individuals in New York state uses cocaine at least once a week. The nation's capital had the highest per capita rate, 32.9 hard-core users among every 1,000 Washington, D.C., residents, the report said. The report was prepared under the supervision of Mark A.R. Kleiman of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Biden said the results of the survey were ``tragic'' and urged a $3 billion drug-fighting plan ranging from research and development of new treatments to doubling law enforcement grants to $900 million. ``Our consciences demand that we act, our pocketbooks command that we do so and our safety demands that it be done immediately,'' Biden said. The report said only one out of 10 hard-core addicts receives drug treatment and that most who are arrested quickly return to the streets. The report estimated that New York state had the most hard-core addicts, 434,000, followed by California, 325,000; Texas, 144,000; Illinois, 142,000; and Florida, 93,000.

DOC.HEAD: Cristiani: U.S. Lawmakers Interfering In Salvadoran Justice
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani says U.S. lawmakers are interfering with Salvadoran justice by saying the investigation into the killings of six Jesuit priests has ground to a halt. A panel of House Democrats, headed by Joe Moakley of Massachusetts, reported April 30 that the investigation into the Jesuit killings had reached ``a virtual standstill.'' Cristiani said Thursday that a U.S. congressional report ``gathered up speculations and sometimes tries to present them as facts. And this makes things difficult because it obstructs the judicial process.'' The American congressmen ``can say it bogged down. But the truth is that it did not bog down. The case continues to be worked on,'' Cristiani said. The House report, based on an investigation that lasted months and included a visit to El Salvador, said authorities were making little effort to determine if senior officers ordered the crime or covered it up. The six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter were shot to death by uniformed soldiers on the night of Nov. 16 at their home on the Central American University campus in San Salvador. The assassinations took place in the middle of a month-long offensive by leftist rebels, and the area was under military control with a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Col. Guillermo Benavides, three lieutenants and four soldiers have been arrested and charged with murdering the eight people. A ninth soldier, a private, is a fugitive. Cristiani spoke shortly after Col. Inocento Montano, deputy minister of public security, told reporters he thought Benavides was innocent. Pretrial testimony showed the soldiers left the Military School, which Benavides directed at the time, on the night of the murders. Four cadets, who were on guard duty at the time, were summoned twice by Judge Ricardo Zamora to testify but failed to appear. Three were sent on a study mission to Fort Benning, Ga., and the fourth to Panama. U.S. officials Thursday said the three cadets at Fort Benning's School of the Americas, where many of El Salvador's third-year cadets receive training, were sent back to San Salvador. The school's commandant, Col. William DePalo Jr., said the three were sent home Wednesday to testify in the case. The army said the guard logbook at the Salvadoran military school disappeared, and Benavides said he never kept a personal diary that soldiers of his rank are supposed to keep. Zamora said Tuesday two other officers summoned to testify have also not appeared. The only evidence against Benavides is testimony from other suspects, and under Salvadoran law such testimony is not valid. Zamora has said there may not be enough evidence to send the case to a jury. At least one retired officer said publicly Benavides acted under orders from high officials to assassinate the Jesuits. Pro-government newspapers had accused the Jesuits of being leftist sympathizers. More than 72,000 people have been killed since leftist guerrillas launched their insurgency a decade ago. Most of the victims were civilians suspected of left-wing sympathies, slain by rightist death squads with links to the military.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers See New Microorganism as Possible Helper to AIDS Virus
DOC.TEXT: A microbe that is a common contaminant in laboratories may be an infectious agent that contributes to the lethal effects of the AIDS virus. The organism, called mycoplasma, was discovered four years ago by Shyh-Ching Lo, but is only now being considered seriously by AIDS investigators, according to an article published today in the journal Science. Lo, a virologist at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology here, said in a telephone interview that his work was ignored until he presented his work last December and March at special workshops. Some of the world's leading experts on mycoplasmas attended the workshops and at least four labs now are trying to confirm Lo's work. Lo reported that in five years of study he has isolated a specific mycoplasma from the heart, kidneys, brain, spleen and liver of AIDS patients. He said the microbe, which he calls mycoplasma incognitus, is a new species that may also be able to independently cause disease. Dr. John Bartlett of Johns Hopkins University, who sponsored Lo at the March workshop, said the findings are ``intriguing'' but that the research needs to be verified in other laboratories before it can be accepted widely. ``Whenever a researcher finds mycoplasmas, the medical community tends to be skeptical,'' said Bartlett. Mycoplasmas frequently are found as contaminants in microbiological experiments, he said. ``I'm not convinced it is a cause of disease, but it needs further study,'' Bartlett said of Lo's study. Other researchers agreed. Lo first reported discovery of his mycoplasma in 1986, but the findings met with ridicule in the research community. Lo now acknowledges there was reason for skepticism. ``The data were not very conclusive,'' he said. Lo continued to work, however, and last year the American Journal of Tropical Medicine published his first paper on mycoplasmas. It captured new interest, he said. ``When we presented this work before, it wasn't understood,'' said Lo. ``Now they have started a lot of work looking into it.'' The findings were strong enough for the government's National Institute of Allergies and Infectious Diseases to convene a workshop last December in San Antonio and allow Lo to present his studies to some of the nation's top microbiologists. Dr. Joel B. Baseman, a microbiologist at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio and chairman of the December workshop, said Lo's studies stood up to close scrutiny from experts in the field. He said many went away convinced that Lo had found enough evidence of a new infectious agent that further study was justified. But just what role, if any, the mycoplasma plays in AIDS is not known. ``It's not absolutely clear what it is doing in AIDS-related disease, but it appears to be present in many cases and seems to the sole source of pathology in specific tissues,'' said Baseman. ``The evidence is reasonable.'' Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, reported that Luc Montagnier, a prominent French researcher and the co-discoverer of the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, believed to cause AIDS, also has studied a mycoplasma in AIDS patients. Montagnier has speculated that a mycoplasma is an AIDS virus co-factor, which means it works with HIV to cause disease. A mycoplasma is neither a virus or a bacteria. It has no cell wall, but it contains genetic material and reproduces by division, as does bacteria. Mycoplasmas have been associated with some rare types of pneumonia and have been isolated in the genital tract of healthy men and women. Baseman said Lo, in his workshop presentation, showed that although the mycoplasma may play a role in AIDS, it may be a lethal infection agent all by itself. He said Lo isolated the mycoplasma in six patients who tested negative for the AIDS virus, but who died from unspecified causes within seven weeks of becoming ill. Four silvered leaf monkeys also died of unspecified disease within nine months of being injected with the mycoplasma, Science reported.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Hope New Charges Show Pattern of Drug Use by Mayor
LaserPhoto WX6
With PM-Barry-Chronology and PM-Barry-Charges
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors seeking six new drug charges against Mayor Marion Barry hope to show a pattern of drug use by the mayor, sources familiar with the case say. The new charges returned Thursday include five counts of misdemeanor cocaine possession and a misdemeanor charge of conspiracy to possess cocaine. They were added to an eight-count indictment, including three felony perjury counts, filed against the mayor in February. The updated indictment alleges that Barry ``possessed cocaine and crack with other co-conspirators at more than 20 locations, including private residences, hotels, government offices and business establishments and on boats.'' The charges ``are intended to establish a pattern, a practice of illegal activity that ranges over a period of years,'' said a law enforcement source familiar with the case. Prosecutors have worried privately that R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's attorney, might suggest in court that the mayor was unfairly lured into drug use on Jan. 18, the night of his arrest in an FBI sting operation, sources said. In order to battle that possible entrapment defense, investigators have sought to portray Barry as a regular drug user, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``These new charges certainly suggest that he (Barry) has done drugs on an awful lot of occasions over the past five or six years,'' said one source. ``Was he an occasional or experimental user? These charges suggest otherwise.'' The new charges allege that Barry conspired to possess cocaine and possessed the drug on numerous occasions between the fall of 1984 and his arrest in January.
