Following the arrest, Barry spent seven weeks in rehabilitation facilities in Florida and South Carolina for treatment of what he said was alcohol and prescription drug abuse. Barry has pleaded innocent to the crimes with which he was charged in February; Herbert O. Reid Sr., the city's corporation counsel, predicted the mayor will plead innocent to the new indictment as well. One new charge says Barry possessed cocaine on Sept. 7, 1988, two days after returning from a secret vacation at a health spa in the Catskills Mountains of New York state. Aides said later that the mayor was receiving dietary counseling and a variety of health treatments designed to help him lose weight and reduce his stress level. In a statement, U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens spoke of the Barry investigation as ``ongoing,'' and a source familiar with the effort said the grand jury will continue hearing evidence. Barry refused to comment on his legal status but said his new troubles with the law will not affect his ability to govern. ``I'm not looking for votes,'' he said during an appearance at a senior citizen's center. ``I'm just being an elected official trying to do my job and trying to make sure the government goes to the people.'' Mundy, Barry's attorney, complained that the charges should not have been lodged so close to the June 4 scheduled start of the mayor's trial, but he predicted that the trial would not be postponed. Barry's mayoral term ends this year and he has not yet said whether he will seek re-election to a fourth four-year term. However, he has been touring the city and speaking to a wide array of community groups in campaign-style appearances. If convicted of a felony, he would be barred from holding office or running for re-election once appeals were exhausted.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the political career of District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry: 1974: Barry, a black civil rights activist, is elected to the D.C. City Council.
1976: Barry is re-elected to the council.

March 9, 1977: Hanafi Muslims shoot Barry in the chest during their seizure of the District Building, the capital's city hall. The bullet barely misses Barry's heart, but he's back at work a week later.
Sept. 12, 1978: Barry, after receiving a last-minute endorsement from The Washington Post, wins the Democratic mayoral primary with 35 percent of the vote. Nov. 7, 1978: Barry is elected mayor.

Jan. 2, 1979: Barry is inaugurated, pledges that ``here in Washington D.C., we will be our brother's keeper.'' During his first term, the city deficit mushrooms, forcing him to cut jobs and services and press for more federal aid. He weathers a major snowstorm and a drawn-out teacher's strike.

1982: Barry is re-elected. His second term sees improved fiscal health, renewal of the downtown area, a decline in unemployment and crime and growing crowding of the city's jails and prisons. Scandals begin to take their toll as 10 top city officials are convicted of various financial crimes.

Sept. 25, 1983: Barry is stricken with chest pains while attending a meeting in a downtown hotel; hospital officials blamed the episode on a hiatal hernia. A physician not involved in his treatment tells police the mayor suffered a drug overdose, a report not revealed for six years. Police then say they could find no evidence for the physician's statement.
Nov. 4, 1986: Despite his mounting troubles, Barry is re-elected to an unprecedented third term, taking 61 percent of the vote.

Jan. 26, 1987: Vacationing in California, Barry is hospitalized briefly after suffering chest pains, later explained as a flare-up of the hiatal hernia. Jan. 30, 1987: The mayor is still on the West Coast when back-to-back snowstorms hit Washington, paralyzing the city. He decides to attend the Super Bowl rather than return to direct the cleanup effort. Apr. 16, 1987: Barry defends the city ambulance system after eight people die in six months following the slow arrival of ambulances. May 22, 1987: U.S. Attorney Joseph diGenova announces federal probe into allegations of fraud in city government. June 18, 1987: Barry denies a local television station's report that he used cocaine with a former city employee.

Dec. 22, 1988: Police officers planning to attempt a drug buy from Charles Lewis, a former Virgin Islands official and acquaintance of Barry's, are called back when it's discovered that the mayor is in Lewis' hotel room. Traces of cocaine are found in the room. Dec. 29, 1988: U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens announces plans to investigate Lewis episode. Dec. 31, 1988: Barry apologizes for ``bad judgment'' in the incident.

Jan. 5, 1989: A grand jury investigating Barry's alleged interference into police drug probe has subpoenaed the mayor's telephone logs. Jan. 6, 1989: Lewis denies ever using drugs with the mayor. Jan. 11, 1989: City Council member Betty Ann Kane calls for council investigation into a joint personnel project involving the Virgin Islands government on which Lewis worked as a consultant to the city. Jan. 12, 1989: The FBI joins the probe into the Lewis episode. Jan. 19, 1989: Barry appears under subpoena before the grand jury and testifies for three hours. He tells reporters he has done nothing wrong. April 24, 1989: Lewis is convicted in the Virgin Islands on four counts of possession of cocaine. May 15, 1989: Lewis is indicted in Washington on 16 cocaine and perjury charges. Sept. 17: Barry responds to hecklers at an outdoor festival by making an obscene hand gesture. Nov. 6: Lewis pleads guilty in a plea bargain to two counts of conspiring to distribute cocaine and names Barry as a person for whom he bought crack cocaine while staying at the hotel where Barry visited him in 1988.

Jan. 7, 1990: Los Angeles Times publishes interview in which Barry ridicules potential mayoral challenger Jesse Jackson. Jan. 18, 1990: Barry is arrested on a drug charge in a downtown hotel. Jan. 21, 1990: Barry announces he will seek assistance ``to heal my body, mind and soul,'' but makes no mention of drug abuse. Jan. 22, 1990: Barry checks into Hanley-Hazelden Treatment Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. His spokeswoman says the mayor will be treated for alcoholism. Feb. 15, 1990: A federal grand jury indicts Barry on three felony counts of perjury and five misdemeanor counts of possession of a controlled substance. May 10, 1990: The grand jury indicts Barry on six more misdemeanor possession charges.

DOC.HEAD: 18 Months After Election, Judge Decides Mayoral Race
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen months after the mayoral elections, a judge has confirmed a decision by the elections board and ruled the pro-commonwealth candidate a winner by 49 votes. San Juan Superior Court Judge Carlos Polo issued a 300-page decision Thursday declaring Hector Luis Acevedo the winner in a bitter contest against New Progressive Party candidate Jose Granados Navedo. The capital has been a stronghold of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party since 1968 and Acevedo's victory is seen as a major blow to the party. Acevedo, the candidate of the Popular Democratic Party, has been occupying the mayor's seat since he was certified the victor by the State Elections Commission in December 1988 with a 29-vote margin. In January 1989, Granados challenged the election results, claiming irregularities in the vote count. The judge's decision Thursday was based on a new count of the disputed ballots. Carlos Canals, a lawyer representing Granados, said he would appeal the decision to the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico. Political parties are aligned according to their support for either statehood, commonwealth or independence. Puerto Rico is a U.S. Commonwealth.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the 14 charges filed against Mayor Marion Barry: _One misdemeanor count of conspiring to possess cocaine and crack cocaine. The charge covers an unspecified number of incidents between the fall of 1984 and Jan. 18, the night Barry was arrested in an FBI sting operation. It carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a fine of up to $100,000 upon conviction. The indictment was handed up Thursday. _Ten misdemeanor counts of possessing cocaine, covering a period from Nov. 7, 1987, until Jan. 18. Four of the possession charges result from a probe of Barry's ties to convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis. Each possession charge carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and up to a $100,000 fine upon conviction. Five of the charges were filed Feb. 15 and five Thursday. _Three felony counts of perjury alleging Barry lied to a grand jury. Barry is accused of lying when asked by the grand jury whether he knew of Lewis' involvement with cocaine, if he ever gave drugs to Lewis and if he received cocaine from Lewis. The perjury charges, returned Feb. 15, each carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a maximum $250,000 fine. If convicted of a felony, Barry would be barred from holding office or running for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Cocaine
Soup Kitchen Provides Mother's Day Cards To Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Volunteers at a soup kitchen figure the Mother's Day cards they bought for the homeless men and women they serve a hot lunch to will be the first their mothers have received in years. The cards were being passed out Thursday at the East First Street Soup Kitchen at Caritas Austin Baptist Chapel. The volunteers got Austin business to donate the cards, and affixed stamps with ``LOVE'' on the envelopes. Several in the lunch crowd of about 100 said they didn't want to put a return address on the cards. Some couldn't remember where their mothers lived. ``One young man said he hasn't seen or corresponded with his mother in six years,'' said Frances Doetsch, a volunteer. ``Don't you know she's going to be thrilled? I hope she's still alive.'' Al Alexander picked a card adorned with pink flowers and addressed it to his mother in Arkansas, whom he hasn't seen in eight years. He wrote: ``I'm going to try to come home soon, and thanks for the loan.'' Alexander said he came to Austin in the boom years with dreams of making it big as a singer, but soon fell on hard times. He may go home soon. ``I was determined I wasn't going to leave broke, but ...'' Gerardo Garcia Garea, 14, and his friend, Jesus Jimenez Lara, 17, were eager to get their cards mailed because they were late: Mother's Day was celebrated in their native Mexico this year on Thursday. Jayzon Wilson said his card was being sent not to his ``real mom'' but to a woman in Texas ``who takes care of about 10 of us. We call her Mom.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Considers Civilians to Edit Military Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is seeking an experienced civilian journalist to edit the Pacific edition of the military newspaper Stars & Stripes, which ran into charges of censorship and mismanagement under its military editor. Jordan E. Rizer, director of the Defense Department's American Forces Information Service, said Thursday the agency also will consider a recommendation by Pentagon-appointed ombudsman Philip M. Foisie that a civilian editor be named for the European edition. Foisie, a former editor with The Washington Post, was named last summer to make recommendations in light of a study by the congressional General Accounting Office that found evidence of censorship and improper management at the government-run daily paper. The Society of Professional Journalists assisted the GAO in its investigation. Stars & Stripes, which was first published during World War I, is designed to be a ``hometown paper'' for service personnel stationed abroad. Foisie, in a report dated April 20 and released by the Pentagon on Thursday, said there is an an ``urgent need for vigorous new hands-on editorial leadership'' of the European edition. He recommended ``a senior experienced civilian daily newspaper editor _ someone not presently on the staff of the European Stars & Stripes _ be selected as soon as possible.'' Foisie visited Stuttgart, West Germany, and interviewed members of the staff. In January, after a similar visit to the Tokyo offices, he recommended that the military officer with the title of editor-in-chief of that edition be made publisher and a civilian be appointed editor. Rizer said the American Forces Information Service expect to advertise next week for applicants for the Tokyo editorship. The post will be filled through federal civil service procedures. Rizer said the former Pacific editor, Col. Ed Montgomery, had been reassigned and Col. Walter de Forest had been appointed commander and publisher. Regarding the European edition, Rizer said, ``We're taking the recommendations of the ombudsman under advisement and will try to react accordingly.'' In his report on the European edition, Foisie said the new editor should be named by the Pentagon, the Unified Command in Stuttgart, and the newspaper's commander and editor-in-chief, Col. Gene E. Townsend. ``There are sharp divisions within the newsroom of the European edition that require attention, and some editorial reorganization may also be needed,'' the ombudsman said.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Headed for Bright Wheat Harvest
DOC.TEXT: Farmers are headed for a whopper of a wheat harvest this year, perhaps enough to boost the nation's depleted stockpile of bread grain by 70 percent or more. The bright outlook is based on the Agriculture Department's forecast Thursday for winter wheat, which accounts for three-fourths of the U.S. total. As of May 1, surveys showed that 1990 winter wheat production could be a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels, up 44 percent from last year's harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. Average yields were forecast at 41.1 bushels per acre, compared with 35.1 bushels last year. In Kansas, for example, winter wheat production was estimated at 460.2 million bushels, more than double the shriveled 1989 harvest of 213.6 million bushels. Both the acreage and average yield were up. Overall, farmers are expected to have about 50.8 million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, up 23 percent from 41.5 million in 1989, the report said. Winter wheat, planted in the fall and harvested the next year, accounts for about three-fourths of the U.S. total wheat production. The remainder is planted in the spring. Carl Schwensen, executive vice president of the National Association of Wheat Growers, said the larger harvest will ``put us in a stock-building mode'' for some time in the future _ at least until something can be done about worldwide capacity for producing too much grain. Schwensen said the United States has ``made a real accomplishment'' by putting millions of acres of marginal land in the Conservation Reserve Program, which takes it out of crop production for 10 years. He said about 11 million acres of that land has come from nation's wheat base. ``No other major producing and exporting nation has even attempted to take the initiatives that we've had _ to set aside marginal lands specifically from wheat production,'' Schwensen said in a telephone interview. In the early and mid-1980s U.S. wheat surpluses grew rapidly, rising to a peak carryover of 1.9 billion bushels on June 1, 1985. Schwensen said he doesn't see that happening again soon, ``but we are going to be getting up to a billion (bushels), I would think, over the next couple of seasons.'' Ideally, he said, the association would like to see year-end U.S. wheat stockpiles maintained at around 800 million bushels, although some others, including USDA experts, say a billion bushels would be all right. However, Schwensen said much depends on how the Soviet Union and China continue to perform as wheat markets, and on the way the U.S. export subsidy program shapes up in the 1990 farm bill. The USDA's first official estimate of 1990 production of all wheat will be issued July 12, with the first estimates for corn, soybeans and some other major spring-planted crops scheduled for Aug. 9, along with revised figures for wheat. Although no official estimates based on field surveys were included, except for winter wheat, department analysts in a related supply-and-demand report did project ``highly tentative'' 1990 production of all wheat at more than 2.69 billion bushels, up from less than 2.04 billion last year. Projections for all wheat and some other crops were based on yield trends and an assumption the crop would have normal weather the remainder of the growing season. The 1990 corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels, up from 7.53 billion harvested last year. Soybean production was projected at 1.925 billion bushels, virtually the same as the crop of 1.927 billion bushels in 1989. According to the supply-and-demand report, the U.S. wheat stockpile will be drained to a 15-year low of 442 million bushels June 1, the beginning of the new wheat marketing year. But with the expected larger 1990 harvest, the wheat stockpile could be rebuilt to about 765 million bushels a year from now. That would be close to the 800 million bushels Schwensen and the wheat growers say is desirable. The projected larger 1990 wheat harvest could put pressure on market prices, which were indicated in the range of $2.90 to $3.30 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with an estimated $3.71 this season. If corn production turns out at the projected level of 8.1 billion bushels, it still wouldn't be quite enough to match domestic and export demand, the report showed. Thus, the U.S. corn stockpile, which may be around 1.33 billion bushels next fall, could edge lower by Oct. 1, 1991. Corn prices were projected at $2.25 to $2.65 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with the current season's forecast of $2.30 to $2.40 per bushel. Looking at the global situation, the analysis said prelminary indications ``point to larger crops in a number of countries and continued growth in use.'' World wheat production is expected to be record large in 1990-91, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Backward Went the Sentences, Reeling Went the Mind ...
DOC.TEXT: There's a novel here somewhere, buried deep in a mountain of 10,000 opening lines, an Everest of literary lunacy by writers trying to be as bad as they can be and succeeding. And whether scrawled by hand or written on word processors, they all vied in the ninth annual Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest, a celebration of mangled language in the name of a 19th century novelist. Linda Vernon, a housewife in Newark, Calif., copped the grand prize this year with her mixed metaphors and overdone images, San Jose State University English professor Scott Rice announced Thursday. Rice, the contest's originator, called Vernon's purple prose ``an example of a writer getting carried away with figures of speech.'' If you're reading aloud, take a breath and give it a try: ``Dolores breezed along the surface of her life like a flat stone forever skipping along smooth water, rippling reality sporadically but oblivious to it consistently, until she finally lost momentum, sank and, due to an overdose of fluoride as a child which caused her to suffer from chronic apathy, doomed herself to lie forever on the floor of her life as useless as an appendix and as lonely as a five-hundred-pound barbell in a steroid-free fitness center.'' Vernon, a 38-year-old mother of three who's taking writing courses, won a word processor. ``It takes a lot of talent to be a bad writer,'' she said. ``This is a good start, but I hope this is not the peak of my career.'' Runner-up Richard G. Carter of Hampton, Va., took a more gruesome tone: ``Since both parties demanded sole custody in the Frankenstein divorce case, the judge called for his Sword-of-Solomon bolt-cutters and ruled an equitable split: Victor was to raise the creature's grotesque body in Palo Alto while his ex-wife reared its ugly head in San Jose.'' Rice, who has published several books from the entries over the years, sees the contest as a way to encourage people to have fun with language and make a statement, in a way, about the importance of literacy. Edward Bulwer-Lytton earned the distinction of a contest in his name by beginning his 1830 novel ``Paul Clifford'' with that potboiling opener popular with Snoopy of the ``Peanuts'' comic strip: ``It was a dark and stormy night.'' In a more inspired moment, Bulwer-Lytton also originated the line, ``The pen is mightier than the sword.'' Here, for better or worse, are some of the category winners: Science Fiction _ ``Far out in the backwaters of the unfashionable end of the Western Spiral arm of the Galaxy lies a small unregarded yellow sun, and orbiting this at a distance of roughly 899,010,000 miles is the flash-frozen body of Farley Wilsputz Jr., and boy is there an interesting story of how he came to be a component of Saturn's ring system.'' By Richard Garrett, Pittsburgh, Pa. Vile Puns _ ``Among us comedy writers, the pun is considered the lowest form of humor and a sure sign of burnout, which is why when I tried to sneak one by, my associates had me committed to the institute for disturbed comic writers at Vail, Colo., so now I know why they say, ``use a pun, go to Vail!'' By Robert M. Quan, San Francisco. Historical _ ``Paul von Hindenburg, only one month old and wrapped in a blue blanket, rested peacefully in his cradle, oblivious to the tragedy that would one day befall a dirigible to be named after him.'' By Kenneth Leffler, Falls, Church, Va. Detective _ ``Mike Hardware was the kind of private eye who didn't know the meaning of the word `fear,' a man who could laugh in the face of danger and spit in the eye of death; in short a moron with suicidal tendencies.'' By Eddie Lawhorn, Huntsville, Ala. Children's Literature _ ```Toadying to the Evil Queen might not be the best gig in the land,' reflected the magic mirror, `but it sure beats working in a damn barber shop for minimum wage.''' Richard G. Carter, Hampton, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Blast Safety of Cargo Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: Design flaws in the Army's advanced transport helicopter forced at least one pilot to take the unusual step of flying the aircraft just 600 feet above the ground. The pilot figured he would have a better chance of landing safely if anything went wrong with the helicopter, say congressional investigators. Members of the General Accounting Office, working for a House panel, told lawmakers Thursday that the Army has been unable to overcome persistent safety problems with the helicopter that killed 15 soldiers in two accidents. Investigators said the CH-47D Chinook helicopter experienced failures with its transmission cooling fans, flight-control rods that burned and cracked cross shafts. ``We recommend that the Army be required to report to Congress on progress in fixing current problems on the CH-47D,'' they said. ``Funding for additional aircraft purchases should be contingent on the Army presenting convincing evidence that aircraft problems have been resolved.'' The Army plans to buy 472 of the helicopters produced by Boeing Vertol of Philadelphia and AVCO-Lycoming of Stratford, Conn. Pentagon plans call for buying the last 144 helicopters at a cost of about $900 million. Investigators, who visited five of the seven Army sites where the helicopters are used, said widespread mechanical problems have forced the service to ground the aircraft nine times. Army officials disputed the conclusions of the yearlong inquiry by investigators into the $6.4 million helicopter. ``The CH-47D is the safest cargo helicopter in the United States inventory,'' Maj. Gen. Donald Williamson, head of the Army Aviations Systems Command, told the panel. But Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, questioned the Army's actions. ``There is simply no justification for putting our soldiers at avoidable risk because of mechanically deficient aircraft,'' Dingell said. A 1988 accident in Chico, Texas, that killed 10 soldiers and injured eight others was blamed on a cooling fan transmission that came apart. Investigators said the fan sometimes shatters when the aircraft vibrates too much, spewing debris that damages the transmission. Investigators also testified it took the Army 18 years to replace the helicopter's aluminum flight-control rods, which are susceptible to burning, with fire-resistant steel rods. During that time, the Army tried to prevent the rods from burning by treating them with a fire-resistant paint and wrapping them in firesleeves, investigators said. A helicopter that crashed in Honduras in December 1988, killing five soldiers, was one of 73 aircraft whose control rods had not been treated with the paint. ``While development, testing and production f steel rods was under way, silicone fire sleeves were installed as an interim measure to afford protection. All aircraft were retrofitted with steel rods by September 1989,'' said Williamson.

DOC.HEAD: CBO Sees $43 Billion in Savings By Relying on Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Congressional analysts say a greater reliance on military reserves could save the United States $43 billion over several years by cutting active duty forces. ``Changes in threats to U.S. security, coupled with downward pressure on the defense budget, suggest that the reserves may take on even greater importance,'' Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, told a Senate panel Thursday. Under the proposed scenario, active duty armed forces would be cut by 463,000, down to 1.6 million. The reduction would increase the share of the reserves in the total force from 36 percent to 42 percent. Analysts presented their findings at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on increased use of the reserves at a time when the Soviet threat to the West has diminished and constraints on the budget has grown. ``In this period of increased warning time and fiscal austerity, I think we have to conduct a fundamental re-examination of the use of the reserves in all of the military services,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the panel. President Bush's defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 calls for $303 billion for the military _ a total that has come under attack in Congress as too high. The CBO director told the panel more than $43 billion could be saved over five to seven years by cutting the active duty forces and maintaining the current level of reserves. According to the CBO, 1.2 million people serve in the selected reserves, which includes personnel who have been on active duty and train part-time. Another 524,000 people belong to the individual ready reserve, many of whom have completed active duty service but do not train in peacetime. The CBO director also proposed new approaches that included ``nested'' ships in the Navy, stored aircraft in the Air Force or cadre units for the Army. Nesting would involve stationing four or five ships together, including one mother ship. ``Except for the mother ship, all the vessels would be in a stored status. They might go to sea for training but would not be deployed overseas in peacetime,'' Reischauer said. The Air Force, according to the CBO, could store its aircraft at Davis Monthan Air Force Base in Arizona, where it would be maintained in non-operating status. The Army could adopt a cadre system in which each Army division would retain on active duty about 3,000 non-commissioned officers and senior officers. In the event of war, reserves who have been off active duty for fewer than 18 months could be called up. The system is similar to that employed in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Baker To See Mubarak In Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will meet in Moscow next week with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak but plans no new strategy for opening negotiations between Israel and Palestinian Arabs, U.S. officials say. Baker's main purpose for going to Moscow is to hold talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on the May 30-June 3 superpower summit meeting in Washington. However, Mubarak will be in the Soviet capital as well, giving Baker a chance to discuss the Middle East situation with the Egyptian leader, the officials said Thursday. Baker's plan for Israeli-Palestinian talks is on hold while Israel tries to form a new government. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir declined to endorse the plan because it provides for Palestinians expelled from the West Bank and former residents of Jerusalem to participate in the negotiations. Still, U.S. officials, who insisted on anonymity, said Baker intends to try again after a new government takes over in Jerusalem. Mubarak has served as a middleman between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization, relaying PLO demands and then advising Washington what Arafat's group finds acceptable or objectionable. Arafat made a one-day visit to Cairo last week to see Mubarak, the only Arab leader whose country has signed a peace treaty with Israel. Their meeting was believed to deal mainly with the PLO's call for an Arab summit. On Thursday, meanwhile, the Bush administration again criticized Israel for settling Soviet Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza but said it was not conspiring with Arab governments at the United Nations to curtail immigration. ``We want to see immigration take place and will oppose efforts by anyone to block it,'' Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said. However, the administration, which is hotly opposed to the settlements, did not promise to veto _ and thereby kill _ any resolution in the U.N. Security Council aimed at Israel. And an Israeli source, insisting on anonymity, said a resolution being prepared condemns settling Soviet Jews in Jerusalem and upholds a right of expatriate Arabs to return to Israel. ``We are very disturbed,'' the source told The Associated Press. Moshe Arad, the Israeli ambassador to Washington, conveyed the concern to Robert Kimmitt, the under secretary for political affairs, on Tuesday at the State Department. Then Foreign Minister Moshe Arens went public, saying in Jerusalem on Thursday that he was troubled the United States was working with Arab governments on a resolution. For the time being the dispute has been sidetracked. The Security Council postponed indefinitely its consideration of the resolution. And the White House and State Department tried to soft-pedal the settlements issue, which has flared for several months. ``We're a member of the Security Council, so quite obviously we would be a part of the deliberations and the discussions but we have not taken a position on that resolution or any specific resolution,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. ``Israel is our close friend, our strong ally. Our bilateral relationship is very strong. As with any strong friendship there are differences of opinion on certain issues,'' said State Department spokeswoman Tutwiler. ``These can and should be managed in a mutually satisfactory fashion,'' she said. The Bush administration insists that settling Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza presents an obstacle to a negotiated settlement in the Middle East. Only a small percentage of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union have wound up in the territories surrendered by Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Six-Day War. The Bush administration considers those settlements an obstacle to Mideast negotiations since the Arabs hope to recover the lands from Israel. Additionally, President Bush objects to Soviet Jews living in East Jerusalem, which Israel won in 1967 and made part of its capital city. Without referring directly to Jerusalem, or to its inclusion in the prospective resolution, spokeswoman Tutwiler said ``the government of Israel is well aware of our concern that Soviet Jews not be encouraged to move into the territories.'' Therefore, she said, ``we find the foreign minister's comments a little confusing.'' And yet, the Bush administration supports Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union to Israel and will keep pressing the Soviet Union to permit direct flights to Tel Aviv, Ms. Tutwiler said.

DOC.HEAD: Foes of Family Leave Bill Say They Can Sustain Veto
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of a bill that guarantees workers up to three months of unpaid leave in family emergencies say they're confident they can sustain a presidential veto of the measure passed by the House The 237-187 vote Thursday sent the family and medical leave bill to the Senate, where it faces a contentious and uncertain future. Alixe Glen, White House deputy press secretary, called the vote close and said President Bush remained firm in his opposition. Bush's aides and spokesmen have threatened a veto. ``He fully supports and encourages flexible family leave policies by all employers, but feels that should not be dictated by a Washington mandate,'' she said. ``Employers and employees know what works for them best.'' One of the sponsors of the final version, Rep. William Clay, D-Mo., called the margin ``a landslide.'' But the vote fell well short of what would be needed to override a presidential veto. Though the bill had the backing of the House Democratic leadership, 54 Democrats sided with business groups that opposed the bill. Thirty-nine Republicans supported the bill. ``The business community is very happy about this vote _ we got well over what we needed to sustain a veto,'' said Mary Tavenner, lobbyist for the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. The bill would require business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid medical leave or leave for the care of a new child or ill child, parent or spouse. It exempts businesses with fewer than 50 workers. Employers would have to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave and restore a returning employee to his or her previous job or an equivalent position. Foes said the bill would be costly and burdensome for businesses, ultimately hurting American competitiveness. But supporters said nearly all industrialized nations already provide such minimum job security to workers, many with provisions for full or partial pay. In the Senate, a similar bill won a committee vote more than a year ago. But it's a divisive issue that could tie up the Senate in protracted debate, and Democratic leaders have yet to schedule Senate floor action. The bill is the second dealing with family concerns the White House has threatened to veto this year, after a child-care assistance bill now in conference committee. Democrats tried to contrast that record with Bush's public support for family values. The bill's supporters hoped election-year pressure would prompt the president to relent in his veto threat. ``Every piece of legislation that comes through here, there's a threat of a veto,'' Clay said. ``I don't know if the president is willing to veto all of these.'' The bill's chief Republican sponsor, Rep. Marge Roukema of New Jersey, said she hoped to persuade Bush not to veto the bill. ``I don't think the president or the Republican Party or the Democratic Party wants to go into an election year looking as though they are against working families,'' Roukema said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Attack Subsidies in Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: Some congressmen challenging the 1990 farm bill say U.S. agriculture policy gives too many subsidies to people who don't need them. ``The bigger you are the more money you have, the more money you are entitled to get,'' Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., said Thursday of the legislation that governs all farm programs. Frank is part of a coalition being organized by Reps. Richard Armey, R-Texas and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., to oppose subsidies in the bill. None of the coalition members is a member of the Agriculture Committee. Schumer acknowledged the members of group aren't all interested in the same subsidy programs, but said ``in general we have agreement that agriculture has gotten out of control,'' Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., said she opposed the wool subsidies and Reps. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y. and John Porter, R-Ill., spoke out against the sugar program. Others opposed the peanut program or any subsidy for farms with annual profits over $100,000. Other congressmen at a press conference to introduce the coalition were Reps. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., and Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif. Armey said several other congressman were also part of the group. ``He's gaining a lot of support with the major media,'' Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said recently of Armey's efforts. ``That will have some effect on the members.'' De la Garza has indicated, however, that plenty of support existed in the House for the bill the agriculture panel is writing. Frank called the multi-billion dollar farm bill ``one of the last vestiges of the bad old days when differences were worked out by adding money to the budget.'' Attempts to cut the federal deficit are requiring tightening of the farm programs as well. Both Senate and House agriculture committees are working with that in mind, though the programs they have approved contain safeguards for farm income. Frank said the government should save its money and let the free market regulate agriculture. Since the Great Depression of the 1930s, the federal government has enacted laws to regulate the food supply and assure farmers of certain prices for their crops. Every five years, Congress approves a farm bill that determines the way and degree in which tax dollars will be used to support farmers.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Security Chief Out as Commission Prepares Report
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top aviation security official is being reassigned a few days before a presidential commission releases a report said to be critical of Federal Aviation Administration security measures. Raymond Salazar's decision to become manager of the agency's Center for Management Development in Palm Coast, Fla., isn't linked to Tuesday's scheduled release of the report by the Aviation Security and Terrorism Commission, FAA chief James Busey said Thursday. ``We needed a good man for the job and we've got one,'' Busey said. But relatives of some of the 270 people killed in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, welcomed Salazar's departure as civil aviation security director. They blame Salazar for flaws in security before the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing and for what they say are failures to improve some conditions since. Salazar has directed civil aviation security since 1986. FAA officials declined to comment on whether the reassignment had anything to do with criticism of Salazar by victims' relatives and members of Congress, including some on the commission. Salazar didn't immediately return a call seeking comment. The seven-member commission, headed by former Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin, will present its report on the Flight 103 bombing and other aviation terrorism issues to President Bush on Tuesday. The commission report will be ``pretty hard on the FAA'' and will call for some reorganization, including setting up a high visibility special security office, according to a congressional source familiar with some of its recommendations. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. Commission spokeswoman Patricia Moran said panel members have agreed not to reveal contents of the report until after they present it to the president and victims' relatives. Paul Hudson of Albany, N.Y., who speaks for one group of Flight 103 relatives, said the FAA removal of Salazar was long overdue. ``He's totally tied to the blunders made prior to 103,'' Hudson said. ``His leadership clearly has not been effective in eliminating the security gap.'' Salazar, appearing at the last commission hearing, denied sworn testimony by Pan Am officials that he had given the airline a waiver of some security procedures at Frankfurt, West Germany, before the bombing. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt en route to London and New York. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar defended security operations under Salazar, saying the security office's budget has doubled since he took over, with $51.9 million proposed for fiscal 1991. The amount devoted to research and development of more sophisticated bomb detectors for airports has increased from $11.3 million in 1986 to $25 million in the new budget, Farrar said. Salazar has been the target of tough grilling by members of Congress at several hearings since the Lockerbie bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,512.14, up 531.88 points or 1.72 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Car Dealer Ponders Fate of Christian Discounts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Freddye in 2nd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A car dealer whose discounts for Christian and Jewish car buyers have been labeled discriminatory by a Jewish group says he'll decide next week whether to continue the program. ``I don't like to step on anybody's toes,'' Freddye ``Action'' Jackson said Thursday. ``Hopefully we can come up with a program that satisfies everybody.'' Jackson said he would discuss the program with partners of Brown Lincoln-Mercury, which began the Christian Members Buyers Plan in August. Patrons who can prove church membership receive discounts ranging from $150 to $600 on Lincolns and Mercurys. Jackson also extends the discounts to Jews because he says they believe in God. He does not, however, include any other religious groups. The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith has called for an end to the discount program, labeling it discriminatory despite Jackson's extension of his offer to Jews. Jackson said he would meet next week with David Friedman of B'nai B'rith. William E. Schuling, chairman of Mid-Atlantic Cars Inc. of which Brown Lincoln-Mercury is the major dealership, was quoted in published reports as saying the program would be abandoned. However, Jackson said he had not made such a decision. Ford Motor Co., which builds Lincolns and Mercurys, has said Jackson is an independent businessman who may decide what type of incentive programs he wants to offer.

DOC.HEAD: Procter & Gamble Pulls Ads Over Critical TV Spot
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co. pulled $1 million of advertising from a television station that had run ads saying coffee made by the company brews ``misery, destruction and death'' in El Salvador. The 30-second spots were bought by a group that advocates a boycott of Folgers coffee because it includes Salvadoran beans, said Sy Yanoff, president and general manager of WHDH-TV. The group, Neighbor to Neighbor, paid $1,000 for each of two spots on Wednesday and Thursday, and the advertisements were cleared with the station's lawyers, he said. ``(The ad) met our commercial and good-taste standards,'' Yanoff said Thursday. Don Tassone, a spokesman for Procter & Gamble, said the spots ``disparaged'' Folgers coffee. ``It's advocacy advertising and we're surprised that any television station is willing to run that type of ad,'' he said. The Boston Globe said WHDH was the only station in the country to run the ad, which is narrated by actor Ed Asner, a critic of U.S. military aid to the Salvadoran government. ``If you want peace in El Salvador, tell Congress to stop our massive military handouts and tell your supermarket that you refuse to buy Folgers, which uses coffee grown in El Salvador. Boycott Folgers coffee _ What it brews is misery, destruction and death,'' Asner says in the ad. ``It's misleading and it's grossly inaccurate,'' Tassone said. ``This ad singles out Folgers even though virtually every U.S. brand contains some Salvadoran coffee.'' Neighbor to Neighbor says coffee income enriches wealthy Salvadorans allied with the rightist Salvadoran government. It says it has targeted P&G for the boycott because the firm was less responsive on the issue than its competitors. Yanoff said Procter & Gamble at first told him they would pull only their ads for Folgers coffee, but the station was told Thursday the firm would pull all its advertising, worth $70,000 for June and about $1 million for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Trinity River Bottom Residents Brace For Predicted Flooding
With PM-Floods, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Each day, water from a small nearby lake edges closer to Elaine Coward's home. Once it reaches her driveway, she's leaving. ``There's nowhere for it to go but to head for the Gulf,'' said Ms. Coward, who hopes to avoid the expected flooding from waters rampaging down the Trinity River. ``But it's got to run over us first.'' The flooding has resulted from last week's heavy rain that inundated north Texas, more than 200 miles away. The waters are heading south down the Trinity, making their way into Lake Livingston and eventually the Gulf of Mexico. But many communities sit in its path, including the Liberty-Dayton area, about 40 miles east of Houston, where residents have been told they may be hit with the worst flooding in 80 years. Some dirt roads already are covered with water, but the real flooding isn't expected until early next week. Already, many residents threatened by flood waters have moved their belongings to higher ground and made plans to stay elsewhere. At Ms. Coward's home, which she has owned for 12 years, the furniture is up on blocks. Clothes, important documents and mementos have been moved into a trailer where she will live temporarily if her home is flooded. ``It's hard to accept the fact that the water is going to come into your home,'' she said Thursday, a mild, sunny day in southeast Texas. ``It's heartbreaking.'' Last July, her home was flooded by heavy rains, causing $7,000 worth of damage. It took four months to repair the house. Now, she keeps an eye on the water that has creeped to the edge of her yard. Once it reaches her driveway, she said she knows it is time to take the dog and leave. The potential flooding is the talk of this town of about 6,000 residents, even though many are not expected to be hurt by the flooding. ``If they're not personally affected, they have family or friends who are,'' she said. Jim Mitchum, emergency management director for Liberty County, said Thursday there already is flooding in some areas because of the large releases from Livingston Dam, about 25 miles to the north. Exactly one year ago, Mitchum said, his agency was dealing with flood victims after receiving 15{ inches of rain. ``How's that for an anniversary?'' he said. While a voluntary evacuation notice went to people in low-lying areas in Liberty County, others _ like George and Brenda Clark _ plan to stay, and they were in town Thursday stocking up on goods. ``Everybody's getting ready. They're not waiting like they did last time,'' Clark said. The couple and their 7-year-old son were stranded last year for two weeks when water flooded the nearby creek and covered the road to their home. ``But we're going to stay. Our house won't get flooded, we're on high ground,'' he said. ``We're prepared this year.''

DOC.HEAD: Rollback Of Hatch Act Heading For Veto Showdown
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 3 million federal employees and postal workers would be allowed for the first time in half a century to campaign actively for their favorite politicians under a bill passed by both the Senate and House. The two chambers still have to iron out differences in their versions of the bill before trying to muster votes for overriding a threatened veto by President Bush. The Senate's 54 Democrats garnered support from 13 of the 45 Republicans to pass the legislation by a potentially veto-overriding 67-30 vote Thursday. ``Hopefully we can sustain a veto'' later, said Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas. In Bush's first 16 months in office, congressional Democrats have been unable in 10 attempts to override any of his vetoes. Bush's senior advisers have said they would urge him to veto any change in the law as ``undermining the integrity and independence of the traditionally non-partisan civil service.'' GOP leaders contended the bill is a ``pot of gold'' for the Democratic Party because federal employee and postal unions already contribute nine times more money to Democrats than Republicans through their political action committees. The eight days of debate, much of it focused on union PACs, before Thursday's final vote provided a preview to what is sure to be more rancorous battle as the Senate takes up rival versions of campaign finance reform legislation today. ``It's ironical to me we have legislation before us to expand PACs to make possible for federal employees to dun other employees ... at the very time ... we will be considering campaign reform legislation to eliminate or at least reduce PACs,'' said Sen. William V. Roth, R-Del. Outlawing PACs entirely while increasing the amount the individual contributors can donate for political causes is the centerpiece of the GOP campaign finance proposal. The bill approved Thursday would overhaul the Hatch Act. The law was passed in 1939 in response to evidence that enrollees in the Works Progress Administration were being required by New Deal political appointees to donate to the re-election campaign of then-Sen. Alben Barkley, D-Ky. The legislation was sought by federal employee and postal unions after the Reagan administration filed Hatch Act charges against three union presidents for endorsing Democrat Walter Mondale in the 1984 presidential election. The charges were later dismissed by a federal appeals court. Because a permanent and professional civil service is well-established now, Democrats contended most of the Hatch Act restrictions are no longer needed. Sen. Brock Adams said federal workers now enjoy fewer political rights under an ``archaic curtain of silence'' than people do in the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. Republicans, however, contend the legislation will return the civil and postal services to a ``spoils system'' in which workers will be subtly coerced to take up political causes. The bill would still prohibit federal workers from engaging in political activities while on the job and from running for public office or soliciting campaign funds from the public. But they could in their off time begin holding office in local, state and national political organizations, attend their conventions as delegates and solicit campaign funds fromco-workers on behalf of candidates or federal employee union political action committees. The House passed by a veto-proof 297-90 vote a year ago a similar but broader bill that also would remove the prohibitions on running for office and soliciting campaign funds. Before the Senate vote Thursday, Republicans made a stab at trying to continue the current restrictions on employees of the IRS, intelligence agencies, the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission. ``Certain critical agencies of this government need to be beyond political involvement ... (and) not have any taint of politics or coercion,'' said Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M. His amendment to exempt employees of those agencies from the looser restrictions on political involvement and forbid government workers from soliciting co-workers for campaign funds was defeated on a 58-39 vote. The Senate, however, did adopt on a 97-0 vote an amendment by Dole that would maintain the current restrictions on the 240 employees of the Federal Election Commission.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead in 2nd item of package to CORRECT age of Percy to 73 sted 74.
DOC.TEXT: Walker Percy, whose deeply humane novels and essays made him a unique voice in American letters, died Thursday of cancer at age 73. Percy's first novel, ``The Moviegoer,'' won him the National Book Award in 1962. After ``Moviegoer,'' Percy's novels included ``The Last Gentleman'' (1966), ``Love in the Ruins'' (1971), ``Lancelot'' (1977), ``The Second Coming'' (1980), and ``The Thanatos Syndrome'' (1987). Percy peddled his 1983 ``Lost in the Cosmos'' as ``the last self-help book.'' His other major piece of non-fiction was ``The Message in the Bottle'' (1975), essays on the philosophy of language. Percy was named by Pope John Paul II as the only American on the Pontifical Council for Culture.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Visit Stirs Faithful
With PM-Pope, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Aurora Hinojosa Casillas traveled more than 200 miles to Chihuahua and although she knew she wouldn't get close to Pope John Paul II, she said just hearing him was enough. She joined more than 100,000 other people Thursday on a dusty stretch of baseball fields to see the ``pilgrim pope.'' ``For us it is the ultimate to come here,'' said Mrs. Hinojosa, of Ciudad Juarez across the border from El Paso, Texas. ``Since I was born, I've been a Catholic and it's important. He is closer to God.'' The crowd sang hymns and chanted cheers as they awaited the pontiff, but turned frantic when John Paul's approach was broadcast play-by-play over loudspeakers. Hundreds clung to a wire fence separating them from the motorcade, while the more agile scurried to keep up with the glassed-enclosed popemobile. ``I am so pleased that I got so close to him,'' said Brisa Rivera, 21, as she wiped away tears. ``I got to see him one moment and no more, but I feel wonderful. This is a proud moment for Chihuahua.'' The crowd waved yellow and white banners and their arms as they sang the hymn ``Hallelujah.'' Occasionally the crowd let out a cheer: ``A la bim, a la ba, a la bim boom ba. Papa, Papa, rah, rah, rah!'' The pope is called ``El Papa'' in Spanish. Although many had brought blankets and lawn chairs, the majority stood under the hot sun and many wore sun hats or straw cowboy hats. In his half-hour homily, the pope criticized the government's family planning program and advised fathers to become more involved in raising their children. ``He gave advice that was very good for the family,'' said Miguel Martinez. ``In particular what he said about the husbands. We need to listen to his advice because he is a very important person.'' For many, the trek to the papal celebration was a Mother's Day outing _ the holiday is celebrated on May 10 in Mexico. ``We have never had a Mother's Day as noble and beautiful as this,'' said Maria Luisa Lopez Martinez, 56, of Durango, who was with her mother and sister. ``It is worth it to be here because we are awaiting the best person of the world. It's something we wouldn't do for anyone else.'' Adela Cota de Santiesteban said she left her home almost 900 miles away in Baja California on Monday, crossed the Sea of Cortez by ferry and arrived here Wednesday. Her family enjoyed the pope's message, she said, because ``It was about the Mother of God, and we are mothers.''

DOC.HEAD: River Floods Wheat Crops, Delays Rice Planting
LaserPhotos covering
DOC.TEXT: Hillary Pipkin has been farming all his life, but at the moment all his wheat fields are good for is fishing. As waters continue to surge down the Arkansas, Red and Trinity rivers in Texas and Arkansas, agriculture is suffering the most. ``I'm just hoping we can pay our debts and stay in farming,'' Pipkin said Thursday, ``'cause there's not any profit to be made this year.'' Pipkin and his brother grow wheat, cotton, soybeans and rice on about 1,000 acres in the community where they grew up, a few miles north of Pine Bluff in central Arkansas. Their land, handed down by their father, is divided by the Arkansas River levee. About 250 acres on the river side of the levee are under water. ``You can walk down there and catch a fish if you want to,'' said Pipkin, pointing to a spot where water swallows the road that used to cut across his wheat field. Pipkin said about half of his 100-acre winter wheat crop is destroyed. ``It's going to hurt the yield, no doubt about that,'' he said. ``I'd say after this we might cut half a crop.'' And his cotton might not be planted at all. ``It's going to hurt us bad,'' Pipkin said. ``If we get in any cotton, it's not going to have time to make enough like it should.'' Officials are estimating that 450,000 acres of wheat statewide have been damaged by the flooding which could amount to a $4.8 million loss. Rough estimates indicate 25,000 to 30,000 head of cattle were stranded by high water, and many are presumed drowned. In a letter Thursday to President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton said initial official estimates of damage to private, non-agricultural property total $6.5 million. According to preliminary state figures, flooding has damaged 251 homes, but that number will go up as the water recedes, said Gary Talley, spokesman for the Arkansas Office of Emergency Services. The flooding was touched off by last week's severe storms, which were blamed for 13 deaths, one in Oklahoma and the others in Texas. In Texas, estimated damage to agricultural production stands at $500 million to $700 million, with millions more to houses and roads. Arkansas farmers have been attacking the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, saying it had mismanaged dams _ at Lake Texoma on the Red River and Lake Eufala, in Oklahoma, on the Arkansas. After meeting with farmers along the Red River on Wednesday, Clinton said he would talk with members of Arkansas' congressional delegation about the possibility of forming a task force to study the corps' flood management. ``So many of them down there felt, rightly or wrongly, that the corps could have made different decisions on over the last few months (and) there would be less flooding,'' Clinton said. The corps rebutted complaints that its discharges from rising lakes was too much, too late. ``Our projects operated as they were designed to. We managed them just exactly as they were designed to operate,'' Ross Adkins, spokesman for the corps in Tulsa, Okla., said Thursday. ``What we do is capture all the water we can to minimize any damages downstream. When Mother Nature dumps as much rain as we had ... they (the reservoirs) took off a heck of a big bump that could have gone downstream. ``If we had not been here, a lot more houses and perhaps lives would have been lost.'' Decisions by the corps on how fast to release water from the reservoirs it manages can have a crucial effect on who is flooded, and how severely. A quick release of water through the dam's floodgates after a heavy rain increases flooding downstream, while slower release can mean more flooding upstream if the reservoir fills up. Marilyn Quayle, Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, visited flooded parts of Dallas on Wednesday and said the Federal Emergency Management Agency had added nine Texas counties to 16 already named in a May 2 disaster declaration.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Will Again Consider Applicants' Criminal Records
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission has reversed a Reagan-era rule and says it will again consider criminal records in evaluating broadcast license applicants. The FCC in 1986, under then-Chairman Mark S. Fowler, rewrote its character-policy rules to consider only felony convictions that appeared to have a direct link with an applicant's ability to tell the truth and comply with commission rules. Also Thursday, the FCC dropped a proposal to allot broadcast licenses by lottery, and formally opened an investigation into the charges home satellite-dish owners must pay to receive network and ``superstation'' signals. The character-policy revision had been called into question in 1988 when the FCC renewed the license of Williamsburg County Broadcasting Corp. to operate WKSP-AM in Kingstree, S.C. The company's principal owner, Gregory Knop, had been convicted of conspiracy to distribute cocaine and sentenced to five years in prison. The station had told the commission that Knop had a ``non-broadcast-related'' felony conviction, and the FCC did not investigate further. The 1986 revision said crimes that ``shock the conscience'' or ``misconduct which demonstrates the proclivity of an applicant to deal truthfully with the commission and to comply with our rules and policies'' were relevant to license-renewal proceedings. The revision did not say whether drug convictions fell into that category. Explaining Thursday's change, FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes said that ``broadcasting pervades and influences our culture and I think we must have reasonable standards for holding a license.'' Under the latest change, all felony convictions and some misdemeanors will be considered relevant in determining whether a party should possess a broadcast license. The decision was one of several FCC actions designed to tighten licensing requirements. Fowler in 1982 legalized unlimited payoffs between competing applicants to build stations, an action critics said drew a flood of nuisance applications from parties simply wanting to be paid off to withdraw. On Thursday, the FCC proposed to restrict such payoffs, perhaps to 50 percent of expenses after the licensing process reaches a newly proposed settlement conference stage. The FCC said its action would discourage ``sham'' applicants. The commission also dropped a proposal by Fowler's Reagan-era successor, Dennis Patrick, to use lotteries to award radio and television station licenses. Opponents have said the selection of licensees should not be left to a roll of the dice and that such a system would throw open broadcasting to unqualified applicants who, after gaining a license, could sell it to the highest bidder. The lottery proposal also would have ended the existing preference in the licensing procedure for applications filed by women members of minorities. In opening the inquiry into prices home satellite-dish owners pay to get the same signals available to cable television companies, the commission was following up on its December finding of ``disturbing evidence'' that cable operators receive preferential treatment from satellite TV carriers. The FCC cited assertions by the National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative that some companies may be charging back-yard dish owners 20 times more than cable TV systems for the same programs.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plunged against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose moderately. The dollar closed at 154.15 yen, down 2.60 yen from Thursday's close of 156.75 yen. It started trading at 155.75 yen, and ranged between 153.90 and 155.75. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 531.88 points, or 1.72 percent, to close at 31,512.14. The index gained 34.65 points Thursday. Dealers attributed the dollar's plunge mainly to its overnight weakness against major European currencies, especially the Swiss franc. The franc has been rising because of high Swiss interest rates, strong Asian demand and the increasing tendency to view the franc as a ``safe haven'' currency, they said. ``The dollar's weakness against European currencies is encouraging Tokyo investors to sell the dollar and buy the yen,'' said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``Although there is demand for the dollar among trading houses, the market is basically in a dollar-selling mood,'' he said. Kanai said the belief that the U.S. economy is slowing also helped push the dollar down against other currencies. A soft economy could allow U.S. interest rates to ease, weakening the attraction of holding dollars. Market participants were reassessing the situation following the dollar's sudden plunge, dealers said. The dollar seemed to have a floor at about 154.60 yen, they said. Some market players remained on the sidelines awaiting the U.S. government's release later Friday of the U.S. producer price index and retail sales figures for April. The surge in the yen as well as in Japanese government bonds helped stock prices but was not fully reflected in the Nikkei's moderate rise, traders said. ``The equity market was surprisingly uninspired by the strength of the yen and bond markets,'' said Matthew A. Rifkin, assistant vice president for equity trading at Prudential-Bache Securities (Japan). Rifkin attributed the market's restrained reaction to big advances earlier in the week and reluctance to make major moves ahead of the weekend. ``The market has moved pretty far already this week,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Banking Regulators Discuss Tight Credit With Bankers
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan and other top banking regulators blame a slowing economy, and not over-aggressive bank regulation, for increased difficulties in getting credit. Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke and L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., joined Greenspan on Thursday in meeting with the board of the American Bankers Association to allay fears about what they call misconceptions about tightening credit. Such a gathering is practically unheard of, though all the regulators frequently meet bankers and other business executives separately. The three asked to attend the association's board meeting to respond to charges that over-regulation is making bank credit suddenly too difficult for real estate developers and other businesses to get. ``We decided that it would be very useful for us to meet with our colleagues and increase communication,'' Greenspan said. He dismissed talk of a ``credit crunch,'' in the Northeast or elsewhere, saying, ``The evidence of that is quite limited.'' ``We need to turn down the rhetoric,'' said Clarke, whose office has sent extra examiners to the Northeast, where real estate prices have been declining and several banks have heavy real estate portfolios. ``It was an opportunity to get the point across to them that we believe that we're doing the right thing,'' Clarke said. ``We need the support of the industry in connection and (need to) try to clarify some of the misconceptions that may be out there about what we're doing.'' The association, which represents banks holding 93 percent of the commercial banking assets in the country, offered a subdued response compared with the criticism Clarke and others have received from politicians. The politicians complain that regulators are overreacting to the S&L scandals, where many institutions were brought down by unsound real estate loans. In a news conference following the hour-long meeting, association officials discounted the severity of any tightening of credit. ``The ABA board told the regulators that thorough but balanced supervision is the best way to keep the commercial banking industry safe, sound and competitive,'' said ABA President Kelly Holthus. The board consists of presidents of banks ranging from international institutions to small state banks. Donald G. Ogilvie, executive vice president of the association, agreed that the credit slowdown has more to do with a general economic slowdown than with aggressive regulatory practices. Association officials, however, said it was true that some banks were cutting back their lending in response to tougher regulatory supervision. A key message brought to the meeting by the regulators was that banks should continue to make sound loans.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Student Campaign Plan Reported
DOC.TEXT: A defector says China's Communist Party planned to browbeat about 100 exchange students in the United States considered ``ringleaders'' in criticizing the Beijing government, The Washington Post reported in today's editions. Xu Lin, a third secretary in the education section of the Chinese Embassy, told the Post that embassy officials were told to go to U.S. college campuses to court sympathetic students and intimidate the others. Xu provided documents to support his claim, the newspaper said. Today's editions of The New York Times also carried an account of the documents. ``To strike the ringleaders, we should give them a bad name,'' the Post quoted one of the documents as saying. ``Now we must think of a name that has a resounding effect; we cannot use the word dissident.'' The documents classify the students under five headings, ranging from loyal Communists to the ``reactionary core elements who actively organize and plan anti-government activities.'' Tactics to be used against the dissidents, the documents suggested, could include keeping files on them, revoking passports, cutting off government stipends, firing them from their jobs back in China and isolating them from their families still at home. President Bush has signed an executive order promising that Chinese students in the United States will not be forced to return home against their will. More than 50,000 government-sponsored exchange students are studying in the United States and Canada, and the documents said 70 percent to 80 percent of them would not return to China. The State Department says it is looking into allegations that students were harassed, the Post said. A Chinese Embassy spokesman told the newspaper that the allegations in the documents were ``rumors.''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: It looked like a breeze election when George E. J. Carr and Theresa B. Quincel ran unopposed for the county Democratic Central Committee. All they needed was one vote apiece. But no one, not even the candidates themselves, wrote their names in and they both lost in Tuesday's primary. Neither Carr or Ms. Quincel were disappointed. Carr, a retired sheet-metal worker, said a friend talked him into running for the job after no one filed nominating petitions. Carr, 71, later had second thoughts. ``I didn't really want the commitment,'' he said. ``I want to come and go as I please. Plus, I have arthritis, so I didn't even vote for myself.'' Ms. Quincel, 36, said her political activity is limited to voting and called her candidacy an honest mistake. She said someone in the party offered her a job similar to one held by her niece, who she said is a precinct judge. ``Two weeks before the election, I found out the job was as a committee member and by then it was too late to change,'' she said. The central committee will fill the vacancies by appointment.

Federal appeals court Judge Alex Kozinski, an avowed film buff, couldn't resist using 204 movie titles in an antitrust decision. In a 25-page decision Wednesday for the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, Kozinski rejected a federal antitrust suit accusing theater operator Raymond Syufy of monopolizing the first-run film market in Las Vegas. By Kozinski's account, the trial lasted not eight days or nine but ``8{,'' as in the Fellini film. He wrote the middle initial of Syufy's lawyer, Maxwell Blecher, as ``M,'' without a period _ the title of the 1931 Fritz Lang-Peter Lorre classic. Syufy was ``somewhat of a Local Hero,'' the judge wrote. Another chain ``stepped into the Major Leagues, and Against All Odds'' began competing seriously. The competitor's theaters ``evolved from Absolute Beginners, barely Staying Alive, into a Big Business.'' Some of the titles were natural fits to the case. Kozinski wrote that antitrust law did not require rivals to finish in a ``Dead Heat'' as long as they were allowed to do their ``Personal Best.'' He described bureaucrats who ostensibly saw ``The Big Picture'' and knew how to ``Do The Right Thing.'' Others matches were more difficult. He wrote that Syufy entered the Las Vegas market with a ``Splash,'' that competitors saw their future as ``Rocky,'' and that a ``Little Big Man'' might hold monopoly power.

DOC.HEAD: First Use of U.S. Drug Law Seeking Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors will seek the death penalty for two men charged with murdering a drug case witness in what would be the first execution by the U.S. government in 27 years. ``We recognize the death penalty is an extreme sanction,'' Andrea L. Zopp, one of the federal prosecutors handling the case, said Thursday. ``We think it is appropriate in this case.'' It would be the first use of a November 1988 federal law that allows the death penalty for murders committed to further drug conspiracies. The so-called ``drug kingpin'' provisions sanction the death penalty for murders ordered by drug dealers as part of their business. Alexander Cooper and Anthony Davis are charged with murdering a federal witness to protect their $50,000-a-day drug ring. Davis is still at large. In a statement, U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said, ``Street level distribution networks such as the one alleged in this indictment cannot be effectively dismantled without the cooperation of citizen-witnesses. ``When those witnesses are murdered because of their cooperation with law enforcement authorities, Congress has determined that this ultimate sanction should be available.'' Federal authorities are ``eager to show that they're tough on drug crime,'' but the law won't stop drug dealers from killing, said Henry Schwarzschild, director of the Capital Punishment Project for the American Civil Liberties Union. ``They expect to get away with it. They don't expect to get caught. And if you expect to get away with it, you don't care if the penalty is 40 years in prison or the electric chair,'' he said in a telephone interview from New York. ``We're certainly not pleased with the federal government getting back into the business of death penalty cases and having a federal hangman again, but it's certainly not anything surprising, and it's not a great legal event,'' said Schwarzschild. No civilian has been executed in a federal case since Victor Feuger was hanged at Iowa State Prison on March 15, 1963, after being convicted on charges of kidnapping and murder, Schwarzschild said. The provision's constitutionality is certain to face court challenges, but Schwarzschild said federal lawmakers were probably careful to make the law conform with guidelines set up by the U.S. Supreme Court in the 1970s. ``We think the statute is clearly constitutional and will pass constitutional muster,'' Zopp said. Older federal law has death penalty provisions for such crimes as treason, assassination of the president and top federal officials, and killings involving aircraft hijackings, train wrecks, kidnappings and bank robberies. Those statutes, however, were never amended to reflect changes in death penalty laws mandated by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1972, and are widely considered unconstitutional. The 1988 law is the first new statute to take the Supreme Court guidelines into account, legal experts said. Under military law, provisions exist for capital punishment for violent crimes or spying. But no member of the U.S. military has been executed in peacetime since 1961, Schwarzschild said. Cooper, 29, and Davis, 39, had been named along with 20 others in two indictments issued Oct. 19 charging them with various federal drug charges. Federal authorities say Cooper ran an extensive street-level operation from 1982 to 1989 that distributed up to six kilograms of heroin and two kilograms of cocaine a week. Cooper directed Davis to kill an associate, Robert Parker, because Parker was cooperating with police and giving federal authorities information about the drug operation, the government said. Parker was shot in the head five times Feb. 6. Telephone calls to attorneys for Cooper went unanswered Thursday night. The death penalty has withstood recent legal challenges in Illinois, which expects to execute a prisoner this year for the first time in 28 years. Thirteen other states have executed a total of 124 inmates since the Supreme Court allowed states to restore the death penalty in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: New Uproar Over Newsday Column
DOC.TEXT: Newsday is in an uproar again after a columnist defended fellow writer Jimmy Breslin _ suspended for slurring a Korean-American reporter _ and in doing so used what one official claimed was an epithet for Irishmen. Peter King, comptroller of Nassau County, demanded that Newsday reprimand columnist Robert Reno and order him to apologize for his article in Thursday's paper. King, an outspoken supporter of Irish nationalism, accused Reno of ``arrogant insensitivity, if not outright anti-Irish racism'' and called him ``a man of unbounded ignorance and stupidity.'' Reno Thursday tried to defend the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist by writing: ``Breslin has a pathologically rotten temper for which all his greatness is no excuse. On the other hand, if he wasn't capable of such mindless, offensive and imaginative rages, he'd just be another windy Irishman.'' The article ran in some editions with the headline ``A Lion's Heart, A Donkey's Head Belong to Breslin.'' ``Even in the rarefied offices of the Newsday editors, someone must be aware that donkey is a derogatory term long used against the Irish,'' King said. He said the term means stupid and thick-headed. ``Apparently, being anti-Irish is a prejudice or an ignorance which is still acceptable at Newsday,'' King said. ``If donkey is a synonym for Irishman, that's a new one on me,'' said Reno, adding he thought King was ``being foolish.'' The Breslin uproar began when reporter Ji-Yeon Yuh sent a computer message to Breslin and the newspaper's editor, Don Forst, in which she called a Breslin colunm sexist. Breslin responded by calling Yuh ``slant-eyed'' and a ``yellow cur.'' Breslin was suspended without pay for two weeks on Tuesday after he made light of the tirade.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Prison Industries Get Unfair Advantages
DOC.TEXT: Private-sector companies face increasingly stiff competition from a prison manufacturing program that's growing so rapidly it may soon become the equivalent of a Fortune 500 company, lawmakers say. Rep. Howard Coble, R-N.C., lobbied Thursday for support of a bill to curb the preferential treatment accorded the federal prison system in selling products to government agencies. ``At least I want the private companies to feel like they're essentially playing under the same conditions'' as the prisons, he said. He said manufacturers in his district were hurt by the prison program, which last year sold $361 million worth of products ranging from clothing to electronics. Furniture sales totaled $90 million, a 20 percent increase over 1988. The program employed 13,000 inmates and 1,400 civilians. The prison program's sales are expected to double by 1992 as the inmate population swells, said Rep. Fred Upton, R-Mich., upon which it ``would rank as a Fortune 500 company and likely dominate the federal market for furniture and many other products.'' Upton and Rep. Paul Henry, R-Mich., testified at a hearing of the House Judiciary subcommittee on courts, intellectual property and the administration of justice. The panel is considering a bill under which prisons would have to compete on an equal footing with private companies once the prisons obtain a 10 percent share of the federal market for a product. Currently, federal agencies must buy products from the prison system if it can meet the purchaser's price and delivery requirements.
DOC.HEAD: Texas Company Recalling Some Pulmanex Resuscitators
DOC.TEXT: Medical personnel who use Pulmanex Manual resuscitators are being asked to return the devices because of a defect that could be fatal to patients, according to the Food and Drug Administration. Life Design Systems Inc. of Carrollton, Texas, is voluntarily recalling resuscitators with model numbers beginning with 90, 91, 95 or 96 and ending with a 0, 1, 2 or 3 after the hyphen, the FDA said Thursday. The recalled models have lot numbers 9321 through 9361 and were made between Nov. 17 and Dec. 27, 1989. Life Designs Systems has recalled other models of the resuscitator for various reasons in five previous recalls, the FDA said. The agency said it did not know of any deaths resulting from a faulty resuscitator. The resuscitator subject to the latest recall comes in adult, pediatric and neonatal sizes. It consists of a mask that is placed over the patient's mouth and nose and is attached to a plastic bag. Squeezing the plastic bag forces air into the patient's lungs. In faulty resuscitators, the rear valves can become dislodged and prevent air from reaching the person being resuscitated, the FDA said. If the problem is not recognized in time, the patient could die.
