DOC.HEAD: Banks Oppose New Student Loan Service
DOC.TEXT: Bankers say a new plan to offer college loans directly through student aid offices could hurt their business. Three large student aid organizations are joining together to form CollegeCredit, a program designed to offer college students one-stop shopping for assistance. It will help aid officers to more easily package loans with other forms of assistance. The partners in the joint venture are: _the Student Loan Marketing Association (Sallie Mae), a federally-chartered, shareholder-owned company that buys student loans from lenders and collects the payments. _The College Board, a non-profit group which administers financial aid for colleges and provides a common aid application form. _the Teachers Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund, a large pension plan for college and private school employees. CollegeCredit plans to offer $150 million in loans through The College Board starting in the 1990-91 school year. Teachers Annuity is setting aside $50 million and other lenders will supply the rest. Sallie Mae will buy the loans, replenishing the money available for future loans. All three groups will earn fee income in the process. Banks complain the program will skim off the cream of the student loan market degree-granting institutions, leaving them loans to trade school and community college students, which have a higher default rate.

DOC.HEAD: Nicarguan Leader Makes Austerity Moves; Workers to Strike
DOC.TEXT: Struggling to stay afloat, the government imposed huge price increases and suspended a law protecting workers' rights. Public employees retaliated by announcing a strike and an occupation of government offices. The indefinite strike by a union federation of the government's 60,000 employees began in some offices late Thursday. A union leader said it would begin officially today. The workers are demanding 200 percent raises to keep pace with inflation. Thursday's austerity measures came a day after Antonio Lacayo, minister of the presidency, announced that Nicaragua was in bankruptcy and even more painful remedies had to be implemented. In addition to the price hikes and suspension of the workers' law, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro devalued the Nicaraguan cordoba 9 percent in relation to the dollar. It was the second devaluation in two days and the fourth in three weeks. Water rates were doubled, electricity rates tripled and telephone service hiked 1,300 percent. The government subsidy for public transportation was eliminated. The cordoba traded at 180,000 to the dollar on the parallel market Thursday, an official rate for most currency transactions. The rate in January was 38,150. The Chamorro government blames its leftist Sandinista predecessors for the country's economic situation. The treasury was down to a bare $3 million when Mrs. Chamorro took office last month, officials of the new government say. In a communique Thursday, government workers said they would protest the new government's actions with ``the immediate takeover of installations and the blocking of access to ministers and vice ministers of the government of Mrs. Chamorro.'' The communique was released by the General Federation of State Workers. However, Lino Areas, a federation official, said the strike could be postponed if the government negotiates. Unions are demanding that the government ``make a fair salary readjustment so that workers can acquire basic consumer products,'' Areas said. Laborers now earn an average of about $44 a month and white-collar workers about $100. They have faced a series of devaluations and soaring prices both under the Sandinistas and under Mrs. Chamorro, who took office April 25. Inflation, after hitting 33,600 percent in 1988, dropped to 1,800 percent in 1989. There are no reliable estimates for this year. The workers' rights law, approved by the Sandinista government less than three weeks after it lost Feb. 25 elections, allows government employees to organize unions, bargain collectively, strike and exercise other rights. Thursday's decree suspends the law until the new government writes its own rules. It also allows the Labor Ministry to review all labor contracts signed during the Sandinistas' lame-duck period. Referring to suspension of the law, the federation accused the government of ``preparing general conditions for the massive firing of state workers.'' On the political front, meanwhile, Contra rebels said they would stop a demobilization process begun Tuesday, when about 80 Contras turned in their weapons to U.N. troops. Contra spokesman Alejandro Acevedo said in Miami that the Sandinista army had failed to pull back from the security zones where the rebels are gathered. The pullback is called for in the demobilization agreement signed May 4. The U.S.-backed Contras battled the Sandinistas during a 9-year war. Acevedo said more than 12,000 Contra fighters still hold arms, but independent observers say Contra forces have been reduced to a few thousand.

DOC.HEAD: Multiple Sclerosis-Type Disease Cured in Mice, Human Treatment Years Away
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf, `In my...' to UPDATE with reference to previous research. PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `Of five...
DOC.TEXT: Scientists cured mice of a disease similar to multiple sclerosis and said their work could lead to successful treatment of the human disease, although a cure for people is 10 or more years away. The new method also might help scientists develop treatments for a variety of other human autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, lupus and myasthenia gravis, the California Institute of Technology announced Thursday. In autoimmune diseases, the body's immune system attacks the body's own tissues instead of simply defending against disease-causing foreign invaders. In multiple sclerosis, certain white blood cells called helper T-cells attack the body's nerve tissue, causing paralysis, muscle cramps and weakness, slurred speech, blurred vision, fatigue, difficulty in coordination, dizziness and loss of balance. About 250,000 Americans have multiple sclerosis. Scientists from Caltech and Washington University in St. Louis said they designed special antibodies _ called monoclonal antibodies _ to destroy the white blood cells that cause a disease in mice resembling human multiple sclerosis. ``While we are quite excited about these results, I think it's important to emphasize at the outset that we have not developed a cure for human multiple sclerosis or any other human autoimmune disease,'' said Caltech biologist Leroy E. Hood. ``In my opinion, our technique is at least 10 years away from human application,'' Hood said in a prepared statement, adding that he wanted to ``avoid raising false hope in those who suffer from this debilitating and quite serious disease.'' During the past decade, other researchers showed monoclonal antibodies could to some extent reverse or prevent the mouse disease. Some even used mouse antibodies to treat human multiple sclerosis patients, who displayed only slight improvement and developed allergic reactions to the foreign antibodies. The method used by Hood's laboratory involved designing antibodies aimed at the exact type of T-cells that cause the mouse disease, significantly boosting the proportion of mice in which the disease was prevented or reversed. Of five sick mice given the new treatment, three showed complete reversal of paralysis within two to seven days, and a fourth's complete paralysis was reduced to slight paralysis of its tail. The fifth mouse died. Five other mice were not given the treatment, and their paralysis wasn't reversed. Related experiments in dozens of other mice showed the disease could be prevented if they were injected with the monoclonal antibodies before scientists tried to make them sick. The study was conducted in Hood's laboratory by research fellows Dennis Zaller and Gamal Osman, and by Osami Kanagawa at Washington University. It will be published in next month's issue of the Journal of Experimental Medicine. Development of the new method ``certainly is significant,'' said Dr. George Ellison, a professor of neurology at the University of California, Los Angeles. If a similar treatment can be developed for humans, ``that would be a major achievement,'' Ellison said, adding that he agreed with Hood such therapy was years in the future. To perform the experiments, the scientists made mice sick with a disease called murine experimental allergic encephalomyelitis, or EAE, which produces symptoms similar to human multiple sclerosis. They did this by injecting the mice with a protein found in the sheaths that coat nerve cell fibers in the brain. The rodents' immune systems then produced helper T-cells that attacked not only the injected protein but the protein in the rodents' brains. After studying the makeup of this type of T-cell in great detail, the scientists designed monoclonal antibodies that, when injected into the sick mice, found and destroyed the disease-causing T-cells while leaving intact T-cells that protect the mice against other diseases. Hood said use of the technique on human autoimmune diseases is years away because they are much more complex than the mouse ailment. Also, he said, understanding of human T-cells is far less advanced than the understanding of such cells in mice.

DOC.HEAD: The `Dice Man' Cometh and `SNL' Cast Members Goeth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Portions of the following may be considered offensive. Sinead is pronounced Shin-AID.
DOC.TEXT: Even his fellow comedians say there's something a little dicey about Andrew Dice Clay, whose shtick prompted a ``Saturday Night Live'' cast member and musical guest to boycott this weekend's show. Is this an attitude, Dice Man? Or what? Pee-wee Herman in a leather jacket, he ain't. Dice is an X-rated Fonzie, the archetypal corner wiseguy, a lewd, sexist makeout artist whose kindest term for a woman is ``broad.'' Dice's comedy is deep, deep blue. He evokes body fluids, orifices and how they get together on bad dates. His critics say his jokes are at best crude, and at worst angry, sexually violent, homophobic and bigoted. Last year, MTV banned Clay for life after he delivered a monologue laced with lewd poetry and references to fat women and sex during the network's awards show. Clay and his defenders say the comedian is only ``acting'' Dice, that his humor mocks the Dice Man's attitudes and has enough truth in it to attract an audience of men and women who love him. ``I talk about what people do, think or say behind closed doors,'' Clay told Playboy magazine in a January interview. ``As I tell the crowds, `I don't write this material. You write it for me.''' ``I don't buy it,'' said Richard Belzer, a comedian who's taken his share of flak as well as praise for his handling of adult themes. ``I don't mean to sound pretentious, but we do have a responsibility as comedians, especially if we deal in inflammatory subjects,'' he said. ``There are people that do jokes _ gay-bashing and anti-minorities _ because it gets a laugh, not because it makes any kind of statement,'' Belzer said. ``I think it's just an easy, cheap, stupid laugh unless you're a Richard Pryor, a David Steinberg or a Robert Klein: Somebody who can take social issues in a comedic context and say something that's incisive and funny without being hurtful or mean-spirited.'' George Carlin, who made a comedy breakthrough by speaking the seven words you can't say on television, is worried that Clay's humor targets the wrong people. ``Andrew Clay is picking on underdogs: Gays, women and immigrants,'' Carlin said. ``His audiences share his beliefs, so they cheer him on. But Andrew ought to remember that he is Jewish and the same people who hate gays, women and immigrants probably have Jews somewhere on their list as well.'' Clay, 32, born Andrew Clay Silverstein in Brooklyn, was a struggling actor-impressionist when he donned the studded jacket, combed up the ducktail and started talking about bad sex. The Dice Man was born. A successful comedy album, HBO comedy specials and sell-out concerts followed. His first starring role in a feature film, ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' opens this summer. The current controversy began when Nora Dunn, a cast member on ``Saturday Night Live'' since the '85-86 season, refused to perform on this week's show because she considers Clay's comedy degrading and repulsive. ``In my heart, I know I don't want to work with him,'' Dunn said. Clay told ``Entertainment Tonight'' that Dunn was being silly. ``I've seen her play from hookers to just, like, street tramps. I wouldn't look at that and go, `If that's really her, I wouldn't do the show.''' Dunn denies ever portraying streetwalkers. Pop singer Sinead O'Conner, whose ``Nothing Compares 2 U'' is No. 2 on the charts, also bowed off the show after her publicist was alerted by the National Organization for Women and the singer reviewed tapes of Clay's act. ``It would be nonsensical of `Saturday Night Live' to expect a woman to perform songs about a woman's experience after a monologue by Andrew Dice Clay,'' the singer said. She was replaced Thursday by Spanic Boys, a bluegrass rock 'n' roll band from Milwaukee, and Julee Cruise, a singer who has been heard on the soundtrack of the series ``Twin Peaks,'' NBC said. ``We're not saying that he should be silenced,'' said Francoise Jacobsohn, a spokeswoman for NOW's ``media reform'' committee. ``We're saying that he's giving a view that is harmful to women.'' She said hate crimes are on the rise in this country. ``We have to make the connection between comics that are sexist and homophobic, and hate crimes,'' she said. ``We have to let people know that this kind of humor is not OK.'' Efforts to interview Clay about the controversy were unsuccessful. ``He has no statement,'' said Clay publicist Susan Dubow. ``He's not doing interviews. He's rehearsing for `Saturday Night Live.''' He also backed out of a scheduled taping Thursday of ``The Joan Rivers Show'' scheduled for broadcast today. Rivers' spokeswoman Linda Lipman said Clay's representatives gave no reason for the no-show, other than ``a lot of hemming and hawing.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Catches Fire in Manila; 30 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with 30 injured, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A Philippines Airlines 737 caught fire from an explosion today as it prepared to take off in Manila with 119 people aboard, officials said. All passengers reportedly escaped, but 30 were injured. Most injuries were minor, according to a nurse at the clinic of the Manila domestic airport. But at least one person was hospitalized, officials said. Airline Vice President Enrique Santos said 113 passengers and six crew members had boarded the flight to Iloilo, 300 miles to the south, when an explosion rocked the plane. Santos said the cabin filled with smoke, but passengers were able to escape by sliding down emergency chutes. Flames engulfed the plane, he said. Santos said one person was taken to the hospital, but he did not know the nature or extent of the injuries. Santos said could not immediately determine what caused the explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Fashion Designer's Will Challenged
DOC.TEXT: The widow of Italian fashion magnate Aldo Gucci is challenging a will that leaves all of his American property to the woman he lived with and to the daughter she bore him. Gucci, who died Jan. 19 in Rome at age 84, left an estate worth millions of dollars. But his will, filed for probate in Manhattan Surrogate Court, says only that the estate is worth more than $500,000. Olwen Price, 82, Gucci's English-born wife who bore him three sons, filed a challenge to the will two weeks ago. Gucci's will, executed in Palm Beach, Fla., on Nov. 3, 1989, leaves half of his U.S. estate ``to my wife Bruna Palombo Gucci'' and half to their daughter Patricia Gucci Losio, 25. There is no indication that Gucci and Palombo ever formally married, nor that he divorced Price, though they lived apart for many years. In their petition for probate of the will, Gucci's lawyers named Price as Gucci's wife, although the will names Palombo. The will also says Gucci ``openly acknowledges Patricia Gucci Losio as his daughter.'' Price, who lives in Rome, and two of the sons, Paolo of West Sussex, England, and Roberto of Florence, say the will was ``not freely or voluntarily made.'' They charge that it was ``procured by fraud, duress and undue influence practiced upon the decedent by an individual purporting to be his wife, to wit, Bruna Palombo.'' Price's third son, Giorgio of Rome, is not contesting the will. Price's court papers also charge that the will was invalid because the witnesses did not sign in Gucci's presence or in the presence of each other. Price, who says she is entitled to the ``widow's share'' of the estate, says the 10-page will filed here was revoked by a will handwritten by Gucci Nov. 8 in Rome. She did not cite the that will's provisions. Karen Barkhorn, a lawyer for the estate, confirmed that an Italian will exists but refused to comment on its validity. Gucci pleaded guilty and was sentenced in 1986 to a year and a day in prison for evading $7.4 million in income taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Novelist Walker Percy Dies At 73
DOC.TEXT: Walker Percy, whose deeply ethical novels dealt with displaced Southern men searching for faith and love in the modern world, has died of cancer at age 73. Percy's first successful novel, ``The Moviegoer,'' won the National Book Award in 1962. It established a theme that would occupy his entire career, that of spiritually marooned men seeking to overcome their alienation. Historian Shelby Foote, a lifelong friend, was with Percy when he died Thursday. ``He belongs with the great Southern writers,'' Foote said. ``I think he makes a fifth with (John Crowe) Ransom, (William) Faulkner, (Thomas) Wolfe and (Eudora) Welty.'' In Jackson, Miss., Miss Welty said: ``I'm very grieved and very, very hurt for all his family. His friendship meant a lot to me and his work meant a great deal to me.'' A funeral Mass and burial was set for Saturday at St. Joseph's Abbey near Covington. While Percy's protagonists were in the southern mold, his philosophical concerns were not the same as other well-known southern writers. Trained as a physician, Percy converted to Catholicism in early adulthood during a period of intense personal examination. His intellectual underpinnings reflected much study of French existentialism, and he held true to these foundations to his death, Foote said. ``He never said, `Why is this happening to me?''' Foote said. ``Nothing like that. He tried to reassure his family that this was all right.'' Said Miss Welty: ``I don't know anybody like him in any way or anybody that did have the strong imaginative power and philosophical power that he had, the scientific power and the fictional power, all of those twined together into one. That is a unique quality in his work.'' Critic Stanley Kauffmann, who edited ``The Moviegoer,'' called him ``one of the loveliest American writers of this century. ... He was a natural ... His novel `The Moviegoer' will last as long as America loves literature.'' Percy's other novels included ``The Last Gentleman'' (1966), ``Love in the Ruins'' (1971), ``Lancelot'' (1977), ``The Second Coming'' (1980), and ``The Thanatos Syndrome'' (1987). His two major works of non-fiction were ``The Message in the Bottle'' (1975), essays on the philosophy of language, and ``Lost in the Cosmos'' (1983) which he called ``the last self-help book.'' Percy's vision of modern malaise was often ironic, hard-edged and eerily prophetic. But his writings also contained some of the most wildly comic and deeply humane messages in contemporary fiction. He also taught writing. It was through his efforts that John Kennedy Toole's ``A Confederacy of Dunces'' was published posthumously. The novel won the 1981 Pulitzer Prize for fiction. Born May 28, 1916, in Birmingham, Ala., Percy was orphaned in his teens. He and his two brothers went to Greenville, Miss., to live with William Alexander Percy, his father's cousin who was author of the Southern classic ``Lanterns on the Levee.'' The Percy household marked young Walker forever with its passing parade of intellectuals, artists, politicians and vagabonds. Percy got a medical degree from Columbia University in 1941. The next year, working as a pathologist at Bellevue Hospital in New York City, he caught pulmonary tuberculosis while performing autopsies on derelicts. ``I've often said that getting a light case of TB was the best thing that could've happened to me. It gave me a period of enforced idleness,'' Percy said. He read voraciously during his three years of recovery and turned to a life of writing. He often gave credit to his ``original Presbyterian work ethic'' for discipline and steadiness. In the mornings he wrote, and in the afternoons he typed what he'd written. He did not believe in writer's block, but he was often furiously frustrated. He told one interviewer: ``It's a question of being so pitiful God takes pity on you, looks down and says, `He's done for. Let's let him have a couple of good sentences.' ``It's a strange, abject, little-understood profession.'' He is survived by his wife, Mary Bernice, two daughters, Mary Pratt Percy Lobdell and Ann Boyd Percy Moores; two brothers, LeRoy and Billups Phinizy Percy, and four grandsons.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Circus Stranded Amid Tales of Bounced Checks and Poor Promotion
DOC.TEXT: Managers of a Soviet circus, stranded after just two stops on a planned two-year goodwill tour of the United States, scrambled to line up investors to get back in the ring. ``It's just one of those shows that went on the road and did not have its act together,'' said Rick Hamilton, executive director of the Knoxville (Tenn.) Civic Center, where the Great Circus Bim Bom performed before small crowds last week. The circus performers were stranded in motels in suburban Atlanta after being kicked out of two motels by managers who questioned whether bills would be paid. The circus animals are in Newburgh, N.Y., at the headquarters of the company transporting them. The performers are crestfallen, one of them said. ``I've been all over the world and this is the first time this has ever happened,'' said Victor Lomakin, who has a chimpanzee act. ``We have a great show. Not being able to perform is like taking a piece of gold and throwing it out.'' The 138-member all-star circus, which includes performers from 60 Soviet circuses, arrived in the United States March 31 to start its two-year tour. After three weeks of training in Wheeling, W.Va., the circus performed in Hershey, Pa., April 25-29. After that stop, the troupe's financial problems began. The trip's backers, a Kuwaiti father and son, withdrew their support, according to Nikolaj Vissokovsky, president of International Showbusiness Inc., a Florida-based firm directing the tour. Brooks Savage, a lawyer for Waleed A.A. Ahmad and his father, Khoorsheed Ahmad, said the men had given the circus a loan and had never intended to back the whole tour. The backers are out $331,000 plus a promised 10 percent of receipts, Savage said. The circus performed to crowds of just 300 and 400 in the 5,200-seat Knoxville arena on May 2 and May 3. Hamilton blamed the poor turnout on lack of advance promotion. ``In Knoxville, we only got the (promotional) stuff four days ahead of time,'' he said. The circus next moved to Johnson City, Tenn., but canceled its performance and moved to suburban Atlanta, where some of the tour's support contractors were based, to regroup. Tales of bounced checks at Hershey, Knoxville and Johnson City soon caught up with the circus, and some members of the troupe were kicked out of a Motel 6 in Marietta on Wednesday and others from the Brittany Park Hotel on Thursday. Most ended up in a Scottish Inns of America, where they were trying on Thursday to find cash to pay their bills and keep their rooms. John Stallion, the circus' promotions director, said a new financial backer planned to wire $2,000 to him to pay for the rooms. He declined to identify the backer. Vissokovsky said the promoters' ``No. 1 priority'' is paying the string of bad debts. He estimated the circus owes about $450,000 to trucking, lighting and other production companies. He said he was talking again with the Kuwaiti investors as well as others who might be interested in sponsoring the circus. ``We're all hanging in there,'' Vissokovsky said. ``We've got a lot of damage control to do. We need to clean up our name.'' Officials in Washington said Thursday they were aware of the circus's plight but had no plans to intervene. ``There are absolutely no political implications _ this just appears to be a case of a business venture gone bad,'' said Sidney Smith of the State Department. Vissokovsky said a Soviet Embassy official told him Thursday that any decision about abandoning the tour would have to be made by the circus' director, Yuri Turkin.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops, Prices Rise in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plummeted against the yen in Tokyo today as the stronger Japanese currency pushed prices sharply higher on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar closed at 154.15 yen, down 2.60 yen from Thursday's close of 156.75 yen. It started trading at 155.75 yen, its high for the day, and ranged as low as 153.90 yen. Dealers said an overnight decline in the dollar's value against the Swiss franc and West German mark pushed it below a technical floor, resulting in widespread dollar selling. The franc has been rising because of high Swiss interest rates, strong Asian demand and the increasing tendency to view the franc as a ``safe haven'' currency, dealers said. Japan's major securities houses sold the dollar heavily in the morning. After lunch, they were joined by life insurers and other major market players, said John Radinoff, vice president of Goldman Sachs (Japan). ``The yen has been massively oversold, and people have been looking for excuses to sell dollars,'' Radinoff said. Some market players remained on the sidelines awaiting the U.S. government's release later today of the U.S. producer price index and retail sales figures, both for April, which are expected to point to an economic slowdown. Concern that the U.S. economy is slowing also helped push the dollar lower, dealers said. None of Tokyo's markets reacted perceptibly to unconfirmed rumors circulating throughout financial circles in Asia that Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, or another senior leader, Chen Yun, was seriously ill, traders said. Chinese Foreign Ministry officials denied the rumor, calling it a ``fabrication with ulterior motives.'' The source of the rumor was unclear, market sources said. The surge in the yen's strength as well as in the Japanese government bond market helped stock prices but was not fully reflected in the Nikkei Stock Average's moderate rise, traders said. The 225-share Nikkei index gained 531.88 points, or 1.72 percent, to close at 31,512.14. The index gained 34.65 points Thursday. The index climbed only 185.68 points in the morning session but surged higher in the afternoon after market participants became confident that the yen had strengthened substantially, traders said. ``In the morning, dealers were staring at their screens and asking if there had been some kind of mistake. It was remarkable,'' said Paul Muller, manager of international institutional sales at Schroder Securities (Japan). ``By the afternoon, it was clear the yen had broke through.'' Share prices advanced across the board, but only a moderate 600 million shares changed hands on the market's first section. ``This implies there's a lot of selling still to be done,'' Muller said. In bond dealings, benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 87.40 points, up from Thursday's close of 86.47 points. Their yield fell to 7.080 percent from 7.275 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Dampens New England; Snow Falls in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: A winterlike storm continued to dump snow on Michigan early today, and rain fell in northern New England. The snow that fell in Upper Michigan was part of a storm that has brought record spring snowfall to the Great Lakes region since late Wednesday. Snow accumulations Thursday ranged from a trace in central Illinois to 4 inches in Chicago's northwest suburbs to more than a foot in some high points on Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Eight inches piled up in Michigan's Marquette, Negaunee and Ishpeming counties, and 12.8 inches fell at Marquette's airport. Up to 8 inches of snow fell in eastern Wisconsin. Dozens of schools were closed throughout the state, and two deaths and hundreds of traffic accidents were reported during the Thursday morning rush hour when snow was heaviest. Elsewhere Thursday, high winds were blamed for a death in central North Carolina. A 50-year-old man was mowing his lawn when a large tree fell on him, authorities said. Tornadoes touched down in Florida near Cape Coral, Fort Myers and Miami. Thunderstorm winds gusted to 55 mph at Norfolk, Va. Showers and thunderstorms rumbled over central New England, much of New York state, eastern Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, eastern Virginia, parts of the Carolinas and southern Florida. Showers and thunderstorms also developed in central California, western Nevada, western Montana and the Idaho Panhandle. Rain dampened eastern Indiana and western Ohio. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms in Texas, southern Oklahoma and Kansas. Rain was forecast for Wyoming to Missouri, and showers were expected in Pennsylvania, New York and Vermont. The nation's high Thursday was 98 degrees at Bullhead City, Ariz., and Presidio, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Our consciences demand that we act, our pocketbooks command that we do so and our safety demands that it be done immediately.'' _ Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., urging a $3 billion drug-fighting plan following a Senate study that set the number of hard-core cocaine addicts in the United States at 2.2 million.

``Without denying the good results obtained ... where a free system reigns, we still cannot be blind to the defects of an economic system that not infrequently makes riches and consumption its principal engine.'' Pope John Paul II, assailing materialism during a trip to Mexico.

``Mr. Hope is not an Indian, but is an Indian at heart.'' _ Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, lobbying for Anthony Hope, a son of entertainer Bob Hope, to be confirmed as chairman of a new federal Indian gaming commission.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Releases Red Squad Surveillance Files
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ordered the release of files on about 1.5 million people, including the city's current mayor, who were spied on by the police department's Red Squad before it was abolished in 1974. Activists said release of the documents ordered Thursday would lay to rest an era of ``social paranoia,'' when activists were targeted by Detroit police surveillance. The Rev. William Cunningham, director of the human rights group Focus:HOPE in Detroit, said he looked forward to seeing his file. ``I'll pursue it out of curiosity and to see what they've got on me,'' said Cunningham. ``It was social paranoia, another chapter of McCarthyism.'' Wayne County Circuit Judge Lucile Watts ordered the city to allot $750,000 to the Red Squad Notification and Distribution Compliance Program. The program will hire 65 employees to field calls and letters from people seeking to learn if they were spied upon. ``Because they spoke out, they were spied on. The 1.5 million people were not trying to overthrow the state of Michigan,'' said Richard Soble, an attorney representing the plaintiffs. Mayor Coleman Young opposed the Red Squad, which had existed since the 1940s, and shut it down after taking office in 1974. However, he wanted to destroy the files, which are contained in 40 cabinets crammed into a a small office in downtown Detroit. Civil rights activists sued to gain access to the files. Young, a civil rights and labor activist for decades before his election, features prominently in the files, which include minutes of meetings that Young attended, said Police Commissioner Roy Levy Williams. ``These meetings talked about the Pentagon being a deterrent to the American objectives by stealing too much from the budget,'' Williams said. ``Anything like that with criticism of the status quo, those folks wanted to know what was being said to protect the common good.'' Williams said the city was satisfied with the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Child Witness Ends Testimony Inconclusively
DOC.TEXT: After squirming on the witness stand and sobbing in her father's arms, the first child witness in Raymond Buckey's retrial repeatedly said she couldn't remember if she was molested at the McMartin preschool. ``I don't remember if it happened or not,'' the 11-year-old said when asked if Buckey touched her sexually. At the conclusion of cross-examination, Buckey's lawyer, Danny Davis, asked the girl whether she was sodomized. ``I don't remember,'' she said. The 31-year-old Buckey is charged specifically with raping the girl and using a foreign object to sodomize her. Clutching a stuffed toy snake, she initially expressed her unwillingness to take the stand Thursday. Then, the youngster said she had a stomachache, left the stand and went into a hallway where she sat sobbing in her father's arms. The parents and prosecutors spent an hour with her in private, and she finally returned to finish her testimony. On Wednesday she had said she was neither sodomized nor raped by Buckey when she attended his family's nursery school in Manhattan Beach. Another change in her testimony came when Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero read to the child sections of her own testimony before a grand jury and a preliminary hearing six years ago. The transcripts indicated the girl had used anatomically explicit dolls to show that she was raped and sodomized. She was then asked whether Buckey hurt her sexually. ``I don't recall but I remember it did happen,'' she said. Ms. Ferrero asked no further questions to clarify the answer. On cross-examination by Davis, the youngster said repeatedly she could not remember giving any of the earlier testimony nor whether any of the events she related happened. She also could not remember that she once described a female teacher as lying on top of her nude and women teachers playing ``naked games.'' ``I can't remember,'' she answered repeatedly. Charges against five female teachers, stemming in part from those allegations, were dismissed after the preliminary hearing for lack of evidence. The first Buckey trial, the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history, ended in January with Buckey acquitted of 40 counts of molestation at the family-owned preschool. His mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of 12 charges. But the jury deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey, and the district attorney decided to retry him on eight of those charges involving three children. The girl who testified Thursday did not appear at the first trial, and the jury deadlocked 11-1 for acquittal on the two charges which involved her. Ms. Ferrero acknowledged in court that the girl did not want to come to court at all Thursday, but her parents brought her anyway. Ms. Ferrero said the girl expressed the desire not to testify when she arrived but ``was trying to be cheerful'' and agreed to cooperate. She said it was difficult to remember events that occurred when she was 3 or 4 years old. She will be 12 in July.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Both Fall as Japanese Sell
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued its slide against the Japanese yen in European trading this morning, but gained ground from Thursday's lower levels against several European currencies. Spot gold prices were driven sharply lower under the pressure of Japanese selling. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 154.15 yen, down 2.60 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it was quoted at 153.99 yen. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: _1.6342 West German marks, down from 1.6368 _1.3995 Swiss francs, up from 1.3950 _5.5285 French francs, up from 5.5235 _1.8410 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8407 _1,206.00 Italian lire, up from 1,205.75 _$1.1770 Canadian, up from $1.1650 The British pound fell to $1.6728 from $1.6770 late Thursday. Some market players remained on the sidelines awaiting the U.S. government's release later today of the producer price index and retail sales figures. Concern that the U.S. economy is slowing also helped push the dollar lower, dealers said. Dealers said an overnight decline in the dollar's value against the Swiss franc and West German mark pushed it below a technical floor, resulting in widespread dollar selling. The franc has been rising because of high Swiss interest rates, strong Asian demand and the increasing tendency to view the franc as a ``safe haven'' currency, dealers said. Japan's major securities houses sold the dollar heavily in the morning. After lunch, they were joined by life insurers and other major market players, said John Radinoff, vice president of Goldman Sachs (Japan). ``The yen has been massively oversold, and people have been looking for excuses to sell dollars,'' Radinoff said. ``Over the next couple of days there will be some serious thinking going on over whether this is the start of a new trend or whether the dollar is just testing to find a new base,'' said Mahesh Trivedi, senior corporate dealer at Daiwa (Europe) Bank Ltd. ``We could be just near the beginning of a sharp rise in the yen,'' said Mark Austin, currency analyst at Hong Kong & Shanghai Banking Corp. in London. Spot gold prices in London dropped as low as $367.50 an ounce in London this morning, off from $371.35 an ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, gold opened at $367.60 an ounce, down from $371.25 bid late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $3.12 an ounce today, to close at $369.10. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $5.06 a troy ounce, down from $5.08 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Legislature Debates Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's legislature today debated proposals to allow direct presidential elections and create a second legislative chamber to meet year-round, according to sources in that country's capital, Ulan Bator. Both changes are supported by Mongolia's fledgling opposition parties, founded during the winter to press for democratic reforms like those being implemented in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. In a speech Thursday, however, President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat proposed that the legislature, known as the Great People's Hural, continue to elect the president. He supported the idea of creating a smaller body that would be made of up Great Hural members and would meet frequently, said the sources, who spoke by telephone from the Mongolian capital. The Great Hural, with 370 deputies, generally meets only once or twice a year. More than 93 percent of its deputies belong to the ruling Communist party, formally called the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party. The opposition says indirect presidential elections help perpetuate Communist control of the government. Also being debated today was a law that would legalize the new opposition parties and give them at least nominally equal status with the ruling party.

DOC.HEAD: Treaty Oak Prisoner Sentencd to 9 years in Jail
DOC.TEXT: A jury sentenced a former burglar to nine years in prison for poisoning the historic Treaty Oak tree in what authorities said was an occult ritual to purge his feelings for a woman. The attorney for Paul Stedman Cullen, 46, who faced a possible life sentence, had pleaded with the jury that less than 10 years would be a fair sentence. ``You have to decide how much a tree is worth,'' said attorney Terry Kirk, who recalled playing as a child under the branches of the centuries-old tree. Cullen had faced the harsh sentence for the criminal mischief conviction because of his previous felony burglary conviction. Cullen had no comment as he was led from the courtroom. The tree, estimated to be as much as 500 years old, was poisoned with the powerful liquid herbicide Velpar in early 1989. About two-thirds of the tree is now dead, foresters said, but the remaining third is still producing leaves. According to legend, the tree was the site of a treaty signing between Stephen F. Austin and Indians. Prosecutors said Cullen poisoned the tree to protect a woman whom he liked and to ``kill'' his love for her. Kirk said the jury withstood extreme community pressure not to severely punish Cullen. ``I honestly do believe ... that there are people out there (who would) make him drink Velpar, hang him,'' Kirk said. State District Judge Bob Perkins, who presided over the trial, said people still find ``this crime unfathomable in terms of rationale _ nobody can figure it out. It makes it that much more of a crime.'' Perkins said he would take off about a year from the sentence because of time Cullen has spent in jail. He has been jailed in lieu of $20,000 bond since his arrest in June 1989. Since the poisoning was discovered, more than $100,000 has been donated to save the tree. Velpar-contaminated dirt was removed from around its roots, the tree has been doused with spring water and elaborate sun screens were built to shade it.

DOC.HEAD: Foster Parents Say `Perfect Baby' Shouldn't Have Died
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old child allegedly beaten to death eight weeks after his adoption should never have been taken from the home where people loved him, his former foster parents said. Dale and Jan May had cared for Maurice West in their Cincinnati home since he was 2 months old. They wanted to adopt Maurice, whom they called ``Reecie,'' but were turned down because he was black and they were white. This week, the Mays came to Rochester to attend the trial of the couple who adopted Maurice, and to hear testimony about the battered child who died just two months after he left their home. Maurice's adoptive parents, Bernice and Gerald Kittelberger, are charged with second-degree manslaughter and assault for Maurice's Aug. 26, 1989, death. Closing arguments in the case are scheduled for Monday. Maurice was ``a beautiful baby,'' Dale May said Thursday outside a Monroe County courtroom while leafing through photographs of a smiling, laughing little boy. Another set of photographs, those introduced as evidence in the Kittelbergers' trial, show a child covered with bruises, burns and scars. Medical experts testified that Maurice had been beaten repeatedly and severely with a blunt object. A doctor who examined Maurice's body in the emergency room of St. Mary's Hospital said the child's limbs were so swollen that he could not find a vein to inject intravenous medicine. Mrs. Kittelberger said the child had choked on oatmeal. Monroe County Medical Examiner Nicholas T. Forbes said the death was a direct result of the beatings. In statements to police, the Kittelbergers _ who are black _ said they had hit the child with a belt, a paddle and a stick wrapped in tape because he had resisted toilet training. They attributed other injuries _ an open gash on his forehead, a tear near his buttocks, burn marks on his hands _ to the child tripping and falling, or accidentally grabbing Mrs. Kittelberger's hot curling iron. But the Mays said Maurice was not that kind of child. ``While Reecie was at our house, he was allowed to go anywhere,'' May said. ``In two years, there were no accidents. No tripping, no falls, no anything.'' By age 2, Maurice was coordinated enough to play computer games and an electronic keyboard and knew how to run their videocassette recorder, Mrs. May said. ``He was smart enough and careful enough that he could turn it on,'' she said. ``You never had to worry about Reecie touching anything, getting into anything or bothering anything.'' Maurice never needed to be scolded or punished, the Mays said. ``An explanation to that child was enough,'' May said. ``A `no, that will hurt you,' was enough.'' The Mays, who have cared for 20 black and biracial foster children over the last three years, applied to Hamilton County, Ohio, officials to adopt Maurice. They told adoption officials that they would enroll Maurice in an integrated school district, and that they would take African culture classes so he would not lose his heritage. They said they would adopt another black child, so that Maurice would not feel isolated when he grew older. ``We did every single possible thing to make what we thought was a good environment for Reecie,'' Mrs. May said. ``And when they said we couldn't have him, we did everything we could to make his adoption as easy as possible.'' The Mays said they hope Kittelbergers are convicted and sentenced to maximum prison terms for destroying Maurice's life. The Kittelbergers face a maximum of 15 years in prison if convicted of the second-degree manslaughter and assault charges. Moreover, the Mays are angry with the system that took Maurice from them and brought him to Rochester. They want to see better investigations of adoptive parents and better monitoring to prevent child abuse. And they want to see arbitrary policies against cross-racial adoptions abolished. ``Love and a wholesome, happy environment is important, not just black and white,'' Mrs. May said.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Resumes Flowing Down Volcano
DOC.TEXT: Lava again started pouring from Kilauea Volcano, but it's too early to tell it posed another threat to this coastal community that has been devastated by molten rock, authorities said. After a three-day respite, lava resumed flowing Thursday from a vent along the volcano's east rift zone, said Hawaii County civil defense spokesman Bruce Butts. Surface activity was spotted at the 1,800-foot level during a overflight by scientists from the U.S. Geological Survey's Hawaiian Volcano Observatory, Butts said. The activity was about five miles away from Kalapana, which has lost more than 60 houses to lava during the past six weeks, he said. Although the outpouring of lava stopped earlier this week, molten rock had continued to flow down the volcano, through Kalapana and into the ocean. However, no lava movement was seen in Kalapana on Thursday, Butts said. Kilauea's latest eruption began Jane. 3, 1983, and since then, lava flows have destroyed 139 houses, causing an estimated $61 million damage to private and public property.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer-Stricken Sammy Davis Jr.'s Health Deteriorating
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr.'s health has deteriorated steadily since the cancer-stricken entertainer left a hospital eight weeks ago to recuperate at home, according to his friends. Publicist Susan Reynolds would only say Davis was ``resting'' and ``there has been no change.'' But friends said the song-and-dance man was emaciated and obviously losing his battle with throat cancer. Davis' weight has dropped to about 60 pounds and he was in a fetal position, a source close to the entertainer told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. The source said he'd be surprised if the entertainer lived another week. Reynolds would not comment on the report. Another source close to the family, who also requested anonymity, said Davis could hardly utter a word because of a tracheotomy performed in connection with his throat cancer, which was diagnosed in September. The source told the AP that stars visiting Davis come away ``heartsick,'' some in tears. Davis, 64, was released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on March 13 to recuperate at home. He was admitted mid-January for treatment of a gum infection and doctors later found that he had a recurrence of throat cancer. No further chemotherapy was planned. Davis was honored Sunday at a testimonial dinner by the Friends of the Israel Defense Forces. In her brief acceptance, Davis' wife, Altovise, said: ``To try and say thank you is almost impossible. We are so grateful. This is quite an honor.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Asks France to Curtail Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 6th, `Mitterrand urged...' and subs 1 graf for 14th, `De Klerk...' to UPDATE with De Klerk in Greece. Pickup 15th, `The last...'
DOC.TEXT: South African President F.W. de Klerk promised reforms and pressed for an end to sanctions against his country during the first visit to the French presidential palace by any South African leader since 1947. ``The mere fact that I met with (French officials) was a recognition of the totally changed situation in South Africa,'' he declared after an hourlong meeting Thursday with President Francois Mitterrand. De Klerk said that because of those political changes, France was prepared to discuss easing sanctions against South Africa with its European partners. ``Sanctions are crumbling,'' de Klerk told a news conference on the first full day of a nine-nation, 18-day trip to Western Europe. Mitterrand's spokesman, Hubert Vedrine, said de Klerk told Mitterrand that sanctions were no longer justified. Vedrine also announced that Mitterrand would meet with Nelson Mandela on June 7 when the African National Congress leader visits Paris. Mandela opposes lifting sanctions. Mitterrand urged de Klerk to push for reform ``as rapidly as possible,'' the spokesman said. De Klerk later traveled to Greece, where he was met at Athens airport by Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras. De Klerk was to meet with government officials today, rest over the weekend, and fly to Portugal on Monday. French officials have depicted themselves as in the middle regarding sanctions against South Africa, with Britain on one side favoring the rapid lifting of sanctions while Denmark and the Netherlands oppose any easing of restrictions now. Mitterrand and other Western leaders agreed to begin easing South Africa's isolation after de Klerk in February ordered Mandela's release from prison after 27 years and lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC. Mandela and de Klerk agreed during talks last week to work together to end political violence and clear the way for formal negotiations on a new constitution that would extend voting rights to South Africa's black majority. De Klerk said he told Mitterrand and Premier Michel Rocard the changes in South Africa were irreversible. He said remaining discriminatory laws were due for repeal or modification by the next session of Parliament. ``There is no turning back,'' he said. ``South Africa will get a new constitution that will be fair to all South Africa... it will recognize the concept of full citizenship for all.'' He described his talks with the French leaders as warm and positive. He also said he discussed with Mitterrand the possibility of cooperation in promoting economic development in Africa. De Klerk also plans stops in Belgium, Britain, West Germany, Switzerland, Spain and Italy. It is the most extensive foreign mission by a South African head of state since the National Party took power in 1948. The last South African head of state to visit the Elysee Palace was Jan Smuts in 1947. The highest-level official meeting since then was in 1970, between prime ministers John Vorster of South Africa and Jacques Chaban-Delmas of France.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Colonel Slain After Acquittal in Rights Abuse Cases
DOC.TEXT: Two attackers shot and killed a retired officer acquitted in two human rights cases, riddling him with automatic gunfire as he sat in a taxi in downtown Santiago, police said. The assassins, young men in high-school uniforms, shot National Police Col. Luis Fontaine Manriquez, 56, at point-blank range Thursday as he sat in the back seat of the taxi at an intersection, police said. Fontaine was hit 18 times, acting Interior Minister Belisario Velasco told a news conference. A woman aide riding with Fontaine, Margarita Moreno, was wounded but was expected to recover, said Gen. Oscar Tapia, National Police commander for Santiago. The cabbie took Fontaine to the National Police Hospital, where the colonel was pronounced dead on arrival. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack. On March 21, two gunmen severely wounded a former air force commander and military junta member, Gen. Gustavo Leigh, along with a business partner, former air force Gen. Enrique Ruiz. A faction of the pro-Communist Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, Chile's main leftist guerrilla group, claimed responsibility for that attempt. In a communique mailed to news media, which arrived Thursday, the Manuel Rodriguez Front said ``popular justice'' was justified because military officers suspected of rights abuse still enjoyed impunity. It named some leading army and navy officials but did not mention Fontaine. In a written statement Thursday evening, the government of President Patricio Aylwin called the latest attack ``an act of extreme cruelty'' and said the killers ``are people stubbornly seeking to alter the process of democratic reconstruction in the country.'' At government request, the Santiago Court of Appeal appointed a special judge to investigate. Fontaine was deputy commander of DICOMCAR, a secretive branch of the National Police involved in rooting out dissidents under the military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, which ended two months ago. Fontaine was tried and acquitted in the 1985 assassination of three members of the then-outlawed Communist Party, whose bodies were found with their throats slit. He also was tried and acquitted in the 1986 torture-killing of a student allegedly involved in a leftist guerrilla group. Last week, he called a news conference and denied involvement in atrocities.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Predicts 50-50 Chance of Eruption in 30 years
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after its massive eruption, there is a 50-50 chance Mount St. Helens will explode its dome again within three decades, a University of Washington seismologist says. Steve Malone, a geophysics professor on a team monitoring the Pacific Northwest, said Thursday that Mount St. Helens is the most likely volcano in the Cascade Mountains to erupt in the next 20 to 30 years. ``Our capabilities for monitoring volcanoes have improved since Mount St. Helens erupted,'' he said. Malone said seismic activity, which the predication is largely based on, is a good barometer of eruptive potential because it indicates the breaking of rock below the earth's surface as molten material rises underneath the volcano. The May 18, 1980, eruption of Mount St. Helens killed 57 people, devastated a vast area and lofted a huge ash cloud that circled the globe.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Slumped 0.6 Percent in April
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales slumped 0.6 percent in April, posting the second consecutive monthly decline and the biggest setback in six months, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said sales fell by $907 million last month to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion. The April decrease was a disappointment to economists, who had been looking for a small rebound following a 0.2 percent decline in March and no change in February. Since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, continued weakness in the area of retail sales was likely to intensify concerns about the country's future economic prospects, especially in light of last week's report that unemployment climbed in April to 5.4 percent. Growing joblessness could promote worries among consumers about the future, causing them to shut off spending, especially for big-ticket items such as autos. The 0.6 percent April decline was the largest since a 1.4 percent plunge last October. The back-to-back declines in March and April marked the first time that has occurred in moe than three years. Originally, the government reported February posted a sales decline as well but sales activity during that month was revised upward in the current report to show no change. For April, the biggest drag on activity came from auto sales, which dropped 2.7 percent. It marked the sixth time in the last seven months that car sales have fallen. Without the big drop in auto sales, total retail sales would have been unchanged last month. Sales at general department stores were off 0.7 percent in April following an even bigger 1.2 percent drop in March. A survey focusing only on the country's largest chain department stores showed sales had generally rebounded in April, when compared to a year ago, boosted by late Easter shopping. Sales at hardware and building supply stores dropped 2.6 percent in April following an 0.8 percent decrease the previous month. There was basic weakness across the board. Sales at gasoline stations fell by 1 percent, restaurant sales were off by 0.2 percent while sales at speciality clothing stores were down 1.9 percent. Drug stores were the only retail establishments showing an increase, a gain of 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Broadcast Reporter Pauline Frederick Dies
DOC.TEXT: Pauline Frederick, an award-winning broadcast reporter who helped pave the way for women in journalism, has died at the age of 84. Frederick, whose married name was Pauline Frederick Robbins, died Wednesday after suffering a heart attack in suburban Lake Forest, where she was visiting relatives. ``She was the first full-fledged woman correspondent and opened doors for women's acceptance in television and radio journalism,'' said Beryl Pfizer, a news producer at NBC who worked with Frederick. ``And beside that, she was a heckuva person.'' Frederick, born in Gallitzin, Pa., worked for five years as an ABC correspondent before moving in 1953 to NBC, where she served as United Nations correspondent for 21 years. At the UN, she covered events including the Cuban missile crisis and China's entrance into the United Nations. Frederick once came to the office from a diplomatic dinner, dressed in a black evening dress, to update reports on a situation in a foreign country with information she gathered at the dinner, Pfizer recalled Thursday. In 1976 she moderated the second presidential debate between Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, the first woman journalist to moderate a presidential debate. She was the first woman to be elected president of the United Nations Correspondents Association and was also the first of her sex to receive a George Foster Peabody Award for achievements in broadcasting. In 1980, Frederick became the first woman to receive the highest award of the Radio-Television News Directors Association. Later in her career, she worked as an international affairs analyst for National Public Radio. Frederick received a bachelor's degree and a master's degree in international law from American University in Washington, D.C. She was married to the late Charles Robbins, former reporter and managing editor of The Wall Street Journal. She has no immediate survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communists Blamed For Unification Fears in East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with West German spokesman blaming Communists for labor unrest. Pickup 6th pvs, ``The Germanys...''
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's former Communists are inciting unrest among workers who fear they will lose their jobs as the nation unites with West Germany, a West German official charged today. Tens of thousands of teachers, textile workers and farmers staged brief protests and strikes on Thursday to demand protection from the widespread unemployment expected as East Germany moves to a free market. Hans Klein, spokesman for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said the organizers of the strikes ``are to some extent exactly the forces who caused'' East Germany's dire economic problems. Klein told a news conference in the West German capital, Bonn, that there was legitimate ``uncertainty and fear'' over the talks between the Germanys on the merger of their economies and social institutions. Guenther Krause, who leads the East German delegation in economic talks with West Germany, also criticized what he called a ``fear campaign by the left'' to trigger mass anxiety over the loss of huge subsidies under the former socialist system. Krause made his comments to the East German Parliament on Thursday while briefing lawmakers on the status of the unification talks. Lawmaker Gregor Gysi, head of the reformed Communist Party, blamed the East German government for the uncertainty among East Germans. He said East Germans were being kept too much in the dark about what was being negotiated and needed to plan for economic changes. He told lawmakers on Thursday that the East German negotiating team has gone into talks in a ``stooped posture'' to the West German delegation, which wants to remove all the vestiges of the former socialist system. The Germanys are to merge their economies and social institutions on July 2, when the West German mark is to become the currency of East Germany. Full unification is expected next year, after the superpowers find a way to agree on the strategic role of a united Germany. Krause said work on the final economic and social agreement between the Germanys should be completed by Sunday. The parliaments of both nations then would consider the treaty. In Bonn, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Thursday that East Germany must restructure its beleaguered economy before the two nations share the West German currency. Kohl also renewed his demand that East Germany be prepared to start dismantling its 41-year-old system of state ownership if economic union with West Germany is going to be a success. Economists predict that many inefficient East German factories will close in the next year because they will not be able to compete in the free market, and that between 500,000 and 2 million East German workers will lose their jobs. Kohl and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere say a quick influx of Western investment will create new jobs and raise East German living standards. The two governments still have differences over the level of job and price guarantees to give East Germans. The talks are being held behind closed doors, and many questions remain unanswered about how West Germany would absorb and dismantle East Germany's vast public sector and social welfare system. The left-leaning Social Democrats, the junior partner in de Maiziere's governing coalition, are pressing the conservative de Maiziere to push for more social guarantees for East Germans used to cheap housing, subsidized food and guaranteed jobs. Krause gave the 400-member Parliament an update on the status of talks between the countries and a grim economic picture of the East German economy. He said East Germany faces a year-end deficit of 120 billion East German marks ($36.6 billion), inflation has risen rapidly in recent months and only 32 percent of the nation's industries are profitable.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Ministry Denies Rumors That Deng Ill, Dead
DOC.TEXT: Rumors that China's senior leader Deng Xiaoping was seriously ill or dead rippled through Asian financial markets today, but the Foreign Ministry denied them. ``The so-called report is a sheer fabrication with ulterior motives,'' the ministry said in a one-sentence statement. Officials traveling with visiting Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said the president was scheduled to meet with Deng on Sunday morning, lending support to the Chinese denial. Tokyo markets did not react to the rumors perceptibly, but brokers in Hong Kong blamed the rumors for a 24.96 point drop in the Hang Seng Index, the stock market's key indicator of blue chips. Deng, 85, has not been seen in public since February, when he met with a delegation from Hong Kong. He stepped down in March from his last official post, as chairman of the government military commission, and even before then had stopped routinely seeing visitors. Chinese sources say Deng, a chain smoker, suffers from cancer. He speaks with some difficulty and walks shakily. The government has refused to give details of his health.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopters Retrieve Japanese Balloonists From Tibet
DOC.TEXT: Three Japanese adventurers whose balloon crashed and burned when they tried to float over Mount Everest returned to Katmandu today in a safer manner _ aboard helicopters. Also today, an American ski instructor, an Australian and a Swede climbed to the top of the world's highest mountain, bringing to 21 the number of people who have scaled the peak in the last two days. Co-pilot Saburo Ichiyoshi, 41, and cameramen Atsushi Saito, 27, spent two nights at the accident site after the balloon crashed and burned Wednesday in the Himalayas. The third balloonist, Michio Kanda, 41, went in search of help. Ichiyoshi, who reportedly broke his leg in at least two places, was brought to Katmandu from Tibet by Nepalese army helicopter and rushed to a hospital. Saito and Kanda, who apparently were not injured, arrived aboard a second helicopter. Colonel B.R. Pun, who piloted one of the rescue helicopters, said the site was so high it was difficult to fly in. The altitude was estimated at 16,400 feet above sea level. The expedition, the first to attempt a balloon flight over Everest, set off from Nyalam, on the edge of the Tibetan Plateau, and the balloon reached an altitude of about 32,000 feet one hour into the flight, Kanda said. But the winds seemed unfavorable for crossing the 29,028 foot-high Mount Everest, he said. They began descending for an emergency landing, looking for points where the expedition's rescue teams would be, but the balloon suddenly hit a rock and caught fire. ``After hitting it, the balloon rolled down two, three, and several times ... I did not know how many times. ... But it rolled down until it reached in a valley,'' Kanda said. Meanwhile, Andre Lapkass, 31, a ski instructor from Estes Park, Colo., reached the summit of Mount Everest today along with a Swedish member of a New Zealand expedition, Michael Reutersward, 25, of Stockholm. They followed the route taken by five Americans and two Nepalese sherpa guides who on Thursday scaled Everest's heights. Minutes after the American and Swede reached Everest's summit, an Australian climber, Tim MacArtney Snape, 34, of Sydney, accomplished the feat. On Thursday, three members of the New Zealand team including the son of Everest's first conquerer, Sir Edmund Hillary, climbed the mountain. The senior Hillary climbed Everest in 1953 with his Nepalese guide Tenzing Norgay. In all, 18 men reached Everest's peak on Thursday alone. The traffic on Everest has raised questions about the effect mountain climbing has on the fragile ecology of the pristine Himalayan Range. An estimated two tons of garbage _ left by climbers _ litter the mountain.

DOC.HEAD: New Haven Mayor's Brother Pleads Guilty to Selling Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT date of plea to Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor John Daniels' younger brother has pleaded guilty to selling cocaine and faces a likely five-year prison term. Robert Daniels, 48, pleaded guilty Tuesday to sale of cocaine and conspiracy to sell cocaine. As part of a plea agreement, New Haven Superior Court Judge Richard A. Damiani said he probably would sentence Daniels to 10 years in prison, suspended after five, and probation for three years. Carol Smith, a spokeswoman for the mayor, said this morning that he would not have any comment. At the time of his brother's arrest, the mayor said he would not request leniency. Daniels is free on $25,000 bond and is seeking treatment in Stamford for drug addiction. In February, just a little more than a month after the mayor took office, his brother surrendered to a third brother, Melvin, a New Haven police detective.

DOC.HEAD: Drowning Of 10-Year-Old Ruled A Homicide
DOC.TEXT: A medical examiner's office has ruled that the death of a 10-year-old girl who drowned while fishing with her father and a younger sister was a homicide. Jeanette Lindsey died Feb. 27 at Lake Worth. Less than two weeks earlier, her father, Wendell Lindsey, had bought life insurance policies on her and her 9-year-old sister, Darlene, authorities said. Deputy Medical Examiner Dr. Marc Krouse said that the case will be presented to a Tarrant County grand jury but declined to comment further. The examiner's office finding of homicide was made Wednesday. ``We have been suspicious since right after it happened,'' said police Sgt. Paul Kratz. He said the investigation was continuing. Lindsey told police he had sent Darlene to the car to get some paper towels when Jeanette fell off a log and landed in the water. He said she was underwater four to five minutes before he could pull her to shore. Darlene said she heard a scream and ran back to the road and flagged down a passing car. When police arrived, they found a crying Lindsey holding Jeanette and saying, ``I've lost my baby.'' Authorities said the water at the site was only about knee deep. Fort Worth police confirmed that Lindsey had purchased $50,000 life insurance policies on each of his daughters less than two weeks before Jeanette's death. Police said the policies carried double indemnity clauses in the event of accidental death, meaning that he would have collected $100,000 if either of the girls died in an accident. Asked for comment on the medical examiner's finding, Lindsey, 33, told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram, ``I'd really rather not go into it.'' Lindsey has filed a $100,000 claim against the city, alleging that the city was negligent because city personnel did not properly attempt to resuscitate the girl and that certain unspecified equipment was not kept in good repair.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Spy Unit Operated Throughout Africa, Mounting Sabotage Campaigns
DOC.TEXT: A South African spy organization put cholera germs in drinking water to disrupt elections in Namibia as part of sabotage operations in Africa and Europe, a newspaper reported today. Vrye Weekblad, a weekly Afrikaans language newspaper, said a former official of the Civilian Cooperation Bureau said in an interview the unit had cells in black African nations and Europe and planned killings of anti-apartheid activists. The South African government is conducting an investigation into the Civilian Cooperation Bureau and allegations that police and military operatives killed anti-apartheid activists. Several former police officers have claimed they were involved in killing activists. Vrye Weekblad, which helped uncover the first public details about the bureau, said it obtained further information in an interview with former bureau official Petrus Jacobus Botes, who said he headed the unit's activities in Mozambique and Swaziland. Botes said Civilian Cooperation Bureau activities ranged from murder and sabotage to bombings, bribery and blackmail, the newspaper reported. Botes claimed his unit was instructed to killed South African Communist Party chief Joe Slovo, then in exile in Zambia, the article said. It did not say if any attempt was made on Slovo's life. The newspaper said Botes claimed that bureau operatives put cholera germs in drinking water at the Dobra refugee camp in Namibia in 1989 as part of efforts to disrupt the South West African Peoples' Organization's election campaign. The story did not say how this was intended to disrupt the election. The organization, known as SWAPO, waged a guerrilla campaign against South African rule of the territory before winning the elections. Namibia became independent in March. Botes, according to the newspaper, also claimed the Civilian Cooperation Bureau planned to kill SWAPO activist Hidipo Hamutenya, who is now minister of information in the Namibian government. It did not say if any attempt was made. The article says the bureau ran destabilization operations in black African nations, with units or cells based in Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zaire and other nations. It said the unit attempted to influence recent elections in Zimbabwe. The article also says that Botes informed Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok in August, 1989 about bureau activities after he was involved in a dispute with the group's leaders about expenses. He also said there was a bomb attempt against him. A police spokesman in Pretoria had no immediate response today to the report. Top government officials have denied any knowledge about the Civilian Cooperation Bureau. The group allegedly used civilians or police officers to kill government opponents and disrupt anti-government activities. Bureau activities, according to testimony given to the government inquiry, ranged from killing activists to using a baboon's fetus to put a magic spell on Archbishop Desmond Tutu.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Waldheim Apologizes For Misleading Israel on Nazi Army Service
DOC.TEXT: Austrian President Kurt Waldheim apologized to Israel in an interview published today for misleading statements about his German army service in World War II, but again denied that he committed war crimes. Waldheim also was quoted as urging Israel to upgrade its diplomatic representation in Vienna and to return the ambassador it withdrew in protest after Waldheim's election in 1986. ``In the past years my hand has been extended, and it has always remained hanging in the air,'' Waldheim said in an appeal to the Jewish state. His interview, conducted Monday in Vienna, was published today in the liberal Haaretz newspaper. A spokesman for Israel's Foreign Ministry said no official message of this kind has reached Jerusalem, but it was unlikely that Israel would return its ambassador to Vienna. Waldheim reiterated that he has not been involved in war crimes. ``The accusations against me are completely baseless,'' he told the newspaper. Waldheim was referring to allegations that he was involved in the massacre of Yugoslavian partisans and the deportation of Greek Jews to Nazi death camps. About 45,000 Greek Jews were sent to Nazi death camps while Waldheim was stationed in the Balkans. A 1988 investigation by six historians said there was no evidence Waldheim had directly taken part in Nazi war crimes, but said his assertions that he did not know about the fate of Jews deported from Greece were ``not believable.'' In his official biography, Waldheim claimed he left the German army after being wounded on the Russian front in 1941. He later admitted he had omitted from the biography being reassigned to the Balkans where he served as an intelligence officer until the end of the war. ``I apologize that I did not bring up the Balkan matter. I confess that there was a mistake here,'' Waldheim said. ``I did not forsee that the issue would open in such a tragic direction.'' ``I certainly express my regret before them on the ommissions,'' he said in an appeal to the Jewish state. Waldheim also dismissed recent reports that he had once declared himself to be a ``loyal Nazi.'' ``To say I was a member of the Nazi Party is not correct. Despite what was claimed, I never admitted this,'' he said. Waldheim said he wanted to improve his relationship with Jews and Jewish organizations around the world which have been at the forefront of investigations into his past. Waldheim suggested that the investigations were caused by Jewish anger over decisions taken by the United Nations while he served as U.N. secretary general from 1972 to 1982. He cited as an example the 1975 resolution equating Zionism with racism. ``The Jewish community accused me of supporting the resolution. That simply was not correct,'' he said. ``The decision was regretful, unjust and damaging, at least to the United Nations.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to remove period from slugline.
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after its massive eruption, there is a 50-50 chance Mount St. Helens will explode its dome again within three decades, a University of Washington seismologist says. DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Anti-Base Rallies; Arrest in Slaying of Americans
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 30 people today during rallies by Filipinos who want the government to refuse to extend the leases on six U.S. military bases when they expire next year. Meanwhile, a police official announced the arrest of a Communist rebel leader accused in the slayings of three Americans and a Filipino of American descent outside the U.S.-run Clark Air Base in 1987. In Manila, Brig. Gen. Marino Filart said a special 500-man security force will guard U.S. and Filipino officials who begin talks Monday on the future of the six U.S. bases, whose lease expires in September 1991. Rafael Alunan, spokesman for the Filipino delegation, told reporters the exploratory phase of the talks could be concluded within a week, and the two sides would then decide whether to begin formal negotiations. The United States maintains about 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at the six bases, which U.S. officials say are crucial to stability in the Far East. President Corazon Aquino has not yet indicated whether she supports extending the lease. Most surveys show that bases supporters outnumber opponents but that a growing number of Filipinos believe the American facilities infringe on national sovereignty. In Manila, police said two people were arrested today when club-wielding police broke up an anti-base rally by about 150 University of the Philippines students in front of the U.S. Embassy. Later, 200 leftist students burned tires and set off firecrackers along a main Manila street to demand the closure of the U.S. bases. In Davao, 600 miles south of Manila, witnesses said 28 people were arrested after protesters splashed red paint on a U.S. Information Service office. Meanwhile, about 3,000 residents of Olongapo, site of the U.S. Subic Bay Naval Base, 50 miles west of Manila, held a rally supporting the U.S. bases and protesting last week's killing of a U.S. Marine sergeant. Several American servicemen in bars and clubs cheered the pro-base demonstrators, who included bar girls and merchants who closed their shops to join the rally organized by city officials. The killing of Marine Sgt. John Fredette, of Buena Park, Calif., caused a slump in the city's economy after U.S. military authorities restricted personnel to the Subic base for several days due to security concerns. Police say Fredette's slaying was non-political and might have resulted from a robbery attempt. Police are holding three suspects on charges of murder and illegal gun possession. A police official ruled out any link between Fredette's slaying and the arrest of a Communist rebel leader who is accused of being involved in a coordinated series of attacks against Americans in the city of Angeles outside the U.S.-run Clark Air Base in October 1987. Provincial rebel chief Alex Capitulo, 33, was arrested Tuesday at a restaurant in the town of Guagua, 35 miles north of Manila, the military said. Capitulo is suspected of involvement in the killings of U.S. Air Force Sgt. Randy Davis, of Portland, Ore., Airman 1st Class Steven Faust, of Pasadena, Texas, Herculano Mangante, a retired Air Force sergeant living near the base, and Joseph Porter, a Filipino businessman of American descent. U.S. intelligence sources say they were apparently killed in reprisal for American troops taking Filipino soldiers wounded in a battle with Communist rebels to the base hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Millions More In HUD Losses Reported; Favoritism Alleged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top three grafs new to say losses probably higher than $177 million; pickup graf 3 pvs, The investigation.
DOC.TEXT: The government probably will lose more than $177 million on a housing program used for developments alongside golf courses and marinas, say internal reports blaming the risky loans on mismanagement and political favoritism. The government already has lost $55 million on sales of foreclosed properties from the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Title X land development program, agency auditors said.
