They said it will cost an additional $122 million if failures and foreclosure sales continue at current rates. Declining values of some of the properties and delays in foreclosing and selling the troubled projects ``may further add to HUD's losses,'' the auditors said. So far, HUD has had to pay claims on 32 of the 65 loans made through the program. Seventeen of the projects are still in the formative stages, ``thus the final claim rate ... likely will be higher.'' The investigation, detailed in two reports completed last week, found several examples of projects being approved despite overwhelming evidence they did not meet requirements or were too risky. Also detailed were several previously undisclosed cases in which former HUD officials or Republican consultants successfully lobbied senior department managers to reverse lower-level rejections of questionable projects. Some of the projects have failed and others are troubled, the reports said. The reports, obtained through the Freedom of Information Act, blamed the problems on Reagan-era abuses but said the losses continued to mount last year because HUD Secretary Jack Kemp, who took office with the Bush administration, had not allocated enough staff to the program. After prodding by HUD's inspector general, or internal watchdog, Kemp last week created a new unit to handle the program. Kemp killed Title X last year but the existing projects still must be monitored. Several Title X projects were built alongside golf courses and include other resort-like amenities. Few catered to low- and moderate-income families. One development reviewed, Bluewater Bay in Niceville, Fla., received $15.4 million in HUD-backed financing. The complex, which had additional private financing, includes tennis courts, bike and hiking trails, a swimming pool, restaurants, a shopping center, 27 holes of golf, a beach and a 120-slip marina. Bluewater Bay was approved in April 1989, two months after Kemp took office, despite regulations that say: ``Land development proposals oriented to recreation-resort housing markets are not eligible.'' HUD General Counsel Francis Keating said Bluewater Bay was funded because HUD had entered into a binding contract in February 1989, just weeks after Kemp took office and before he named most of his top aides. ``These kind of proposals could not and would not be approved on Jack Kemp's watch,'' Keating said. Among former HUD officials successful in lobbying was Shirley McVay Wiseman, who in congressional testimony last summer criticized the role of politics during her tenure at the agency. It was Wiseman who first cast doubt on assertions by former HUD Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. that he played no direct role in funding decisions. Since then, others have testified that Pierce was involved. He and several former top aides are being investigated by a court-appointed special prosecutor. The new audit reports said Wiseman was paid $182,600 to serve as a consultant for two Texas developments. They said another former HUD official, Maurice Barksdale, earned nearly $170,000 for lobbying on Title X projects and also lobbied for developments in other HUD programs. The two Texas developments, Southcreek in Dallas and Steed's Crossing in Austin, were approved by HUD headquarters after being rejected by regional offices. They received more than $20 million in HUD-insured financing. Both owners have kept up loan payments but the audit reports questioned the long-term viability of the developments. The two were cited in a list of 10 projects that auditors said should not have been approved. In six of the 10, ``there were indications of consultant influence with HUD's program decisions,'' one report said. Telephone calls seeking comment from Wiseman were not immediately returned. Virtually all of the questioned decisions were made by James Nistler, HUD's former deputy assistant secretary for single-family housing, according to the reports. He left the agency shortly after Kemp took over, and efforts to locate him for comment Thursday were not successful. Favoritism also played a role in the approval of a Houston development whose owners defaulted on a $25.6 million mortgage, forcing HUD to pay a $23 million insurance claim, auditors said. In that case, Nistler in 1986 allowed developers to refinance the troubled Cumberland development, first backed by a $13.2 million HUD loan in 1982. Nistler approved the loan despite evidence of myriad problems and explicit regulations against using Title X loans for refinancing, auditors said. They said the father of the principal developer, Marc D. Kovens of Florida, ``was a good friend'' of Nistler's. ``It appeared HUD approved the project because of an intent to favor the owner's interest over those of HUD,'' the auditors said. The refinancing allowed Kovens to pay off a $2.7 million debt, they said. Other consultants who lobbied to win approval of Title X projects were Lou Kitchin, an adviser to the Reagan and Bush presidential campaigns, and Milton Masson, who served as western regional director of the 1984 Reagan-Bush campaign. Kitchin, who has acknowledged lobbying HUD, was hired by several Title X developers, including a North Carolina investors group involving former Republican Gov. James E. Holshouser Jr. Holshouser and his partners, with Kitchin's help, received a waiver to secure a $1.7 million loan for a Wilmington development without posting collateral. The owners defaulted last December. Two of Holshouser's partners in that deal were among the developers of another North Carolina project, Northwoods in Cary, whose 1988 default cost HUD more than $2.6 million. Masson's firm received $285,000 to lobby for approval of a $10 million Tennessee project, the reports said. The auditors said the mortgage was bloated by $1.2 million because HUD's Nashville office approved excessive land appraisal and development costs. The auditors said HUD employees approved those rates because of pressure from supervisors. ``They were constantly aware of the consultant's influence and felt extraordinary pressure,'' one report said of the staff.

DOC.HEAD: Mills Board to Reconsider Vote Admitting Men Undergraduates
DOC.TEXT: The trustees of Mills College will meet next week to reconsider their decision to admit male undergraduates but will reverse the vote only if another way to preserve the school's finances can be devised, the school's president said. The incoming student body president, Melissa Stevenson-Dile, said she was ``very pleased'' by Thursday's action but added that students will stand by their pledge to shut down the institution until they have official proof that men will be kept out of undergraduate classes. Males have been admitted to graduate programs since the 1930s. Mills President Mary Metz said the board's 12-member executive committee voted unanimously to reopen the issue on the basis of a plan from the alumnae association to start an intensive fund-raising drive and increase the $72 million endowment by $10 million. She said that before the board takes another vote, the faculty, administration, staff and students must present plans that ``show promise of the college achieving financial stability.'' The students have been blockading the administration building and boycotting classes since the board of trustees voted May 3 to admit male undergraduates, citing decline enrollment and revenues. Mills has about 775 undergraduates, and trustees have said it needs 1,000 to survive. The student protesters say they enrolled at the 138-year-old school because they believed that not having to compete with or be distracted by men improved their chances for a good education. They cite studies showing that graduates of women's colleges are more successful. The 35-member board is expected to reconsider its decision at meetings May 17 and 18.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Police Stage Drug Raid On Indian Reservation
DOC.TEXT: Gambling opponents on this besieged Mohawk reservation welcomed a drug raid by Canadian police but said they feared the arrests would touch off renewed violence by casino supporters. The raid Thursday by three Canadian police agencies at the St. Regis Indian Reservation netted about 4 pounds of cocaine and a half-pound of marijuana, worth about $800,000 in U.S. currency, said Ontario Provincial Police spokesman Peter West. Police also seized about $32,000 in U.S. currency and 12 guns, including three automatic rifles, West said. Police arrested 21 people on drug and weapons charges at Cornwall Island on the reservation and in nearby Cornwall, Ontario, West said. Sixteen suspects were still at large this morning, said Sgt. Al Crocker. The reservation straddles the U.S.-Canadian border. Both New York and Canadian police said all was quiet today on their respective sides. Chief Mike Mitchell, head of the tribal council that governs the Canadian side of the reservation, said he saw the raid as ``reaffirming the struggle of the people to rid themselves of the criminal element in our society.'' Mitchell and other gambling opponents blame casinos on the U.S. side for drug trafficking, weapons smuggling and other crime. Gambling supporters say the casinos are an economic boon for the impoverished reservation. Canadian police and New York state troopers have blockaded the reservation since May 1, when two Mohawks were shot to death during fighting between pro- and anti-gambling factions. Gambling opponent Doug George, who edits a newspaper on the reservation, said the arrests may spark fresh violence by groups such as the Warriors Society, a self-appointed reservation security patrol that has backed the casino owners. ``I think it will make them very angry and I would suspect this weekend that they're going to plan something in retaliation,'' George said. The arrests came after a 14-month undercover investigation on the reservation, West said. About half of the suspects live on the reservation. Most were charged with drug trafficking, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison, West said. Warriors Society spokesman John Boots said no members of his group were involved in the arrests. ``We have no connection whatsoever,'' Boots said. Mohawks who resent the police presence said authorities used too much force and were careless in making the arrests. Police smashed a glass door at the home of Elvis Thompson, who was arrested along with three brothers and two cousins, said his girlfriend, Amanda Adams. Police ``didn't even give us a chance to get halfway to the door before they broke it down,'' Adams said. Most of those arrested were released on bail after their arraignments Thursday. Chief Harold Tarbell, a gambling opponent who heads the tribal council that governs the U.S. side, said he wished police would launch a similar initiative on the New York side. Unlike the Canadian sector, the U.S. side has no independent Mohawk police force.

DOC.HEAD: German Army Transport Plane Crashes, Killing All 10 Aboard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with all 10 aboard killed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A West German army transport plane loaded with kerosene crashed near the southern city of Wuerzburg today and burst into flames, killing all 10 people on board, officials said. The plane went down in a remote, wooded area near Wuerzburg, 75 miles south of Frankfurt, Defense Ministry officials said. The plane was carrying a shipment of kerosene and caught fire when it crashed, police said. A witness reported seeing the airplane flying at a low level over the area just before the crash, according to Wuerzburg police. A rescue helicopter rushed to the scene and found the burning plane wreckage amid some trees. The plane was carrying five West German soldiers and five technicians.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 12:40 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Bush Sets Timetable for Putting American on Mars
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts graf 11, The administration, with background.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, heralding a ``new age of exploration,'' said today he believes the United States will send astronauts to Mars in 30 years. Bush had previously announced he would send a manned mission to Mars, but the commencement speech at the Texas A&I University marked the first time he gave a time goal. In the first of a series of graduation speeches this weekend, Bush turned attention to his space program, leaving behind a capital in an uproar over taxes and budget negotiations. ``Thirty years ago, NASA was founded and the space race began. And 30 years from now I believe man will stand on another planet,'' said Bush. ``And so I am pleased to return to Texas today to announce a new age of exploration with not only a goal but also a timetable,'' he said. ``I believe that before Apollo celebrates the 50th anniversary of its landing on the moon, the American flag should be planted on Mars.'' In a speech highlighting space as part of America's heritage of progress, Bush said, ``It's time to open up the final frontier. There can be no turning back. America's space program is what civilization needs to begin this journey to perfect the commitment to go beyond.'' Further, he said, ``Each time we go to the frontier and beyond, we bring back more than we hoped for. This time we have a chance to bring back more than we can imagine.'' Bush declared that the July 20, 1969, landing of Apollo 11 as the first manned spacecraft on the moon ``showed we could meet our commitments to ourselves and to the world, proof that democracy could triumph as decisively in peace as it had in war.'' Bush said that his space plans, which include reviving the moon program and having an operational space station by the end of this century, ``will help rekindle public interest in science and mathematics and revitalize an area of our education system that has become disturbingly weak.'' It will ``revolutionize everything from computers to communication, from medicine to metals, regaining and retaining America's high-tech competitive edge,'' he said. The administration has offered no budget figures for its space program. Some members of Congress have expressed doubts that the massive funding anticipated will be available given the budget-tightening needed to reduce the federal deficit. The president also is commencement speaker Saturday at the University of South Carolina in Columbia and Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va. The trio of speeches follow Bush's first commencement address this year, at Oklahoma State University last week. All are dedicated to the general theme of change in the world. In South Carolina, Bush is to focus on changes in Eastern Europe and the need for a standard of justice as well as democratic government, an administration official said. Before his departure for Texas this morning, Bush's week was consumed by back-and-forth with Congress on the issue of a fiscal year 1991 budget. He remained uncharacteristically out of sight on Thursday as White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater faced reporters to disavow a comment by Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, which reflected greater rigidity than the president has voiced on the administration's budget posture. Bush has said he is entering a series of budget talks with congressional leaders with ``no preconditions.'' That differs from his past promises of ``no new taxes,'' even to reduce a raging budget deficit. But Sununu said Wednesday that no preconditions meant that Democrats were free to suggest tax increases and the White House was free to say no. Sununu's comments were seen as an effort to appease conservative Republicans who are attacking Bush for abandoning the ``no new taxes'' pledge. They brought immediate criticism, however, from congressional Democrats who voiced fears that Bush was setting an election-year trap to get them to push for a tax increase the Republicans could attack. Fitzwater, however, reiterated that nothing is predetermined in the budget talks, and that the ``table is clean.'' Further, he insisted, Bush speaks for himself, and his position is ``no preconditions.'' The budget talks got under way Sunday when Bush called congressional leaders to the White House and proposed they work out a budget both the administration and Congress can agree on.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Suggests NASA Buy More Shuttles
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf pvs, A new ... to UPDATE with number of space shuttles now in existence or under construction
DOC.TEXT: NASA should buy at least one more space shuttle because there's a 50-50 chance a craft will be lost in the next several years, a congressional report suggested today. A new shuttle, like the one being built to replace the destroyed Challenger, would cost $2 billion to $2.5 billion. The Office of Technology Assessment said NASA's goal of 14 launches a year poses increased risks to astronauts and that the schedule could be limited ``to a regular, sustainable rate of eight to 10 launches'' by limiting flights to payloads requiring human crews. ``The actual reliability of the shuttle system is unknown, but may lie between 97 percent and 99 percent,'' the report said. ``If reliability is 98 percent, the nation faces a 50-50 chance of losing an additional orbiter in the next 34 flights.'' The Challenger explosion in 1986, which killed seven crew members, happened on the 25th shuttle flight; there have been 10 missions since. The loss of Challenger left three shuttles in the NASA fleet, Discovery, Atlantis and Columbia. A new shuttle, to be called Endeavour, will be finished next year and flying in 1992. OTA, a congressional advisory group, said in its report that the nation can make do with existing launch systems until the next century if it follows the current course of steady growth in civilian and military space activities. But if the United States wants a permanent lunar base, missions to Mars or a space-based defense system, the report said, it should be prepared to spend $10 billion to $20 billion in development costs alone for new launch systems. ``Because the nation cannot afford to invest in all the good ideas proposed for improved or new launch systems, Congress and the administration will have to choose from a wide range of options,'' the report said. ``Some choices must be made in the next two to three years. Others can wait longer.'' The most immediate choices are making improvements in expendable rockets that are based on 1950s and '60s designs, limiting shuttle flights, buying more orbiters and paying for shuttle improvement program. ``Much like the B-52 bomber, which has steadily grown more capable and remained operational for over 30 years, the ability of the shuttle orbiters to stay in service can theoretically be extended for another two decades,'' the report said. NASA is improving the shuttle's main engines, has begun a program to build more reliable, higher capacity advanced solid rocket motors, and is installing new computers more tolerant than the ones built in the 1970s. The report also said: _The risk to the shuttle fleet would be reduced by developing a heavy-lift launch system, known as Shuttle-C, that would replace the orbiter with a cargo container. NASA estimates the Shuttle-C will cost $1.1 billion, plus $400 million for each launch. _Congress should decide whether to develop a rescue vehicle for astronauts aboard the space station that will be in orbit late in the decade, the report said. It would cost $1 billion to $2 billion. ``To decide whether a risk-reducing effort is worth the investment required, Congress must be advised about how much the investment would reduce the risk,'' OTA said. ``Even if an alternate crew-return vehicle were built, and worked as planned, it would not eliminate all risks to station crew members.'' _For the long haul, Congress should look to developing two new launch systems: a personnel carrier-launch system that would carry little cargo and be launched atop an expendable rocket, and a larger advanced manned launch system using a reusable vehicle. Work on those systems would be cheaper, OTA said, than building an aerospace plane that would take off like an airplane from a conventional runway. Technology for such a plane is being developed jointly by NASA and the Air Force. A full-test vehicle, OTA said, may cost more than $5 billion. The OTA report was one of a series entitled ``Access to Space.'''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, West Germans Haggle Over How To Cover Red Army Costs
DOC.TEXT: West Germany could find itself picking up part of the tab for Soviet troops based in East Germany after the two Germanys merge their economies this summer, Bonn officials said today. The officials said preliminary negotiations have started between Moscow and Bonn on an arrangement to use West German marks to temporarily cover the living costs for Red Army troops stationed in East Germany. The officials spoke on condition of anonymity. It appears that the 380,000 Soviet soldiers in East Germany could start receiving West German marks for their living costs in exchange for Soviet rubles after the German economies are merged on July 2. Such an agreement would mark the first time a NATO country ended up paying in its own currency for the stationing of Soviet troops. A West German government spokeman, Dieter Vogel, said that Finance Minister Theo Waigel will travel to East Berlin on Monday to discuss the Soviet troops issue with the East German government. Under current bilateral agreements, the Soviet Union buys East German marks in exchange for so-called transfer rubles at a preferential rate. Transfer rubles are not convertible to Western countries. The East marks are then used to pay for goods and services for Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany. These have been relatively inexpensive because of state subsidies. When the West German mark becomes East Germany's official currency July 2, East Germany will also start to eliminate state subsidies. That means a new exchange rate will have to be established between the West German mark and the Soviet transfer ruble, and the steep price rises anticipated as a result of the loss of subsidies will also have to be taken into account. It remains unclear how much West Germany would end up paying to maintain the Soviet troops or whether the average Soviet soldier would come out ahead. A West German government official said the bilateral talks with Moscow are just at a beginning phase, and it is not clear how a new arrangement for covering the cost of stationing the Soviet troops will be worked out. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not know what the current costs for the Soviet troops are. He said the West Germans ``have not yet seen any concrete proposals'' from the Soviet side on how to cover the Red Army's costs.

DOC.HEAD: Obsessed Baby Sitter Charged With Kidnapping; Girl Safe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from girl, parents today. Picks up 10th graf, `The youngster...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TD1
DOC.TEXT: A 5-year-old Massachusetts girl was found unharmed at a Gulf Coast fishing lodge and was to return home with her parents today after a 38-day abduction by an obsessed baby sitter, authorities said. Kenneth M. Cole II, a 24-year-old former bus driver, was charged with kidnapping after he was arrested Thursday on a tip from the lodge owner, who saw a local news report on the abduction. Nicole Ravesi of Milford, Mass., showed no signs of abuse, FBI spokesman Paul Cavanagh said. She was to head home today after getting a new dress and a medical checkup. When asked how she felt, Nicole said, ``good,'' but didn't respond to any other questions when the family met briefly with reporters at their hotel. ``We're thankful to get our daughter back,'' said Frank Ravesi, adding that the girl was ``kind of scared of the cameras.'' His wife, Debra, said she was ``very happy, very happy.'' Cole appeared before a U.S. magistrate late Thursday and agreed to be returned to Massachusetts to face kidnapping charges there. Cole and Nicole had been staying since May 5 at a trailer behind Sportsman's Lodge in East Point, a panhandle fishing village about 70 miles southwest of Tallahassee, owner Bob Allen said. He said the girl called Cole ``Dad'' and never spoke of her mother and real father. When Allen called Cole out of the trailer so FBI agents could rescue the girl Thursday, Nicole was ``kind of down at first,'' Allen said. But she responded quickly after she was given a sandwich, cookies and milk, said Franklin County Sheriff Warren Roddenberry. ``She had learned, I guess, to depend on this character, but she is doing quite well,'' the sheriff said. The parents arrived in Tallahassee shortly before 11 p.m. Thursday on a private jet and were taken to a downtown hotel, where they were reunited with their daughter. The reunion was taped by ``America's Most Wanted,'' a Fox network television program, which featured the case three times last month and paid for the plane. The youngster was reported missing April 3 after she was taken from a car where she was with a sister waiting for her mother to finish work. In February, social workers had noticed Cole's attachment to the little girl and alerted the Ravesis, who obtained a restraining order against Cole to prevent him from seeing or speaking to Nicole. But the five-day order expired and the family did not pursue the issue because Cole had stayed away, police said. FBI agent James Cagnassola Jr. said Cole may have taken Nicole to Florida by train. Cole's car was found in an Amtrak parking lot in Providence, R.I. Authorities believe the two spent some time at a lodge in Panama City Beach before apparently traveling to East Point by bicycle _ a distance of 83 miles, Cagnassola said.

DOC.HEAD: Jetliner Explodes, Catches Fire; Seven Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with official saying blast occurred before engines started. Pickup 4th, `The cabin...' Inserts 1 graf after 12th, `Carrascoso said...' with additional quote on bomb investigation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MLA2,4
DOC.TEXT: A Philippine Airlines jet carrying 119 people exploded and burned today as it prepared to take off, and officials said a bomb may have been planted on board. Seven people were killed and more than 80 hurt. Survivors spoke of up to three blasts aboard the Boeing 737-300, and at least three large holes were torn in the roof. Flames quickly gutted the interior. The plane was being towed to the runway for a domestic flight when it was rocked by at least one explosion, which occurred before the jet's two engines were started, said Oscar Alejandro, director of the government's Air Transport Office. The cabin filled with smoke, but most passengers escaped by sliding down emergency chutes before flames engulfed the plane, he said. Passengers said some people panicked and trampled one another rushing for the exits. ``There was an explosion in front of me and there was a very bad smell,'' said passenger Isidro Retaso, 33, of Iloilo. ``So I immediately opened the emergency exit. I was the first one out of the plane. ``They were still demonstrating the safety equipment when it occurred. There were three explosions, loud explosions, and the ceiling shuddered. On the second explosion, I immediately opened the emergency exit.'' The bodies of six adults and one child were found inside the burned-out cabin, said Ed Carrascoso, manager of Manila's domestic airport. He said they were either killed by the blast or died of smoke inhalation. All were passengers. At least 82 passengers were treated for injuries at the airport clinic, most for slight sprains and bruises, said airline employee Alfredo Estrella. Twenty-two passengers were hospitalized, one in serious condition, officials said. The plane was bound for Iloilo, 290 miles to the south, with 113 passengers and six crew members aboard. It was not known how many foreigners were among the passengers, although authorities said a Japanese man was treated for burns. The injured included Aurelio Periquet Jr., a nationally prominent business leader and president of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce, and Rep. Albertito Lopez, a congressman from Iloilo. The plane's departure had been slightly delayed because of heavy air traffic over Manila, officials said. Carrascoso said there had been no bomb threats. But Oscar Alejandro, director of the government's Air Transport Office, said: ``We're looking into the possibility that a bomb was placed aboard.'' Alejandro also said police were examining the plane to determine whether a bomb triggered an explosion. Dante Santos, president of Philippine Airlines, said flames swept through the plane in only four minutes. One blast apparently occurred near the center of the passenger cabin, near where the bodies were found, he said. ``Initial reports said there was an explosion inside the cabin, maybe in one of the passengers' baggage,'' he said. ``Everything looked normal, but then there was a loud explosion,'' said passenger Sony Villareal, 30. ``It was really deafening and strong because luggage fell from the upper compartments. ``After the explosion, there was fire and thick smoke billowed,'' he said. ``Everybody panicked after that. People were stumbling over each other trying to get out of the plane.'' Smoke continued to billow from the plane for about 30 minutes as firefighters poured foam on the jetliner. The plane was later towed to a hangar for inspection. President Corazon Aquino dispatched her executive secretary, Catalino Macaraig, to the scene to report on the investigation. Officials said the aircraft was leased by Philippine Airlines in November. Today's disaster was the worst aviation tragedy in Manila since July, when a Philippine Airlines BAC1-11 overshot a runway on a flight from Zamboanga and slammed into a busy highway. Eight people, all of them on the ground, were killed and 91 people were injured in that accident.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 5th graf with transit police enforcing the ban since February, picks up 6th graf, The court . . .
DOC.HEAD: Court Tells New York it Can Stop Panhandling in Subways
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has ruled that New York City can oust panhandlers from the subways because asking for money is not a protected form of speech. ``The only message that we are able to espy as common to all acts of begging is that beggars want to exact money from those whom they accost,'' the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said in a 2-1 opinion Thursday. The decision reversed a lower court ruling that said the Metropolitan Transit Authority's begging prohibition was unconstitutional because begging is a form of free speech protected by the First Amendment. The earlier ruling had overturned a city program, begun in October, to crack down on vagrancy in the subway. Many of the city's estimated 80,000 homeless people congregate underground to stay warm, sleep and ask for spare change. The appeals court ruling means the Transit Authority can ban begging on trains, near subway stairways, escalators and elevators and within 25 feet of token booths. A transit police spokesman, Sgt. Robert Valentino, said the police had been enforcing the ban since February because the lower court ruling had been under appeal, although officers were not rigorously applying it. The transit police officials were mapping strategy today to more vigorously enforce the ban now, even if it is appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court, Valentino said. The court said U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand, who made the earlier ruling, showed ``an exacerbated deference to the alleged individual rights of beggars and panhandlers to the great detriment of the common good.'' The Transit Authority, which operates the subway system, has an obligation to provide a safe environment for its ridership, the appeals court said. ``It is fair to say that whether intended as so, or not, begging in the subway often amounts to nothing less that assault, creating in the passengers the apprehension of imminent danger,'' the 51-page majority decision said. In a dissenting opinion, Judge Thomas Meskill pointed to regulations that allow organized charities to solicit donations in the subway system. He said beggars deserve the same protection. ``I simply fail to see why the Transit Authority should be able to permit organized charities, but not beggars, to rattle a cup full of change as one passes by,'' Meskill said. Robert Kiley, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, called the decision a victory for the millions of subway riders. ``We believe the subways are a means of transportation, not an open field for panhandling,'' he said. ``The transit police may now proceed with our efforts to restore order to the transit system.'' The appeals court decision stemmed from a class-action lawsuit brought by the Legal Action Center for the Homeless last November on behalf of all people who beg in the subway system. A lawyer said the homeless advocates might appeal the decision.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Rules Out Negotiating With Israel Over Hostages
DOC.TEXT: An influential Shiite Moslem leader today ruled out negotiations with Israel on a prisoner exchange that could secure the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon. ``The believers have every moral, religious and humanitarian objection against negotiating with Israel,'' Hussein Musawi told a news conference at his headquarters in east Lebanon's ancient city of Baalbek. ``Our war with the enemies of God is open-ended,'' Musawi said. Excerpts of the news conference were broadcast by the Communist-run Voice of The People radio station. Musawi heads Islamic Amal, a pro-Syrian wing in the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for Shiite extremists holding most of the 16 Western hostages, including six Americans. Musawi is believed to wield influence on Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the group that released American hostage Robert Polhil, 55, on April 22. Another group calling itself the Organization of Islamic Dawn released another American, Frank Reed, 57, on April 30. Iran and the hostage-holders demanded a goodwill gesture from the United States after the release of Polhill and Reed. They have asked Washington to pressure Israel to release some 300 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees, and that the United States and its Western allies help determine the fate of four Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon in 1982. The Iranians were kidnapped in the Christian heartland north of Beirut by right-wing militiamen. Militia officials have said they believe the Iranians are dead, but Tehran says it has information they are still alive. Israel says it would negotiate a swap provided it includes an Israeli airman and two soldiers captured by Shiite groups in south Lebanon in 1986. Political analysts assume that if the swap of Israeli and Lebanese and Palestinian detainees occurred, some of the 16 Western hostages would be freed. In addition to the six Americans, the Western hostages include four Britons, two Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest held is Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: State Deptartment Backs Chinese Couple Who Fled Forced Abortions
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has ruled that a Chinese couple who fled their homeland's forced abortion policy qualify for refugee status, clearing the way for them to receive political asylum, their lawyer said today. Li Jin Lin and his wife, Wang Sai Zhen, are the first known cases to test President Bush's Nov. 30 directive that grants asylum to people fleeing forced abortions or sterilizations in their native countries. They had been awaiting a U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service hearing that would decide whether they could stay in the United States, but the State Department ruling effectively ended the proceedings against them, said Kathleen Rimar, the Lis' lawyer. The State Department letter said the Lis qualify for refugee status under federal law, but did not specifically mention the abortion issue. ``They got, really, just a form letter,'' Rimar said. The letter rejected refugee status for the Lis' nephew, Chun Kong Cheung, who accompanied them on their trip to the United States, but Rimar said she would ask the State Department to reconsider based on new evidence that the Chinese government has been looking for Chun and that he might face sterilization or death if forced to return. Li, a 37-year-old machinist, and his 34-year-old wife fled their hometown of Fuzhou last year when Ms. Wang became pregnant with what would have been the couple's second child. Chinese law limits most families to one child and requires women who conceive again to undergo abortions. The couple paid smugglers in Canada about $1,500 apiece to get into the United States illegally, but the INS caught them in Albany. Ms. Wang was allowed to remain in the United States because of her advanced pregnancy, but Li was sent back to Canada. When he and his nephew tried to cross the border again last October, they were caught at the international Peace Bridge in Buffalo and jailed. After Bush issued his order, they applied for asylum under it and reached a plea bargain on the illegal-entry charges that freed them from jail. Chun cannot be deported until 1994 in any case, thanks to a presidential order covering all Chinese refugees, Rimar said. The Lis, who are now working in restaurants in New York City, will have to return to Buffalo for an interview with the INS, but that will be little more than a formality, Rimar said. John Ingham, INS district director in Buffalo, was not in his office this morning and did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment. The State Department's policy is not to comment on individual asylum cases, a spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Captain Describes Fatal Blaze
DOC.TEXT: When the captain of the USS Conyngham reached the bridge minutes after a fire swept through his ship, he feared he might have to order the crew to abandon ship, he said today. ``But when I saw the determination of the faces of my men, all those thoughts left my mind,'' Cmdr. William R. Williams told reporters in front of the damaged guided missile destroyer at the Norfolk Naval Station. The fire Tuesday killed the ship's operations officer, Lt. Cmdr. Algernon Pope Gordon Jr., and injured 18 crewmen. Gordon's promotion to lieutenant commander was to have taken effect in a few weeks, but the Navy said today it gave him the honor posthumously. A hole 6 feet by 5 feet has been cut in the ship's aluminum superstructure for repair work. Inside the ship, bulkheads melted, overhead decks were missing and insulation and wire hung everywhere. Williams said about 90 percent of the crew was asleep when the fire broke out at 5 a.m. in the forward boiler room after ``a major fuel leak.'' The fire quickly rose up through passageways burning through decks and sending black, inky smoke through berthing spaces, he said. The decks were red hot, with fireballs periodically exploding out of hatches, he said. Because the fire was in the middle of the ship, the crew was split half on the bow, half on the stern. Officers mobilized firefighting crews and worked inward to battle the blaze, Williams said. Petty Officer 2nd Class Otis Tate, 24, of Hartwell, Ga., said he ran from his berth to his battle station on the mess deck. A five-year Navy man, Tate said passageways were filled with smoke when he led a seven-man crew into the fire area with fire extinguishers. ``This is my first shipboard fire and I hope it's my last,'' Tate said. Williams said the crew had been training for a major inspection which would have tested their firefighting skills. ``For us, the exam came early,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Kills At Least 11 in Ural Mountains; 18,000 Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with local officials saying 11 confirmed dead, sted 14 reported by media, more than 18,000 evacuated, sted 20,000, 130 villages submerged, moves up damage figure. Pickup 5th, `The floods...' Subs last 2 grafs with 3 grafs with quotes on danger from radioactive spillage.
DOC.TEXT: Floods have killed at least 11 people, wrecked hundreds of homes and forced the evacuation of more than 18,000 people in the Bashkiria region of the southern Ural Mountains, officials said today. Three people were reported missing. The Soviet press has been largely silent about the flooding, which began about a week ago when the Belaya, or White River, overflowed its banks due to heavy rains and melting snow. Alexei I. Kharlov, deputy prime minister of the Bashirian Autonomous Republic, said by telephone that the flood submerged 130 villages and 13,000 houses. Eleven people were killed and three were missing, he said. The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda and the unofficial news agency Postfactum put the death toll at 14, with one missing. The TV news program Vremya said ``loss of life has occurred'' but did not give a figure. Damage was estimated at $161 million, said Postfactum, one of several independent news agencies that began in the Soviet Union in recent years. Authorities used helicopters to rescue people from some of the villages inundated by rising waters that destroyed hundreds of houses and submerged hundreds of miles of roads and railways, the Communist Party daily Pravda reported. The floods ruined 90 bridges and swept away telephone and power lines in the region between the industrial cities of Ufa and Chelyabinsk 720 miles east of Moscow, said Komsomolskaya Pravda, the Communist youth newspaper. Farm lands were devastated, and more than 160,000 cattle were cut off from pastures or stalls. ``This flooding has beaten all the records,'' Pravda reported, quoting the deputy prime minister of the Bashkirian Soviet Autonomous Republic, E. Galin. The region is part of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. It was the third disaster to strike Bashkiria over the last year. A gas pipeline explosion near Ufa in May claimed more than 600 lives, and toxic wastes poisoned tap water in Ufa last month. Postfactum said the latest flooding also raised the danger of overflow from lakes that have been used to collect radioactive wastewater from nearby nuclear production facilities. Lev G. Strobbe, deputy chief of the Chelyabinsk region executive commitee, said that ``so far I can assure you that there is no danger from these lakes in connection with this flooding.'' But, he said, ``if worse comes to worst, the contamained silt will go by way of northern rivers into the Arctic Ocean, and the consequences may be disastrous.''

DOC.HEAD: Interior Minister Blames Rightist For Desecration of Tombs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 15th, `It seems...' to ADD anti-racism demonstration in Denmark. Pickup 16th, `In a...'
DOC.TEXT: The interior minister said today he held far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen indirectly responsible for the desecration of a Jewish cemetery in which a corpse was dug up and impaled on an umbrella. Le Pen denied responsibility and said the desecration of 34 tombs at the cemetery in south-central Carpentras was probably planned by people who wanted to discredit the extreme right. France's National Assembly suspended its session for 15 minutes today in protest, and leaders across the political spectrum reacted with outrage at the vandalism, which was discovered early Thursday. Relatives held an impromptu religious ceremony at the cemetery, while about 50 Jewish demonstrators gathered outside under a banner reading ``We Will Not Let History Repeat Itself.'' Interior Minister Pierre Joxe said several tombs in Carpentras were left ``in conditions so abominable that one can't describe them without embarrassment.'' Joxe traveled to the town to inspect the site. The body of an 81-year-old man who died about two weeks ago was found impaled on an umbrella, police said. Grave markers had been knocked over and flower pots were trampled. A previously unknown group calling itself the ``Mohamed El Boukima Group'' claimed responsibility in a phone call to a local newspaper. Police said they were trying to authenticate the call. Authorities said the fingerprints of at least four people were found on tomb stones. The incident occurred two days after a nationwide telecast of a three-hour documentary about Nazi Germany and the Holocaust. Officials in Strasbourg, meanwhile, reported that a Jewish cemetery there had been desecrated. Twenty tomb stones were overturned between April 12 and May 4 at the Wissembourg Israelite cemetery, they said. And in a related incident, swastikas and Nazi graffiti were scrawled on official buildings in Rambouillet, near Paris, officials said. Joxe said Le Pen, of the extreme-right National Front, was a ``racist and provocateur.'' The far-right party has been accused of condoning anti-Semitism and other forms of racism. ``Consequently, he, like all racists, like all who express their anti-Semitism in an explicit or implicit fashion, he is obviously one of those responsible, not by the acts at Carpentras yesterday, by all that has been inspired by racist hate for years.'' Le Pen, in Denmark for a meeting of right-wing European politicians, said the incident was a plot to soil his party's reputation. ``It seems more and more evident that it is a political plot against the National Front,'' he said from his hotel north of Copenhagen. ``I don't feel guilty at all in this case. I condemn those who did this, and I condemn all those who organized this.'' After Le Pen left the hotel, about 400 demonstrators threw paint, smoke bombs and empty bottles at police, Danish radio reported. The demonstration, which appeared unrelated to the tomb desecrations in France, occurred outside the Marienlyst Hotel in Helsingoer, 25 miles north of Copenhagen. Protesters shouted ``fascists'' and ``Le Pen go home,'' and several windows were smashed by stones. In a telegram to Carpentras Jewish leader Freddy Haddad, President Francois Mitterrand said, ``I learned with horror of this criminal act.'' Mitterrand later went to the home of France's chief rabbi, Rabbi Sitruk, to express his distress. ``I've come as one does for a family in mourning,'' Mitterrand said. Jean Kahn, leader of a national coalition of Jewish groups, said the desecration comes at a time when racial hatred is being encouraged ``by those who promote anti-Semitic rhetoric and fascist themes.'' Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel, who left the gala dinner opening the Cannes film festival after learning of the desecration, said a racist climate was on the rise in France. ``French society must now examine its conscience _ and urgently,'' he said. Mayor Jean-Claude Andrieu described Carpentras as a quiet town of about 26,000. Recent polls show about 15 percent of the electorate support Le Pen and his National Front Party, which has one seat in the 277-seat National Assembly. Le Pen won 11 percent of the vote in the first round of the 1988 presidential election. Le Pen has become increasingly visible as the Socialist government tries to deal with immigration and racism, top issues in France today.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Debate Allowing Sale of Dog, Cat Meat
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland's most prominent animal rights campaigner Friday denounced government plans to allow sales of dog and cat meat as ``monstrous and obscene.'' Franz Weber, in a column in Lausanne's Le Matin newspaper, charged the proposed law endorsed ``a kind of cannibalism'' and would ``lower us to the level of the disparaged monsters of the Philippines and Korea.'' Swiss authorities have proposed a sweeping revision of 1954 food regulations that would drop the ban on butchers' selling dog and cat meat. The aim is to bring Swiss law into line with the European Community. The government proposal, which needs parliamentary approval, has been circulated for public comment through May 31. Werner Friedrich, deputy director of the Swiss Hotel Association, told Bern's Der Bund newspaper the prospect was ``frightening.'' ``Such a change of food laws would definitely overstep the boundaries of good taste,'' he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Sets Himself on Fire in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: A Lithuanian doused his body with alcohol and set himself on fire at a border crossing between the Soviet Union and Hungary, suffering serious injuries, police said Friday. Police near the border crossing at Zahony in northeastern Hungary said they did not know the reason for Thursday's incident. They said they did not know if it was connected with Lithuania's independence battle with Moscow. The Lithuanian was identified as Rimantas Daugintis, a resident of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. He was hospitalized with burns over 80 percent of his body, police said. On April 26, 52-year-old Stanislovas Jamaitis, a Lithuanian protesting Soviet moves against his homeland, committed suicide in front of Moscow's Bolsho Theater by setting himself on fire. The Baltic republic of Lithuania, which was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, declared itself independent in March. The Kremlin has imposed sanctions against the republic in an effort to end the independence drive.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Ask Japan to Apology, Compensate for Wartime Atrocities
DOC.TEXT: About 100 elderly protesters marched toward the Japanese Embassy on Friday and demanded that Japan apologize and offer compensation for wartime atrocities. Riot police using shields and buses stopped and surrounded the protesters when they were about 100 feet from the embassy in central Seoul. Most of the demonstrators were relatives of Koreans who were drafted by Japan and killed during World War II. They sat down on the street after being blocked by police. ``We oppose President Roh's visit to Japan,'' the protesters shouted. ``Japan, the war criminal, must make an open apology.'' Roh is scheduled to visit Japan on May 24. There were no clashes or arrests. Police appeared cautious in handling the protesters. Japan colonized Korea from 1910 to 1945, drafting hundreds of thousands of Koreans into the military and forced labor.

DOC.HEAD: East German Experts Reportedly Sent Home By Aden
DOC.TEXT: About 200 East German security experts have been sent home by South Yemen because their government has not paid their salaries for months, a Saudi Arabian newspaper reported Friday. The daily Asharq Al-Awsat said the cutoff in pay followed the political changes that took place in Eastern Europe. The newspaper's report was attributed to unnamed informed sources in Aden, South Yemen. South Yemen became the Arab world's only Marxist state with its independence from Britain in 1967. It fostered strong ties with the Soviet Union and other communist nations. East Germany's communist regime was overthrown in October. The Saudi paper said the East German experts were helping in the field of security.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Palace Duck Scared Away, Comes Back
DOC.TEXT: Japan's most famous waterbird, a traffic-stopping duck, returned to her Tokyo pond Friday after being scared away by a horde of photographers and a wildlife worker hoping to mend the bird's bad leg. For at least a decade, the spotbilled duck has returned each May to a decorative pond in front of the headquarters of trading giant Mitsui and Co. and hatched a brood of ducklings. A few weeks later, after the young birds are strong swimmers, the mother has herded them across an eight-lane road to spend the summer in the Imperial Palace moat. The operation requires a squad of police to stop traffic, and usually there are five times as many photographers as ducks. The ducks' passage has become a rite of summer that is reported as avidly as the cherry blossoms in April. This year the rite seemed in danger. The duck had a bad leg, and city authorities tried to capture it for medical treatment Thursday night. But the bird flew away, apparently scared by a photographer's camera flash. Photographers had promised not to use flashes. Mitsui reported the bird returned early Friday, still with a bad leg, and press reports said another attempt might be made to capture it. The Japan Wild Birds Society disagreed with the plan. ``That duck was strong enough to escape,'' said Takio Nakamura, head of the society's protection department. ``She's probably strong enough not to need protection.'' But Nakamura agreed that it is ``quite a special case ... because that duck is famous.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede DENVER
Interior Secretary Says Endangered Species Act Should be Weakened
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 11 grafs to update with Lujan spokesman comments and criticism from environmentalists; picks up 5th graf pvs, Under the ...
DOC.TEXT: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan prompted outrage from environmentalists today by suggesting that the Endangered Species Act should be changed to more easily accommodate some economic development. Lujan made the remark Thursday in Colorado when he noted that concern about a group of both were charged in the case. Allison was convicted of murder last year in a separate trial. The couple was charged in the killing of policeman Melvin Pyne, whose headless body was found March 31, 1989, in the Monrovia suburb of Caldwell, where the Allisons lived. Witnesses said the couple planned to use the officer's blood in a ritual aimed at giving the major general the power to topple President Samuel Doe. The couple told judges they were framed by police officers jealous of their wealth and flamboyant lifestyle. Mrs. Allison's lawyers have filed an appeal against the judgment. Allison was sentenced to death last year and is in prison. No execution date was set.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Wash Out Fish Farm
With AM-Floods-Tourism, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A fish farm near here is among the casualties of the high waters that have saturated parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas. Leann Doss of Southwest Fish Hatchery near Terrell, about 25 miles northeast of Dallas, said a wave of water came over a levee Thursday, sweeping most of the fish away. ``We lost most of our brood fish,'' said Mrs. Doss. ``They are scattered everywhere. I'd estimate only 25 percent of the fish stayed on the farm.'' She said 22 of the hatchery's 55 one-acre ponds were destroyed. With them went schools of channel catfish, hybrid bluegills, bass, croppie and shad.

DOC.HEAD: After 7 Years in Prison, Dale Johnston Awaits Freedom Today
LaserPhoto CO1
DOC.TEXT: A man who served more than seven years in prison for two mutilation slayings he says he didn't commit prepared today to leave jail for good and begin fighting to clear his name. Dale Johnston learned of his release Thursday after an appeals court ruled that prosecutors could not use evidence they claimed was crucial to obtaining a second conviction in the 1982 deaths of his stepdaughter and her fiance. The prosecutors then dropped the case. ``This day I knew would get here sooner or later,'' Johnston said in an interview at the Licking County Justice Center. ``I made it my No. 1 priority. Now I plan to make finding the real killer of those kids my No. 1 priority.'' Annette Cooper Johnston, 18, and Todd L. Schultz, 19, both of Logan were last seen alive in that southeast Ohio community on Oct. 4, 1982. Their torsos were found 10 days later in the Hocking River. Other body parts were unearthed in a cornfield. Prosecutors contended jealousy was the motive for the killings and that Johnston had a sexual relationship with his stepdaughter. Johnston, 56, was convicted in 1984 on two counts of aggravated murder and was sentenced to death. The Ohio Supreme Court in 1988 threw out the verdict and ordered a new trial, ruling that a witness whose memory had been refreshed by hypnosis had been improperly allowed to testify. The second trial was put on hold last July after Judge William Gillie ruled that statements police obtained from Johnston during 8{ hours of questioning without a lawyer present were inadmissible. Gillie also threw out clothing taken from Johnston, including boots that prosecutors linked to footprints near where the bodies were found. On Thursday, a state appeals court unanimously upheld Gillie's decision, saying police tried to deceive and coerce Johnston into making statements against his will and gave no legitimate reason for so lengthy an interrogation. Prosecutor Charles Gerken dropped the case Thursday afternoon, and Johnston would be released as soon as the order is filed with the Franklin County clerk of courts, said Thomas Tyack, one of Johnston's attorneys. ``I still believe in the criminal justice system but I was a victim of some members of that profession who were not the best that they should be,'' Johnston said in Thursday's interview. He would not elaborate. Johnston won't say where he'll go after his release for fear of retribution from people he claims have threatened him, his family and his attorneys. He and another defense lawyer, Robert Suhr, declined to identify any of the people. Johnston's ex-wife, Sarah, said she was happy but indicated she still suffered emotional wounds. ``You have to get over the grief. But it's always there every day. I kid you not. Every day,'' she said. The Johnstons are divorced. She remarried and is living in southern Ohio outside Hocking County. Schultz's father, Donald, said there is no doubt in his mind that Johnston killed the two. ``He knows who did it. He did it,'' Schultz said. He noted that Johnston was found guilty by three trial judges.

DOC.HEAD: Rules Eased for Czeck, East German Reporters
DOC.TEXT: The State Department disposed of another Cold War remnant Friday, announcing that Czechoslovak and East German reporters will be able to enter the department unescorted. Correspondents from those countries had been ineligible for building passes. The department earlier had relaxed the rules on building access for Hungarian and Polish correspondents. U.S. reporters are allowed to enter the department unescorted.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Ignores Warning Shots to Reach Lebanese Port
DOC.TEXT: A ferry carrying 66 passengers ignored warning shots Friday from Gen. Michel Aoun's gunners to reach a port controlled by rival Christian militia forces, authorities said. The shelling came two days after Aoun declared the coastline of the Christian enclave off limits to international shipping. That was in an effort to keep supplies from reaching the Lebanese Forces militia commanded by his rival, Samir Geagea. Police said Aoun's gunners on a mountain ridge overlooking the Mediterranean fired two warning shots from a 155mm howitzer at the Victory I ferry as it approached the port of Jounieh on Friday morning. Jounieh is controlled by Geagea's forces. The ship, arriving from Larnaca, Cyprus, stopped a few miles offshore for about two hours before heading into the port. It let off its 66 passengers and then headed back to Cyprus, police said. The ferry is one of the few remaining links to the outside world for residents of the Christian enclave, which is surrounded on land by Syrian troops and their Moslem militia allies. Police said four civilians were wounded when Aoun's gunners fired on the Beirut port at midday to keep Geagea's machine gun-mounted speedboats away. The battle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has left 930 people dead and 2,576 wounded since it erupted Jan. 30. Geagea's militia controls most of the Christian enclave's 28-mile-long coastline. Geagea's speedboats are blockading a three-mile coastal strip at Dbaye, between Beirut and Jounieh, where Aoun's forces have set up a makeshift harbor to try to bring in military supplies. Both sides have been reported to be running low on ammunition. Rival Christian snipers in front-line positions in east Beirut and the surrounding hinterland kept most of the enclave's roads closed to traffic for a fourth straight day Friday. Police said only mediators representing Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the Maronite Catholic sect, were allowed to pass through checkpoints manned by the rival Christian forces. They were shuttling between Geagea's seaside command post near Jounieh and Aoun's headquarters at the hilltop presidential palace in Baabda in an effort work out a cease-fire, a police spokesman said. Aoun has rejected an Arab League-brokered peace accord, supported by Syria, to end Lebanon's many-sided civil war, because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops. Geagea has recognized the Syrian-backed government of President Elias Hrawi and cautiously accepted the peace plan, which calls for an equal distribution of power between Christians and Moslems. In south Lebanon, meanwhile, rival Shiite Moslem factions allied with Syria and Iran declared a cease-fire Friday morning in Iqlim Al-Tuffah. Fighting between the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the pro-Syrian Amal militia has been raging in the area since Dec. 23. The confrontation is part of a 2-year-old struggle for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, who make up the largest single sect in the country.

DOC.HEAD: Observatory Records Intense Earthquake in Sea of Japan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake was recorded Friday in the Sea of Japan about 370 miles northeast of the North Korean capital, the Hong Kong Observatory reported. It said the quake measured 5.2 on the Richter scale. An observatory statement said an initial reading of the quake, recorded at 9.14 p.m., determined the epicenter to be 372 miles northeast of Pyongyang, North Korea. No further details were available. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause serious damage on land, and a quake measuring 6 can cause severe damage.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Unwanted Death Penalty, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0591,0528
DOC.HEAD: Minneapolis Council Approves Resolution Seeking to Keep Death Penalty Out
With PM-Federal Death Penalty, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with resolution approved 10-3. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The resolution...'.
DOC.TEXT: The City Council decided today that the federal law allowing the death penalty for some drug-related homicides has no place here, overwhelmingly approving a measure aimed at blocking enforcement. The council voted 10-3 to approve a resolution urging the city's law officers to bypass the U.S. attorney's office if the death penalty is at stake. Officers instead would be urged to turn cases over to state and local prosecutors, because Minnesota has no death penalty. ``My personal opinion is that the death penalty serves no useful societal purpose,'' said council member Joan Campbell, chief sponsor of the resolution. ``I'm not in any way suggesting that the crimes are not heinous,'' Campbell continued. ``I don't think it's the responsibility of a civilized society to kill people if they kill other people.'' But council member Dennis Schulstad, who opposed the resolution, said, ``The message we're sending is that we care much more about the criminals in this city than we care about the victims.'' Another opponent on the council, Walt Dziedzic, argued that it ``sends the wrong message out there that this city, this great city, is soft on crime.'' The resolution was sparked by a 1988 federal law that sanctions the death penalty for some drug-related homicides. In the first use of the law, federal prosecutors in Chicago said Thursday they will seek the death penalty against two men accused of murdering a federal witness to protect their $50,000-a-day drug ring. Before the vote, Campbell said passage of her resolution would show that ``we don't like the death penalty, and we don't like the federal government telling the state of Minnesota what to do. She added that it is ``not a deterrent to crime. It's been proven over and over again.'' The resolution was approved 4-1 last week by a City Council panel. ``My hope is that this sets an example to other jurisdictions and to other cities that they can say no to the federal death penalty,'' said Hennepin County Attorney Tom Johnson, who helped draft the resolution. Critics say the resolution lacks teeth because federal authorities could step in and try a homicide case even if local officials didn't refer it to them. Schulstad, who voted against the resolution last week, called it ``strictly a public relations thing.'' Minneapolis Police Lt. Richard Huss, the only person to testify against the resolution last week, said Thursday that the measure would call attention to what he considers the state's already lax criminal system. U.S. Attorney Jerome Arnold in Minneapolis said he is willing to push for the death penalty in the first appropriate case. Minnesota has not had such a case so far, he said, but ``with the attendant violence to drug crimes, there is some degree of likelihood that a homicide would fall into the federal categories.''

DOC.HEAD: Former ``Today'' Producer to Run ``NBC Nightly News''
DOC.TEXT: Steve Friedman, the executive producer of NBC's ``Today'' show when it was first in ratings, is returning to NBC as executive producer of the ``NBC Nightly News,'' the network said today. Friedman will succeed Bill Wheatley, the program's executive producer for five years. No date has been set for the change, but it will be soon, said Peggy Hubble, a spokeswoman for NBC News. A call to the office of Tom Brokaw, the program's anchor and managing editor, seeking comment was referred to Ms. Hubble's office. But the move comes at a time his program and Dan Rather's ``CBS Evening News'' have been alternating in third place in the ratings. Brokaw's program has been third in ratings for two consecutive weeks. Friedman's association with Brokaw goes back to the early 1970s when Brokaw was an anchorman and Friedman a news writer at NBC-owned KNBC-TV in Burbank, Calif. They also worked together on ``Today'' when Brokaw was its co-host. Friedman left ``Today'' three years ago to develop and produce what proved to be an ill-fated television version of USA Today newspaper. Costing $40 million to start up, the syndicated program, ``USA Today on TV,'' was a critical and commercial failure, and was axed last year after 15 months on the air.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Tantalizes Britain With Boasts About Another Mole
DOC.TEXT: The KGB is in town, tormenting the British with boasts about yet another top traitor in the Kim Philby mold, possibly the long-sought ``Fifth Man.'' This latest caper includes a Soviet TV movie on the affair and a KGB public relations man who was in London on Friday to help answer reporters' questions. Some scholars of espionage have long suspected that Soviet penetration of the British secret service did not end with the unmasking of Guy Burgess, Donald Maclean, Anthony Blunt and Harold ``Kim'' Philby, and that there was probably a fifth man. Others maintain the KGB has deliberately fostered the theory to keep Western intelligence in doubt. Until now, the hunt for the Fifth Man has leaned heavily on conjecture, dragging several illustrious British names through the mud. Now comes the KGB, almost gleefully claiming the speculation is true. Yuri Modin, one of Philby's handlers, says in a Soviet film about the spy's exploits that ``the fifth one is not known to our ex-enemy, ex-opponent, so I am not in a position to tell you anything about that.'' So a Fifth Man really existed? ``Yes, that's a fact.'' Has he met him? ``Yes, I know him personally.'' Is he an interesting man? ``Well, now I'll try to avoid your question. He is an interesting man with his own peculiarities, etc., with his own ideas...'' At a preview of the film at a London televison studio, KGB press officer Col. Igor Prelin gave more details, claiming the Fifth Man is ``of Philby's generation'' and retired from espionage work. Philby died in Moscow in 1988 at 76. He implied that the KGB had asked the Fifth Man if he would like to be identified, and the answer was no. ``This person has done a great deal for us. Why should we do him harm?'' Prelin said. Was he in the Soviet Union? No. Britain? Prelin wouldn't say. Had he ever received a title or other honor in Britain? No comment. But then Prelin offered ``another little secret: these five people had information covering all the different departments and institutions of the British government.'' Philby was in the secret service, Blunt worked for the royal family, and Burgess and Maclean for the Foreign Office. And the Fifth Man? ``Work it out for yourself,'' said Prelin. A British reporter grumbled that it all sounded like ``typical KGB mischief-making.'' Not at all, insisted Prelin. But when asked why the KGB was divulging the Fifth Man's existence, he replied through an interpreter that ``It gives us pleasure.'' The Philby group, converted to communism while at Cambridge University in the 1930s, served the Kremlin faithfully until its unmasking after World War II. In fact, the documentary says, Philby helped set up the CIA while posted to Washington. Until Philby's defection in 1963, it was one of the most successful intelligence operations in history. The film, ``Comrade Philby,'' was made by the Soviet state film company and was being screened on Soviet TV Friday night. British viewers will see it Monday. One man who dismisses the Fifth Man theory is historian Hugh Trevor-Roper, now Lord Dacre. ``I just don't believe them. I'll consider it if somebody produces evidence, but I don't regard statements by the KGB as evidence,'' he said. He noted that Oleg Gordievsky, a senior KGB officer who defected to Britain, had insisted publicly that there was no Fifth Man. ``I can see no reason why Gordievsky should not be speaking the truth,'' he said. ``I can see why the KGB would be telling a lie, just to keep us worried.'' Rupert Allison, a Conservative member of Parliament, said he thought the Soviets may have revived the Fifth Man issue because they were unhappy that Gordievsky appearing on British television. ``Nobody likes insiders spilling the beans,'' said Allison, who writes about espionage under the pseudonym Nigel West. `` I think it is not improbable to believe that the KGB is saying, `We've all got our secrets and if you try to embarrass us with Gordievsky, we will respond.'''

DOC.HEAD: Police Launch Dragnet For Radical Students
DOC.TEXT: Police have launched a dragnet for 20 fugitive student and dissident leaders believed to have instigated or led violent anti-government protests this week, prosecutors said Friday. Police said homes, schools and other places frequented by those in hiding will be searched in one of the largest crackdowns on the opposition in recent months. Dissidents are being sought in connection with nationwide protests on Wednesday by about 100,000 radicals. During the violence, protesters burned a U.S. diplomatic building in the capital. ``I think it just happened to be a target of opportunity,'' said U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon. But he added: ``Mindless violence is the enemy of democracy.'' Prosecutors said 55 protesters were formally arrested Friday for violating a law banning firebombs and for participating in illegal rallies in connection with the violence. Another 129 people were given summary court trials and sentenced to jail terms of up to 30 days, prosecutors said. Despite government warnings against violence, dissidents said Friday they would step up anti-government protests to topple the government of President Roh Tae-woo, and radical students staged scattered protests. In the southern city of Kwangju, about 1,500 students hurled firebombs and rocks when riot police used tear gas to block anti-government protesters from marching off Chosun University, the South Korean news agency Yonhap reported. In Seoul, six radical students armed with firebombs and iron bars seized a third-floor office in South Korea's tax administration headquarters. They demanded Roh resign, saying his economic policies favored big companies. Police immediately charged into the building, knocked down barricaded doors with hammers and arrested the six. One protester was injured. In leaflets scattered through the building, the protesters accused Roh's government of implementing a tax system that favored the rich. With inflation climbing, criticism of Roh's government has mounted among South Koreans. Housing and other prices have nearly doubled since Roh took office in February 1988. Police took 1,084 protesters into custody in Seoul on Thursday, when more than 6,000 students and dissidents staged violent street protests in capital and nine other cities for the second consecutive day. Thousands of riot police have remained on alert in Seoul since students demanding Roh's resignation rampaged through central Seoul on Wednesday, burning police vehicles and setting fire to an office of the U.S. Information Service. About 150 people, including 100 police, were injured. The violence coincided with the inaugural convention of the newly created Democratic Liberal Party. Opponents contend the gigantic new governing coalition, a merger of the ruling party with two opposition groups, was a political coup that altered party alliances without an election. The protests were the largest and most violent since nationwide demonstrations forced former authoritarian President Chun Doo-hwan to announce major reforms three years ago. Those reforms included popular presidential elections that put Roh in power. The government has said it will take firm action against labor and political violence, contending South Korea's sagging economy cannot endure further disturbances.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatrists Conflicted Over Mother's Day
DOC.TEXT: They didn't eat their peas, they never call, and they almost always hold their annual meeting on Mother's Day. What's a mom to do with the members of the American Psychiatric Association? For the fifth straight year, APA members will spend that special day in meetings, courses and talks, prompting this headline in The Wall Street Journal: ``Oedipus Wrecks Mother's Day.'' Instead of taking Mother to brunch, the psychiatrists will attend sessions such as ``Psychological Management of Schizophrenia,'' ``Object Relations Theory in General Psychiatry'' and ``New Developments in Geriatric Psychiatry.'' Well, docs, here's an old development in geriatric psychiatry: your elderly mom would like some attention on the second Sunday in May. Seth Stein, executive director of the APA's New York state affiliate, said that over the years some members have complained about the convention's scheduling. But he said that finding a time that's good for 10,000 people _ and a city that can accommodate them all _ is not easy. ``In the grand scheme of things, I can't see what relevance this has,'' he sniffed. He also pointed out that the official opening session was not until 5 p.m., which would allow members to telephone their mothers _ if they're not visiting the Bronx Zoo, the World Trade Center or Times Square. John Hoffman, manager of convention services for the city's tourism bureau, said Mother's Day weekend was not prime convention time. ``It's kind of sacred,'' he said. ``I can't even get a lot of my own people to work.'' The psychiatrists have met on Mother's Day 10 times in the past 22 years, a tradition that even the election of the group's first woman president in 1985 did not weaken. But change looms. Although the association will meet in New Orleans next year on Mother's Day _ lots of distractions there, too _ in the following three years the session will be on other weekends in May. ``I think it's very likely we'll not be scheduling any more meetings on Mother's Day,'' said Dr. Elissa Benedek, the organization's president-elect. And this year the Ann Arbor, Mich., psychiatrist has a solution: she's bringing her four kids with her.

DOC.HEAD: Matheney Sentenced to Death for Murder of Ex-Wife During Prison Furlough
DOC.TEXT: A man who used the hours of a brief prison furlough to murder his former wife was sentenced today to die in the electric chair after he told a judge she was to blame for her death. Alan L. Matheney was condemned by Lake Superior Court Judge James E. Letsinger for the beating death of Lisa M. Bianco. Matheney, 39, stood silently as Letsinger read the sentence. Moments earlier, Matheney had blamed Ms. Bianco herself for her slaying, saying she had conspired with St. Joseph County Prosecutor Michael Barnes to imprison him unjustly. He had been in prison for attacking her at the time of the furlough. ``It was the illegal acts these two people did to me that led to the acts of March 4,'' the day Ms. Bianco was beaten to death in 1989, Matheney said. The death stirred widespread outrage among advocates for battered women, in part because prison officials admitted they had failed to notify Ms. Bianco that the furlough had been approved, despite her requests for such notice. After the couple's 1985 divorce, Matheney was sentenced to two years for criminal confinement for taking the children out of state. In 1987, he was arrested for attacking Ms. Bianco and pleaded guilty to assault in exchange for the dismissal of rape and confinement charges. No execution date was set. The conviction and death sentence will be appealed automatically to the Indiana Supreme Court. The victim's father, Eugene Bianco, said he was pleased with the sentence. ``I just hope they carry it out, and I'm there to pull the switch,'' he said. Letsinger, a special judge in the case, could have sentenced Matheney to a maximum 80-year prison term if he had not ordered the death penalty. Matheney was convicted April 11. Matheney's attorney, Scott L. King, said prior to the sentencing that his client was emotionally disturbed and unable to control himself when he beat Ms. Bianco to death. ``This was a crime of passion,'' said King, disputing prosecutors' contentions that the crime was coldly planned. Matheney had violated the terms of his pass and an earlier court order when he left central Indiana during his furlough, bound for Ms. Bianco's home in Mishawaka in the northern part of the state. After a brief confrontation in the house, he chased Ms. Bianco into the street and clubbed her with an unloaded shotgun outside a neighbor's house. The state's prison furlough program was suspended after her death and later reinstated with tightened restrictions that would have prevented Matheney's release.

DOC.HEAD: John Paul Prays For Plane Crash Victims
LaserColor XMON1, LaserPhoto XMON2,3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th, `The crowd...' to CORRECT that pope on eight-day visit, sted crowd drawn on eighth day of visit. Pickup 14th, `Without denying...'
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II prayed today for pilgrims who died in a plane crash while on their way to see him, assuring mourning relatives that ``death is not the last word'' for those who have faith. ``Although human words don't have much value, in these moments of sorrow I want to express that I actively share in the suffering,'' the pontiff said in a hastily scheduled stop at this city's bone-white Colonial cathedral. The plane that crashed Thursday had been carrying pilgrims to see the pope at Tuxtla Gutierrez. The 28 dead included the bishop of Tapachula, a city near the border with Guatemala. The pope had not been scheduled to enter the cathedral, but a brief memorial was arranged so he could pray for the victims and comfort their families.
