The pope prayed and kissed the Bishop Luis Miguel Canton Marin's coffin, then spoke to and blessed a group of 16 weeping mourners. ``Death is not the last word, because for those who have faith, life does not end, it transforms itself,'' the pope said. ``Illuminated and aided by that truth, we raise our petition to the Lord for those who died and invoke consolation for those who mourn their loved ones,'' John Paul said. The pontiff sprinkled holy water on the bishop's coffin and spoke individually to 16 mourners, many of whom burst into tears. ``We have faith we will see him again,'' said Rogelio Gutierrez, the bishop's brother-in-law. The pope then proceeded to a scheduled outdoor service, where he addressed a huge crowd that included refugees from Guatemala fleeing repression in their native country. The pope's visit to Tuxtla Gutierrez, 425 miles southeast of Mexico City, was partly designed to counter expanding Protestant sects, which are finding fertile ground in the hopeless poverty of the peasants and those who have moved to neighborhoods of shacks in the cities. On Thursday, John Paul criticized family planning and materialism as he hopscotched across northern Mexico, telling a crowd of more than 500,000 that workers should not become cogs ``in an immense production machine.'' The crowd, the largest the pope had drawn on his eight-day trip to Mexico, gathered Thursday evening in Monterrey, the nation's third largest city, to hear a homily entitled ``The Sanctification of Work.'' ``Without denying the good results obtained ... where a free system reigns,'' he said, ``we still cannot be blind to the defects of an economic system that not infrequently makes riches and consumption its principal engine.'' The throng, gathered on a riverbed and surrounding hills, roared and waved acres of flags and pennants as the pontiff spoke. Above the altar was a billboard reading ``Welcome, John Paul II,'' flanked by two ads for Carta Blanca beer, one of the city's largest industries. Earlier Thursday, in Chihuahua, John Paul criticized this largely Roman Catholic country's family planning program, called for freedom of religious education and demanded greater parental input on sex education in public schools. The crowds in Chihuahua and Monterrey included many U.S. residents; the two cities are respectively 225 and 100 miles from the border with Texas. In Chihuahua, the pope launched an impassioned attack on artificial contraception, a controversial issue in Mexico, which has one of the Third World's most succesful family planning programs and where the church is banned from taking political positions. ``If, in the conjugal union, the possibility of conceiving a child is artificially eliminated, the couple closed themselves to God and opposed his will,'' John Paul said. On Wednesday, the pope had linked materialism and contraception by saying that materialism is often the force behind population control efforts. Mexico's family planning program has helped cut the population growth rate from nearly 3.7 percent in 1977 to 1.9 percent, according to government figures. Government health clinics distribute contraceptives and perform vasectomies, but abortion is illegal. Nearly half of married women use contraceptives, according to International Planned Parenthood figures. Still, the population has increased nearly 30 percent since John Paul first visited in 1979, reaching 85 million. The pope's position has attracted hostile comments in a country where infant mortality, illiteracy and malnutrition are severe problems.

DOC.HEAD: Landlady Battles Drugs, Foreclosure in Housing Struggle
LaserPhoto AX3
DOC.TEXT: Sandra Hartman, a pistol-packing landlady, banged on the open apartment door with her .380-caliber automatic and peered in at the litter of cocaine bags and razors lying among broken toys. ``Maintenance. Anybody here?'' she called, crunching broken glass underfoot as she made sure no one was hiding in the apartment. ``Look at this, they've been burning in here,'' she said, pointing to carpet burns and blackened aluminum cans, more evidence of cocaine. ``But I could fix this place up, this apartment, real easy _ the cabinets are still here and the floor's OK _ for about $5,000.'' Gordon Valley is 200 bullet-riddled, low-cost apartments in a seedy section of Martin Luther King Jr. Drive. It's also the newest stop on Ms. Hartman's daily _ and nightly _ patrols of her 11 low-cost apartment complexes. Wearing her bulletproof vest, Mrs. Hartman evicts drug users and pushers, disperses loiterers and punishes litterers. She says it's the only way to keep the ``good tenants.'' During a visit in December, U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp praised Mrs. Hartman's anti-drug approach to housing. But she says she will lose all her properties unless someone in the government lends a hand. In a city where 20 percent of low-cost housing is substandard and more than 700 people are on the Atlanta Housing Authority's waiting list for openings, Ms. Hartman has a reputation as a firm but just landlady. ``Ms. Hartman, she'll work with you,'' said Ann Parks, who has lived at Oak Valley Court, a complex that won a federal Rental Rehabilitation award, for a year. ``I help, though. When they fight out here, I talk to both sides to try to stop it. I say this neighborhood ought to get along together.'' Ms. Hartman spends about $10,000 a month on 24-hour security for the complexes. She has fenced in the largest, Overlook Atlanta, where tenants say they now feel secure. ``One time, a lot of young kids would be hanging around the corner all day, and you know what they were doing, with their gold chains on and their cars with the gold trim,'' said Donna Dawson, who has lived at the complex two years. ``Now, the tenants are real proud at how clean it is.'' Ms. Hartman doesn't believe she can stop drug trafficking. The traffic from Overlook Atlanta simply moved across the street to a convenience store, she says. And one dealer _ known to tenants as Frog _ has managed to elude her. ``He was hassling me one day,'' Ms. Dawson said. ``He said he was going to shoot me. But he's not as big as he'd like us to think he is.'' Other dealers repeatedly have threatened her. Ms. Hartman, 41, bought her first low-cost complex eight years ago. Three years later, she had 1,400 units throughout the city and a 5 percent vacancy rate. Drug-related evictions have dropped her occupancy rate to about 30 percent. She lost her own home and 122 units to foreclosure this year and hasn't made mortgage payments on some complexes since January. She expects a response on her request for federal aid, including a moratorium on back payments, within the month. Without it, she says she could lose everything. ``If I don't get the (mortgage) payments reduced, all the efforts I've made, risking my life, all I've done for my tenants and my kids will be for nothing because they will be boarded up again,'' Ms. Hartman said. ``How could they allow 1,400 units to be slums again?'' Ms. Hartman has $500,000 in federal funds to renovate Gordon Valley, but no one will lend her the $700,000 more she needs. And Mayor Maynard Jackson hasn't answered her proposal to house the homeless in her projects instead of building more projects, as Jackson has proposed. Ms. Hartman said she has always been a survivor. She left the poor coal-mining town near St. Louis where she grew up with $60 and no college education. She came to Atlanta, succeeded in real estate and opened her own firm, Hartman Investment Co. ``I believe in what I'm doing. I know I can provide safe, affordable housing for people,'' she said. ``If I give up, I lose and they lose. If somebody would listen to me, we all could win.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The designer Mr. Blackwell, best known for his annual worst-dressed celebrity lists, had his face redesigned Friday. The 60-something-year-old designer underwent a $20,000 ``complete face sculpturing,'' including cheekbone augmentation, eye restoration, removal of silicone from previous cosmetic surgery and regluing of his nose, said publicist Michael Sands. Regluing of his nose? Blackwell, whose real name is Richard Sylvan Seltzer, had a nose job previously and it got out of line recently when he bumped his schnoz, Sands said. Blackwell, who won't reveal his age except to say he's ``under 100,'' said in a telephone interview from the plastic surgeon's office: ``You take in a dress if it's a little big, don't you? Well, it's a little big.'' The six-hour surgery was videotaped for airing on a medical show, Sands said. ``We will have an unveiling later. He will look like he did when he was young.'' The caustic Blackwell, who in the past designed clothes for Marilyn Monroe and Zsa Zsa Gabor, has heaped disdain on celebrity fashion frumps for 30 years.

Comedian John Cleese and his second wife, Barbara Trentham, were divorced Friday. Publicist Theo Cowen quoted the former Monty Python star as saying the couple's two-year trial separation ``had gone so well they decided to make it permanent.'' Cleese, 50, did not contest the petition filed by Ms. Trentham, 44, according to the news agency Press Association. The couple had no children. The two wed in 1981, three years after Cleese divorced Connie Booth, his co-writer and co-star on the television series ``Fawlty Towers.'' Both of his ex-wives are Americans.

Sportscaster Brent Musburger says journalists should bypass public relations people and go directly to the source of stories. ``To me, the entire notion of ballclubs or individual players issuing statements through public relations people is laughable,'' he told about 350 people at the University of Montana on Thursday night. Musburger, who was fired by CBS last month and recently signed a contract with ABC Sports, said he spoke from experience. When journalists reported his firing, Musburger said, many accepted the version presented by CBS spokesmen and failed to call him directly. Musburger was in Missoula this week to receive an honorary doctorate of humane letters from the university. Musburger is a Billings native and owns a ranch near Big Timber.

Gov. Gaston Caperton and Rachael Worby, conductor of the Wheeling Symphony, announced Friday they plan to get married in a small ceremony later this month. The couple made the announcement at a news conference at Oglebay Park Amphitheater, where the orchestra appears during the summer. Ms. Worby said she didn't think her first lady obligations would affect her conducting duties. ``I intend to be music director for the Wheeling Symphony for as long as everyone in the Ohio Valley wants me,'' she said. ``She'll do a great job, a great job,'' the Democratic governor said. Ms. Worby said she plans to keep her name as well as her Wheeling home. The governor's mansion is in Charleston. The announcement comes less than seven months after Caperton and his wife, Dee, divorced. They had been married 23 years. Her fraud lawsuit against him was settled for a reported $11 million.

Filmmaker Spike Lee drew a crowd of 2,000 _ and a bomb threat _ for a lecture at the University of Georgia. Lee's informal talk at The Coliseum on Thursday night was delayed about 45 minutes while police inspected the arena and found nothing. ``This is my second bomb threat this year,'' Lee told the students. Lee, director of films including ``Do The Right Thing'' and ``She's Gotta Have It,'' said he is starting to feel a bit put upon by the media scrutiny. ``Because there are so few black filmmakers out there, I've been elevated to this level of a messiah,'' he said. ``And I'm really uncomfortable with that. It's not something I've asked for.'' One student criticized Lee for endorsing a brand of athletic shoes when some young people have been killed by thieves for their expensive sneakers. ``In my heart, I have no problem endorsing a product I wear,'' Lee said.

Catherine Cookson, one of Britain's most popular romantic novelists, is in satisfactory condition after suffering a heart attack, a hospital said Friday. The 84-year-old author was stricken on May 5 but an announcement was withheld until her condition stabilized, said a Hexham General Hospital official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mrs. Cookson has written more than 80 novels since publishing her first 40 years ago. A survey last year of the 100 most-borrowed books from British libraries found that 35 were written by Mrs. Cookson.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Nine-time Emmy-winning sports director Chet Forte acknowledged he is a compulsive gambler after pleading innocent Friday to federal tax and mail charges. Forte, 54, is accused of two counts of mail fraud, six counts of transporting stolen property across state lines and failure to file a federal income tax return in 1987. U.S. District Judge Joseph H. Rodriguez set a July 2 trial date. Forte, who directed or produced ABC coverage of such events as ``Monday Night Football,'' the 1968 and 1984 Olympics and the World Series, told reporters after the hearing that he has been unable to find a job in the television industry because of his gambling addiction. ``Gamblers don't wake up until it's too late,'' said Forte. Forte's attorney, Lawrence Lustberg, said his client's debts are ``in the million-dollar area.'' Forte left ABC in 1987 to become an independent director and producer.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Party Quits Parliament to Protest Attacks
DOC.TEXT: One of the three leading parties walked out of Romania's makeshift parliament Friday to protest recent violent attacks on opposition leaders. The National Peasant Party's pullout symbolized the growing tension before Romania's first free elections in more than 50 years, planned for May 20. Anti-government protesters seeking the resignation of former Communists, including interim President Ion Iliescu, demonstrated for the 20th straight day in downtown Bucharest. About 5,000 government supporters rallied a half-mile away. On Thursday, the United States announced it was recalling its ambassador because of concerns the elections will not be entirely free and fair. Ion Diaconescu, vice president of the Peasant Party, told a session of the Provisional Council of National Unity, the interim parliament, that his group was withdrawing its three deputies. Two other deputies joined the Peasant Party in the pullout. It was prompted by opposition accusations that the dominant National Salvation Front is behind recent attacks on its opponents and is using its leading position to manipulate state funds and the media. In an afternoon session, parliament scrapped a 1978 decree that placed the state radio and television under government control. Opposition members have claimed the government has interfered with independent broadcasting. Until the elections, radio and television will be subject to control by the provisional parliament. The Peasant Party was one of Romania's main political parties before World War II and claims to have attracted some 600,000 members since Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted by a popular revolt in December. On Wednesday, Ion Ratiu, the Peasants' candidate for president in the May election, joined with another opposition leader, Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party, in offering to withdraw from the race. The two said they would pull out if Iliescu also withdrew and agreed that the president be elected by the new parliament instead of by direct ballot. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front are favored to win both the presidential and parliamentary votes. In a letter made public Friday, Iliescu said the Front rejects any monopoly on power and seeks a ruling coalition to steer Romania out of its political and economic chaos. ``We don't claim to possess absolute truths, but we do not have wonder solutions either,'' Iliescu said. He suggested that the Front, a loose coalition of intellectuals and disaffected Communists, was the target of unfair accusations that it seeks to re-establish Marxist rule. ``The anxiety felt by public opinion across the nation is caused by exclusivist slogans, obsessively recited untruths and sincere or fake fears apt to generate uncontrollable evolutions toward chaos and violence,'' the 60-year-old interim leader said. Ratiu and Campeanu both have been physically attacked during electoral rallies in southeastern Romania in the past two weeks. While they did not directly blame the Front for the attacks, some Romanian newspapers said the assaults were meant to discourage opposition and the electorate in the May vote, which is to be the country's first free elections since 1937. The U.S. Embassy, in a statement issued Friday, said Ambassador Alan Green was being called to Washington to give his account of the campaign and underlined that fair, free elections were crucial to developing good ties.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Have Biggest Setback in Six Months
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales, held back by another big drop in auto demand, fell 0.6 percent in April, the biggest setback in six months, the government said Friday. The Commerce Department said sales fell to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion last month after a 0.2 percent decline in March and no change in February. Disappointed private economists, who had been hoping for a small rebound in activity, warned that the lackluster sales would likely translate into slower economic growth in the months ahead as businesses face growing inventories of unsold products. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity, has been the driving force during much of the economic recovery in its eighth year, a record for peacetime. ``We have now had three months in a row of weak retail sales,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The consumer is fading from the scene.'' Sandra Shaber, senior economist at the Futures Group, said that at this stage of the recovery there is little pent-up demand left. ``The most disturbing trend here is the weakness in department store sales. That's a pretty good indicator of the overall mood'' of consumers, she said. Analysts said that unless consumer spending weakens further, the country should still be able to avoid a recession, although the predicted overall growth as measured by the gross national product, would expand at a sluggish pace of 2 percent this year. The 0.6 percent April decline in retail sales was the largest monthly drop since a 1.4 percent plunge in October. The March and April declines marked the first time retail sales have posted consecutive monthly declines in almost three years. The biggest drag on activity came from auto sales, which dropped 2.7 percent. It marked the sixth time in the last seven months that car sales have fallen. Analysts said that was particularly worrisome because it was coming at a time when auto companies were offering heavy incentives to reduce inventories. ``The consumer has clearly backed off,'' said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, a consulting company in Lexington, Mass. ``The incentives are costing car companies a lot of money and sales are still weak.'' Even without the big drop in car sales, spending in other retail areas was weak. Sales at general department stores were off 0.7 percent in April after an even bigger 1.2 percent drop in March. The late Easter had been expected to boost sales in early April. Sales at hardware and building supply stores dropped 2.6 percent in April after an 0.8 percent decrease the previous month. Sales at gasoline stations fell by 1 percent. Restaurant sales were off by 0.2 percent, while sales at speciality clothing stores were down 1.9 percent. In the only major areas showing gains, sales at furniture and home furnishing stores edged up 0.4 percent while sales at drug stores posted a 1.2 percent gain.

DOC.HEAD: Man, Couple Stay, But Prepare to Flee
With AM-Floods-Tourism, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From his vantage point on the edge of a flood-swollen lake, Royce Fikes can look in a 360-degree circle and see nothing but water. Fikes, 74, is a solitary sentry against a raging waterway _ the Trinity River. The river was forced from its banks by record flooding in north and east Texas that killed 12 people in the state and caused hundreds of millions of dollars in damage. Authorities in southeast Texas expect the river to crest there next week. Fikes, a resident of the community of Sportsman's Paradise on the upper end of Lake Livingston, about 80 miles north of Houston, uses a boat to get around the flooded homes and trailers abandoned there. Most of his neighbors have left, he said late Thursday. ``Some of us is trying to hang around and more or less try to watch after the place,'' he said. Guarding against the ever-present threat of looters, some using boats, is his big worry, he said. ``If the water gets up real far, we can cut the electricity off,'' he said. Until then, he said, he watches television and answers an occasional telephone call. His car is underwater, so when it's time to check out one of the 25 scattered homes in the development, he goes by boat. ``I have been going out fishing some, too,'' he said. ``But the fish are not fighting too good. The water is too swift. I won't get into that fast-moving water.'' In another flood-stricken community near the lake, Vivian and E.L. Butler are also prepared to flee their mobile home if they feel endangered. The waters have reached her yard, but still are not near her home, said Mrs. Butler. ``I'm naturally nervous and watching it real close and don't intend to stay if it gets bad,'' she said. ``Right now I love it here and I wouldn't move unless it forces me out,'' said Mrs. Butler, who retired to Sportsman's Paradise with her husband. The Butlers are among a small group sticking it out on the highest ground in the subdivision. The lakeside property has flooded before, but this time, the waters are expected to keep the area isolated for weeks. John Jadrosich of the Trinity River Authority said the region from Lake Livingston south to Liberty, midway between Houston and Beaumont, could be flooded throughout the summer and into the fall. Mrs. Butler said the couple has a boat standing ready with life jackets, food and clothing in case they need to flee. ``I've put all my valuable papers and whatnot up in the bank. I've got pictures and my Bible in a metal box to take in the boat with me _ things that I don't want to lose,'' she said. ``We've moved everything up off the floor in case the water gets up high. We're just going to play it by ear.'' Trinity County Judge Jimmie Thornton said he and other officials also will patrol the area by boat to prevent looting. The lake is expected to reach about 7 feet above its normal level, Thornton said. ``This flooding limit was designed for the hundred year flood, and it looks like that's what we're getting,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Taxes-Budget
DOC.TEXT: Here is the transcript of President Bush's question and answer session with reporters aboard Air Force One today. President Bush: I'm certainly looking forward to this visit to Texas. Q: Well maybe you could help us. Q: We need help. A: I'm not sure I can help anybody. Q: There seems to be so much confusion these days over what your lips are reading on the subject of taxes. A: Well, why don't you just listen to what I say and see what we do. And there's no subject _ the question is there's no conditions. That's the way it is, that's the way it's going to be, and that's the way it must be. And so people can talk all day long, pointing prematurely to discussion of one subject or another, and I'll simply repeat that I have made this proposal that we meet with no conditions, and that's exactly the way it's going to be. And we're hearing comments from you people _ by that I mean astute journalists _ wanting to probe beyond where I'm ready to speak. We're hearing comments from the political left, middle, center, right. And my position is: I've made this offer to sit down in good faith and talk with no conditions, and that's exactly the way it's going to be. Q: Did your chief of staff accurately reflect your posture, though, when he said. ... A: I would ask you to reflect my posture to talk about what I say, and I've spelled it out just as well as I possibly can, just as clearly. And tomorrow there'll be a flap on something else, and the next day a flap on something else. But I am determined to address this problem in good faith in the way I've told you. So I would respectfully suggest you take your guidance from me on this one, because that's the way it is. Q:How are you going to be able to get to Mars in 30 years since we're hobbled by. ... A: (With a laugh) Going to have to go fairly fast, it's a long way out there. Q: How about financially, how are you going to do it? A: Well 30 years is a long time. Q: Did Speaker Foley seem concerned yesterday when you talked to him? Is he getting conflicting signals? A: Yeah, you know, I keep reading that I called Foley to talk about this, but then, in fairness to Foley, he explained the way it was. I wasn't concerned about that, and he was. Yes, he did express concern, and I think he expressed it at a press conference. But I think he sees the need to go forward on the basis I have called for, and I respect him for that. Q: Mr. President, is it your posture that if taxes are to be discussed. ... A: Look, Frank, you can come at me all day long. That would not be dealing in good faith to _ to _- if I started going into these details. I'm not going to do it. Q: Let me ask you one other. ...- A: Nice try! Q: Do you feel that it's inevitable that the Gramm-Rudman targets are going to have to be stretched out in this process, that the budget cannot. ... A: I'm approaching this with the idea that we can, if everybody comes together, we can solve some significant problems out there. So I'm not prejudging anything. Q: Do you still think the budget can be balanced by '93? A: Well, I think this is certainly an objective, and we want to go forward and deal in good faith. And I think everyone realizes something ought to be done, so let's see if we can get something done. But, you know, I don't contribute to it if I start talking about my approach or what I think is the right way to do it and try to dictate to anybody. But I'll be there with no preconditions, and then we'll have a good negotiating team and see where we go. So tomorrow there'll be another tidal wave, so keep your snorkel above the water level and do what you think is right. It goes back to what my mom taught me when I was about six: Do your best, do your best. Well, I'm trying hard to stay calm. ...- Q: Mr. President? A: Yes? Q: Is Governor Sununu in trouble? A: (With a chuckle) This so silly! This is so stupid! (Scattered laughter.) None of these congressmen are in trouble, either. I'm approaching it in _ very openly, and I recognize there's controversy swirling around from one statement or another. But look, stay on track; stay steady as she goes and be open, deal frankly with people, and to deal in the way I said: no preconditions. That doesn't _ I'm not going to show you my hand, and I haven't seen a lot of hands being laid down up on the Hill, but that's the way it ought to be. If we're going to get anywhere, there's some tough decisions out there and we've got to discuss them, discuss everything. Q: Has the deficit problem degenerated to the point that it really presents the country with almost an economic crisis situation? A: No, I wouldn't say that at all. I noticed the very salutary prediction yesterday about continued growth from some of the leading financial experts in the country. And so that's good. We're not dealing in a crisis mentality. But we've got a major deficit problem, and we've got a law that says where it has to be, the deficit. And I'm determined to fulfill my obligations to comply with that law. But we're going to need cooperation because isn't going to be easy. It's going to be very difficult, and people will be charged and countercharged, but you can't be thin-skinned in a business like this. I can't react to every charge or some flamboyant congressman up there blasting me. I mean that's not _ I don't think that's the way a president should conduct himself. Q:Do you have any message for the 19 senators who wrote you or the conservatives who. ... A: No. Say _ hey, listen. Say what you think. Democrats, Republicans, leaders, back-benchers, columnists, anybody. Say what you think. But I think the president has a certain responsibility to stay cool and make clear to people that he's dealing in good faith, and do my best. And that's exactly what I intend to do. And I can't be ruffled by these things, or I've got to be understanding when people come forward and express themselves forcefully on something or other. Q Would you call on the American people now and prepare them somehow to share the sacrifice, to take the steps. ... A: Well, I think we've got to _ if we can hammer out a deal, I certainly will make clear that we support it. So, let's wait and see what happens. Q: Is there any way out of this without raising revenues? A: We'll see what happens. We'll just go there and discuss everything. That's the way we're going to do it. Open agenda. Open. And that's the only way you can get strong-willed people to the table, in good faith. And that's the way it will be. Q: Do you have a timetable. ... A: And now if I'd only get going, I might get to Texas A&I before you guys do, or a little later. (Laughter.) President Bush: I hope I've been able to clarify all this for you. Thank you. ... END TEXT

DOC.HEAD: Jupiter-Bound Galileo Spacecraft Fires Thrusters
DOC.TEXT: The Galileo spacecraft, looping through the solar system on the way to its 1995 exploration of Jupiter, fired its thrusters today in a major maneuver meant to steer it near Earth late this year. ``We're trying to reshape the trajectory slightly so we move closer and closer to our aim point near Earth on Dec. 8,'' said Neal Ausman, mission director at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Galileo's tiny rocket thrusters, which are small enough to fit in the palm of a hand, started firing at 11:10 a.m. PDT and will fire roughly 3,000 times by the time the maneuver ends Saturday afternoon, laboratory spokesman Jim Wilson said. The two-day maneuver will slow the spacecraft, which was traveling about 66,000 mph earlier today, by about 25 mph. It also will gradually alter its direction, Ausman said. It is the second of three or four maneuvers needed to bring Galileo within 1,000 miles of Earth, which will act as a gravity slingshot to help expand the spacecraft's orbit around the sun and propel it toward Jupiter, he added. Without maneuvers, the spacecraft would miss Earth by 1.5 million miles. As of today, Galileo was 96 million miles from Earth, but has traveled a looping path of 365 million miles since it was launched from space shuttle Atlantis last Oct. 18. Its trip to Jupiter will total 2.4 billion miles. Galileo will make a second swing past Earth in December 1992. It flew past Venus in another gravity slingshot maneuver on Feb. 9. In July 1995, the spacecraft separates into a 4,890-pound orbiter and a 760-pound probe. They are scheduled to reach Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet, on Dec. 7, 1995. The probe will plunge into the planet's atmosphere, relaying measurements to the orbiter before the probe is destroyed by intense atmospheric pressure. The orbiter will spend at least two years studying and taking snapshots of Jupiter and its major moons Europa, Ganymede and Callisto.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buy More U.S. Wheat
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 250,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month, the Agriculture Department said Friday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat was sold by two private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Dickerson said 313,950 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price subsidy program. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought more than 3.5 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and 13.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. In 1988-89, the sixth year of the agreement, the Soviet Union bought about 5.4 million tons of wheat and more than 16.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans, soybean meal and grain sorghums. All but about 700,000 tons of the wheat was bought under EEP. A metric tons is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 250,000 tons are equal to nearly 9.2 million bushels worth about $32 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Dickerson reported the subsidies at an average of $18.18 per ton, or about 50 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest wheat was sold by Cargill Inc., 185,000 tons; and Central States Enterprises, 65,000 tons.

DOC.HEAD: Little Church That Bought Crack Houses Gets Compliments, But Needs Hard Cash
LaserPhoto NU3
With AM-Pistol-Packing Landlady, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A little church that bought seven crack houses to turn them into affordable apartments has received praise from the federal drug czar but still needs more than $62,000 to complete its task. ``We have borrowed to our capacity. We can't borrow any more,'' said Benjamin Edwards Jr., executive treasurer of Third Shiloh Missionary Baptist Church. ``If we didn't put up our own money I could understand. But we put up our own money.'' A year ago, the church voted to use its own $175,000 building fund _ 20 years' worth of church dinners, car washes and Sunday collection offerings _ to buy the abandoned duplex houses. The 25-year-old cinderblock church is buckling, and Edwards figures it will last only three to four years at best. But across the street, four unfinished duplexes testify to work put in by the church, which has about 80 active members and 220 others who show up for occasional services. More than 80 families have signed up for the 14 unfinished units. ``We have people stopping here every day who want to rent the apartments. But we just had to stop taking applications,'' said Edwards. Third Shiloh hopes to have the first two duplexes finished by early June. ``We're rolling around the clock. We're working up to 10 at night, then coming out at 4, 5 in the morning to try to get it completed,'' Edwards said. ``When you all bought those houses and nailed them up and fixed them up, I said, `Oh, boy, what a relief,''' Benjamin Brown, an elderly man who lives across from the church, told Edwards. Four of the houses are on Piety Street, separated only by a chain-link fence from the Desire housing project _ one of the city's worst. Brown and Oscar Robertson, whose house is next door to the church, said that two summers ago their street was full of people buying or selling cocaine. After a particularly rough Fourth of July weekend, police SWAT teams hauled out many of the dealers and patrolled the area, Brown and Robertson said. ``Police were walking out here with rifles on their backs like it was Vietnam,'' said Robertson. When the church decided to buy the houses last year, it estimated it would cost about $240,000 to purchase and renovate them. It borrowed $71,000 in addition to its building fund and began work. Church members cut down the 6-foot-high weeds that had grown around the houses. They hauled away stairs to make it harder for vandals to get into the houses, which stand on 4{-foot pilings to be safe from floods. Concrete foundations were dug and poured. Much of the work is being done by volunteers, helped out by formerly unemployed workers who say they will work for whatever wages the church can pay them. The contractor, a former member of the church, has deferred payment until the project is done, Edwards said. The houses turned out to need a lot more work than first thought, Edwards said. The roofs and many walls had to be replaced. The houses also held tiny one- and two-bedroom apartments, with kitchens hardly big enough to turn around in. The congregation decided to build 25-foot-long additions to each building, doubling the kitchen floor space and adding a bedroom and utility room to each apartment. Edwards estimated this week that the church needs at least $62,500 to complete the work. The church has applied for $72,000 in federal renovation money _ the maximum it is eligible to apply for. But Edward said he hasn't heard anything. Edwards does have a nice note of from federal drug czar William Bennett, along with a page from a speech in which he commended the church as an example of the sort of private initiative needed to fight drugs. The Hearst Foundation has given $10,000, Freeport McMoRan Inc. $2,500 and the Riley Foundation $5,000, with an offer of $5,000 more if the church can find an equal amount. But all other contributions from outside the congregation have been from private citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Matsunaga Honored With Table
DOC.TEXT: The late Sen. Spark Matsunaga, D-Hawaii, was honored Friday as only a senator could be: A table in the Senators' Dining Room in the Capitol was named in his memory. The Senate adopted a resolution designating the ``Spark M. Matsunaga Table'' to memorialize his ``exemplary diligence, legendary warmth, compassion, courage and firm devotion to American ideals.'' During his 13 years in the Senate, Matsunaga provided a service to constituents that visitors from other states could only envy. He personally tried to provide a guided tour of the Capitol to every visiting Hawaiian and to take them to lunch at the center table in the Senators' Dining Room. Matsunaga died of cancer last month.

DOC.HEAD: Plans Take Shape for Wedding of Emperor's Son
DOC.TEXT: There won't be any walk down the aisle, organ music or kissing at the altar when the emperor's youngest son ties the knot next month. His imperial parents aren't even invited. But there will be rice _ of the fermented, drinkable sort _ and plenty of pomp. In one of the final formalities before the ceremony, imperial messenger Yasuo Shigeta, dressed in a gray morning coat and carrying a silk top hat, called on Prince Aya's fiancee, Kiko Kawashima, and her parents at their home Friday to inform them the royal nuptials will be June 29. Miss Kawashima lives with her parents and younger brother in an apartment on the campus of Gakushuin University. She is a student of psychology at the university, and her father, Tatsuhiko, teaches economics there. Gakushuin is also Aya's alma mater and is where he met the 23-year-old Kiko. Aya, 24, will be the first imperial family member to marry since Emperor Akihito's cousin, Prince Norihito, wed in December 1984. Aya is next in line to the throne after his brother, Crown Prince Naruhito, who is 30 and has yet to choose a bride. The marriage date was unofficially selected soon after Aya's engagement received unanimous approval in September by the Imperial Household Council, a 10-member body headed by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Details of how the government plans to conduct the wedding and parties afterward, for which it has alloted roughly $1 million, remained vague until a palace announcement this month. The short ceremony will begin at mid-morning at a shrine to the sun goddess Amaterasu, from whom legend says the imperial line descends. Like most of the wooded palace behind a moat and closely guarded gates, few commoners have ever seen the wooden shrines, which are looked after by the emperor's private ritualists. The newlyweds, wearing silk robes similar to ancient court attire, will be joined in marriage by sipping sacred rice wine from a lacquered cup. In the afternoon, they will formally greet the emperor and Empress Michiko at the palace and inform them of the marriage. Kaifu, top government officials and other domestic dignitaries and foreign ambassadors will be invited to palace receptions the following day. Members of the old peerage will gather at the palace July 1. Palace officials refuse to disclose the number of guests who will be invited. For those well-wishers whose station in life does not warrant an invitation, a register will be set up outside the palace. After a reception for friends and classmates of the couple is held July 2, Aya and his bride will travel to the Grand Shrines of Ise, the center of sun goddess worship in Japan's indigenous Shinto religion. They will also pay their respects at the tomb of Aya's grandfather, the late Emperor Hirohito, and Japan's first emperor, Jimmu, who according to myth ascended in 660 B.C. In hopes that other young couples may want to imitate the royal pair, a Tokyo kimono school has begun renting a $320,000 kimono patterned after the 12-layered one Miss Kawashima will wear. Getting into the bulky garment, which weighs about 50 pounds, can take up to three hours. For the past two years Aya has been studying zoology _ he has a particular interest in catfish _ at Britain's Oxford University, and he is not expected to return to Japan until less than two weeks before the ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Census: Cities Contemplate New Suit
DOC.TEXT: Officials of major cities are considering filing a second lawsuit against the Census Bureau over what they fear will be serious omissions in this year's national head count. Hulbert James, an assistant to New York Mayor David Dinkins, said Friday that there have been serious discussions of such a lawsuit because of potential differences between census counts and those of local governments. James' comments came after a meeting of the census committee of the U.S. Conference of Mayors. Jessica Heinz of the Los Angeles city attorney's office said talk of a new lawsuit may be premature, although her city also has concerns about differences with the bureau. Lance Simmens, a staff members of the mayor's group, speculated that the census undercount could climb to 15 percent. In 1980, only about 1.4 percent of Americans were not counted. Peter Bounpane, deputy census director, promptly disputed the Simmens' figure and said the comment was not appropriate. ``The census isn't over yet,'' Bounpane said. ``We had a plan and we are still following it. The only thing that happened is that fewer people mailed back than budgeted, which means we have to hire more people and spend more money,'' he said. The bureau had anticipated 70 percent of Americans would respond by mail, and so far only 63 percent have done so. That means an extra $180 million or more to hire people to go door-to-door, a process that is expected to continue for several weeks. James echoed Bounpane's comment that the count is not over, and said many city officials are engaged in efforts to encourage their residents to cooperate with census takers. One concern, James said, is to make sure that city and census officials cooperate during the census follow-up that will start in late summer _ especially in asking people if they were counted and finding those who were missed. Procedures for that cooperation, and making sure that the census bureau has done everything possible to count everyone, could be the focus of the new lawsuit, James said. A pending suit filed by several local governments wants to require that the final figures be adjusted to include people who were missed. A new suit would be separate, James said, focusing on the counting process rather than adjustment.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aide Rejects Soviet Arms Offer; Naval Chief Hints at Interest
DOC.TEXT: A senior U.S. arms control negotiator Friday rejected a Soviet plea for talks on cutting tactical nuclear weapons at sea, although the Navy's chief officer told Congress such negotiations ``could be in our interests.'' The top arms adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Congress on Tuesday that future talks on other nuclear and conventional weapons could be derailed by continued U.S. resistence to naval arms talks. Ronald Lehman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, told a Senate panel that the Soviets had not formally insisted on linking naval weapons with other arms, even though Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev raised it before Congress, and so the United States isn't compelled to respond. ``We have come to the conclusion that now is not the time'' to address the issue, said Lehman. Lehman said the administration remained optimistic it could reach agreement with Moscow on the main provisions of a treaty cutting long-range nuclear weapons before Gorbachev arrives in Washington May 30 for a summit meeting. The U.S. has said progress on the treaty has slowed in recent weeks. ``We see no reason why we shouldn't be able to get an agreement'' next week when Secretary of State James A. Baker III meets Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Moscow, said Lehman. Gorbachev proposed at his meeting with Bush in Malta last December that the superpowers negotiate cuts in short-range naval nuclear arms, but the administration has resisted. Bush has said such cuts would undermine America's position as the predominant maritime power. Lehman said the Bush administration saw no way negotiated reductions in short-range naval nuclear arms _ mainly torpedoes, depth bombs and anti-ship missiles _ would strengthen U.S. security. He said it could instead harm the security of U.S. allies. ``We've spent a lot of time studying it and we just haven't found it'' to be in U.S. interests, Lehman told the Armed Services subcommittee on projection forces. But Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost, chief of Naval operations, took a different approach. Although he expressed doubt about Soviet intentions in pursuing such negotiations, Trost said he could contemplate eliminating all tactical naval nuclear arms if related weapons such as bombers assigned to naval fleets also were banned. ``If we could, with proper confidence in their willingness to abide by an agreement, be sure there were no nuclear weapons that threatened either side's ships at sea, I'm sure we'd both be more comfortable that way,'' Trost told the panel. Later, under questioning by Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, who said he opposed such negotiations, Trost said he was referring only to the tactical category of naval weapons, not to sea-based cruise or ballistic missiles of longer range. ``Yes, it could be in our interests if all the `ifs' I previously stated are included,'' Trost said, quickly adding, ``And you could label me as a lifetime pessimist on the likelihood of ever concluding such an agreement.'' Trost is due to retire at the end of June. Trost's description of an acceptable formula for talks to eliminate short-range nuclear arms at sea appeared similar to that offered Tuesday by Akhromeyev, who said his government was willing to include related weaponry such as that carried on aircraft carriers, submarines and land-based naval aircraft. Joshua Handler, an arms analyst with Greenpeace U.S.A., which advocates the elimination of all nuclear weapons, said Trost's comments departed from the Navy's past unconditional opposition to talks on tactical nuclear arms. Trost and Lehman both stressed the administration has been willing to negotiate certain measures short of cutting tactical naval arms. Lehman cited a 1988 agreement to provide advance notice of all launches of strategic ballistic missiles, whether from land or sea. ``It isn't that we're stonewalling,'' on naval nuclear arms, Trost said. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., chairman of the subcommittee, said he could not understand why the administration was willing to deal in all areas of arms control except naval. ``Why aren't we prepared even to talk'' with the Soviets? he asked.

DOC.SECOND: AM-BRF--Plane Blown Over, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0609,0176
DOC.HEAD: Small Plane Blown Off Runway By Jet Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with plane NOT blown over, only blown off runway. NTSB investigates, wind also a factor. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Blasts of air from high winds and a jet blew a commuter airplane off a runway at Kennedy International Airport on Friday, authorities said. No injuries were reported. The two-engine commuter plane, operated by American Eagle, was crossing behind a Northwest Airlines Boeing 747 that was waiting to take off when the accident occurred, said Terry Benczik, an airport official. The smaller plane was flung nose-first into a blast fence, but the only two people aboard, the pilot and co-pilot, walked away and did not require medical attention, authorities said. The plane did not turn over, as reported initially by airport authorities. The jumbo jet took off. The accident occurred at 12:35 p.m., when wind speed was 30 to 45 mph, authorities said. The National Transportation Safety Board has begun an investigation, said Benczik.

DOC.HEAD: Cemetery Desecration Shocks France, Fuels Fears of Racism
LaserPhotos PAR1,3
DOC.TEXT: The desecration of a Jewish cemetery and mutilation of a corpse horrified the nation Friday, reawakening memories of the Holocaust and fueling fears of a resurgence of racism. The French Senate and National Assembly suspended their sessions for 15 minutes, and leaders of all major religious faiths condemned the desecration. Special radio and TV shows were planned, and some channels devoted their entire evening newscasts to the subject. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe said extreme right-wing leader Jean-Marie Le Pen must take some responsibility for the crime. But Le Pen denounced the desecration as ``barbaric'' and said it was likely a sham staged to disgrace him and his National Front, a party that has won 15 percent support in recent opinion polls. Politicians across the political spectrum made pilgrimages to the town of Carpentras, near Avignon, where Jews first settled in the first century. Mourners on Thursday found 34 graves desecrated and the body of an 81-year-old man dug up and impaled on an umbrella. Police detained one man for questioning but provided no details. ``We are making verifications. Don't draw any conclusions,'' an officer said. Families of the dead held an impromptu religious service at the cemetery, and Jewish demonstrators gathered at the gate under the banner: ``We Will Not Let History Repeat Itself.'' ``They impaled Felix, my husband,'' wept Magdeleine Germon. ``They merit being impaled themselves,'' she said. ``Since he was the last buried, they took their revenge on the freshest grave. To impale a dead person. Can you imagine what hate one must have!'' Her husband, buried less than a month ago, was found sprawled across a neighboring tomb stone, impaled on an umbrella stick. A star of David pulled from another grave lay nearby. Grave markers had been knocked over and flower pots trampled. ``It is an aggression against all humanity, a barbarous and bestial act,'' said Israeli Ambassador Obadia Soffer, who visited the cemetery. ``It is also a warning to all civilization for humanity. ... This is a racist act of the first order.'' Police said fingerprints and footprints indicated at least four vandals took part in the desecration, discovered when several mourners visited the cemetery to lay flowers. A previously unknown group calling itself the ``Mohamed El Boukima Group'' claimed responsibility for the crime in an anonymous phone call to a newspaper. Police said they were trying to authenticate the call. Racism has for years been a major issue in France, which is home to more than 4 million immigrants, many from former African colonies. Racism recently returned to the forefront with a series of attacks on Moslems, and it presents the biggest political hurdle for the Socialist government of Premier Michel Rocard. Le Pen's party wants to deport immigrants, and some center-right politicians have taken up the call for tight curbs on immigration. Twenty tombstones recently were overturned at an Israeli cemetery in Strasbourg, the Jewish community there reported Friday, and swastikas were found scrawled on walls in the town of Rambouillet. Serge Klarsfeld, a well-known lawyer and Nazi hunter, said the Carpentras desecration was unprecedented. Even during World War II, he said, the Nazis left Jewish graves alone. Joxe called Le Pen ``racist and provocateur.'' ``Like all racists, like all who express their anti-Semitism in an explicit or implicit fashion, he is obviously one of those responsible ... because of all that has been inspired by racist hate for years,'' Joxe said. Le Pen, who has been convicted of making racist remarks, rejected the claim, saying: ``I don't feel guilty at all.'' He suggested that Communists or subversive Moslem fundamentalists were behind the desecration. ``The pretended rise in anti-Semitism and racism is a political sham,'' he said. ``The Carpentras operation is that of political manipulation.'' At the very least, Le Pen said, politicians were exploiting the event. President Francois Mitterrand urged France to ``get hold of itself.'' ``There is an unhealthy climate in France, a racist climate,'' said Nobel Peace Prize winner Elie Wiesel, visiting Carpentras. ``It's ballooning, it's heating up, it's becoming more and more dangerous.'' ``French society must now examine its conscience and urgently,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dignitaries Pay Respects at Desecrated Cemetery
With AM-France-Desecration, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A parade of dignitaries arrived on a solemn pilgrimage Friday after vandals desecrated Jewish graves in the town that is home to France's oldest synagogue. ``The choice of Carpentras wasn't an accident,'' businessman Jacques David said. ``It was picked as a symbol.'' Israel's ambassador to France, mayors of nearby cities, Cabinet ministers and political party leaders made their way to the cemetery to inspect the damage and pay their respects to the dead. ``The dead will judge us,'' said Elie Weisel, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for his writings about the Holocaust. Located in southern France, about 350 miles south of Paris, Carpentras has been a haven for Jews since the 13th century, when they enjoyed protection under papal rule and were free to worship as they chose. Recent archaeological discoveries have revealed the presence of Jews in the region hundreds of years earlier. In 1967, scientists working on a site near Cavaillon unearthed an oil lamp decorated with a seven-branch candelabra. According to French historian Rene Moulinas, the lamp is the oldest vestige of Judaism in France, dating ``probably to the end of the year 1 B.C.'' The 15th century synagogue is now a classified historical monument, known for its spire, ritual baths and an oven dating from the Middle Ages and used to bake the unleavened bread eaten by Jews at Passover. After the French Revolution when Jews received citizenship, they moved away from the area and settled in other parts of France. Today, the synagogue is hardly used for religious worship _ Carpentras' Jewish community is too small to have its own rabbi. The town's 26,000 inhabitants include about 100 Jewish families, many of them immigrants from North Africa. The mayor, Jean-Claude Andrieu, described Carpentras as a tranquil town in which the Jews lived harmoniously. The vandals must have been outsiders, several residents said. Families of the dead held an impromptu religious service at the cemetery, and Jewish demonstrators gathered at the gate under the banner: ``We Will Not Let History Repeat Itself.'' ``This wasn't a crime against the Jews. This was a crime against all humanity,'' said Dr. Freddy Haddad, leader of the local Jewish community.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Marooned on India's southern Coast
DOC.TEXT: About 50,000 villagers were without food and water for the second day Friday after the decade's worst cyclone battered towns on India's southern coast, killing at least 210 people. The cyclone roared in from the Bay of Bengal on Wednesday and swept inland Thursday, swamping 100 villages, flattening thousands of houses and affecting more than 2 million people. The storm weakened Friday. ``Forget food, there is even no drinking water,'' said a relief official in Machilipatnam, one of the worst-hit areas.``By conservative estimate, at least 50,000 people have nothing to eat and drink.'' Village wells were unusable, brimming with sea water swept in with the cyclone. ``We planned to drop water bottles along with food packets, but none of the 12 helicopters could take off today due to bad weather,'' said Arjuna Rao, the top relief official in Andhra Pradesh state, which bore the brunt of high winds, heavy rains and tidal waves. Rao said at least 200 people died in the state. ``The toll will be higher as more and more bodies are surfacing every hour,'' Rao said. In neighboring Tamil Nadu state, 10 people died. Most of the deaths occurred when walls collapsed or flood waters carried people away. Some people died when they were struck by falling live electric wires. Many towns and villages were also still without electricity because the storm ripped out power lines. Trains stopped running, and about 100 telephone exchanges were damaged. A 1977 cyclone in the region, although less intense, left more than 10,000 people dead. This time, early satellite warnings resulted in the quick evacuation of 150,000 people, officials said. A mobile telephone exchange with a satellite link was sent to Krishna district, where the entire telecommunications network had broken down. Troops and medical teams were in the affected areas. A team of army engineers with mechanized boats and pumping sets were on way to Vijayawada and Machilipatnam towns which were still under waist-deep water. Road communication between the two towns was restored, but in most other places it was disrupted because of flooding. Thousands of uprooted trees littered highways. News Reports said large tracts of rice, a major crop of the region, were badly damaged. Commercial mango and banana gardens also were affected.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Cashing Life Insurance Policies
DOC.TEXT: Many East Germans are cashing in their life insurance so they can have more savings on hand when their money is converted to West German marks, the government said Friday. Long lines have formed at state insurance bureaus in recent days because East Germans believe they will get a better exchange rate on cash than on insurance, the official news agency ADN said. Cash savings up to $2,440 for most East Germans will be converted at a 1-1 rate, while insurance policies are expected to be converted at a 2-1 rate to the West German mark. Many also fear dissolution of the state insurance system after the two Germanys merge their economies. The state insurance office on Wednesday asked that a 1-1 conversion be granted for East German insurance policies. Experts from the German states are negotiating a state treaty under which their economies and social institutions are to be joined by July 2. East Germany will move to a free market economy, which will replace the 4-decade-old socialist system that heavily subsidizes food, housing and employment. Prices and unemployment already are increasing as Western products flood into East Germany. East Germany is trying to negotiate some job and social benefit guarantees during the transition to a market economy. East Germans pay about the same amount of money for their monthly rent _ sometimes as low as $38 per month _ as a West German pays for two tanks of gasoline. An East German official said Friday that some price controls on rents must be maintained. ``The prevailing income structure in (East Germany) makes rent price maintenance absolutely necessary,'' said Ingemar Axel Viehweger, minister for housing and construction. ``Too hasty steps in this sensitive area will only imperil the real income of the citizens during the monetary union,'' he said. He proposed a gradual adjustment of rents to market prices, taking into consideration income and actual costs for upkeep and management of apartments. Unification with West Germany has been fueled by East Germany's decrepit economy, eroded by the exodus of East Germans to West Germany and poor economic planning by the ousted Communist government. Large numbers of East German factories are expected to close when they are forced to compete with more efficient Western businesses that produce better quality goods. East Germans already swarm across the borders, opened in November, to buy West German food and clothing. Border crossings are typically packed with returning East Germans toting huge satchels stuffed with groceries. East Germany's beleaguered shoe industry, where in recent weeks workers have held one-hour strikes to protest Western imports, said it would cut prices and try to improve quality to compete with the West, ADN said Friday. Tens of thousands of teachers, textile workers and farmers staged protests and strikes Thursday to demand protection from the unemployment expected as East Germany moves to a free market. Hans Klein, spokesman for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said the organizers of the strikes were former Communists who ``are to some extent exactly the forces who caused'' East Germany's dire economic problems. Klein told a news conference in the West German capital, Bonn, that there was legitimate ``uncertainty and fear'' over talks between the Germanys on the merger of their economies and social institutions.

DOC.HEAD: US Probes Alleged Harassment of Dissidents by Chinese Embassy
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government has been investigating allegations that Chinese officials have been harassing Chinese students in the United States who are critical of the Beijing government, the State Department said Friday. The department's statement followed allegations by a defector from the Chinese Embassy who reported that embassy officers were ordered to intimidate critics. The comments of the defector, Xu Lin, appeared in Friday's editions of The Washington Post. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that as the investigations proceed, ``we will continue to take appropriate action to afford Chinese students here the full protection of United States law. ``We have advised the Chinese government on several occasions that harassment of its citizens in the United States would violate our laws and would damage our bilateral relationship,'' she said. When he defected last week, Xu, a third secretary at the embassy, took documents which he claimed proved the extent of Beijing's crackdown on dissidents. They are purported to show an effort by the embassy to isolate and stigmatize about 100 ``ringleaders'' who have been involved in the campaign against the communist leadership in Beijing. ``To strike the ringleaders, we should give them a bad name,'' the Post quoted one of the documents as saying. ``Now we must think of a name that has a resounding effect; we cannot use the word dissident.'' The documents classify the students under five headings, ranging from loyal communists to the ``reactionary core elements who actively organize and plan anti-government activities.'' Tactics to be used against the dissidents, the documents suggested, could include keeping files on them, revoking passports, cutting off government stipends, firing them from their jobs back in China and isolating them from their families at home. President Bush has signed an executive order promising that Chinese students in the United States will not be forced to return home against their will. More than 50,000 government-sponsored exchange students are studying in the United States and Canada, and the documents said 70 percent to 80 percent of them would not return to China were harassed, the Post said. A Chinese Embassy spokesman told the newspaper that the allegations in the documents were ``rumors.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Going Ahead With Radar-Jammers Program
DOC.TEXT: A top Pentagon official on Friday defended a revived $7 billion program to build radar jammers for military aircraft even though he canceled the plan last year with the approval of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood also confirmed that the Air Force, which proposed termination of the public program and dropped out of it because of budget constraints, is working on a separate, classified version. The Pentagon's deputy inspector general, speaking to the same congressional panel that Atwood addressed, said later that the system's effectiveness was unproven, and he recommended delaying production decisions until tests are completed. Atwood was questioned, at a hearing by a Senate Governmental Affairs subcommittee, about a newly disclosed July 1989 memorandum in which he proposed terminating the airborne self-protection jammer program. ``I originally killed the program based on the fact that the Air Force recommended it be killed. Secretary Cheney then approved'' the termination, he said. That public effort, a Navy-Air Force program, has now been revived by the Navy alone. And Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., chairman of the subcommittee, disclosed the existence of a secret Air Force program. ``This is one of the old shell game tricks,'' Pryor told Atwood. ``You don't get a program ... or it's not working, you simply put in, as they say, a `black program,' which is a top secret program.'' ``The Congress really has no control over this,'' he said. ``We don't get to ask questions.'' The Pentagon envisions that the electronic system, to be installed on more than 2,000 Navy and Air Force aircraft, would increase the survivability of the planes by jamming or deceiving an enemy's radar-controlled weapons. Atwood said he changed his mind on cancellation of the program after the Navy appealed the decision and vowed that changes would be incorporated into the system. ``I said all right as far as the Navy was concerned and then Cheney approved that and that was in our budget,'' Atwood said. Shortly after the deputy defense secretary's testimony, the Pentagon's own deputy inspector general told the panel that a recent department audit raised serious questions about the jammer system. ``The effectiveness and suitability in combat has not been proven,'' said Derek Vander Schaaf. The audit also found that the Navy's plans call for buying 436 of the jammers before operational tests and evaluation are completed and said that the overall cost estimates may be $1.6 billion too low. The department's own cost analysis and improvement group estimates that the program may cost about $9 billion. Based on this information, Vander Schaaf recommended that the department delay decisions on production until tests are completed and delivery of 100 jammers be stretched out. Robert Duncan, director of operational tests and evaluation at the Pentagon, said he expects the tests on the jammer to begin in May 1991 and be completed by October 1991. But Vander Schaaf said he believes the results won't be in until much later. Pryor questioned the two officials as to whether Congress should approve the $173 million in the defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 that is earmarked for the jammer program. Duncan said yes; Vander Schaaf said no. Earlier, Atwood said Congress should approve the money, arguing that if the system proves itself in testing, the program will be worth it. Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III told Pryor that the jammer program is the only system that meets the service's needs and abandoning the program would force the Navy back to the drawing board at a considerable expense. But the Navy secretary stressed that if the system fails to meet the service's criteria, he will propose cancellation. ``I'm not bashful about recommending that a program be terminated,'' Garrett said.

DOC.HEAD: Oral Roberts University Cuts Tentative Deal To Buy PTL Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The newspaper ...' to restore first reference to the newspaper
DOC.TEXT: A court-appointed trustee says he will sell Jim Bakker's former satellite network to Oral Roberts University for $6 million at the end of the month unless he finds a buyer for the entire PTL complex. ``I do have a firm deal with Oral Roberts University. However, in the contract, I expressly reserved the right to sell all the assets until the point of approval of the sale of just the network,'' the trustee, lawyer Dennis Shedd, said Thursday. The 500-acre Heritage USA Christian retreat founded by Bakker in Fort Mill and 1,700 acres of undeveloped PTL land in South Carolina have been for sale along with PTL's broadcasting holdings since April 1988. Shedd filed legal papers in Columbia on Thursday asking U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Thurmond Bishop to approve the sale of just the television production equipment and PTL satellite and cable leases to the Tulsa, Okla.-based university May 31. The Roberts ministry has been plagued by tight finances, especially since donations to television evangelists plummeted following the 1987 scandals of Jimmy Swaggart and Bakker. In September, Oral Roberts, a 72-year-old faith healer, closed his City of Faith hospital and medical school and put his home and other ministry-owned property on the market to repay $25 million in debts. The Tulsa World newspaper quoted Roberts' son Richard as saying God told his father ``in what my dad believes is his last major charge from God, to create a 24-hour-a-day, seven-day-a-week global Christian, charismatic healing network.'' Richard Roberts said regents approved the offer this week, and the university made a down payment of $1 million raised from longtime backers. Mark Swadener, chief financial officer for the ministries, told the newspaper he thought the network could provide a vital source of revenue for the university. He called the plan to purchase the network ``an act of faith.'' The ministry also was seeking guaranteed access to the airwaves at a time when secular networks are displacing evangelists on Sunday mornings in favor of news shows and cartoons, the newspaper reported. Bakker was convicted last fall of fraudulently raising $158 million from PTL contributors and is serving a 45-year prison sentence in a federal prison in Minnesota. In Charlotte, N.C., the evangelist who introduced Bakker to church secretary Jessica Hahn pleaded guilty to lying to a federal grand jury about why he set up the meeting, which eventually led to Bakker's downfall. U.S. District Court Judge Robert Potter was expected to sentence John Wesley Fletcher later this month, Fletcher's lawyer said Thursday. The perjury count could carry a sentence of eight to 14 months. Fletcher denied during a September 1987 appearance before the grand jury that he brought Miss Hahn to a hotel to have sex with Bakker. He later testified he had lied. The broadcast network purchased by Roberts is operating with a skeleton staff of about 10 employees. It broadcasts shows produced by other evangelists such as Jerry Falwell, James Robison and Richard Roberts. At the time PTL declared bankruptcy in June 1987, the satellite network was carried on 1,300 cable systems that had 12 million subscribers. According to court papers filed Thursday, that has slipped to 800 systems with 6.4 million subscribers. Even in its weakened condition, the PTL network would be a major plum for Roberts, said Jerry Rose, president of the National Religious Broadcasters Association. ``You're still talking about a major network that has an awful lot of potential,'' Rose said. Besides PTL, there are four other religious satellite networks in the United States: Pat Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network, the Southern Baptist Convention's ACTS network, Paul Crouch's Trinity Network and Jimmy Allen's LIFE TV. Other evangelists such as Roberts buy time on those four networks.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Aircraft Bolt Maker Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with plea entered, CORRECT that fines and costs total $18 million sted $37 million, sentencing date set; also moving on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The biggest maker of aerospace fasteners pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and agreed to pay $18 million in fines and costs to settle federal charges that it schemed for 15 years to falsify test reports on parts. VSI Corp. pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy and three counts of mail fraud before U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein. The pleas were entered by company Vice President Donald S. Parker. Two former managers also pleaded guilty to one count each of conspiracy. Rothstein set sentencing for Aug. 17. In a statement before a the court hearing, VSI said that as part of the plea agreement it agreed to pay a $2.5 million fine and pay the government an estimated $1 million for the costs of the investigation. To resolve a separate civil case, VSI will make an additional payment of $14.5 million, part of which the government will distribute among three former VSI employees who initiated the investigation. On Wednesday, the federal government filed its complaint claiming VSI and the two managers of the test-falsfying scheme, which featured a phantom ``Inspector 11.'' VSI, a Fairchild Industries Inc. subsidiary, was accused of skimping on tests and inspections, sometimes even delivering substandard parts to boost profits. ``We deplore violations of testing requirements that may have occurred in the past and have taken steps to prevent such conduct from ever taking place again,'' Ben W. Prescott, president of Fairchild Fastener Group, said in a statement. ``At the same time we can assure the public that air safety was not jeopardized at any time as a result of testing discrepancies.'' Fairchild Fasteners Group includes the fastener divisions of VSI. The complaint is the largest to date in a two-year investigation of the integrity, testing and inspection of bolts and other parts used to hold engines, wheels and other key aircraft components in place, Carter said. The probe was triggered by a complaint from whistleblower Tom Runion shortly after he left his job in the metallurgical laboratory at VSI's Voi-Shan plant in Chatsworth, Calif., Carter said. James E. Ryan, a former Voi-Shan quality assurance manager, and Aram Marderian, a former metallurgical laboratory supervisor for Voi-Shan, also pleaded guilty to conspiracy. Each faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Inadequate Voi-Shan parts were found during aircraft assembly and installation and were returned to the manufacturer but investigators do not know whether there have been any imminent safety threats, Carter said. ``No accidents have been traced to Voi-Shan bolts,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: For One Persecuted Policeman, A Decade of Pain Ends
DOC.TEXT: For one policeman persecuted for daring to organize a policeman's union nine years ago, Friday marked a day of victory and vindication. To cheers and a few tears, a Warsaw court granted legal status to the Independent Self-Governing Trade Union of Police. ``I can really say that the 11th of May is the happiest day of my life,'' said the policeman, senior Sgt. Jan Jablonski, now deputy national chairman of the union. His fight for the police union was an open wound left over from the tulmultuous years of 1980-81, when Solidarity was born from national hope, crushed by martial law. For most of the 1980s, Jablonski suffered anonymously, through a string of unanswered petitions, low-paying jobs and averted looks from former colleagues who passed him on the street. It all began in 1981, when Jablonski and 500 other Interior Ministry officers banded together and asked to be registered as ``The National Trade Union Committee of Police Functionaries.'' ``We wanted in our ministry a broader democratization in social life, among other things to separate political goals from police functions,'' he once said in a petition to government ombudsman, Ewa Letowska. ``Certainly, like every union, we wanted to defend the rights and interests of workers. Of course social issues and pay issues were included in this,'' he said. Jablonski, already an 18-year veteran, said Poland's ousted Communist rulers worked to create distrust between the police and the rest of society, so it would be easier to use the police against the people. ``In the West the policeman has much more respect of people. ... I think this was a conscious action of governing teams to facilitate their wielding of power,'' he said, explaining why police wanted an independent organization to represent them. But all 500 founding union members were persecuted and then fired before they could set up the organization. ``I wanted to change the world and it turned out that finally the world changed me,'' Jablonski said of the years that followed. His first job after being dismissed was obtained through the Roman Catholic Church. He checked coats in a restaurant, then moved on to becoming a meter reader for the state power company. Friends from years on the police force were under orders, he says, not to talk with him. A proud man, Jablonski kept up a steady battle to get his job back, through court filings, appeals to the ministry, contacts with journalists and a petition to Ms. Letowska. Solidarity regained its legal status in April 1989 and the non-Communist government was installed in September. That month Jablonski put a notice in Solidarity's Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper asking any police interested in an independent union to contact him. Eventually, a nationwide meeting was organized in southern Poland, where an active-duty captain, Roman Hula, was elected national chairman of the steering committee and Jablonski was made his deputy. Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak agreed to recognize the union provisionally in January, and Jablonski and other dismissed officers were reinstated to their jobs in February. Formal court registration was put off until after enactment by Parliament last month of an Interior Ministry reform law that abolished the secret service and placed the ministry under civilian control. The law took effect Thursday and the court agreed to register the union Friday. About 70 percent of the 80,000 police have already declared their intention to join his organization, Jablonski said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges ``Good Faith'' Budget Talks, With No Conditions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new grafs 7-8, bgng in Washington, with Lugar comments; picks up 7th graf pvs, Bush's invitation
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush brushed off a political firestorm over possible tax increases on Friday, saying ``I can't be ruffled'' but refusing to reveal what he will put on the table at next week's budget summit with Congress. ``I'm not going to show you my hand. I haven't seen a lot of hands being laid down,'' Bush said as he embarked on a two-day trip of college commencement speeches. Democrats have been reluctant to be the first to mention taxes, urging Bush instead to take the lead in offering a formula to cut the growing budget defict. The administration has warned there would be mandatory spending cuts of upwards of $100 billion this fall unless Congress and the White House agree on major reductions in the deficit.
