Bush, talking with reporters on Air Force One, refused to provide any clues about his strategy but promised to bargain in good faith with Democrats. ``There's no conditions, and that's the way it is,'' Bush said. ``That's the way it's going to be and that's the way it must be.'' In Washington, Sen. Richard G. Lugar, R-Ind., said the budget talks shouldn't just work toward a broad agreement. He suggested members dealing with the budget should be given official status as a joint committee that actually shapes a final budget bill for House and Senate action. But Lugar said he is not optimistic the planned talks can produce an agreement. ``The gaps are so large, and the politics of it are so difficult,'' Lugar told reporters. Bush's invitation to budget negotiations has raised suspicions among Democrats of an election-year tax trap and sparked fears of election setbacks for Republicans who have made anti-tax pledges a key part of their campaigns. Bush has not said he would endorse tax increases, but he has muted his no-new-taxes pledge for the budget talks, which begin Tuesday. The administration is telling Republicans privately that the ``no preconditions'' stance offered by the White House does not necessarily mean Bush will accept increased taxes. The atmosphere for the talks was clouded when White House chief of staff John Sununu suggested this week that the president would not accept a tax increase regardless of what the Democrats propose. Bush, asked if Sununu's remarks reflected his position, said, ``I would ask you to reflect my posture, to talk about what I say ... So I'd respectfully suggest you take your guidance from me on this one, because that's the way it is.'' And Bush said Sununu was not in trouble for his remarks. ``That's silly, so stupid. None of these congressmen are in trouble, either,'' he said. ``I'm approaching it very openly, and I recognize the controversy swirling around from one statement or another,'' he said. ``But look, stay on track, steady as she goes, and be open, deal frankly with people and deal in the way I've said.'' Bush said that, ``Tomorrow there'll be another tidal wave so keep your snorkel above the water level and do what you think is best. ``(It) goes back to what my mom taught me when I was about six: `Do your best, do your best.' Well, I'm trying hard. Stay calm.'' Bush said, ``I think the president has a certain responsibility to stay cool, make clear to people that he's dealing in good faith and do my best. ``That's exactly what I intend to do, and I can't be ruffled by these things,'' Bush said. ``I've got to be understanding when people come forward and express themselves forcefully on something like this.''

DOC.HEAD: Retiree Groups Say SSA Services Have Declined
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf pvs, Enoff said, to CORRECT that figure was not cited to commissioner
DOC.TEXT: Six straight years of budget cuts have sharply reduced the ability of the Social Security Administration to serve older Americans, retiree organizations told Congress on Friday. A 21-percent slash in the Social Security payroll has been accompanied by ``a marked decline in service and renewed complaints about inaccurate information, constantly busy telephones (and) arbitrary rulings on eligibility,'' said Lawrence Smedley, executive director of the National Council of Senior Citizens. ``In some offices, clerical positions have been reduced to the point that managers are often covering reception desks and spending time on data entry,'' Margaret Dixon, a director of the American Association of Retired Persons, told a hearing by the Senate Finance Social Security subcommittee. Louis D. Enoff, deputy commissioner of Social Security, acknowledged the agency is being stretched to near its limit. Nevertheless, Enoff said, ``satisfaction with SSA service has also remained high, with over 83 percent of respondents in a national survey last year rating SSA's service as either good or very good.'' One reason, Enoff said, is that the agency has been able to retain technical employees and those who work directly with retirees and the disabled. The testimony was presented at a hearing on a bill by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., chairman of the subcomittee. The legislation, whose chief goal is removing the agency from the Department of Health and Human Services, would boost Social Security staff by 7,000, to 70,000 full-time workers. Enoff said agency officials were confident an increase of that size was not needed, although a former deputy used that figure in a memo to an associate earlier this year. Enoff said approval of President Bush's budget would assure that Social Security staff would be held at 63,000 ``and give SSA the period of stability it so sorely needs.'' John F. Delfico, a director of the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, said that although there may be a need for more workers in some areas, ``a thorough study needs to be undertaken before wholesale increases in staffing are made.'' Another part of Moynihan's bill would require Social Security to list local office numbers in telephone directories. The agency now lists only a toll-free nationwide number, but on request will give a local number to anyone who calls the toll-free line. ``Because the mental, physical and educational handicaps of some older and disabled Americans makes the telephone an uncomfortable and unfamiliar instrument, local offices must remain accessible and adequately staffed,'' said Mrs. Dixon of AARP.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: South African Spy Group Contaminated Refugees' Drinking Water
DOC.TEXT: A South African spy organization poisoned drinking water at a refugee camp to disrupt elections in Namibia as part of sabotage operations in Africa and Europe, a newspaper reported Friday. However, a Namibian health official said refugee camp water and sewage was extensively tested last year and that no traces of cholera were found. ``It sounds like absolute nonsense,'' Rodion Kraus, director of community health services in Namibia, said of the reported claim that cholera germs had been put into drinking water. Vrye Weekblad, a weekly Afrikaans language newspaper, quoted a former official of the Civilian Cooperation Bureau as saying in an interview that the unit had cells in black African nations and Europe and planned killings of anti-apartheid activists. The South African government is conducting an investigation into the bureau and into allegations that police and military operatives killed anti-apartheid activists. Several former police officers have claimed they were involved in killing activists. President F.W. de Klerk told the commission not to investigate activities outside South Africa. Vrye Weekblad, which helped uncover the first public details about the CCB, said it obtained further information in an interview with former CCB official Petrus Jacobus Botes, who said he headed the unit's activities in Mozambique and Swaziland. Botes said CCB activities ranged from murder and sabotage to bombings, bribery and blackmail, the newspaper reported. The paper said Botes claimed his agents were responsible for a 1988 bomb blast in Mozambique that blew off the arm of African National Congress legal expert Albie Sachs. Botes also claimed his unit was instructed to kill South African Communist Party chief Joe Slovo, then in exile in Zambia, the article said. It did not say if any attempt was made on Slovo's life. The newspaper said Botes claimed that CCB operatives put cholera germs in drinking water at the Dobra refugee camp in Namibia in 1989 as part of efforts to disrupt the South West African Peoples' Organization's election campaign. The story did not say how this was intended to disrupt the election. SWAPO, which waged a guerrilla campaign against South African rule of Namibia, won the elections. Namibia became independent in March. Kraus said there was no cholera at Dobra refugee camp. He said since many of the 40,000 Namibians who returned from exile to vote had come from cholera-infected areas, stringent checks were made of the water and sewage. Police and Defense Force spokesmen in Pretoria had no immediate response Friday to the newspaper report. Cabinet members and other top government officials denied any knowledge of the CCB until late last year. The group allegedly used civilians or police officers to kill government opponents and disrupt anti-government activities.

DOC.HEAD: Abducted Massachusetts Girl Heads Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference scheduled for 5 p.m. EDT, after family arrives in Boston.
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor TD4
DOC.TEXT: Clutching a new stuffed animal, a 5-year-old girl boarded a private jet with her parents for home Friday, 39 days after her abduction by a man authorities described as an obsessed baby sitter. Kenneth Cole, accused of abducting Nicole Ravesi on April 3, awaited transfer to Massachusetts to face charges. The girl was reunited late Thursday with her parents, Frank and Debra Ravesi of Milford, Mass. Nicole was found earlier in the day with Cole in a trailer in a small Gulf Coast fishing village about 70 miles southwest of Tallahassee. The Ravesis had at one time taken out a restraining order against Cole after social workers alerted them that the sometime baby sitter's attachment toward Nicole appeared obsessive. However, the family allowed Cole to see the girl at least twice after the order expired. After leaving a hotel Friday, the Ravesis stopped at a shopping mall, where a store owner gave Nicole a blue-and-white striped dress, pink shoes and the stuffed dog. The girl was examined by a private pedetrician before the family departed. Mrs. Ravesi said later the girl was in good shape and had not been hurt during the ordeal. When asked how she felt while leaving the hotel, Nicole said, ``good.'' She didn't respond to other questions. ``We're thankful to get our daughter back,'' said Ravesi, who described his daughter as ``kind of scared of the cameras.'' Mrs. Ravesi said she was ``very happy, very happy.'' She said they hadn't talked with Nicole about her experiences during her ordeal. Cole, 24, remained at the medium-security Federal Correctional Institution in Tallahassee while the U.S. Marshal's Service worked out details on returning him to Massachusetts, FCI spokesman Dan Rouse said. The youngster was reported missing after she was taken from a car where she and a sister waited for her mother to finish her work as a bus driver. Cole had been a former co-worker of Mrs. Ravesi's. He lost his job as a bus driver and began baby-sitting occasionally for the family. When Nicole was hospitalized last year for a hip infection, Cole visited her frequently. The hospital staff reported him to the Department of Social Services because they saw him kissing her on the lips and showing affection they thought excessive. Social workers investigated and told the family in February that Cole's attachment to Nicole seemed to be obsessive. The Ravesis obtained a restraining order against Cole to prevent him from seeing or speaking to Nicole. However, the couple say they allowed Cole to see the child in two parking lot rendezvous after the five-day restraining order expired, because they thought he was harmless. Cole was arrested Thursday by the FBI and Franklin County Sheriff Warren Roddenberry. Authorities were tipped late Wednesday on the whereabouts of the fugitive after television stations in Panama City, Fla., broadcast material on the two, said James Cagnassola Jr., FBI agent in charge for north Florida. The case was featured on the ``America's Most Wanted'' Fox Network program April 8, April 15 and April 29, Cagnassola said. Fox paid for the family's transportation home. The girl and her accused abductor apparently had been living in a travel trailer since late last month after spending some time at the Pine Ridge Lodge in Panama City Beach. The two apparently left Panama City Beach on April 28 and traveled 85 miles to East Point by bicycle, Cagnassola said. Cagnassola said the two may have reached Florida by train. Cole's car was found in an Amtrak parking lot in Providence, R.I., where it had been parked since shortly after the girl disappeared.

DOC.HEAD: Gang Fight Breaks Out During Crowded Night-Court Session
DOC.TEXT: A gang fight at a crowded night-court session left a blood-spattered courtroom and shaken court employees demanding better security, but there were no arrests because nobody wanted to get involved, police said. The ruckus late Wednesday involved several young men and was witnessed by about two dozen lawyers, court employees, defendants and others on the seventh floor of the Public Safety Building, which also houses police headquarters. There was no security officer or judge present when a young man entered Seattle Municipal Court No. 1 and got into a fight with two others who were already there, apparently waiting for hearing dates, police said. Several other young men in white clothing and hats then entered the room and joined in the brawl, punching the man whose arrival apparently sparked the fracas, throwing him to the floor and kicking him in the head, witnesses said. By the time police arrived, the victim and most of the youths had left. Blood was spattered near the judge's bench, the prosecutor's table, the courthouse hallway and an elevator. Police spokesman Mark Amundson said officers found several witnesses but ``none of them wanted to get involved.'' The victim, found later on the street, refused medical attention and wouldn't press charges, Amundson said. ``Two suspects were still there when the officers arrived, and the officers could have arrested them but only if a victim made a complaint or the witnesses said something,'' Amundson said. ``None of them would.'' While a police officer questioned a defense lawyer, a black-clad youth waiting in line for a court date warned her not to get involved, the Seattle Post-Intelligencer reported. ``You should just keep it quiet, just keep your mouth shut,'' he told her. ``I don't believe our courtrooms should be armed camps, but we need security,'' Municipal Judge Barbara Yanick said. ``I guess it's a sign of the times.'' Municipal Court Administrator Esther Bauman said she'll shift $18,000 of the budget to hire a police officer for night screenings after June. Police Chief Patrick Fitzsimons will post an officer at the court until then, she said. Ms. Bauman said court workers has been concerned about an increased gang presence since last year, when officials began scheduling initial court appearances for defendants four nights a week to streamline the process. Ms. Bauman said the night hearings, in which 400 defendants a week are assigned a public defender and a court date were ``very cost effective'' but differed from a formal courtroom because there was no judge and defendants were required to stand in three separate lines, causing tempers to flare.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Makers Recall Play Phones, Trucks
DOC.TEXT: Two toy manufacturers are recalling more than 69,000 toys because they contain parts that present choking hazards to small children, a government agency said Friday. The first toymaker, Goldwell International, Inc., is recalling 13,583 Public Telephone toys that were sold nationally since March 1989, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The toys which resemble push-button, coin-operated telephones and come with plastic coins in various sizes and colors and were sold for children under age three. However, the coins and the buttons which can become detached from the phones may be swallowed and could choke small children. In the second instance, Minneapolis-based Target Stores has recalled 27,000 My First Buddy Wrecker trucks, 27,000 My First Buddy Pumper fire trucks and 1,497 Potpourri Baby Dolls. All items were sold nationwide in 1988 and 1989. The emergency light on the wrecker trucks, the nozzle on the pumper trucks and the arms and legs of the dolls all present small-parts choking hazards, said the CPSC. The companies and the commission are not aware of any injuries involving the toys, but consumers are urged to return them to the stores where purchased for a refund.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson and Winnie Mandela Receive Emotional Welcome at Angola ANC Camp
DOC.TEXT: Nelson and Winnie Mandela received an emotional welcome from South African political exiles Friday at an ANC training camp, where they spoke of their hopes and fears for South Africa. The Mandelas urged rank-and-file discipline when the African National Congress' estimated 15,000 exiles around the world eventually return home. ``We feel the day we have been waiting for might be close at hand,'' said Nelson Mandela, standing in a hut at Viana. Viana is 12 miles outside the Angolan capital of Luanda. ``The ANC calls on you to act in a disciplined manner when you return, and I must say (members) can't expect to be able to live like millionaires _ choosing mansions in whatever part of town they prefer,'' he said. Mandela was greeted by chants of ``we know you are our father,'' in the Zulu and Sotho languages. He gave the crowd of about 200 a detailed account of his talks last week with South African President F.W. de Klerk. The two agreed to work for an end to political violence and clear the way for bringing blacks into the government. The ANC deputy president was obviously moved by the warm reception. He read the agreement reached with de Klerk in full to the crowd and later answered members' questions in a session closed to the handful of foreign journalists covering the visit. Mandela said he believed de Klerk and the government delegation at the talks were sincerely searching for a peaceful solution but warned, ``We don't know if the delegation stands for all whites in South Africa, and that's what we're worried about.'' He repeated ANC demands that all exiles should be allowed to return home under a general amnesty; that all political prisoners _ including those facing death sentences _ be released; and that the state of emergency dating from 1986 be lifted before any truce in the fight against white-minority rule. Winnie Mandela paid tribute to the militants working abroad for as long as 30 years, saying, ``you have made us walk tall, made us feel we could challenge Pretoria with the knowledge you could hit where we inside (South Africa) couldn't.'' De Klerk legalized the ANC in February after a 30-year ban. The same month, he ordered the release of Mandela, who had been in jail 27 years and was serving a life sentence for plotting against the government. Both Mandelas urged ANC members to accept land offered by South African local authorities for housing projects, citing job and housing shortages. Both were frequently interrupted by cheering and singing as they joked with the crowd through much of the speeches. Mandela ridiculed former South African governments for accusations that the ANC envisions a ``Soviet-style Marxist state,'' and reiterated that the ANC wants a democratic South Africa. ``When we fight against apartheid, we're not fighting against the whites, we're fighting against a policy,'' he said. The Mandelas arrived Thursday from Lusaka, Zambia, for their first visit to Angola. Angola was the ANC's most prominent foreign supporter in the mid-1970s, allowing guerrillas from the movement's military wing to train in at least seven major military camps. Luanda's pledged to end military aid to the ANC in Dec. 1988 as part of regional peace accords signed by Angola, Cuba and South Africa. The 2,500 ANC members currently in Angola are political exiles living in civilian training camps near the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lists 12 Organizations That Will Transmit Opinions
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court announced Friday the selection of 12 organizations that will make the court's opinions quickly available via computer beginning June 1. The organizations will be able to reach thousands of subscribers by providing the opinions electronically within minutes after they are announced, the court's public information office said. The organizations are The Associated Press, the Bureau of National Affairs, Commerce Clearinghouse, the Department of Justice, Mead Data Central, the National Clearinghouse for Legal Services, the Supreme Court Opinion Network, the Thomson Group, United Press International, UUNET, West Publishing and a consortium of Case Western Reserve University, the National Public Telecomputing Network and the Interuniversity Communications Council. Each organization will pay the court $500 this year to participate and will provide its own computer connection to the court's computer system through equipment lent to the court by the Supreme Court Opinion Network. The network is a nonprofit consortium that includes as its members the American Bar Association, the C-SPAN cable television network, Knight-Ridder, Mead Data, United Press International and The Washington Post.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Investigate Alleged Illicit Activities in State Building
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Friday investigated allegations of illegal activities in a legislative office building where a woman said she was interviewed for an ``escort service.'' Robert Stewart, chief of the State Law Enforcement Division, would say only that an investigation was under way at the request by House Speaker Robert Sheheen. The basis for the allegations, according to media reports, is a classified advertisement that appeared in The State newspaper asking for ``host-hostesses for private parties.'' It offered up to $1,000 a week for full- or part-time work. A woman who had her identity cloaked told WIS-TV for a broadcast Thursday that she answered the ad and went to an office in the Blatt Building shared by Reps. Joe E. Brown of Columbia and Ennis Fant of Greenville. Both are Democrats, as is the House speaker. Brown adamantly denied Thursday ever talking to a woman about any such activity. He said he welcomed the investigation to prove his innocence. On Friday he suggested the woman may have been confused about which suite she went to in the building, where all 124 state representatives have offices. Fant also denied any involvement. ``I'm a Baptist preacher, and I sure wouldn't be involved in any such thing,'' he said. ``I sometimes sell a little insurance out of my office here, but that other stuff, absolutely no way.'' Stewart refused to say whether specific lawmakers were under investigation. The ad gave respondents a telephone number to call Monday through Friday between 6 p.m. and 10 p.m. The number is for a telephone in Columbia but not at the Blatt Building, Stewart said. A recording said the number was disconnected Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Berkeley Unveils Program to Teach About Minorities
DOC.TEXT: The University of California at Berkeley, recently disrupted by student protests demanding more minority teachers, has launched a new cultural studies program. Beginning with the freshman class of 1991, all undergraduates will be required to take one course on minority culture. Each of the courses will focus on three minority ethnic groups, said Ron Choy, assistant director of the new program. ``We're creating a whole new program from scratch,'' said Choy, assistant director of the new Center for the Teaching and Study of American Cultures. The center, planned for some time, opened Thursday. Choy said he expects students to welcome the courses, noting the ethnically diverse student body has a strong interest in race and minority reations. Some students boycotted classes for two days last month to protest the lack of ethnic diversity among the faculty. Out of 1,636 full professors, only 24 percent are women or members of minority groups. ``Frankly, this center was created partly to help get the faculty up to date,'' Choy said. ``We have to teach them, too.'' The 1989-90 student body is 45 percent white, 27 percent Asian, 13 percent Hispanic, 8 percent black, 1 percent American Indian and 6 percent undeclared, according to the school. The cultural studies center was created as part of a restructuring of Berkeley's 1960s-era ethnic studies programs, Choy said. ``Most ethnics studies classes just talk about one group,'' he said. ``We want to create new classes that will deal with at least three minority groups at one time in an integrated, comparative way.'' Such an overlapping picture of ethnic groups will better mirror society, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Number in April Up Slightly From Year Earlier
DOC.TEXT: The number of workers employed by farmers rose seasonally in April and was up slightly from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said Friday. A quarterly report said the hired work force on farms was estimated at 833,000 during the week of April 8-14, up from 695,000 in January. A year ago in April, the work force was 830,000. Those did not include 203,000 ``agricultural service'' workers provided by crew chiefs and labor contractors. In April, those totaled 143,000 workers; in April 1989, they were estimated at 198,000. ``Widespread rains during the week of April 8-14, 1990 slowed field work in the Corn Belt, Delta and Southeast,'' the report said. Average pay for all workers hired directly by farmers was reported at $5.54 per hour, down from $5.70 in January but up from $5.35 in April 1989. For workers hired by contractors, there was no national wage rate available. However, workers in California were reported at $6.59 per hour, compared with $6.20 in January and $6.45 a year ago. Florida workers averaged $5.93 per hour, compared with $6.23 in January and $6.24 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Sponsor Says Missing Chinese Farmers Are Welcome to Return
DOC.TEXT: Seven Chinese farmers who mysteriously disappeared on arrival in this country may have been on an extended sightseeing trip, their would-be host said Friday. ``This is kind of a sad story in a way that the mistake of one group can do so much harm,'' said sponsor Molly Aitken, who reported receiving a letter this week from the farmers. The letter said the farmers merely slipped away to see more of New York City and were embarrassed by the national kidnapping investigation their departure touched off. ``I think everyone wants to forgive them, but they're going to have to come back and work hard now to make up for what they've done,'' Mrs. Aitken said in a telephone interview from her farm in Athol. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, whose police continue to investigate the case as a reported abduction, is checking out the letter. ``It's just loony enough to possibly be true, but we're not ruling anything out at this point,'' said spokesman Allen Morrison. The letter, postmarked in New York City and received Wednesday in Athol said the men were embarrassed, felt they had ``lost face,'' and were afraid to return in case they risk deportation, Mrs. Aitken said. The seven Chinese arrived April 25 at New York's Kennedy International Airport with nine other peasants. They came to participate in a project to build a model Third World village during an 11-month stay at Mrs. Aitken's estate on the outskirts of Athol, a small town about 50 miles north of Springfield. Mrs. Aitken, president of the World Energy Foundation organizing the project, met the farmers at the airport and told police she was afraid they had been kidnapped when she saw some of them being hustled into a car. The letter, signed by three of the missing farmers on behalf of all seven, explained that they were met by friends at the airport and decided to slip away to tour New York's Chinatown, Mrs. Aitken said. ``According to the letter, they didn't realize they had caused so much trouble,'' she said. The letter also said the peasants did not see Mrs. Aitken at the airport and planned to contact her after a few days in New York. Mrs. Aitken said she has spoken with officials at the New York Chinese Consulate and with officials in Fujian Province, home region for the farmers. ``I don't know the position that the Chinese government will take, but I imagine that it will also be one of understanding,'' she said. ``I certainly hope that it will be.'' Officials with the Chinese consulate in New York did not return a telephone call Friday from The Associated Press. Charles Troy, spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York, said the agency would like to interview the farmers if they are found, and would not say what they plan to do after that. Morrison said the Port Authority doesn't think the farmers broke any laws. Investigators were skeptical of the kidnap story because the three alleged abductors grabbed the seven without weapons and got them into a car. Morrison said the authority has a copy of the letter, which they will investigate to make sure it is not a hoax and was not written under duress. ``We will not consider the case closed until we see them and interview them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Child Unharmed as Murder-Suicide Ends Custody Dispute
DOC.TEXT: An 18-month-old child was found unharmed in the arms of her dead mother after a custody battle ended in a murder-suicide, police said. The baby's father, Charles C. Tolliver, 47, shot his estranged girlfriend in her Tampa apartment Wednesday, then flew to Columbia, S.C., and killed himself Thursday, said Hillsborough Sheriff's spokeswoman Debbie Carter. A manager at the apartment complex found Gloria Goines, 39, dead in the living room, nearly 18 hours after the shooting, police said. Her daughter, Jimisha Carol Tolliver was lying in her mother's bloody arms. Sheriff's investigators said Tolliver and Ms. Goins had been fighting over custody of the baby. About the same time, police at Fort Jackson, an Army training base outside Columbia, called Tolliver's apartment manager in Tampa about a suicide at the base. Investigators went to the apartment and found a suicide note, but refused to describe its contents. Tolliver was found in a rented car with a .38-caliber gunshot wound to the side of his head, according to coroner Frank Barron. Authorities said they didn't know why Tolliver, a member of the Air Force Reserve, went to the base, which is near his family's home. The toddler was taken into custody by the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services.

DOC.HEAD: South African Spy Unit Operated Throughout Africa, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported that a South African spy organization put cholera germs in drinking water at a refugee camp in Namibia. But a health official said tests turned up no such traces. Vrye Weekblad, a weekly Afrikaans-language newspaper, quoted a former official of the Civilian Cooperation Bureau, or CCB, as saying in an interview that the contamination of the camp's water was part of a sabotage operation aimed at disrupting the Namibian elections. It quoted the official as saying the unit had cells in black African nations and Europe and had planned killings of anti-apartheid activists. The South African government is conducting an investigation into the CCB and allegations that police and military operatives killed activists. Several former police officers have claimed they were involved in killing activists. But President F.W. de Klerk told the commission not to investigate activities outside South Africa. Police and Defense Force spokesmen in Pretoria had no immediate response Friday to the report. Cabinet members and other top government officials have denied any knowledge of the CCB until late last year. On the cholera allegation, a Namibian health official said refugee camp water and sewage was extensively tested for cholera last year, and no traces were found. Vrye Weekblad, which helped uncover the first public details about the CCB, said it obtained further information from former CCB official Petrus Jacobus Botes, who said he headed the unit's activities in Mozambique and Swaziland. The CCB ran destabilization operations in black African nations, with units or cells based in Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zaire and other nations, the article said. Botes said CCB activities ranged from murder and sabotage to bombings, bribery and blackmail, the newspaper reported. The paper said Botes claimed his agents were responsible for a 1988 bomb blast in Mozambique that blew off the arm of African National Congress legal expert Albie Sachs. Botes also claimed his unit was instructed to kill South African Communist Party chief Joe Slovo, then in exile in Zambia, the article said. It did not say if any attempt was made on Slovo's life. The newspaper said Botes claimed CCB operatives put cholera germs in drinking water at the Dobra refugee camp in Namibia in 1989 as part of efforts intended to disrupt the election campaign of the South West African Peoples' Organization, or SWAPO. Rodion Kraus, director of community health services in Namibia, said there was no cholera at Dobra refugee camp. He said since many of the 40,000 Namibians who returned from exile to vote had come from cholera-infected areas, stringent checks were made of the water and sewage. ``It sounds like absolute nonsense,'' he said of the reported claim. Botes was quoted as saying the CCB was in chaos last year, and the outcome of its plans in Namibia was ``the mistaken murder'' of Anton Lubowski, the only white SWAPO executive member. Lubowski was assassinated outside his home in September. SWAPO, which waged a guerrilla campaign against South African rule of the territory, won the U.N.-supervised elections. Namibia became independent in March. Although South African police have said they believe CCB members were involved in Lubowski's murder, de Klerk specifically forbade the commission from including that case in its investigation. The article also said Botes informed South African Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok in August 1989 of CCB activities after he was involved in a dispute with the group's leaders about expenses. Botes, according to the newspaper, also claimed the CCB planned to kill SWAPO activist Hidipo Hamutenya, who is now minister of information in the Namibian government. It did not say if any attempt was made, but Hamutenya said, ``I'd been warned during those days that there was a plan to kill me.''

DOC.HEAD: South African President Visits Greece On Diplomatic Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs `Several Greek' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with protest, clash with police, arrests. Pickup 4th pvs, `At a...'
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa expressed optimism Friday that his country's isolation will soon end as he came to Greece on a European trip aimed at winning support for his reforms. De Klerk held separate talks with President Constantine Caramanlis and Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis during a one-day visit to this European Community member. On Friday night, police battled about 200 anarchists outside Parliament who were protesting De Klerk's visit. The police fired tear gas and charged the demonstrators, who were at the end of a protest march by thousands of students, after the anarchists hurled firebombs. Four protesters were arrested, a police spokesman said. One policeman was slightly injured after he struck on the head by a stone, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. At a joint news conference with Mitsotakis, de Klerk said he was pleased with the outcome so far of his 18-day European tour, which began Thursday with a meeting in Paris with French President Francois Mitterrand. ``There has been a surge of new interest in what is happening in South Africa,'' de Klerk said. ``We have found that in actual fact there is a reevaluation taking place in the total international community with regard to the situation in South Africa.'' Mitsotakis said he was impressed by de Klerk's viewpoint on the situation in South Africa, which ``aims at the total abolition of apartheid.'' Western leaders agreed to begin easing South Africa's isolation after de Klerk in February ordered the release of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela and legalized the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. It is the most extensive foreign mission by a South African head of state since the ruling white-minority National Party took power in 1948. On his trip, de Klerk is seeking to win support for his reform initiatives and the lifting of European Community economic sanctions. Mandela has opposed lifting the sanctions. Mitterrand said the issue of sanctions would be taken up at the EC summit scheduled for June 25-26 in Dublin, Ireland. At his Athens news conference, de Klerk said Denmark had decided to send an ambassador to South Africa, signaling the changing attitude in the West toward South Africa. ``We actually find that some foreign governments are acting on their own accord,'' he said. ``One good example is the establishment of full diplomatic relations at ambassadorial level with Denmark.'' Denmark has maintained its diplomatic representation in South Africa at the consular level. Friday was a holiday in Denmark, and there was no government comment on de Klerk's remarks. However, a low-level duty officer at the Foreign Ministry in Copenhagen said there had been no announcement there of a change in relations with South Africa. Denmark and the Netherlands have been the staunchest opponents in the EC of easing sanctions against South Africa. Relations between Greece and South Africa have been traditionally close, due mainly to the 100,000-strong Greek community in South Africa. The Greek royal family took temporary refuge in South Africa during the Nazi occupation. Greece has abided by EC sanctions that ban certain South African imports and new investments in South Africa. De Klerk was scheduled to remain in Greece over the weekend on an unofficial stay, before leaving for Portugal on Monday. He also plans stops in Belgium, Britain, West Germany, Switzerland, Spain and Italy. The Greek government has said it expects Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, to visit Athens when he starts his own European tour next month. Mandela and de Klerk agreed during talks last week to work together to end political violence and clear the way for formal negotiations on a new constitution that would extend voting rights to South Africa's black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor Suffers Complications, Six More Weeks in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor suffered complications including new infections in her fifth week of hospitalization for pneumonia, and will remain hospitalized for about six more weeks, doctors said Friday. The recovery of Miss Taylor, near death two weeks ago with viral pneumonia, was dealt a setback by bacterial pneumonia and a yeast infection, her doctors said. During the next 1{ months, she will require intravenous therapy in the hospital, they said in a statement released by St. John's Hospital and Health Center. Bacterial pneumonia is generally considered less serious than the viral pneumonia Miss Taylor initially contracted. That's because antibiotics are effective against bacteria but not viruses. ``She is tolerating this therapy extremely well and her doctors are pleased with her progress,'' Miss Taylor's publicist, Chen Sam, said after talking to doctors. Hospital spokeswoman Paulette Weir said she couldn't go beyond the statement. Miss Taylor was still in a private room and not the intensive care unit, she said. Earlier this week, Ms. Sam said the 58-year-old actress was improving and would be released from the hospital this week to recuperate at home. During a news conference last month, Miss Taylor's doctors revealed she was near death on April 22. The Oscar-winning star of ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ``Butterfield 8'' entered Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with a sinus infection, but her condition deteriorated and she was moved to St. John's for treatment of viral pneumonia. Miss Taylor was reportedly in one of the hospital's suites. Suites are ``like a small hotel room with a sitting room, a living room area,'' Weir said without confirming whether the actress was in a suite. Visitors throughout Miss Taylor's hospitalization included her four children, Maria Burton-Carson, Liza Todd-Tivey and Christopher and Michael Wilding. Entertainer Michael Jackson also paid a visit.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Director's Complaint: So Many Crooks, So Few Agents
DOC.TEXT: FBI Director William S. Sessions said Friday that just 40 percent of an estimated 550 major drug trafficking organizations are under active investigation by the bureau. If the bureau were to pursue every drug ring it has identified, Sessions said, ``We could use, not the 1,200 agents that are currently assigned to drug investigations. We could use 9,500, and you know it and we all know it.'' Sessions, in a meeting with reporters at his office, said the same problem applies to the FBI's pursuit of fraud cases at banks and savings and loan institutions. He said about 550 institutions actually are under investigation, while the bureau has had more than 20,000 ``referrals'' _ complaints _ from various other governmental agencies. The bureau has about 600 agents assigned to such cases. Still, Sessions pronounced himself satisfied with the bureau's pace in both the drug and financial arenas. ``I think the FBI's national drug strategy is right on target,'' he said. On other topics, Sessions said: _He is not discouraged that the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December of 1988 remains an open case, with no one yet charged. All 259 people aboard the Boing 747 were killed, as were seven people on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. ``I was confident then and I am confident now that we will successfully complete our investigation,'' he said. _Leads ``are consistently moving and progressing very well'' in the investigation of four mail bombings in the South, including those which killed a federal appeals judge, Robert S. Vance, in Birmingham, Ala., and a civil rights lawyer, Robert F. Robinson, in Savannah, Ga. Asked if the investigation were at the ``tie-up'' stage, Sessions said. ``We're not there yet. But we're approaching it.'' _It is too early for the FBI to declare a ``peace dividend'' by allocating counter-espionage resources elsewhere. ``Even though there is a tremendous move towards freedom and democracy in the (Eastern) bloc countries, we do not know about how that will actually change the operation of the approach of the various intellgence services,'' Sessions said. ``We do have things other than military secrets ... there is a perception that these countries will need to succeed economically, and that they will, therefore, be looking not just for military information but for technological and scientific information that is not properly theirs.'' Asked if he were aware of Soviet or Eastern European agents attempting to enlist Americans in recent months, Session replied ``Yes. The patterns and activities of the past do continue.'' He would not elaborate. Sessions repeatedly declined comment on the FBI's role in the investigation of Washington Mayor Marion Barry, who faces 14 drug-related charges. But the FBI director did acknowledge he had seen an FBI videotape which purportedly shows the mayor smoking crack cocaine after being invited to do so by a female informant.

DOC.HEAD: Big Rally on Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rocketed to near record-heights on Friday as favorable inflation news and falling interest rates drew investors to Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks finished up 63.07 at 2,801.58, short of the record high close of 2,810.15 reached on Jan. 2. It was the biggest one-day advance for the Dow average this year. Broader market indicators also rose sharply, with advancing issues swamping decliners on the New York Stock Exchange. The government reported that the producer price index of finished goods dropped 0.3 percent in April, in contrast to Wall Street's expectations of a 0.1 percent-0.3 percent increase. Another government report said retail sales, another widely watched statistic, fell 0.6 percent last month. Analysts said the figures provided the markets with a double dose of evidence that the pace of the economy remained slow and inflationary pressures were subdued, making stocks and bonds a much more attractive investment.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese High Roller Leaves Casino $10 Million in Hole
DOC.TEXT: A group of high-rolling baccarat players who bet $200,000 a hand at one of Donald Trump's casinos lost about $10 million after their weeklong binge. Trump said Friday that Japanese businessman Akio Kashiwagi had been up by nearly $10 million earlier in the week before the cards turned against him and for the Trump Plaza Hotel & Casino. ``He was up $9.6 million and then we had a good run,'' Trump said in a telephone interview. Kashiwagi attracted a gathering of amazed small-time players whenever he came down from his 37th-floor suite to play $100,000 a hand while two companions placed $50,000 bets. Trump said Kashiwagi tried to come back and play Thursday after surrendering early that morning $10 million in the hole. ``We said, `forget it, that's enough,'' Trump said. ``Frankly, you have to be in the mood.'' Kashiwagi sat at the baccarat table Thursday with $1 million in chips while his companions had $500,000 apiece. He got up before any of the cards were dealt and did not return. Trump said he did not know if Kashiwagi would return to play again. Kashiwagi could not be reached for comment. A casino operator said there was no room listed for anyone named Kashiwagi. In February, Kashiwagi won $6.2 million from Trump Plaza at baccarat, a high-stakes card game where players seek to bet on the hand that comes closest to totaling nine. Face cards are worth zero. Trump acknowledged allowing Kashiwagi to play is a gamble but said that's part of the casino business. ``It's risky, but I like it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Death Row Inmate Freed From Jail
DOC.TEXT: A former death-row inmate convicted in the mutilation slayings of his stepdaughter and her fiancee in 1982 was set free Friday after prosecutors decided not to try him a second time. Dale Johnston, 56, who has maintained he is innocent, emerged from the Licking County jail promising to search for the real killer. ``It's a beautiful day,'' Johnston told reporters he met in his lawyer's office in Columbus. He was freed secretly after the sheriff's department received a death threat against him, said Sheriff Gerry Billy. Three judges found Johnston guilty in 1984 of aggravated murder in the slayings of his stepdaughter, Annette Cooper Johnston, 18, and her fiance, Todd Schultz, 19, both of Logan in southeast Ohio. He was sentenced to death in the electric chair. Ms. Johnston and Schultz were last seen Oct. 4, 1982, in Logan. Their torsos were discovered 10 days later in the Hocking River. Other body parts were unearthed in a cornfield. Prosecutors alleged that Johnston killed the two on his Hocking County farm with a .22-caliber handgun, then dismembered their bodies. Prosecutors said jealousy was the motive for the killings and that Johnston had a sexual relationship with his stepdaughter. Johnston spoke of long years in prison and his resolution to search for a murderer. ``For the last 7{ years, I've taken everything one day at a time. I'll continue with that for a while,'' he said. ``A soon as possible, we'll start pursuing the one goal I have left, and that's to find the person who killed my daughter.'' Johnston had been held in the county jail in this central Ohio city, about 30 miles east of Columbus, awaiting a second trial. Johnston served more than seven years in prison for slayings. Johnston's ex-wife, Sarah, the mother of the slain woman, was waiting for Johnston at the jail. She expressed happiness with Johnston's release. ``It's going to be a beautiful day. It's just fantastic to know that his attorneys have finally prevailed, that justice finally came through on our side this time,'' she said. The Johnstons are divorced. She remarried and is living in southern Ohio outside Hocking County. Johnston's release was cleared after a prosecutor on Thursday dropped charges following an appeals court's ruling that certain evidence could not be used against Johnston. The prosecutor contended the evidence was crucial to obtaining a second conviction. Johnston's first conviction was thrown out by the Ohio Supreme Court in 1988, which ruled that a witness whose memory had been refreshed by hypnosis had been improperly allowed to testify. A second trial was put on hold last July after Judge William Gillie ruled that Johnston's rights were violated when police questioned him for 8{ hours without a lawyer present. Gillie also ruled that boots, a vest and other clothing taken from Johnston during the interrogation could not be used as evidence. The judge said a police officer tried to deceive Johnston into thinking that he had blood on his boots. Prosecutors tried to link the boots to footprints near where the bodies were found. The 10th Ohio District Court of Appeals on Thursday upheld Gillie's decision. Logan County Prosecuter Charles Gerken then decided to drop the charges. Schultz's mother, Sandra, said she was not surprised by the events that led to Johnston's release. ``But I'm not happy about it. It's a hard day for us,'' she said. Schultz's father, Donald, said there is no doubt in his mind that Johnston killed the two. ``He knows who did it. He did it,'' Schultz said in an interview with The Columbus Dispatch.

DOC.HEAD: 48 Killed in Bus Crash in Peru
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS throughout to UPDATE death toll, adds comment on cause, depth of gorge. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A bus plunged into a 600-foot-deep gorge near this southern city Friday, killing 48 people and seriously injuring three, police said. The bus, operated by the Ormeno bus line, was headed to Lima from Arequipa, 545 miles southeast of the capital. The accident occurred between the towns of Tambillo and Vitor, 20 miles west of Arequipa. A spokesman for Ormeno said the bus was forced off the road by a truck driving in the wrong lane. On April 14, a flatbed truck carrying about 70 people careened off a narrow Andean mountain road and tumbled down a 450-foot cliff into a river, killing at at least 40 people. Flatbed trucks are often used in Peru's countryside for passenger transport. That accident occurred 50 miles east of Lima, near the town of Huinco.

DOC.HEAD: Art Exhibitors Fear More Water Leaking on Works
With AM-Floods-Tourism, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dealers feared for their art Friday after leaky roofs at a Chicago landmark and hard rain yielded water damage to at least five pieces on display at the Chicago International Art Exhibition. The exhibit, with works said to have total value of nearly $1 billion, was to be the last major exhibition at Navy Pier before a renovation that could cost more than $150 million, said John Schmidt, chairman of the Metropolitan Pier and Exposition Authority. The authority oversees Navy Pier and nearby McCormick Place. The Lakeside Group, which organized the exhibition, spent $500,000 for roof repairs as a condition of staging the show at the pier, which juts into Lake Michigan from downtown. But it didn't prove enough to combat torrential rains Wednesday night that dumped from more than 4 inches on the Chicago area. Barry Bauman, an art expert working with the exhibition, had to dry out five works sent to him so they could be shown at Thursday night's $125-a-person opening. Bauman said none of the works was irreversibly damaged. An estimated value of the wet art was not immediately available, officials said. They also would not identify the works. The exhibit includes works by Jannis Kounellis, Annette LeMieux, Sam Francis, Donald Judd, Wayne Thiebaud and Sherrie Levine. Thiebaud, a former Disney animator, designed the posters promoting the show. The 100 copies of the poster sold for $10,000 each. Workers, meanwhile, put up layers of plastic under the roofs of the two main halls at Navy Pier to try to shield the art from any more water. ``It's like closing the barn door after the cows escape,'' said Margaret Failoni of Rome's Il Ponte Galleria. One of her pieces in the show got wet. The weather forecast called for an 80 percent chance of rain or thunderstorms on Saturday, which made some exhibitors nervous. ``We've been lucky so far, nothing's been damaged,'' said Penny Pilkington of PPOW, a New York gallery that had about 20 paintings, sculptures and other objects on display. ``But we don't know if they've done anything about fixing the roof yet.'' The two leaky sheds at the pier are housing about half of the 198 dealers at the show. About 65,000 people people are expected to view the show, which ends Tuesday. Schmidt said repairs to solidify the structure as well as to plug holes were demanded of the Lakeside Group before the show opened. ``This is the last year that we will ever use the sheds,'' Schmidt said. ``They are totally deteriorated.'' The pier was completed in 1916. Tom Blackman, executive director of the Lakeside Group, lamented that even with the expenditure, ``we still had an awful lot of water.'' Some exhibitors, however, did not seem too upset. ``We've been here before, so we knew what to expect,'' said Chicago gallery owner Betsy Rosenfield.

DOC.HEAD: Floods At A Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here's a look at the status of and developments in flooding in Oklahoma, Texas and Arkansas, where intermittent rains fell Friday and are forecast for the next few days:
DOC.HEAD: OKLAHOMA:
DOC.TEXT: _Lake Texoma, a popular Red River lake on the Texas line, crested Monday at 644} feet above sea level _ 27 feet above normal _ and dipped to 641 feet Friday. The Corps of Engineers expects it could be 45 to 60 days before the lake returns to a ``decent level.'' At Lake Texoma State Park, 270 of 300 campsites are closed; about half the lake's commercial marinas are either inacessible or underwater, and 700 concession workers have been laid off. _In eastern Oklahoma, the 20 camping areas around Lake Eufaula have limited access because of high waters. _One flood-related death has been reported.
DOC.HEAD: TEXAS:
DOC.TEXT: _The Trinity River, which inundated north Texas after heavy rains a week ago, brings severe flooding to its watershed as its crest heads for the Gulf Coast. Authorities warn residents in Dayton and Liberty counties, about 40 miles east of Houston, to expect what could be the Trinity's worst flooding in 80 years. _The Red River has flooded 40 homes near Texarkana, where almost 200 National Guard troops were in their fourth day of reinforcing levees. The Salvation Army says it has served 3,000 meals to flood victims and rescue workers in the past 48 hours in the Texarkana area. _Twenty-five counties have been designated as federal disaster areas due to flooding, which has cost 12 lives and between $500 million and $700 million in agricultural damage in Texas, millions more to houses and roads.
DOC.HEAD: ARKANSAS:
DOC.TEXT: _The Red River crested 8 feet above flood stage Thursday at Fulton and closed westbound lanes of Interstate 30. Two other state highways near the Texas line also are closed and expected to remain so for up to two weeks. In Little River County, an estimated 51,000 acres was under water and thousands of head of cattle were stranded. _The Arkansas River slowly is falling from its crests above flood stage at Little Rock and Pine Bluff. _Gov. Bill Clinton, in asking Thursday for a presidential disaster declaration in 29 counties, said initial official estimates of damage to private, non-agricultural property total $6.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Transit Police Begin Vigorous Enforcement of Ban on Subway Panhandling
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: Transit police Friday began a vigorous campaign to rid the rails of beggars one day after a federal appeals court reaffirmed a ban on subway panhandling. ``They told us about it at roll call _ `no more panhandling,''' an officer at the Grand Central Terminal subway stop said on condition of anonymity. ``The ruling makes it easier, because it's going to back us.'' And the word seemed to have gotten out quickly _ transit police officers in the subways said there were fewer panhandlers to move along than usual. An unscientific eyeballing through the system seemed to bear that out, although panhandlers have been fewer since October when the Transit Authority began its Operation Enforcement to rid the system of those who disobey the rules. On Thursday, the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 2-1 that a ban on begging in the subway system is constitutional because panhandlers don't convey a social or political message. The decision reversed a lower court ruling that said the agency's panhandling prohibition was unconstitutional because begging is a form of free speech protected by the First Amendment. The appeals court ruling means the agency can ban begging on trains, near subway stairways, escalators and elevators and within 25 feet of token booths. Also, the appeals court unanimously reinstated a ban on begging in terminals of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which the lower court also had ruled unconstitutional. Douglas Lasdon, a spokesman for the Legal Action Center for the Homeless that brought the lawsuit, said attorneys had not decided whether to appeal. ``My fear is that this decision gives them tremendous authority and discretion to harass homeless people,'' he said. ``You can't decree an end to hunger and homelessness. You have to deal with the fundamental problems.'' Sgt. Robert Valentino, a transit police spokesman, refuted that, saying the ruling applied only to panhandling and the agency was not taking any additional steps against the homeless. Meanwhile, Transit Authority police Chief William J. Bratton and his top lieutenants mapped strategy Friday morning to begin the vigorous enforcement. ``Panhandling will not be tolerated in the transit system,'' Valentino said. Valentino said teletype messages were going out to every field office so officers and other employees would know that the banishing of panhandling is a priority. Motormen, conductors and token booth clerks were to be instructed to notify police officers if they see beggars. ``They stand right here and beg,'' a token booth clerk at the 77th Street station of the IRT said as he gestured toward the side of his booth. The clerk said that 40 people usually beg at his station. But, throwing his hand back toward his telephone, he noted that the instrument has been out five weeks at a time and it would be hard to notify police. ``They need more cops to protect the station,'' he said. ``I think it's wonderful because I find it annoying. They give the city a bad appearance, to tell you the truth,'' train rider Glenda Silversack said about the ruling. ``I'm for it and I'm against it,'' said another rider, Karl Adams. He didn't mind the passive panhandlers with cups extended but was bothered by those shouting, ``Yo, you got a dollar, Yo, you got a dollar?'' ``There may not be much of a choice. I'm a big male and I refuse to ride at night. I can't tell the difference between someone asking for a quarter and ones who put a knife to my throat,'' Adams said. Matthew Vaffney, 67, a resident of the Bellevue shelter who was begging at Grand Central Terminal, shoved a reporter and said he had already been interviewed by three other reporters. ``You've stopped me from making a quarter,'' he said, jangling change in a coffee cup. ``I do what I think is right'' _ gathering enough money to see his mother's grave on Mother's Day, he said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Seizes Houses, Cars, Trucks Bought with Buried Drug Treasure
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents on Friday seized luxurious homes, cars, and boats bought with $43 million unearthed from drums buried in a farm owned by a reputed drug kingpin, authorities said. Agents from the FBI and Drug Enforcement Administration confiscated property in Vega Baja, 35 miles east of San Juan, and two other Puerto Rican towns as part of an investigation launched March 10. The probe began after authorities heard Vega Baja residents were using large amounts of cash to buy luxury items, including homes, cars, motorcycles, boats and jewelry. The FBI said it has so far traced $11 million of the $43 million buried in a farm in Vega Baja allegedly belonging to a drug baron. Agents also have confiscated millions of dollars worth of property bought with the treasure. The estimate of $43 million is three times higher than when reports of the buried treasure surfaced in April. FBI spokesman Anibal Torres said Friday the 9.7-acre farm belonged to alleged cocaine kingpin Ramon Torres Gonzalez, who authorities say runs a ring that smuggles South American cocaine from the U.S. commonwealth of Puerto Rico to the mainland United States. He said criminal charges against Torres Gonzalez have not been filed and that an ivestigation is continuing. The FBI refused to say if it knows where he is. ``Ramon Torres Gonzalez is a narcotics importer that has been directly involved for many years in the importation of multi-kilo loads'' of cocaine between Puerto Rico and mainland United States, according to an FBI court document. The document, filed with the U.S. District Court for the District of Puerto Rico and released Friday, said that in early March, several residents ``sneaked'' into Torres Gonzalez' farm and took money buried in 22 plastic drums. ``After these incidents the persons that stole the money commenced a big shopping spree wherein cars, houses, jewelry, motorcycles and other articles were purchased with the drug proceeds of Ramon Torres Gonzales,'' the FBI document states. FBI spokeswoman Alina Bloom said FBI and DEA agents on Friday seized from the towns of Vega Baja, Dorado and Carolina dozens of cars, houses, trucks, bulldozers and motorcycles purchased with the money found in the farm. Authorities said the farm had a helicopter launching pad used for drug trafficking. An FBI press release said the seizure of property was supervised by the office of U.S. Attorney Daniel Lopez Romo. Ms. Bloom said the value of the property seized Friday has not yet been determined. The FBI court document says $32 million of the $43 million unearthed from the farm is believed still in the possession of Torres Gonzalez. It says $11 million was divided up among more than 10 people, and that more than $500,000 of the stolen cash has been returned since March 31 and dozens of cars and trucks, houses, real estate and jewelry had been recovered prior to Friday's seizures. The FBI said Torres Gonzalez ran a construction equipment company to front his narcotics activities and launder drug trafficking earnings. Since the investigation began, his farm and construction equipment has been consficated. According to the FBI document, any property bought with the money is U.S. property because of a law on drug proceeds. Torres Gonzalez served a one-year sentence in 1982 in Tallahasse, Fla., on charges of conspiracy and distribution of cocaine, the FBI documents says. It said Torres Gonzalez ran a ring in the 1970s out of New York that smuggled Peruvian cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Accused of Fraud Refuses to Testify Before Congressional Panel
DOC.TEXT: A scientist won't testify at a Congressional panel investigating accusations that she falsified data in a genetics research paper she had written with a Nobel Prize-winner, her attorney said Friday. ``She feels very much hounded ... by an unwarranted intervention and intrusion by the government into the scientific process,'' said Bruce A. Singal, attorney for Dr. Thereza Imanishi-Kari of Tufts University. Imanishi-Kari is declining to testify Monday before a House subcommittee reviewing charges she misrepresented research reported in a 1986 article published in the scientific journal Cell. The committee's investigation has focused on forensic studies performed on Imanishi-Kari's notebooks by Secret Service specialists who allegedly found as many as 40 pages were prepared up to two years after their recorded dates. Monday's hearing also was scheduled to examine a May 4 forensics study that suggests the Boston pathologist made fraudulent tape recordings to support the paper, which was researched at Tufts and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ``This a case study of how institutions respond or don't respond ... when there are questions or allegations about the quality or accuracy or integrity of research,'' said Dennis Fitzgibbons, a spokesman for the subcommittee. The Congressional investigation began in 1986 after a former MIT researcher charged she could not duplicate the published study, which examined the immune cells in genetically altered mice. Investigations were conducted by both MIT and Tufts, where Imanishi-Kari now works, but both schools reported the research required no corrections. The National Institutes of Health also has investigated the charges, but Singal said his client would not cooperate unless the panel detailed the allegations against her. ``This is becoming an annual rite of spring, being invited back to the Dingell committee every May,'' Singal said. Imanishi-Kari testified a year ago before the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations chaired by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich. At that time, she told the committee that her notebooks had nothing to do with the published experiments and showed only that ``I am not a neat person.'' David Baltimore, an MIT molecular biologist and co-author of the study, has joined other scientists backing Imanishi-Kari's claim that the notebook had no bearing on the work. ``It is apparent that, after years of investigation, a reasonable person must conclude that the Cell paper was an honest report of collaborative research,'' said Baltimore, a 1975 Nobel laureate who has been named president of Rockefeller University in New York. In a letter sent Thursday to Dingell, Singal said the latest hearings were ``nothing more than a rehash'' that his client would decline to attend. ``We frankly do not understand why this same set of so-called findings is now being recycled one year later,'' Singal wrote. ``It is as insignificant and irrelevant now as it was a year ago to any legitimate scientific issue.'' Singal said the Secret Service report issued May 4, and made public by his client Thursday, contained ``deficiencies and omissions which ... preclude the possibility of any meaningful response at this time.'' He said Imanishi-Kari would be willing to respond to the charges her tapes were fraudulent after more information and clarification of the charges was made available. Fitzgibbons declined to elaborate on the report, which was to be the subject of Secret Service testimony Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir: No Prior Knowledge of Jewish Settlement in Old City
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Friday he did not know of the government's secret funding of a Jewish settlement in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City before it was publicly disclosed, a spokesman said. Also Friday, an Arab killed a Palestinian activist who tried to burn his house in the West Bank village of Yatta, Arab reports said. Shamir made the statement in a conversation with Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek, said Shamir's aide, Avi Pazner. Kollek just returned from a visit to the United States, where he met with President Bush. ``He (Shamir) did not know of the settlement beforehand,'' Pazner said in an interview. Last month, 150 settlers moved into a building owned by the Greek Orthodox Church, prompting protests by Christian and Moslem Arabs and touching off a controversy that strained Israel's relations with the United States. The settlers evacuated the building May 1 following an order from the Supreme Court. Some 20 caretakers remain inside pending an appeal of the decision. The church claims a former tenant illegally leased the building to the settlers. Officials in the Housing Ministry, led by David Levy, one of Shamir's leading rivals within the right-wing Likud bloc, disclosed the ministry secretly put up some $1.8 million to help fund the settlement and that the Finance Ministry was aware of the funding. Shamir has been in charge of the Finance Ministry since the mid-March collapse of the coalition government that united the Likud with the center-left Labor Party of former Finance Minister, Shimon Peres. Pazner insisted ``the initial sums were given when Peres was Finance Minister.'' He said the remainder of the money was transferred without Shamir's knowledge and the move did not require his approval. Jerusalem city spokeswoman Bonnie Boxer refused to comment on Shamir's statement. She said Kollek ``stands by everything he said, which was that the settlement in the Christian quarter was a mistake.'' In recent weeks, Shamir's caretaker government has authorized the construction of two new settlements, one in the occupied West Bank and one in the Gaza Strip. The United States has protested the construction of the settlements, calling them an obstacle to peace. The occupied lands are home to 1.7 million Palestinians and about 70,000 Jewish settlers. Friday's violence came when a group of Arab activists set fire to the house of Fatima Ale, believed to be an informant for the Israeli administration, Palestinian journalists said. Her husband, Abu Zedan, opened fire with a machine gun, killing Imahem Abu Zamran, 18, the journalists said. Arabs assisting Israeli authorities are sometimes issued weapons for self-protection. The army confirmed the death, but said it resulted from a conflict between villagers. The incident is under police investigation, the military said. At least 685 Palestinians have died of Israeli gunfire in the 29-month revolt against Israeli rule. An additional 212 have been slain by their Arab brethren on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Minneapolis Council Approves Anti-Death Penalty Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The City Council on Friday urged police to bypass federal prosecutors in cases that could draw the new federal death penalty for drug-conspiracy homicides. The council approved 10-3 a non-binding resolution urging police detectives in Minnesota's largest city to present such cases to county or state prosecutors rather than the U.S. Attorney. The action came one day after federal prosecutors in Chicago announced the first use of the death penalty law enacted in 1988. They said they would seek capital punishment for two men accused of killing a witness to protect a $50,000-a-day drug ring. The federal law allows capital punishment for murders committed to further drug conspiracies. The Minneapolis resolution won initial approval last week by a City Council panel. ``My personal opinion is that the death penalty serves no useful societal purpose,'' council member Joan Campbell, the resolution's chief sponsor, said Friday. ``I don't think it's the responsibility of a civilized society to kill people if they kill other people. ``I'm not in any way suggesting that the crimes are not heinous,'' she said. U.S. Attorney Jerome Arnold indicated the resolution would have little or no effect in determining whether his office would prosecute a case where the death penalty might be warranted. ``What a municipality may do in passing resolutions will have no effect on what the federal government is going to do in a given case,'' Arnold said. Council member Walt Dziedzic, a former city police officer who opposed the resolution, said it ``sends the wrong message out there that this city, this great city, is soft on crime.'' ``I'm not soft on crime,'' Campbell said. ``I think we ought to be as tough on crime as we can be up to this point.'' Council member Dennis Schulstad, the only Independent-Republican on the Democrat-Farmer-Labor-dominated council, said the resolution in effect tells drug dealers the federal government is ``too mean'' and that they therefore should be prosecuted by the county attorney. ``That is not the message I want to send,'' said Schulstad, who also voted against the resolution. ``We are weak on crime and punishment in Minnesota and don't let any person tell you differently,'' he said. ``I couldn't disagree with you more about the message,'' said council member Pat Scott. ``I would contend that the people committing these kinds of crimes aren't listening'' to any arm of government, he said. ``I don't think the criminals are listening to us, Councilman Schulstad,'' said Council President Sharon Sayles Belton, a former state probation and parole officer. Former Council President Alice Rainville joined Schulstad and Dziedzic in voting against the resolution. Campbell said the resolution reaffirms a vote in the 1989 Minnesota Legislature in which the House Judiciary Committee killed a proposal to reinstate the death penalty by an overwhelming, bipartisan vote. Minnesota repealed its death penalty in 1911. Hennepin County Attorney Tom Johnson, who helped draft the Minneapolis resolution, said Thursday he hopes the policy statement ``set an example to other jurisdictions and to other cities that they can say no to the federal death penalty.''

DOC.HEAD: Rains Linger In Flood-soaked Southern Central States
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms dumped more rain Friday on the already soaked ground of north Texas, southwestern Arkansas and southeastern Oklahoma, where the flooding Trinity and Red rivers have caused millions of dollars in damage. Flash flood watches were posted through Friday night for parts of northeastern and north central Texas, where showers ranged into Oklahoma and western Arkansas. Showers and a few thunderstorms also extended from northern Arkansas to western Alabama. Rain and snow showers fell on the northern and central Rockies. Rainshowers ranged across southern South Dakota. A few morning rainshowers lingered over the Northeast, but dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation by Friday afternoon. Strong and gusty northwest winds were ushering cool air into the Northeast, and gale warnings were in effect for Lake Erie, Lake Ontario, and the coasts of Maine and New Hampshire. Strong northwesterly winds prevailed across the lower Great Lakes region, upper Ohio Valley, and the middle and northern Atlantic Coast states. Strong northwesterly winds blew across North Dakota and northwestern Minnesota. Strong southerly winds prevailed from the southern Plains to the middle Mississippi Valley. Strong and gusty winds also blew through the Southwest. Winds at Guadalupe Pass, Texas, gusted to 67 mph and wind advisories were posted through Friday night for the deserts of Southern California. Temperatures reached the 40s and upper 30s in parts of eastern Wyoming and northeastern Colorado on Friday, and into the 50s from the Great Lakes to New England. Temperatures were in the 80s across southern Texas, the Florida Peninsula and the desert Southwest. Morning lows were in the 30s and 40s across much of the nation east of the Mississippi River, with readings in the 20s reported in Wisconsin and Upper Michigan. A number of cities reported record low temperatures for the date: Columbia, Mo., had a low of 38 degrees, a degree chillier than the 1952 record; Madison, Wis., was 29, a degree lower than the '67 mark; Marquette, Mich., was 23 (25 in 1989), and Paducah, Ky., was 38 (40 in 1969). The low for the nation Friday was 21 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: What's So Special About a Few Squirrels?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS a0686 to put under Washington category code
Eds: Subs 3 grafs new quotes from spokesman for 14th graf pvs, He said
DOC.TEXT: Conservationists reacted with anger Friday to Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan's suggestion that a $200 million telescope should be built despite its potential effect on an endangered squirrel. ``Do we have to save every subspecies?'' Lujan had asked. Interviewed Thursday by the Denver Post, the interior secretary noted the controversy surrounding the Arizona project, which could be stopped under the Endangered Species Act. At issue is the Mount Graham red squirrel. All that are left _ fewer than 100 _ are in a colony on the mountain where the University of Arizona, the Smithsonian Institution and others want to build a powerful telescope and observatory. Conservationists have sought to stop construction because the squirrel is on the Endangered Species List. In the interview, Lujan suggested Congress should soften the act and commented: ``Do we have to save every subspecies? The red squirrel is the best example. Nobody's told me the difference between a red squirrel, a black one or a brown one.'' He also said the law was ``just too tough'' and added, ``We've got to change it.'' As the interview circulated Friday, conservationists vented their rage. Michael Francis of the Wilderness Society said the interview ``shows Mr. Lujan's incredible lack of understanding of biology and public policy. ``I'd have to say he's getting pretty close to another Jim Watt. ... Mr. Lujan certainly is trying to better his mark.'' Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, said he was incensed ``that the very Cabinet official whose job it is to be the country's front-line protector of endangered wildlife would make such outrageous statements.'' Hair said that the Mount Graham red squirrel ``is in the 11th hour of existence on the planet.'' A spokesman for Lujan did not quarrel with the published interview, which the secretary gave while attending a National Park Foundation banquet at the Mesa Verde National Park, near Durango, Colo. Steve Goldstein, Lujan's press secretary, said his boss had sought only to point out some ``frustrations'' he has had with enforcing the Endangered Species Act. He said Lujan wants Congress to ``determine whether (the law) is being implemented correctly.'' Later Friday, after conferring with Lujan, who was in Colorado, Goldstein said Lujan does not consider the changes he would like Congress to make as a weakening of the Endangered Species Act. ``He wants Congress to look at two things. How far down we should go in protecting subspecies and what protection should be afforded when the same species exist in multiple locations,'' said Goldstein. Goldstein said Lujan believes that, increasingly, the law is being used by people ``as a last recourse to stop economic development projects they don't like'' and not specifically to protect endangered species. ``Manuel Lujan will diligently enforce the Endangered Species Act as it is written, but he wants Congress to determine whether it's being implemented correctly or if it's just being used to stop development projects,'' Goldstein said. Lujan had said in the interview that he expected his views would ``upset a few people.'' The Arizona controversy is one of several that have surfaced recently involving the endangered species law. The Interior Department also is considering whether to halt the Animas-La Plata water project in Colorado because of a threat to the endangered squawfish. In addition, an emotional dispute between loggers and environmentalists over the Spotted Owl has raged for more than a year in the Pacific Northwest. Lujan said in the interview that he is ``obliged'' under the law to protect endangered species ``wherever they exist'' without regard to economic considerations and to take into account only biological facts. But he questioned the narrowness of that requirement. ``Do we have to save (an endangered species) in every locality where it exists?'' Lujan asked. He cited the turmoil over the squawfish. In that case, he said, his department is ``caught between two things.'' The $582 million Animas-La Plata project would provide water for four Indian tribes and irrigate southwestern Colorado and New Mexico farmland.
