But the water diversion would threaten the squawfish by depleting water in the San Juan basin. ``By law, I am protector of endangered species. And, by treaty, I am trustee for Native Americans,'' Lujan said.

DOC.HEAD: Sunup and Sundown Cause Hubble to Tremble
DOC.TEXT: Each time the sun comes up or goes down on the Hubble Space Telescope, the the $1.5 billion instrument wobbles slightly for reasons engineers still don't fully understand. ``It extends for several minutes, 10 or maybe 30 minutes after we come from the dark to the sunlight,'' Jean Olivier, a top NASA telescope official said Friday. ``It's only in the later two-third of the sunlight portion of the orbit that it begins to die down.'' The telescope orbits Earth every 97 minutes and goes through the dawn-to-dusk cycle nearly 15 times a day. The stabilization problem, which showed up earlier this week, is one of many headaches that have put setup work on the telescope far behind schedule. Still, astronomers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland hope they will see the first photograph from the telescope Wednesday or Friday. Olivier said scientists are all but certain that the telescope's solar arrays are causing the wobble. The two arrays, 40 feet by 8 feet, gather energy from the sun. The energy is converted to electricity to provide power for the telescope. ``What we haven't determined is what is exciting the solar arrays,'' Olivier said. ``We don't know whether it's something on board the vehicle that is moving ... it could be the thermal changes.'' Olivier said the astronauts of shuttle Discovery, who put the telescope into its orbit on April 25, saw a slight twist in one of the arrays _ about a 4-inch difference between one side and the other. But, Olivier said, it is not known whether that is causing the problem. ``It's not conclusive what that means, its just an observation the crew made. We're taking it, like everything else, as something to look at,'' Olivier said. The telescope also is rolling slightly, but project scientist Ed Weiler said that problem is expected to disappear once the instrument finds star arrangements that match the pattern stored in computers. The first picture to be taken by the telescope is to have a one-second exposure. The roll is so slight, Weiler said, that an exposure would have to last 10 to 20 minutes before any movement was visible in the resulting photograph.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Outlines Widespread Needs of Mississippi Delta
DOC.TEXT: The poverty-plagued Mississippi Delta needs a broad range of remedies, including a regional bank, expanded Medicaid coverage and magnet schools, to catch up with the rest of America, says a report released Friday. The $3 million report, to be presented to Congress on Monday, is billed as ``a handbook for action'' for a region of rich soil and struggling farms, modern hospitals and dying babies. The region is home to some of the nation's top writers and poorest readers. The study offers a long list of ambitious goals and broadly worded requests for help from federal, state and local governments, businesses, religious leaders, and just about anyone else who might be willing to lend a hand. But the report by the Lower Mississippi Delta Commission makes scant mention of where the money might come from to pay for its recommendations. The commmission, created by Congress in 1988 to prepare a 10-year plan for economic development of the Delta, wasn't responsible for finding sources of funding, said commission member Ed Jones. ``We don't know where the money is going to come from,'' said Jones, a retired Democratic congressman from northwest Tennessee. ``That wasn't our job.'' The report defines the delta as a 219-county strip along the Mississippi River from Illinois and Missouri to Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana. The study's main recommendations include: _ Coordination of efforts by federal agencies dealing with infants and pregnant women to reduce the high rate of infant deaths in the Delta; _ Creation of comprehensive state programs aimed at reducing the number of teen-age pregnancies; _ Expansion of Medicaid coverage for former welfare recipients who find jobs and increased efforts to attract more doctors and nurses; _ Establishment of a regional bank to pay special attention to small businesses and those owned by minorities; _ Revision of federal tax codes to allow first-time, low-income home buyers to set up tax-free savings accounts for down payments; _ Establishment of model magnet schools in each of the Delta states and a regional magnet school for math and science; _ More money from Congress for Head Start educational programs; _ More training for Delta farmers trying to keep up with advances in agricultural technology; _ More loans from the Farm Credit System and the Farmers Home Administration and simplification of the paperwork for such transactions; _ Additional state and federal money for upgrading highways throughout the region and for improving rural airports and ports; _ Coordination of state and federal efforts for reducing hazardous waste disposal, protecting wetlands and reducing soil erosion.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Plane with 11 Aboard Crashes into Mountain
DOC.TEXT: A chartered jet carrying 11 people crashed on a steep slope Friday near Mount Emerald in north Queensland state, officials said. An army helicopter spotted the wreckage of the Cessna Citation 10 miles south of the town of Mareeba during a break in fog and rain early Saturday, said Richard Smith, spokesman for the emergency center at Brisbane Airport. The helicopter crew could not get a close look and was unable to say if the pilot or any of the 10 passengers survived, Smith reported. He said the weather closed in again almost as soon as the wreckage was found and the helicopter had to return to base. The plane, owned by the Air North Queensland charter company, was reported missing Friday in a heavily forested area between Atherton and Mareeba, sugar milling communities 875 miles north of Brisbane and 35 miles southwest of Cairns. Civil Aviation Authority spokesman Bill Evans said poor weather conditions and heavily forested terrain hampered search and rescue efforts. The aircraft was flying to Mareeba from Proserpine, 360 miles to the south, and was nearing the end of its flight when it dropped off radar screens, the Australian Associated Press reported.

DOC.HEAD: Desecration Coincides With Jewish Revival, Rise of Far Right
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th pvs `The Sephardim' and 16th pvs `In the' to CORRECT spelling of Ashkenazic. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-France-Desecration, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For French Jews, flourishing more than at any time in their history, the desecration of tombstones in a southern town was a brutal reminder of France's long, sordid history of anti-Semitism. From the conviction of army officer Alfred Dreyfus nearly 100 years ago to roundups of Jews by French police during World War II to the bombing of a Paris synagogue in 1980, anti-Semitism remains a major fear among French Jews. ``Anti-Semitism is a dormant volcano whose eruptions are never predictable,'' wrote political analyst Robert Sole. This week's vandalism and mutilation of a recently buried corpse in Carpentras came in an era of renewed Jewish pride in France. It also coincided with the steady rise of the extreme-right National Front, a party that has rallied an estimated 15 percent of voters around an anti-immigrant, racist platform that also targets Jews. Its leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen, prides himself on ``saying out loud what everybody is thinking to themselves.'' He has joked about the Nazis' crematoriums and called the gas chambers ``a detail'' whose existence was still ``being debated by historians.'' He regularly rails against ``Jewish lobbies,'' and frequently accuses the media of being dominated by Jews. His followers deny their policies fuel racial hatred and anti-Semitism, but French Jews aren't so sure. Traumatized by World War II, which saw the deportation of some 117,000 Jews from France to Nazi concentration camps, a community of guilt-ridden survivors harbored fears of new persecution. After the war, many renounced their Jewish identities, changed their names, refused to circumcise baby boys or to give their children Jewish educations. Today, Jewish life is thriving. In the past 15 years, the number of synagogues in the Paris area has jumped from 30 to 70. In 1950 there were three kosher butchers. Today there are more than 100. Kosher restaurants, fast-food outlets, supermarkets and professional caterers are too numerous to be counted. Jewish publications boast more readers than ever, and 13 radio stations broadcast Hebrew and Yiddish songs, cultural and news commentaries. The revival is due largely to the 150,000 Sephardic Jews from Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia who poured into France during the 1950s and 1960s as the French colonies won independence. The Sephardim _ Jews of Spanish origin as opposed to Jews from Eastern Europe known as Ashkenazic _ make up more than 60 percent of France's population of about 650,000 Jews. That is possibly the world's third-largest Jewish community after the United States and Israel, since immigration has reduced the number of Jews in the Soviet Union. Besides their own folklore and cuisine, the Sephardim brought an unconditional commitment to Judaism and a demand for Jewish culture in France. In the three decades since they arrived, they have become as prominent in French life as their Ashkenazic counterparts, enjoying enviable positions in industry, government, the media and the arts.

DOC.HEAD: Drought-Stricken Peru Seeks Int'l Food Aid
DOC.TEXT: Peru, hit hard by drought, is calling on industrialized countries and the United Nations to donate food to help it get through the next nine months, a government spokesman said Friday. For the past year Peru, along with neighboring Bolivia, has been suffering the worst drought in the region this century. The drought comes as Peru copes with its worst economic crisis in 90 years. The drought has led to strict water rationing in the capital Lima and its port city of Callao, with a total population of 7 million. Many outlying areas depend on water delivered by trucks. Lima's mayor, Ricardo Belmont, has warned that the Rimac River, the city's main source of water, may run dry by July. Peru's electricity supply, which comes mainly from hydroelectric complexes, has also been cut by the drought. Only 14,000 tons of food remain in the counry's storehouses, said Estuardo Diaz, head of Peru's National Office of Food Support. He said about 260,000 tons of food were needed. Peru is seeking aid from the United States, the European Community, and wheat-rich Argentina, as well as the United Nations, Diaz said. Agriculture Ministry sources have said more than half Peru's annual crop of wheat, rice and potatoes has been lost and next year's crop is threatened. The country's Andean mountain regions have been hardest hit. Many peasants are abandoning the countryside. Thousands of others have had to slaughter their cattle for lack of feed. Peru's main wheat- and rice-producing centers are mainly along the country's arid Pacific coast and are irrigated by rivers that flow out of the mountains, which are running at far below normal levels. No substantial relief is expected until the next rainy season, in November. Rising guerrilla violence and the flood of peasants to the cities have driven down food production for the past decade. Last year, Peru imported $700 million worth of food. Now Peru lacks foreign reserves to step up imports. The annual inflation rate is topping 2,000 percent, and the government is all but bankrupt. Maoist Shining Path guerrillas have sought for years to cut the flow of food into Lima, hoping to spark an insurrection in the city.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: We'll Send Americans to Mars _ By 2019
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-9: ``Later, at,'' with Bush in S.C., preview of Sat. speech; DELETES outdated penultimate graf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, setting a distant deadline in space exploration, said Friday that Americans should walk on Mars by the year 2019. ``It's time to open up the final frontier,'' Bush said. ``There can be no turning back.'' Bush, who next Tuesday will begin a budget summit with Congress in an effort to cut the federal deficit, did not cite a cost estimate for a manned Mars landing or say how the government would pay for it. NASA has put a $500 billion price tag on the mission, which would include establishment of a base on the moon. Asked how the United States could get to Mars, Bush quipped to reporters, ``You have to go fairly fast. It's a long way out there.'' As for the money, Bush said, ``Thirty years is a long time.'' By 2019, Bush would be 95 years old. Bush proclaimed the Mars deadline in a speech at Texas A&I University, opening a two-day trip of three commencement addresses. Later, at a Republican fund-raising event in Columbia, S.C., Bush again called for a cut in the capital gains tax rate, saying, ``I'm going to keep on like a broken record until I get that thing done up there.'' In his speech at the University of South Carolina on Saturday, Bush will annouce formation of a volunteer ``Citizenship Democracy Corps,'' an administration source said. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the corps would try to help the new democracies of Eastern Europe establish democratic institutions and legal systems. Proclaiming his goal for a mission to Mars, Bush said NASA is in line for the largest budget increase of any major agency of the government. He declared that leadership in space exploration ``takes more than just dollars. It also takes a decision, and so I'm announcing one today.'' He said he was returning to Texas, his adopted home state, to announce ``a new age of exploration, with not only a goal but also a timetable: I believe that before Apollo celebrates the 50th anniversary of its landing on the Moon, the American flag should be planted on Mars.'' The Apollo moon landing was on July 20, 1969, falling within the 10-year deadline set by then-President John F. Kennedy. ``Thirty years ago, NASA was founded and the space race began,'' Bush said. ``And 30 years from now I believe man will stand on another planet.'' In a speech last summer commemorating the lunar landing, Bush set a goal of a manned expedition to Mars, but did not specify a timetable. He also proposed completion of a manned space station by the end of the century and the establishment of a permanent lunar base by 2010. ``You are coming of age during a golden age of space,'' Bush told the graduating students, also mentioning the Hubble space telescope now in orbit. Bush said his space budget proposal was ``proof positive of America's commitment to an active, exciting and continuing presence in space, to America's leadership in space.'' The president proposed $15.2 billion for NASA, a 24 percent increase, the largest percentage boost for any major agency of the government. Nearly $1 billion of that would contribute directly or indirectly to exploration. Some $188 million is to begin a variety of technology studies for an advanced launch system, a lunar observer and a satellite called Lifesat, which would study radiation biology. Another $775 million includes work on a new power plant and the Mars Observer mission in 1992. NASA's planning has focused on going back to the moon in the years 2004 to 2010 and to Mars between 2016 and 2020. The National Research Council two months ago said it would be a mistake to use the space station, the next big American project, as a staging area for a moon-Mars mission. It said, too, that nuclear power will be essential for such bases and that nuclear propulsion for spacecraft should be tested. For any Moon-Mars project, the United States would have to develop rockets with far greater power than those in use currently. It would need to work also on developing new systems to sustain the lives of astronauts for a voyage of two years. In Texas Friday, Bush made a brief stop to greet flag-waving youngsters. Bush stopped his motorcade, hopped out of his limousine and shook hands with some of about 100 cheering pupils lining the street near their school, McRoberts Elementary. On Saturday, Bush will deliver commencement speeches at the University of South Carolina and at Rev. Jerry Falwell's Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Circus Kicked Out of Second Hotel
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in two days, members of the Soviet Great Circus Bim Bom were kicked out of a hotel Thursday as circus officials scrambled to get money to pay a lodging bill. The 138-member Soviet circus, which had just started a planned two-year goodwill tour of the United States, is stranded in this Atlanta suburb without money following a disagreement with its financial backers. Meanwhile, the circus animals are stuck in Newburgh, N.Y. The company that was transporting the animals took them there, to its headquarters, when the tour broke off after performances in just two cities. Eight circus leaders were turned away from the Brittany Park Hotel Thursday, said Ben Silva, art director of International Showbusiness Inc., a Florida-based firm directing the tour. ``When we went there this afternoon, they said, `We don't want you here.' It was a pretty nasty ordeal,'' Silva said. A Brittany Park Hotel employee who refused to give her name said the eight circus leaders were kicked out Wednesday because one of them was abusive to desk workers. She said there may have been a question about whether the circus officials were able to pay their bill. Hotel managers refused to comment. Other members of the Great Circus Bim Bom, which includes performers from 60 Soviet circuses, were kicked out of a Motel 6 in Marietta on Wednesday. Those performers were accepted later that night at a Scottish Inns of America, where they scrambled Thursday to pay their bills and keep their rooms. Uneko Sugimura Glass, director of operations for the hotel, gave the circus members till Friday to pay. ``We can't help it. I have to pay the employees,'' Ms. Glass said. ``Tomorrow they'll have to move.'' The circus used credit to hold the rooms, but Ms. Glass said she would require cash before the troupe members would be allowed to stay. John Stallion, the circus' promotions director, said a new financial backer planned to wire $2,000 to him Thursday to pay for the rooms. He declined to identify the backer. The circus came to the United States March 31 for a month of training in Wheeling, W.Va. After the first performance, in Hershey, Pa., on April 25, the trip's backers, an Iraqui father and son, withdrew their support, according to Nikolaj Vissokovsky, president of International Showbusiness. Brooks Savage, an attorney for Waleed A.A. Ahmad and his father, said the men had given the circus a loan, and had never intended to back the whole tour. They are out $331,000 plus a promised 10 percent of receipts, he said, refusing to identify Ahmad's father. The only other stop was in Johnson City, Tenn. The performers came to the Atlanta area because that is the home of some of the support contractors for the tour.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Attorney Gets Help From Fidel Castro
DOC.TEXT: Fidel Castro has lent a hand to Manuel Noriega in his drug-trafficking case, the ousted Panamanian leader's lawyers said Friday. The Cuban president met with Noriega's defense team in March, said attorney Frank Rubino, adding that he couldn't reveal what Castro told them due to the classified nature of the information. ``Fidel Castro met with some of Gen. Noriega's lawyers and discussed certain sensitive issues with us,'' Rubino told the Miami Herald. ``He further provided us with certain documentation.'' Castro was quoted by a Brazilian television reporter as saying his information will clear Noriega. ``I have even talked with Noriega's lawyers,'' Castro said. ``If this is the evidence (prosecutors) have against Noriega, then they have no evidence against him, and I have all the proof which proves the falsehoods of the accusations.'' The Cuban leader did not say what kind of evidence he gave the lawyers, but claimed ``to have all the cards in my hands to irrefutably prove the lies.'' According to a February 1988 indictment, the Cuban leader mediated a dispute in 1984 between Noriega and Colombia's Medellin drug cartel over a raid on a drug lab the Panamanian leader had supposedly been paid to protect. Noriega is at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami awaiting trail on charges he took money from the cartel to make his country a safe haven for cocaine smuggling. On Friday, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ordered prosecutors to explain why it gave $5.8 million confiscated from Noriega to Panama's new government. Hoeveler said it appeared the U.S. government had failed to follow normal legal procedures before surrendering the cash found at Noriega's quarters in Panama during the U.S. invasion in December. ``Although it's not common to have $5 million or $6 million in one's bedroom.... it appears the money was his,'' the judge said. ``That raises an interesting question about what right the government had to give it away.'' Hoeveler spoke during a hearing called by defense attorneys, who've threatened to withdraw, saying they haven't been paid since Noriega was captured Jan. 4, two weeks after the invasion began. Prosecutors have seized $20 million in 27 bank accounts around the world. The defense says Noriega must have earned at least some money legally during his 25-year career as military officer and de facto ruler of Panama, and told the judge it needs some of that money to represent Noreiga in the complex, expensive case. Hoeveler has ordered prosecutors to show why the money shouldn't be released to Noriega and his attorneys, saying the government has an obligation to show money was obtained illegally before freezing accounts. Hoeveler also questioned the defense contention that Noriega had no information of his own about where his assets were, saying he wanted the general to tell him by the next hearing whether he has additional accounts. Defense attorney John May said Noreiga had not told them about any additional money, and added that he had no records with him in jail. ``We are not talking about accounts as you or I might have,'' May said. ``These were handled by intermediaries, and certain people who handled a lot of these matters are under indictment.'' Defense attorney Steven Kollin said prosecutors have given the defense information on accounts in the United Kingdom valued at about $10 million. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan asked the judge to block the defense from seeing any more details from the list, saying some of the information could help the defense. ``They contain considerable allegations, sources of information the government has accumulated,'' Sullivan said. Defense attorneys said they would accept a stripped-down list with just the account numbers and the agency currently controlling them, but the judge did not rule on the issue. Noriega had been scheduled to attend the hearing, but Rubino, his lead attorney, was held up in another case and the attorneys for both sides decided to proceed without them. The judge set a new hearing date for May 21, and Sullivan said prosecutors would have more information about Noriega's sources of income by that time. The defense has subpoenaed records of the CIA, the Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies seeking to show Noriega received about $11 million in payoffs from the United States government, as well as up to $7 million more from foreign governments.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Appeals to Mexican Indians, Prays For Plane Crash Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with higher crowd estimate, pope asks Indians return to church, quake in Mexico City. Picks up 9th pvs, `Mexico's native' with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY32
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Friday comforted the families of pilgrims who died in an airplane crash, then urged Mexico's downtrodden Indians to fight to improve their lives. ``Don't be seduced by vices, like alcohol abuse, which causes so many ravages, and don't cooperate with drug trafficking, which causes destruction to so many people in the world,'' he told more than 150,000 people at an outdoor prayer service. John Paul also expressed concern for refugees fleeing political persecution and death squads in Guatemala. Tuxtla Gutierrez is about 100 miles northwest of the Guatemalan border and 425 miles southeast of Mexico City. Behind the altar were misty green mountains in the heart of Mexico's Indian country. Massed marimbas played and thousands of Indian women wearing traditional black dresses and red-embroidered blouses cheered as the pope arrived. Before the outdoor service John Paul stopped at the whitewashed colonial San Marcos Cathedral to pray for 28 pilgrims who died Thursday in a plane crash while flying in to see the pope. ``Death is not the last word, because for those who have faith, life does not end, it transforms itself,'' the pope said. ``Illuminated and aided by that truth, we raise our petition to the Lord for those who died and invoke consolation for those who mourn their loved ones.'' He kissed a bronze cross on the coffin of Luis Miguel Canton Marin, bishop of Tapachula, who worked closely with Indian groups. He then comforted family members, many of whom burst into tears and kneeled to kiss John Paul's ring. At a Mass in Villahermosa, 90 miles north of Tuxtla Gutierrez, the pope lamented the expansion of U.S.-based evangelical churches in Mexico, especially strong in Indian areas, and pleaded with converts to return to the Catholic faith. ``I think again about those people who have distanced themselves from the Catholic Church ... I would like to meet with each one of you to say: return to the breast of the church, your mother!'' the pope cried at a Mass for nearly 100,000 people. The pontiff's homily reflected growing alarm in the Vatican over the success of non-Catholic churches in Latin America and particularly in Mexico. The number of Protestants grew more than 500 percent in Mexico from 1950-80, to 2.7 million. An estimated 90 percent of Mexico's 85 million people remain Roman Catholic. As the pope began his homily, a brief earthquake shook Mexico City, 400 miles away to the northwest. It was not felt in Villahermosa. Mexico's native Indians suffer widespread poverty and discrimination, and despite land reform laws many have lost their communal lands to private farmers. Alcoholism is a serious problem; others have turned to drug trafficking. Protestant sects have translated the Bible into native languages, finding fertile ground in the hopeless poverty of landless peasants and those who have moved to neighborhoods of shacks in the cities. In Tuxtla Gutierrez, the pope encouraged Indians not to ``lose hope in the face of poverty or the continuous assalt on your cultural traditions.'' He added that the Indian's traditional emphasis on the paradise of the afterlife was admirable, ``but you also have the obligation to improve your own human situation.'' ``Everyone must act in accordance with his own responsibility, without waiting for all the political, assistential and social structures,'' the pontiff said. Six million people here speak only Indian dialects, and ancient Mayan is a growing language. The pope greeted Indians in the indigenous Tzotzil and Zoque tongues, drawing roars of laughter and cheers as he joked about his own pronunciation. ``Now I have a difficult task,'' John Paul remarked as he was about to embark on a few lines of Tzotzil saying, ``Jesus loves you, as he loves all his disciples who are `the salt of the earth and the light of the world.''' A rhyming Spanish chant of ``Indians, friends, the pope is with you'' went up; the pope said ``Yes'' and repeated the line. As cheering continued, the pope remarked, ``Your shouting is very good for the pope, because he can rest a little.''

DOC.HEAD: AM-Obit-Oliver,0411
Actress Susan Oliver, `Peyton Place' TV Star
DOC.TEXT: Susan Oliver, a star of the old ``Peyton Place'' TV series and a veteran of many other shows and movies, has died of cancer. She was 53. Miss Oliver, also an accomplished private pilot who made a solo trans-Atlantic flight, died at Thursday night at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital, spokeswoman Louella Benson said Friday. Miss Oliver played Ann Howard in ``Peyton Place,'' a prime-time soap opera that ran from 1964 to 1969 on ABC. Her character was killed off in 1966 by being pushed off a cliff near the fictional New England town. She also appeared on such television shows as ``Star Trek'' and ``The Wild Wild West,'' and in movies including ``Butterfield 8,'' and ``Looking for Love.'' Born Charlotte Gercke on Feb. 13, 1937, in New York, she was the daughter of astrology book author Ruth Oliver and George Gercke, a newsman who became a U.S. Information Agency official in Tokyo. She lived there as a teen-ager. She took up flying in 1964 and eventually began taking part in air races, winning first place in the 1970 Powder Puff Derby. In addition to a private license she earned a commercial license and an instrument rating and also trained in a Lear jet. A week after her ``Peyton Place'' character was killed off she survived the crash of a Piper Cub near Santa Paula, Calif. A friend was piloting. In 1967 she flew a single-engine airplane across the Atlantic by herself, flying from New York to Labrador, Greenland, Iceland, Scotland and finally Denmark. Her hope of ending the trip in Moscow was denied. The flight was detailed in her 1983 book ``Odyssey.'' She did eventually get to Moscow as a State Department delegate to a film festival. Other television appearances included ``The Invaders,'' ``The Virginian,'' ``Ben Casey,'' ``The Rogues,'' ``The Outsiders,'' ``Man From U.N.C.L.E.'' and ``The Defenders.'' She also had parts on episodes of ``Bonanza,'' ``The Nurses,'' ``Dr. Kildare,'' ``Burke's Law'' and ``The Fugitive.'' More recently she was in ``Murder She Wrote,'' ``Magnum P.I.'' and ``Simon & Simon'' among others. She directed episodes of ``M-A-S-H'' and ``Trapper John M.D.'' Miss Oliver's movie roles included ``Green-Eyed Blonde,'' ``The Disorderly Orderly,'' ``Your Cheating Heart,'' ``A Man Called Gannon,'' ``Change of Mind'' and ``Ginger in the Morning.'' A memorial service will be held at The American Film Institute in Hollywood but the date has yet to be scheduled, Ms. Benson said.

DOC.HEAD: Blast in Philippines Jet Kills 8; Bomb Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to show eighth body found, details. Picks up 17th pvs, `At least...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA4;LaserColor MLA201
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire tore through a Philippine Airlines jet Friday as it prepared to leave Manila, killing eight people and injuring 82. Officials said a bomb may have caused the explosion. Panic-stricken passengers trampled one another rushing for the exits, survivors said. Survivors and witnesses gave conflicting accounts of how many explosions there were before the fire, with some saying as many as three. ``They were still demonstrating the safety equipment when it occurred,'' said Isidro Retaso, 33, of Iloilo, the flight's destination. ``There were three explosions, loud explosions, and the ceiling shuddered. On the second explosion, I immediately opened the emergency exits.'' Another survivor, Sony Villareal, 30, also of Iloilo, said she heard one loud explosion. ``After the explosion there was fire and thick smoke billowed. Everybody panicked after that. People were stumbling over each other trying to get out of the plane,'' she said. Flight PR143, a Boeing 737-300, was bound for Iloilo, 290 miles south of Manila. It carried 119 passengers and crew members and was being towed onto the runway at about 3:20 p.m. when the explosion occurred. Oscar Alejandro, director of the government's Air Transport Office, said the planes engines had not even been turned on yet. Police were examining the aircraft to determine the cause of the explosion. ``We're looking into the possibility that a bomb was placed there,'' he said without elaboration. Eduardo Carrascoso, the airport manager, said no bomb threat was received. None of the Philippines' insurgent groups has a history of random terrorism, such as bombing airliners. The last time any such incident occurred was in 1976, when a bomb carried by a would-be hijacker exploded in the toilet of a Philippine Airlines aircraft flying from Manila to Cebu. The hijacker was sucked out of the aircraft, and it was not determined if his motive was political. In 1986, a bomb exploded aboard a Thai Airways jet flying from Manila to Japan, killing one man. Police concluded the man had bought explosives in the Philippines and was returning to Japan when he accidentally detonated a grenade in the aircraft's toilet. Enrique Santos, vice president of Philippine Airlines, said the plane in Friday's incident was being towed to the runway when it was rocked by a single explosion. Dante Santos, the airline president, said flames swept through the plane in only four minutes. One blast apparently occurred near the center of the passenger cabin, near where the bodies were found, he said. The cabin filled with smoke. Most of the people escaped by sliding down emergency chutes before flames spread, survivors said. Airline employee Alvin Rieta said he was a few yards from the plane and heard only one explosion. ``Immediately the door opened and people scampered out,'' he said. ``We suspect it's a bomb, but we can't confirm it.'' The bodies of six adults and one child were found inside the burned-out cabin. The child, a girl, was found clutched to the chest of an adult woman, presumably her mother, rescuers said. Santos, the airlines vice president, said the eighth body was found shortly early Saturday after the plane was towed to a nearby hangar. It could not be determined whether the casualty was male or female because the body was charred. At least 82 passengers were treated for injuries at the airport clinic, according to a airline employee Alfredo Estrella. Twenty-two of the injured were hospitalized, one of them in serious condition. The blast left three large holes in the top of the plane. It was towed to a hangar, where agents of the National Bureau of Investigation began examining it. Officials refused to say late Friday what they had found. It was not known how many foreigners were among the passengers, although authorities said a Japanese man was treated for burns. Two British women escaped injuries, officials said. Among the injured were Aurelio Periquet, president of the Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Rep. Albertito Lopez, a congressman from Iloilo. Officials said the aircraft was leased by Philippine Airlines in November. Tom Cole of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group in Seattle said a three-man Boeing team was going to Manila to take part in the investigation. He had no details on the plane's flight history. The explosion was the worst aviation disaster in Manila since July, when a Philippine Airlines BAC1-11 overshot a runway on a flight from Zamboanga and slammed into a busy highway. Eight people, all of them on the ground, were killed and 91 people were injured in that accident.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn, Moscow Negotiate Over How to Cover Red Army Costs in EGermany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf `East German' to CORRECT typo from Foreign Ministry to Foreign Minister. Picks up 18th pvs, `West German...'
DOC.TEXT: West Germany disclosed Friday that the price for German unification may include temporarily picking up part of the tab for Soviet troops based in East Germany. In another development, West Germany's chief government spokesman accused East German communists of inciting labor unrest in that country. He also said the two Germanys are close to agreeing on the final terms of a treaty that would merge their economies in two months. The economic merger, which will make the West German mark the official currency of East Germany, will cause financial problems for the Soviet Union, which keeps 380,000 troops in East Germany. A West German government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Soviet-West German talks began this week in Bonn over how to cover the living costs of the Red Army troops in East Germany. It appears that Soviet soldiers in East Germany could start receiving West German marks for their living costs in exchange for Soviet rubles after the economic merger. Such an arrangement would mark the first time a NATO country ended up paying in its own currency for the stationing of Soviet troops. Under current troop-stationing agreements with East Germany, the Soviet Union buys East German marks in exchange for so-called transfer rubles at a preferential rate. The East marks are then used to pay for goods and services for Soviet soldiers stationed in East Germany. These are relatively inexpensive because of state subsidies. But West German officials say two complex problems have to be worked out in the talks on covering the troop costs. When the West German mark becomes the East German currency, some sort of an exchange rate will have to be established with the Soviet transfer ruble, which now is not convertible to Western currencies. Also, the economic merger will result in the scrapping of East German subsidies, and the steep price rises that are anticipated will also have to be taken into account. The West German official said the bilateral talks with Moscow are just starting and that it is not clear what kind of arrangement covering the Red Army's stationing costs will be worked out. It also remains unclear how much West Germany would end up paying in deutsche marks to maintain the Soviet troops, or whether the average Soviet soldier would come out ahead. The official said he did not know what the current costs for the Soviet troops are. Any arrangement would be seen as temporary by West Germany. Bonn has said it is willing to let Soviet troops remain on what is now East German territory but only during a transition phase in the unification process. Bonn has insisted that a unified Germany belong only to NATO. Moscow has opposed this, saying that after reunification Germany should be neutral or temporarily belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. East German Foreign Minister Markus Meckel on Friday said the idea of united Germany belonging to both alliances was ``absurd.'' Meckel also said he expects a substantial reduction in Soviet troops soon. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, trying to win Soviet support for his unification plans, has offered expanded economic ties as an inducement to Moscow to back down on its resistance to NATO membership. West German government spokeman Dieter Vogel said that Finance Minister Theodor Waigel will travel to East Berlin on Monday to discuss the Soviet troops issue with East German officials. Meanwhile, West Germany's chief government spokesman, Hans Klein, accused East German communists of inciting Thursday's labor unrest in East Germany. Tens of thousands of teachers, textile workers and farmers staged brief protests and strikes on Thursday to demand protection from the widespread unemployment expected as East Germany moves to a free market economy. Klein said the strike organizers ``are to some extent exactly the forces who caused'' East Germany's dire economic problems before last fall's democratic upheaval ousted the Communists from power.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says It's Difficult to Ban South African Diamonds
DOC.TEXT: A ban on imports of diamonds mined in South Africa could be ineffective and probably would be widely evaded, according to a a congressional study released Friday. Such a ban would have little effect on South Africa's economy, said the study by the General Accounting Office, the investigating arm of Congress, because diamonds are only about 2 percent of the country's exports. Diamonds are not covered by the 1986 law that imposed various trade sanctions on South Africa in an action against the country's racial separation policy, apartheid. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., asked the General Accounting Office for a report on the feasibility of banning imports of South African diamonds. Diamonds cannot be physically distinguished by country of origin. The DeBeers Central Selling Organization, which buys most of the world's diamonds and markets 75 percent to 85 percent of all diamonds sold in the world, already has refused to cooperate in keeping track of South African diamonds. DeBeers' mines in South Africa, Botswana and Namimbia account for 36 percent of world production, and 17 percent of the value of the sales of the selling organization come from diamonds mined in South Africa, the GAO report noted. Diamonds are traded so often before reaching the major consuming countries that ``many opportunities would arise to create false certificates of origins for diamonds of South African or unknown origin,'' GAO said. False certificates already are reported used for sales to India, which bans diamond imports from South Africa, the agency said. The only possibility of an effective ban would come through agreements between the United States and other nations with major diamond cutting indusrtries _ Belgium, India and Israel, the report said. In such a case, GAO said cutters could be forced to chose between buying from DeBeers and direct purchases from producing countries, and the producers might not sell to them because they derive advantages from their DeBeers connection _ notably the company's marketing expertise and policy of buying diamonds even when the market is weak. But if the producers broke loose, they could capture some of DeBeers' profits, either independently or in a cartel, at the cost of assuming the risks of market fluctuations, GAO said.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia Suspends Rights of Israelis to Visit Without Visas
DOC.TEXT: Protesting the smuggling of Israeli weapons to cocaine traffickers, Colombia on Friday suspended a 28-year-old treaty that allowed Israeli citizens to enter the country without visas. Colombia's foreign minister notified Israeli Ambassador Gideon Tadmor of the decision Friday, a foreign ministry spokesman said. There was no immediate comment by the Israeli government. The decision means Israelis who are in Colombia must apply for a visa from the government, and Israelis who wish to travel to Colombia must submit a visa application to a Colombian consulate. Israel has claimed it has no knowledge of how a shipment of weapons it exported ended up being diverted to cocaine baron Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. Rodriguez Gacha was slain in a shootout with police in December. Israel has accused the national security adviser of the Caribbean country of Antigua, Vere Bird Jr., of playing a key role in diverting the shipment of Israeli-made arms to Colombia's notorious Medellin drug cartel. Reports have said the weapons deal was arranged by two Israelis, Maurice Sarfati, a former Israeli army officer, and Col. Yair Klein. Colombian officials have accused Klein, a reserve officer in the Israeli army, of organizing, training and equipping paramilitary groups, and declared him a fugitive from justice. Klein has said the arms shipment was intended for a training school he wanted to set up in Antigua for Panamanian rebels opposed to Gen. Manuel Noriega, who was ousted by U.S. forces in December. When plans for the school fell through, he said, the weapons somehow were diverted to Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal's King Wants to Retain Monarchy
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra proposed Friday a constitutional reform commission be set up and that monarchy be institutionalized in Nepal along with a multiparty democracy. The move drew fire from the Nepali Congress Party, which led a movement that forced Birendra to accept democratic changes in the Himalayan kingdom and on April 6 propelled to power an interim government made up of pro-democracy forces. Party General Secretary G.P. Koirala said, ``We are for a new constitution. A reformed constitution is out of question.'' Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai said the king did not consult him _``It was a surprise.'' A statement from the royal palace said the proposed commission would have seven members, with Supreme Court Chief Justice Biswanbath Upadhyay as chief. ``The constitutional commission will make recommendations institutionalizing constitutional monarchy and the multiparty democracy in the interest of Nepal and the well being of the Nepalese people,'' it said. On April 6, police fired into a crowd of pro-democracy activists marching to the palace, and witnesses said at least 200 people were killed. The outcry forced Birendra to lift a 29-year-old ban on political parties, dismiss a rubber-stamp government and disband a partyless system of government known as the Panchayat. Nepali Congress is the largest group in the interim coalition government. A seven-party United Left Front, two independents and two Birendra nominees complete the Cabinet. Bhattarai's government took office April 19, ending 29 years of rule by the monarch and the Panchayat.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Issues Emergency Stay in Missouri River Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT spelling to Bismarck; SUBS 9th graf to CORRECT that Gavins Point is last dam downriver from lake sted second dam.
DOC.TEXT: A regionally divided federal appeals court on Friday issued an emergency order allowing release of water from a reservoir in the Dakotas into the drought-shrunken Missouri River. The order by the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals is the latest development in a battle between upstream and downstream states over water from Lake Oahe, which stretches through the central Dakotas. It allows the Army Corps of Engineers to let water out of the lake to raise levels in the Missouri, a move the corps and the downstream states contend is needed to maintain shipping on the river. The 8th Circuit order stays a previous ruling by a U.S. District Judge in Bismarck, N.D., which ordered the corps to maintain lake levels through June 1, after the spring hatch of walleye pike. The stay was issued by a three-judge panel of the 8th Circuit until arguments can be heard on the case. The court scheduled those arguments for May 16 in St. Paul, Minn. Judges George Fagg, of Des Moines, Iowa, and Pasco Bowman, of Kansas City, were in favor of granting the emergency stay. Judge Roger Wollman, of Pierre, S.D., dissented. Montana and the Dakotas want to keep the water where it is _ in Lake Oahe, a 232-mile long reservoir that cuts through North and South Dakota. They contend the release would cripple their fishing industry and tourism. Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas and Missouri want the pent up water turned loose to keep barge traffic moving and the wheels of commerce turning in their states. Officials from the downstream states maintain that drinking water, wildlife and power plants would suffer, in addition to shipping companies. A spokesman for the corps said releases into the Missouri would be increased again from both Lake Oahe and the last dam downriver, Gavins Point, which is on the South Dakota-Nebraska border. ``Because of the rain we're getting, the effect on Lake Oahe will be very modest,'' said Paul Johnston, a spokesman for the Corps' Missouri River Division in Omaha, Neb. Attorneys from the Justice Department asked for the stay Thursday, a day after U.S. District Judge Patrick Conmy in Bismarck, N.D., issued an order to curtail the flow of water into the river at the request of the three northern states.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Mayor to Address Racial Tensions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES grafs 13-14, `He mentioned...,' duplicated matter.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY33,41
DOC.TEXT: In an impassioned speech to a city divided by racial conflicts, Mayor David Dinkins on Friday called on New Yorkers to end the city's long history of ethnic conflict. ``This city is sick of violence and we're aching and we must heal the pain,'' Dinkins said in the 27-minute speech broadcast by several of the city's television and radio stations. Dinkins, under fire from the media and supporters, offered to intervene personally in a confrontational, 4-month-long boycott by blacks of two grocery stores owned by Korean-Americans. ``All of us want to live our lives in peace and dignity _ free to walk any street and shop in any store, at any time, in any neighborhood, without fear of force or violence,'' the city's first black mayor told about 300 invited guests. ``We will never allow any group or any person to turn to violence or the threat of violence to intimidate others no matter how legitimate their anger or frustration may be,'' Dinkins said. He mentioned several racial conflicts, including the boycott in Brooklyn. That controversy has spilled over into the courts, where a judge chastised Dinkins for not intervening. Also, a brawl erupted last week at a Brooklyn college during a speech by a professor who believes in white superiority. A Columbia University sports banquet was disrupted by a soccer player's verbal attack on gays and Jews. Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Jimmy Breslin was suspended for two weeks by New York Newsday after slurring an Asian-American co-worker. Guests at the speech _ including religious leaders, city officials and representatives of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith _ listened as Dinkins spoke in City Council chambers. Dinkins noted that New York has many problems, including expensive housing, crack, AIDS and a faltering economy. ``Unfortunately, some small-minded people prey upon these pressures, spreading a message not of unity but of division,'' he said. ``I challenge all of the people of this city to reject these calls to bigotry.'' Dinkins said blacks, Jews and immigrants from Ireland, Italy and other countries faced violence as they arrived here. ``It's an old story, a cycle of immigration and discrimination that's as old as this city itself,'' he said. Dinkins outlined a plan to heal the racial divisions, including formation of a bias strike force at the City Commission of Human Rights and a study by the commission of discrimination in bank lending practices. Hours before the speech, a black construction worker was beaten with bats and billy clubs by as many as five white men in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. The man was found wandering in Bensonhurst about a mile away from the attack and was treated for cuts and bruises, police spokesman Lt. Ray O'Donnell said. Police said they didn't know whether the beating was racially motivated since the victim said no words were exchanged. In downtown Brooklyn, two juries deliberated for another day in the case of two white teen-agers accused of murdering Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old who came to their mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood to look at a used car. Outside the courthouse, 200 to 300 demonstrators and spectators had gathered by mid-afternoon. Earlier, a small cluster of people hung a banner reading, ``Civil rights or civil war.'' Both juries recessed for the evening, and were to resume deliberations Saturday. Emotions at the trial boiled over Wednesday when defense lawyer Stephen Murphy was punched in the face by one of several hundred demonstrators demanding murder convictions. Demonstrators tried to hit Murphy again Thursday, but he was surrounded by police and apparently escaped injury. Murphy also represented a client in the Howard Beach case, the last major trial that stirred tensions between blacks and whites in the city. Dinkins, at his Jan. 1 inauguration, described the city as ``a gorgeous mosaic'' of different nationalities, colors and sexual preferences. In recent weeks, supporters and reporters harshly questioned why he had not rallied to the defense of the mosaic. ``He believes in what he refers to as quiet diplomacy. He thinks it will work. And I hope it will,'' said former Mayor Edward I. Koch. But the Rev. Calvin Butts of Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem said, ``We don't need a quiet diplomat _ we need strong, forthright leadership.''

DOC.HEAD: New York Prosecutor To Oversee Probe Of Georgeia-Alabama Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with one graf to incorporate Sessions' optimism from a0679
DOC.TEXT: An associate U.S. attorney from New York will coordinate the investigation of package bombs that killed a federal judge in Alabama and a city official in Georgia, the Justice Department said on Friday. Louis Freeh, a former FBI agent, is being given overall responsibility for the investigation, the department said in a statement. Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals was killed Dec. 16 in his home in suburban Birmingham, Ala., when a package delivered to his house blew up when he opened it. On Dec. 18 Robert Robinson, a civil rights lawyer and a Savannah, Ga., city councilman, was killed by a similar device. Package bombs similar to the ones that killed the two men also were found at the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta and the NAACP office in Jacksonville, Fla., authorities have said. Those bombs were defused. The FBI and other federal agencies investigating the killings have considered offering a $500,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of a suspect, sources have said. Though the Justice Department statement made no reference to any progress in the investigation, FBI Director William Sessions said in a meeting with reporters that leads in the case ``are consistently moving and progressing very well.'' Asked if the investigation were at the ``tie-up'' stage, Sessions said: ``We're not there yet. But we're approaching it.''

DOC.HEAD: Girl Needing Heart Surgery Taken From Hospital, Mother Sought
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with official saying mother has called relatives saying she wants to return her daughter. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Schneidman said...
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday sought a 12-year-old girl needing heart surgery and her mother, who authorities said abducted the girl from a hospital because the woman's religion forbids blood transfusions. The girl, Kimberly Winfield, was believed to have left Children's Memorial Hospital about 1 a.m. Thursday, said police Lt. Edmund Beazley. The mother, Caroline Winfield, called relatives to say she wanted to return her daughter, said Dave Schneidman, spokesman for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. But she was afraid to surrender for fear of being prosecuted. Police obtained an arrest warrant for the 35-year-old mother on a charge of child abduction because Kimberly is a ward of the state, Beazley said. ``We're not real interested in catching the mother if she doesn't want to be caught, but we do want the child back so we can save the child's life,'' Schneidman said. Police and the state Department of Children and Family Services said they were reasonably certain the mother was responsible for the child's disappearance. ``There doesn't seem to be any doubt of it right now,'' Beazley said. ``Before the child was discovered missing, the mother had told relatives that she was going to take the child from the hospital because she did not approve of the surgery,'' said department spokesman Schneidman. Schneidman said the child needed open-heart surgery to survive. ``The prognosis is she has anywhere from a week to a month to live without the surgery,'' he said. However, Children's Memorial Hospital spokeswoman Jan Benzies said Kimberly, who was admitted Wednesday, was not critically ill. ``She was undergoing tests to determine the severity of her heart problem,'' the spokeswoman said. ``Her doctor does not believe her life is in immediate danger. ``However, it is clinically advisable that she be located and treated within a month,'' she said. No one at the hospital saw the mother or child leave, Beazley said. ``Apparently, she just got her dressed and walked out,'' he said. ``They were allowing the mother to stay in the room with her, which is pretty common with young children. The nurse came back to check on them and they were both gone.'' The mother is a Jehovah's Witness, Beazley said. Jehovah's Witnesses refuse blood transfusions as being against the teachings of the Bible. ``You can't do surgery without a transfusion of blood,'' Schneidman said. The Department of Children and Family Services waited about 34 hours after the disappearance to notify the press so police could check leads on Winfield's whereabouts, Schneidman said. Those leads were exhausted, he said. The agency was named temporary custodian of Kimberly and two brothers, ages 2 and 8, about a month ago because Winfield was unable to care for them, Schneidman said. ``They were living on the streets without proper housing or any evident means of support,'' Schneidman said. The boys, whose names were not released, are now living with their paternal grandmother in Chicago, Beazley said. A department caseworker noticed Kimberly was ill and took her to the hospital, Schneidman said. Larry Winfield, Kimberly's father, had been notified and was very concerned, Schneidman said. He maintains a permanent residence and is employed, but the mother and children have not lived with him for some time, Schneidman said.

NASA should buy at least one more space shuttle because there's a 50-50 chance a craft will be lost in the next several years, a congressional report suggested today. A new shuttle, like the one being built to replace the destroyed Challenger, would cost $2 billion to $2.5 billion. The Office of Technology Assessment said NASA's goal of 14 launches a year poses increased risks to astronauts and that the schedule could be limited ``to a regular, sustainable rate of eight to 10 launches'' by limiting flights to payloads requiring human crews. ``The actual reliability of the shuttle system is unknown, but may lie between 97 percent and 99 percent,'' the report said. ``If reliability is 98 percent, the nation faces a 50-50 chance of losing an additional orbiter in the next 34 flights.''

Opponents of a bill that guarantees workers up to three months of unpaid leave in family emergencies say they're confident they can sustain a presidential veto of the measure passed by the House The 237-187 vote Thursday sent the family and medical leave bill to the Senate, where it faces a contentious and uncertain future. Alixe Glen, White House deputy press secretary, called the vote close and said President Bush remained firm in his opposition. Bush's aides and spokesmen have threatened a veto. ``He fully supports and encourages flexible family leave policies by all employers, but feels that should not be dictated by a Washington mandate,'' she said. ``Employers and employees know what works for them best.''

Federal prosecutors will seek the death penalty for two men charged with murdering a drug case witness in what would be the first execution by the U.S. government in 27 years. ``We recognize the death penalty is an extreme sanction,'' Andrea L. Zopp, one of the federal prosecutors handling the case, said Thursday. ``We think it is appropriate in this case.'' It would be the first use of a November 1988 federal law that allows the death penalty for murders committed to further drug conspiracies. The so-called ``drug kingpin'' provisions sanction the death penalty for murders ordered by drug dealers as part of their business. Alexander Cooper and Anthony Davis are charged with murdering a federal witness to protect their $50,000-a-day drug ring. Davis is still at large.

The coordinator of the government's war on drugs says he will not change strategy despite a Senate study that sets the number of hard-core cocaine addicts in the United States at 2.2 million, more than double the administration's estimate. National drug policy director William J. Bennett angrily rejected suggestions by a Senate committee chairman Thursday that the administration's focus on discouraging casual use of cocaine should be changed to give more attention to hard-core addicts. The addiction statistics in the Judiciary Committee report contrast with an estimate by the government's National Institute of Drug Abuse that there are 862,000 hard-core addicts, defined as individuals who use cocaine at least once a week. The report and the criticism by committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., touched off a day of feuding between Biden and Bennett, who said the senator was seeking ammunition for congressional election campaigns this fall.

Pope John Paul II assailed family planning and materialism as he crossed northern Mexico, telling a crowd of more than 500,000 that workers should not become cogs ``in an immense production machine.'' The pontiff also called for freedom of religious education and demanded greater parental input on sex education in public schools. John Paul drew the largest crowd of his eight-day trip Thursday evening in Mexico's third largest city for his homily on ``The Sanctification of Work.'' ``Without denying the good results obtained ... where a free system reigns,'' he said, ``we still cannot be blind to the defects of an economic system that not infrequently makes riches and consumption its principal engine.''

NATO nations will have fewer nuclear weapons on their soil as a result of an alliance review of its future nuclear strategy needs, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney predicts. Cheney, speaking with reporters after a two-day NATO meeting in Western Canada, also left the door open for a unilateral alliance move to withdraw aged nuclear artillery shells from Western Europe. ``It's entirely possible,'' Cheney said. ``It wouldn't be the first time it's been done.'' The defense secretary said the North Atlantic Treaty Organization clearly is in the mood to pare its nuclear arsenal in light of the near-evaporation of the Warsaw Pact, prospects for Soviet troops withdrawals from Eastern Europe and East-West agreements to slash conventional forces.

DOC.HEAD: Visit Malaysia Year Boosts Tourism
DOC.TEXT: Malaysia started taking tourism seriously only three years ago, but learned fast. One million foreign visitors arrived in the first three months of 1990, designated Visit Malaysia Year, more than double the same period of 1989. That doesn't count 2 million people who dropped in from Singapore, the prosperous city-state next door. The numbers may not be large compared with renowned vacation spots, but are impressive for a place that almost had to be coaxed into putting out the welcome mat. ``For a long time, there was no political will to develop the industry,'' said Sabbaruddin Chik, culture and tourism minister. Malaysia remained aloof for years while its neighbors wooed free-spending foreigners. It is comfortably cushioned by an array of resources and is developing manufacturing to supplement exports of natural rubber, palm oil, cocoa, pepper, tropical hardwoods, tin, petroleum and natural gas. Tourism's status as a major international industry finally prompted the government to create a Ministry of Tourism and Culture in 1987. Chauvinists immediately demanded the names be reversed to give culture precedence over selling the country to foreigners for profit, something that might be tolerated but not particularly liked. They prevailed. A speaker told a forum in January the Visit Malaysia Year campaign is ``making a mockery of Malaysian society,'' something for which the people are not socially prepared. Minister Sabbaruddin's response to that: ``If you wait until everything is ready before you promote tourism, we will never, ever be ready.'' Promoters try to reconcile their goals with the conservative habits of a country that has Islam as its official religion. While the culture has no tradition of tourism, it does put a premium on hospitality. Both social dictates and Islam enjoin Malaysians to treat guests better than themselves. There are limits, however. Without consulting Sabbaruddin, the Culture Division of his ministry banned a Valentine's Day performance by pop singer LaToya Jackson, elder sister of Michael Jackson. She posed seminude for Playboy magazine last year, Kuala Lumpur newspapers reported, and an official said her presence was ``against the values and norms of the local culture.'' Visit Malaysia Year, launched with much hoopla in 1988, was designed to attract foreigners and get them to stay longer, foster the arts and culture and encourage locals to see Malaysia first before they venture abroad. Appointed mascot was Wira the orangutan, representing an endangered species of ape found only in Borneo and Sumatra. Independence Day, Aug. 31, is the anchor for 84 major events, 14 festivals and nine exhibitions. Malaysia offers distinctive Malay, Chinese and Indian cultures along with the architectural heritage of its Portuguese, Dutch and British colonizers. There are unspoiled jungles, spectacular coral, clean beaches and hill resorts above the tropical heat. One resort has a casino. Sightseers can watch rubber trees being tapped and monkeys helping harvest coconuts from tall palms. In Borneo, they can spend the night in the longhouses of former headhunters. The official target for the year is more than 4.2 million tourists and earnings of $926 million, compared to 3.9 million people and $741 million last year. Malaysia was fourth in the region in 1989 after Hong Kong, Thailand and Singapore. Before the campaign began, tourism promoters worried that Malaysia had no readily identifiable image abroad, except perhaps as the country that had sentenced 250 people to death for drug trafficking since 1975 and hanged 84 so far. Simple possession of more than 15 grams (0.529 ounces) of heroin or 100 grams (3.53 ounces) of marijuana is regarded as trafficking and the death penalty is mandatory. Officials were not amused when comedian Steve Martin, an announcer on the Academy Awards telecast in March, told an international live audience: ``We would have liked to have gone `live' from Malaysia, but the TV crew got hung at the airport.''

DOC.HEAD: Saturday Night Fever: Americans Savor It
DOC.TEXT: Saturday night: a night to dance, make love, commit murder, get drunk, watch television, go cruising, rent a video, go out to dinner _ or read a book about what people do on Saturday night. Author Susan Orlean hopes a lot of people will chose the latter and pick up her new book, ``Saturday Night'' (Alfred A. Knopf, $19.95). Orlean, a former Boston Globe columnist and free-lance writer, explores the magic of Saturday night in an episodic journey through the lives of such diverse people as Wellesley co-eds, Bowery drug addicts, a Park Avenue socialite and a suburban baby sitter. The writer traveled to 16 spots across the country. She went cruising with car enthusiasts in Elkhart, Ind., watched diners at the nation's busiest restaurant in Saugus, Mass., and even spent a Saturday night locked in the bowels of an MX missile silo outside Cheyenne, Wyo. ``Fundamentally, it's a travel book that does travel through an idea rather than a landscape,'' Orlean said in an interview at her Manhattan apartment. The sociological question of what makes Saturday night special is neatly folded into each chapter. Orlean cites Saturday night facts: It's the night the fewest long-distance phone calls are made, the fewest suicides occur, the fewest airplane flights are scheduled. It also is the night when most murders occur, the most liquor is sold by the glass and the highest number of reported incidents of cow toppling in rural Pennsylvania occurs. Cow toppling involves pushing a cow over as it sleeps. Cows sleep standing up. Local college kids think this is a zany prank; the cows do not. But it is sociology offered in a non-academic way, thanks to Orlean's witty and descriptive writing. In a chapter on polka dancing at Blob's Polka Park in Jessup, Md., Orlean highlights a sprightly, 82-year-old named Cecelia Kostler who has 350 polka outfits and lives for her Saturday night polka fix. On one Saturday night, Orlean writes that Cecelia was ``feeling more original than traditional.'' So she dressed herself in ``a ruffled white blouse, black bell-bottomed stretch pants, a silver vinyl belt with a large square buckle, silver spike-heeled sandals, a gold chain with walnut-sized links and, as the most eye-catching addition, a side-vented, back-belted, zipper-fronted vest made of red Chinese satin and black-and-white artificial pony fur.'' Orlean also conveys the frustration of jailed criminals, the expectations of recovering drug addicts, the merriment at a Texas zydeco social and the hopefulness of 15-year-old Hispanic debutantes. ``My theory, ... `Does Saturday night matter to people?' got proved fast. The answer was, yeah. So I decided to use Saturday night as my net,'' Orlean said, ``and I think what I caught was interesting.'' Orlean was amazed that none of her would-be subjects turned her down. ``That really goes against my own premise that Saturday night is a very private time. Here I was asking total strangers to let me intrude, and they did. ... I would probably turn me down.'' She did experience one rejection of sorts. She was asked to leave socialite Nan Kempner's Park Avenue home _ by the rear door, of course _ before guests arrived for a formal dinner party. ``That struck me as interesting. It was the only place that people drew the curtain. It was a more private world than a nuclear missile silo.'' Another subject, a drug dealer who was supposed to take Orlean along on his Saturday night rounds, never panned out, ``We tried to get together about six different times and I finally gave up because he said he was just too busy. I later found out he got out of the drug business to sell aluminum siding.'' She also learned after completing the book that one of the convicted criminals she quoted liberally in a chapter titled ``Killing'' came to an abrupt end _ he murdered a federal drug agent in New York after being paroled and was later himself mysteriously gunned down. ``That certainly made me feel creepy,'' she said. The only normal Saturday night activities Orlean didn't get to explore were going on a first date and staying home watching television with a couple. ``I just couldn't figure out a way to do that, insert myself in the situation without changing it,'' she said. ``Those are the private type of Saturday night moments that are just going to have to remain that way.'' One of the most difficult tasks in researching the book was deciding what to wear at each stop. ``I guessed wrong a lot of times,'' Orlean said, like the time she went club hopping with a pair of Los Angeles teens, who had a different outfit for every stop. Orlean chose a simple black outfit. ``They were horrified and told me to make sure I told everyone I was from out of town.'' But without a doubt the hardest thing for Orlean was giving up three years of her own Saturday nights. ``I never got used to being away and working on the weekend,'' she says. ``It mattered. I suffered. I hated it.''

DOC.HEAD: Arabia: Sand, Sea and Sky
DOC.TEXT: Mention Saudia Arabia, and most people won't think of sharks. Or bats. Or baboons. How about monsoon rains _ or migratory birds splashing around in marshes created from 40,000-year-old fossil waters? These and numerous other natural wonders actually exist in Saudi Arabia, and they're captured on film for disbelieving Western eyes in a new three-part series, ``Arabia: Sand, Sea & Sky,'' debuting Tuesday on cable TV's Discovery Channel. The series, by British producer-director Michael McKinnon, should give viewers a new perspective on a region mostly associated with sand dunes, oil fields and ``Lawrence of Arabia.'' McKinnon was researching his 1985 documentary on the Arabian culture, ``Treasure of the Gulf,'' when he discovered that the western end of Saudi Arabia along the Red Sea harbored a wonderful abundance of wildlife, vegetation and strange geological forms. Coral reefs sheltered fish, eels and sharks. On land, there were mangroves. In the foothills, forests of junipers, acacias and palms were inhabited by birds, bats, lizards, butterflies and large mammals, including hundreds of thousands of baboons, mountain camels and small herds of the rare ibex. Farther north, the remnants of extinct volcanoes created a pseudolunar landscape. ``I said, `My God, this is a completely unknown thing,''' McKinnon recalled in a recent interview. His documentary series has proved to be an eye-opener not only to Westerners, but to Arabs as well. ``I think it will be a surprise for most Arabian viewers,'' McKinnon said. At preview showings of the series, he said, ``It's been a consistent reaction among people of the peninsula that there was this diversity of wildlife in the peninsula.'' The first episode, ``The Mountain Barrier,'' focuses on the relatively lush foothills along the western and southwestern coasts of the Saudi peninsula. The greenery owes its existence primarily to a 1,000-mile string of western mountains reaching 13,000 feet high that wring most of the moisture out of eastward-sailing Red Sea clouds. At the same time, oil-financed irrigation projects seem to be creating a new ecological order. Migratory birds have changed their routes to take advantage of newly created wetlands from irrigation projects that are pumping fossil waters from 3,000 feet beneath the parched surface. Cinematographers John Bulmor and Tony Bomford do a fine job in capturing these images, and Richard Kiley provides suitably spare narration. The second episode, ``Red Sea Rift,'' deals with the rich underwater flora and fauna along the Red Sea coast. The final segment, ``Eye of the Camel,'' focuses on the mammoth southeastern sand desert, the Rub Al Khali, and the traditional Bedouin lifestyle that is under siege from agribusiness, oil and superhighways. McKinnon noted that conservation is making a comeback in Saudi Arabia after traditional means of preserving the fragile landscape were swept aside as petrodollars transformed Saudi life virtually overnight. The Saudis created the National Commission for Wildlife Conservation five years ago as improved transportation and irrigation systems pushed crops and livestock into areas that never before would have supported farming or grazing. Wheat and sorghum fields seem to be a boon to wildlife, but grazing isn't. McKinnon said the future of the peninsula's wildlife will depend on how well the Saudis preserve vegetation from herds of goats and sheep. ``There's a big move now ... to protect flyways for birds, to fund new breeding grounds for gazelle, ibex, to set aside areas for conservation,'' he said. There are other hopeful signs. He said that in some protected areas, ``botanists are finding desert plants they didn't know existed.''
