DOC.HEAD: Congress Intervenes in Dispute Over Bulletproof Vests
DOC.TEXT: Slowly, deliberately, Richard Davis loads his .44-caliber Magnum handgun. He grasps the pistol with both hands, points it at his abdomen and stares ahead grimly. He fires; his body jerks with the impact. A grin spreads across his ruddy, weather-beaten face. ``Nothing to it, folks,'' he says with the satisfaction of a man who has shot himself more than 130 times as a sales pitch for the bulletproof vests his company manufactures. But despite Davis' confidence in his product, the federal government is pushing national standards for body armor that he and other producers consider unreasonable. The feud has become so bitter that some law enforcement groups, for whom vest quality is a life-or-death matter, are asking Congress to intervene. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., said he expects to introduce a bill to establish mandatory standards this month. Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., has written Attorney General Dick Thornburgh urging him to mediate a compromise. ``The increasing uncertainty can only hurt law enforcement officers,'' Levin wrote. The highly technical debate boils down to four issues: how the vests should be designed, particularly the amount of stuffing needed to stop bullets; how they should be tested for effectiveness; who should set the standards; and whether they should be voluntary or mandatory. The National Institute of Justice, a branch of the Justice Department, has set voluntary standards for vests and tested them for quality since the early 1970s. During testing, vests are mounted on clay blocks and bullets are fired into them from varying distances and angles. To meet NIJ standards, a vest must not only stop bullets; it must also prevent them from making an excessively large dent in the clay. That's because a bullet can strike with enough force to damage internal organs even if it doesn't penetrate the vest. The government toughened its standards in 1987 to keep pace with changes in weapons and ammunition, said Lester Shubin, science and technology director for the NIJ. Suddenly, more than 50 percent of the vests were flunking the tests. Manufacturers _ including Davis' Second Chance Body Armor of Central Lake, Mich., _ cried foul, saying the only way to ensure that their vests consistently passed was to make them so thick and bulky that police wouldn't wear them. ``Police officers don't really want to wear the stuff, anyway. Give them any excuse to take it off and they will,'' said Ed Bachner, ballistics manager for E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Co. His company manufactures Kevlar, the synthetic fiber used in most bulletproof armor the past 20 years. ``Police are dying because they aren't wearing vests, not because the vests are bad,'' Bachner said. Surveys show that only about 30 percent of police wear vests, even though many law enforcement agencies require it, said George Austin Jr., national executive officer of the Fraternal Order of Police. Manufacturers say the number may be lower. Du Pont has documented more than 1,000 ``saves,'' or incidents in which wearing Kevlar body armor prevented death or serious injury, Bachner said. Most are shootings, but many saves have involved stabbings, auto accidents and even a couple of bull gorings. A single vest retails for about $350, Davis says, although he recently sold 4,000 to the Detroit Police Department for $175 apiece. Larry Gates, executive director of the Personal Protective Armor Association, an industry group, says no vest has ever failed to protect a wearer from bullets it was designed to stop. ``They've performed flawlessly in the field, where it counts,'' he said. ``But in the laboratory tests under the NIJ standards, over half the vests fail. The test is flawed ... but the NIJ won't budge.'' Shubin counters that vests have a good field record because his agency's tests have kept duds off the market. ``We believe a lot of their armor is marginal,'' he said. ``But we believe if it passes our standard it's going to work 100 percent on the street, and it has. We're being faulted for being successful.'' Last year, Du Pont and the Personal Protective Armor Association established their own standards, which they say produce more consistent test results while meeting wearers' comfort requirements. Shubin and many police leaders aren't convinced. ``I could put up with a little discomfort in exchange for extra protection,'' said Austin, the FOP officer and a Poquoson, Va., beat cop. ``And I'm the one out there on the street getting shot at.'' Police generally have sided with the government in the dispute, although not unanimously. New York City Police Commissioner Lee Brown, who favors the NIJ standards, calls the debate over vest design and testing procedures a ``smoke screen.'' ``The issue is who's going to develop the standards,'' Brown said. ``I want them developed by someone who has no vested interest in selling a product.'' The Fraternal Order of Police wants Congress to designate a non-industry body such as the NIJ to set national standards, and the International Association of Chiefs of Police has taken a similar position. But the State Association of Chiefs of Police, a division of IACP, voted last month to oppose congressional intervention and to ask the manufacturers and the NIJ to accept binding arbitration. One vest manufacturer that supports the government standards is Point Blank Body Armor of Amityville, N.Y. Company president Richard Stone says the industry's primary motive is to protect Kevlar's dominance of the bulletproof vest market. ``This is basically a commercial situation,'' Stone said. ``Du Pont's had a virtual monopoly on body armor for 20 years and they want to keep it that way.'' Du Pont's Bachner disagrees, saying the controversy arose before the recent emergence of competing synthetic fibers. ``I tell police if they can find a better product they ought to buy it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: The God Complex: Puppet Creations
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: He may not be as famous as Jim Henson, but in his own way, Frank Ballard has done as much to advance the art of puppetry in the United States as the man who brought us Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy. For 23 years, Ballard has directed the puppetry program at the University of Connecticut, the first school in the United States to offer a bachelor of fine arts degree in puppetry and the only one with bachelor's and master's programs still in existence. In a series of basement rooms overrun by scraps of cloth, woodworking tools, sewing machines and an endless supply of puppets, Ballard has taught students how to design and make marionettes, hand puppets and stick puppets. He shows them how to operate the dolls, write scripts and stage large-scale puppet productions. Ballard's students have gone on to work for Henson on various Muppets projects, movie production companies in Hollywood and their own traveling tours. One former student is a psychologist, using puppetry in therapy, and another designs toys for Fisher Price. ``I guess I've worked all my life trying to upgrade the standards of puppetry,'' said Ballard, 60, who plans to stop teaching this year and devote his time to creating a museum for the thousands of puppets he and his students have created, from tiny hand puppets wearing intricate clothing to larger-than-life monsters with wagging tongues and rolling eyeballs. ``I'd like to ... see the art respected and accepted as a true art form rather than kiddies' play. ``To do that, part of it is the responsibility of the puppeteers, who have to upgrade the quality of their work. Part of the problem is there's no formal training in puppetry.'' In Europe and Asia, puppetry has a strong tradition, with countries in Eastern Europe offering subsidized puppetry training to students and then often providing them with jobs. Puppetry doesn't enjoy such status in the United States, where puppets are generally thought of as the cute and cuddly domain of children. Several of Ballard's students say they had trouble convincing their parents that it was worth spending four years in college for a puppetry degree. Ballard has worked to change that image, through his classes and the grandiose, adult productions his students have staged, such as ``Macbeth,'' ``Peer Gynt,'' ``The Fantasticks'' and ``H.M.S. Pinafore.'' ``We do large productions here because nobody else can _ to give as many students an opportunity to work in productions as possible and to teach the audience, because the preconceived notion of what a puppet is so squared in,'' Ballard said, sitting with five students at a table covered with glue droppings, saw dust and puppet eyes. In the world of puppetry, Ballard and his program are well known. His students have performed a puppet opera at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, and Ballard has addressed the United Nations General Assembly. Ballard has served as president of the Puppeteers of America and L'Union Internationale de la Marionette. He has been honored by the New England Theatre Conference and by the Connecticut Commission on the Arts. Last year, President Bush saluted Ballard in a letter, praising him for his contribution to the arts. Perhaps the best testament to Ballard's fame came a few years ago when one of his students was traveling in the Soviet Union, where puppeteering enjoys great popularity. The student was pulled aside and interrogated by police, who wanted to know what he was doing in the Soviet Union. All the student had to do was mention Frank Ballard and the University of Connecticut, and he was immediately released by some very impressed and friendly Soviet security agents. Ballard's love for the craft began when he attended a puppet show at age 5. He received a puppet for his birthday and began staging his own shows, eventually putting himself through college. He came to UConn in 1956 to teach in the Dramatic Arts Department. Within a few years, he was teaching puppetry, and in 1966 began offering bachelor's degrees. The University of California at Los Angeles and the University of Hawaii eventually began puppetry programs, but both have since folded. Ballard is not giving up the helm of UConn's puppetry program because he wants to, but because his health requires it. He has Parkinson's disease, a degenerative neurological disorder that causes tremors and muscular rigidity. ``I can't manipulate my hands anymore and I can't perform,'' he said. ``It gets harder. I'd rather stop now than be carried out.'' Technically, Ballard retired last fall, but he continued to teach this year because he didn't want to see the puppetry program end while the school searched for his replacement. For Rolande Duprey, one of two graduate students in the program, ending the puppetry program would have been a disaster. Starting last spring, Duprey began preparing for a performance she finally staged a few weeks ago. First, she chose a 15th-century French farce called ``Pierre Pathelin.'' Then she translated it into English, and rewrote it in verse, adding a few more characters and deleting some of the monologue to make it more appropriate for a puppet show. Last summer, she began molding heads for the main characters. Then she began making bodies and stitching costumes and a curtain. She also trained puppeteers, some of whom were newcomers. ``You have to do it because you love it, something like this which can be so difficult, so demanding _ you have to love it,'' Duprey said, showing off one of her lifesize _ and lifelike _ creations, an old man hand-and-stick puppet whose haughty eyelids open and close and jowls droop to perfection. Sandy Bellock, a UConn senior and puppetry major, agreed that the puppetry program was demanding because it requires students to design, create, act and write, but that's why she likes it. ``All my life I've been interested in the arts as a whole _ dance, acting, music _ and I discovered puppetry was an art form that would allow me to combine my interests,'' she said. ``Plus I like the idea of creating a whole reality. Instead of just casting a bunch of characters, you get to create characters. I call it the God complex.''

DOC.HEAD: Global Changes Propel Peace Corps Revival
LaserPhoto WX19 of May 10
DOC.TEXT: The Peace Corps is undergoing an impressive revival as increasing numbers of foreign governments seek the kind of low-cost expertise the volunteer agency provides. ``In the next 18 months, we will enter more countries than were entered in the last 18 years combined,'' says Paul Coverdell, the former Georgia state legislator who has served as Peace Corps director for the past year. President Bush, who has stressed the importance of volunteerism, is a big booster of the Peace Corps. At a time of budget austerity, Bush is showing his commitment by asking for $181 million for the Peace Corps for 1991, a record $16 million increase. Congress also has been supportive, partly because of the 20 former volunteers who have since become lawmakers. Everything seems to be going the Peace Corps' way lately. Internationally, governments are showing less interest in ideology and more concern about solving human problems. For many of them, the Peace Corps is a logical place to turn. The anti-communist evolution in Eastern Europe last year opened up a whole new region from which the Peace Corps had previously been excluded. When the agency was created in 1961, East bloc countries were asked whether volunteers would be welcome. The answer: No, thanks. With English becoming increasingly accepted as the language of international business, what better agency than the Peace Corps to fill the need for classes? ``Everybody wants to learn English,'' Coverdell said. The Peace Corps also sends out experts in agriculture, urban development, engineering, health, nutrition and a new area suddenly in vogue: the environment. ``There's no institution ready to do so much for so many for so little,'' said Coverdell, an Atlanta businessman and long-time Bush backer. After an auspicious beginning under President John F. Kennedy almost 30 years ago, the Peace Corps eventually fell into disfavor in the mid 1970s. Enrollment dropped along with the budget. Watergate and the war in Vietnam made many qualified young people cynical about serving in a government agency, and applications fell. Some volunteers were haunted by charges they were CIA operatives disguised as do-gooders _ even though Kennedy, early on, ordered the CIA to stay away from the agency. President Nixon stripped the Peace Corps of its independent status, making it a part of an umbrella volunteer agency. In the process, the corps lost some of its unique identity. The agency became independent again in 1982. The current enrollment, 6,500 volunteers and trainees, is still far below the late 1960s high of more than 15,000. But Coverdell predicts that almost 7,300 will be serving by the end of 1992. When Coverdell, 50, took over in May of 1989, the Peace Corps was operating in 64 countries. By the end of this year, he expects that figure to rise to 76. Volunteers will be at work in Hungary and Poland in the coming weeks and in Czechoslovakia in a few months. Initial contacts with Bulgaria and Romania have been made, and even Mongolia, one of the world's most isolated countries, has shown interest. Latin American countries that once shunned the Peace Corps are now welcoming volunteers. ``There is broad expansion on every continent,'' Coverdell said. Obviously, the Peace Corps can have only a marginal impact on a given country. The Philippines historically has had the largest number of volunteers _ there are about 300 there now _ but poverty remains pervasive, afflicting well over half the population. And as the first Peace Corps director, Sargent Shriver, sees it, the volunteers, not the host country, get more out of the experience than anyone. As always, Peace Corps performance is impaired by some volunteers who view their two-year stint less as a commitment to the poor than as a chance to see exotic places. But not since the halcyon days of 1961 has the agency's image been as favorable as it is now. Compared with those early years, when the ranks of the Peace Corps were dominated by young liberal arts graduates, the agency projects a grayer appearance nowadays, thanks to the 12 percent who are over 50. The average age of all volunteers is 31, a more mature force than the one envisioned by Nixon who, campaigning against Kennedy in 1960, said the Peace Corps would become a discredited haven for restless youth _ a ``Kiddy Corps,'' as Nixon described it.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Aim New Criticism at Liberal Justice Marshall

EDITORS NOTE: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. Recent polls indicate only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the eighth in an occasional series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.
DOC.TEXT: Thurgood Marshall's place in history was assured before he became a member of the Supreme Court in 1967. Now his conservative critics, long distressed by Marshall's liberal record, say it's time for the first black justice to step aside for a more youthful, energetic successor. Marshall, a civil rights pioneer who as a lawyer helped changed the nation, will be 82 in July. He shrugs off questions about retirement with customary curmudgeonly humor. ``I have a lifetime appointment and I intend to serve it,'' he has said numerous times. He once told The Washington Post, ``I expect to die at 110, shot by a jealous husband.'' For decades before President Johnson named him to the high court, Marshall had traveled the nation as the recognized legal champion of the poor and the powerless. Some say he ranks with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. as a leader in the battle for racial equality. Over 23 years as legal director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and then as the federal government's solicitor general, Marshall argued 32 cases before the Supreme Court. He won 29. His biggest NAACP victory came in the 1954 ruling that declared racially segregated public schools unconstitutional. ``He changed America,'' said Erwin Griswold, the onetime Harvard University Law School dean and himself a former solicitor general. ``When I think of great American lawyers, I think of Thurgood Marshall, Abe Lincoln and Daniel Webster,'' said Georgetown University Law School Dean Thomas G. Krattenmaker. Experts agree Marshall's legal accomplishments before joining the high court far surpass those of any fellow justice. It is his stature as a justice that has been questioned of late by conservative critics. They say he is losing interest in much of the court's day-to-day work and delegates too much responsibility to his young law clerks. Former clerks deny it. Marshall declined to be interviewed for this article. One of the harshest attacks on Marshall was penned by Terry Eastland, onetime aide to former Attorney General Edwin K. Meese III. Eastland last year wrote in the conservative National Review, ``One joke has it that if Marshall retired, at least he wouldn't be paid for watching television.'' The reference apparently was prompted by earlier reports that Marshall is a fan of ``The People's Court'' and watches the TV show in his court office. The justice has denied the reports, saying, ``That's an awful program.'' Criticism of Marshall's supposed work habits are often accompanied by questions of his health. Standing 6 feet 2 and overweight, Marshall shuns exercise. He had a heart attack in 1976, has suffered from bouts of pneumonia and bronchitis. He was hospitalized in 1987 with a potentially dangerous blood clot in his right foot. Marshall walks slowly and with apparent difficulty. Family members reportedly convinced him a few years ago to stop driving; he now gets to work in a chauffeur-driven limousine. Former clerks, however, insist his health is not deteriorating. Georgetown law professor Mark Tushnet, a Marshall clerk in 1972, said, ``He did not look in good health then. He doesn't look any different now.'' Tushnet, who is writing a biography of Marshall, also dismissed the idea that the increasing dominance of the court's conservatives has soured Marshall. ``He seemed grumpy when I worked with him and he seems grumpy now,'' Tushnet said. Legal scholars say a succession of conservative court appointments has denied the old civil rights fighter the chance that was briefly his to shape the law. Within two years of Marshall's appointment to a predominantly liberal court, Chief Justice Warren Burger replaced Earl Warren and the court's evolution toward conservatism had begun. ``But Marshall has been very important in providing visions of where the law should go,'' said Krattenmaker. ``He has written several (dissenting) opinions that may prove to be persuasive.'' Marshall and Justice William J. Brennan are the court's most consistent liberals and most frequent dissenters. They stand alone in opposing capital punishment in all circumstances, press for broader protection for criminal defendants and lead the way in supporting affirmative action for minorities and women. Marshall's former law clerks call him the court's conscience and say his role is one of making sure the other justices realize their decisions are affecting real, flesh-and-blood people. Marshall suffers from glaucoma. At times, it seems he has trouble reading summaries of his opinions from the bench. At a celebration of his 80th birthday, he insisted that television camera lights be turned off because the glare bothered his eyes. Rumors of declining alertness were fed by an incident last fall during an oral argument session before the court. Marshall posed several questions to a lawyer he seemingly believed was representing the government when, in fact, the lawyer was representing the other side. ``If I appear confused, I am,'' Marshall said at one point. When another justice noted whom the lawyer represented, Marshall recovered by telling the lawyer, ``Well ... there is no bar to you giving me some help.'' Marshall's public appearances away from the bench are rare. But, when he does appear, he doesn't mince words. In televised interviews in 1987, he said President Reagan's civil rights record ``ranks at the bottom,'' and accused Meese's Justice Department of trying ``to undermine the Supreme Court itself.'' In a speech to a conference of lawyers and judges that year, he said he was not about to quit fighting right-wingers. ``Don't worry, I'm going to outlive those bastards,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Edwin Cooperman, Head of the Card Machine That Drives American Express
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Edwin Cooperman's successes at American Express Co. are recounted nightly in commercial television scenes. There's the toddler who feeds the new videocassette recorder gloppy breakfast cereal. The traveling executive who loses his charge card just before trying to check into a hotel for the night. The Yuppie dad who cancels all appointments and buys a fishing boat to take his kid on vacation. They are stories with happy endings, thanks to American Express and Cooperman, who as president of the Travel Related Services division is the man behind those scenes. During Cooperman's three years at the helm of the card division, American Express has introduced such innovations as a ``Global Assist'' 24-hour help line for cardmembers, the ``Optima'' extended payment card, and buyer assurance plans guaranteeing charged items against loss, theft or damage. The ads pitching these extras aren't concocted by copy writers. They are based on real calls and letters to American Express, which has made service a cornerstone of the card division under Cooperman. Trim and slightly graying at 46, Cooperman spends a majority of his time on the road or in the air, visiting the company's far-flung ofices, from Beijing to Berlin, Singapore to St. Louis. He's not a Mastercard or Visa holder, but keeps five American Express cards in his wallet _ Platinum, Gold, Green, Corporate and Optima. ``Each one has a different use,'' he said. ``My daughter, of course, now she wants five. But that's a whole different story. She'll stick with her two.'' A lawyer by profession, Cooperman has been with the company for nearly two decades. He has an 18-year-old card-carrying daughter in college and another 15-year-old daughter in high school. When he's in his 40th-floor corner office overlooking southern Manhattan, Cooperman studies the competition intensely, collecting newspaper and magazine articles about the card business. He especially enjoys showing visitors a yellowed clipping by financial columnist Dan Dorfman, portending the demise of American Express's growth. It was written 10 years ago. ``Since that time we've had the greatest growth in our history,'' Cooperman said. There has been speculation that Cooperman's division may feel increased pressure to perform now because of weaker sister businesses, notably Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which has been pinched by the recession on Wall Street and freshly bankrolled by its American Express parent. Cooperman said he's not overly concerned. ``I think we're going to run our business as usual. But you know all the employees and myself, we stand a little taller these days. We want to show the strength of the company,'' he said. ``So I guess in that respect, we put pressure on ourselves.'' Cooperman's division spends a lot of money _ by some estimates the company's advertising budget is about $250 million, more than Visa and Mastercard combined _ but Cooperman is no moneyloser. Rising from relative obscurity in the company's General Counsel office, he has helped make Travel Related Services the most profitable part of the company. Last year, for example, the division earned $830 million on revenue of $8.4 billion. By contrast, the company's IDS Financial Services unit earned $175 million, American Express Bank earned $122 million, Information Services $83 million and Shearson $110 million. Cooperman helped pioneer the push into high-tech advancements that American Express uses to battle Visa and Mastercard. American Express computers enable it to replace a card anywhere within 24 hours, check a cardmember's credit history instantly and provide help ranging from airline tickets to bail money. Even in mundane monthly billing, Cooperman said, American Express has introduced an imaging technology that provides customers with copies of each charge receipt they've signed. ``Our competitors give you nothing,'' he said. ``They've moved to just telling you what you bought but not giving you the copy back.'' Competitors have watched the number of American Express Cards in the United States grow to more than 24.3 million, up more than 50 percent since late 1985 when Cooperman took command. The card is accepted at more than 3 million establishments worldwide, more than double the number at the end of 1985. Still, Visa and Mastercard remain the dominant plastic in the United States, with a combined total of about 90 percent of the market or more than 200 million cards. American Express may give more, they concede, but customers pay more in membership fees and cannot finance payments, unless they have an Optima card. Financial services analysts say they're not sure how many inroads American Express will make into Visa and Mastercard territory. Nonetheless, most express admiration for the card division and Cooperman. ``When you call up American Express with a problem, you get much better service,'' said Gary Hovis, who follows the company for Argus Research Corp. in New York. Cooperman, he said, ``seems to be a very good executive, a very hard worker. I think he's a plus for the business.'' Bruce Brittain, head of an Atlanta-based market research firm that studies credit-card use, said the quality of service likely will remain an advantage for American Express over bank-issued credit cards. ``No matter what Visa or Mastercard promise, it boils down to what kind of service you get from the issuing bank,'' Brittain said. ``You always hear about the horror stories. There's a real advantage to having one central issuer.'' The high-profile television ads are a hit with Cooperman, who stresses the factual base for the company's service claims. The VCR ad, for example, ``was based on a letter from the mother of this child, who told us this incredible story. It was a positive letter of how pleased she was, and how quickly American Express helped her out and got a new VCR.'' Not all cardmember feedback is so effusive. But Cooperman displays a sense of humor about the limits of some services, such as the lost-stolen-damaged guarantee. ``Obviously anytime you launch a new program like this, you're not going to think of everything,'' he said. A farmer's demand that American Express compensate him for a milkless cow purchased with a card led to a no-animal proviso, Cooperman said. In another instance later excepted from the policy, a cardmember billed American Express for a dozen golf balls whacked off a fairway. ``Under our policy at that time, that was not excluded so we sent the gentleman a funny letter back, and a check, and told him the next time, perhaps, he ought to tie a string to each golf ball,'' Cooperman said. ``Just imagine every golfer in America buying their golf balls with the American Express card. Great business, but the way I play golf ... we'd lose a lot of money.''

DOC.HEAD: Economic News Relieves Wall Street Blues
DOC.TEXT: In the long-running debate over whether the economy is growing too fast or too slowly, Wall Street has begun to entertain the possibility that neither side is right. A surprising run of statistical reports in recent days has prompted some analysts to toy with the idea that conditions are close to a happy medium _ favoring continued slow but steady growth without any drastic change in inflation. Few people in the forecasting business are content simply to proclaim ``clear skies ahead'' and flip the switches off on their computer-powered crystal balls. As practitioners of the dismal science, they are paid to worry continuously about whatever might go wrong. Still, just a few hints that the economy might be maintaining a healthy, sustainable momentum have been enough to lift the stock market to near-record levels of late. For the moment, neither the inflation nor the recession worries that have beset the financial world in recent months appear to have come to fruition. ``Some economists are convinced that the economy could fall into a recession because there is a credit crunch in the financial markets,'' said Edward Yardeni at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``We've argued that this is just another scare which will soon blow away. ``So far the optimistic approach seems to be outperforming the pessimistic approach to investing, although we admit that the first four months of the year were not kind to bond investors. ``We believe the inflation scare which unnerved the bond market is just about over, and the credit crunch scare may soon be over as well.'' The mood in the markets began to brighten early this month, with interest rates having hit their highest levels in a year. The Labor Department's report on April employment, showing much slower than expected growth in jobs, seemed to signal that the pace of business wasn't strong enough to support the kind of inflationary expectations that had been building. That positive view took on some fresh urgency Friday, when word came of a 0.3 percent drop in the producer price index of finished goods and a 0.6 percent decline in retail sales last month. That helped the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials post a 91.22-point gain for the past week to 2,801.58, not far short of the record closing high of 2,810.15 reached on Jan. 2. Other readings for the week showed the New York Stock Exchange composite index up 6.83 at 192.24; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market up 9.49 at 438.10, and the American Stock Exchange market value index up 6.77 at 352.50. Volume on the Big Board averaged 164.34 million shares a day, up from 139.90 million the week before. The revival of optimism in the stock market by no means reflects a unanimously rosy view of the outlook. Indeed, some economists on the Street lately have lowered their estimates of growth for the spring and summer months, at the same time that others are raising their projections. Inflation fears die hard, especially in the bond market. Furthermore, analysts remain mindful of how frequently and rapidly sentiment has shifted among investors recently. ``The economy and inflation have given false signals in the past,'' says the Value Line Investment Survey in its current appraisal of business prospects. ``Volatility is likely to remain the order of the day.''

DOC.HEAD: CEOs Get An Earful During Annual Meeting Season
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders of some of the nation's biggest companies, angry over lower profits, higher debts and rising pay for executives, are using the annual meeting season to vent their displeasure at management. Discontent was particularly evident this past week as executives of CBS Inc. and Pan Am Corp. were put on the defensive at raucous meetings. At the Time Warner Inc. and USX Corp. gatherings, shareholders used votes on stock incentive plans for management to express their dissatisfaction. At CBS, the issue was the third-place finish for the company's television network over the past three seasons. Shareholders criticized the dearth of directors with broadcasting experience on the CBS board and the poor quality of the network's programming. Chairman Laurence A. Tisch was forced to concede the company's prime-time TV performance has been ``a total disaster,'' but he tried to mollify shareholders by pointing out CBS is No. 1 in daytime and sports ratings. ``We are not a total disaster,'' he said. The angry shareholders at Pan Am's meeting were employees of the airline, which hasn't made money since 1980. Teamsters union members, furious because they have been working under conditions imposed by the company for two years since federally mediated contract talks failed, repeatedly interrupted Pan American Corp. Chairman Thomas Plaskett at the meeting in Miami. The USX annual meeting had been expected to be one of this season's most dramatic as shareholders there considered takeover strategist Carl Icahn's proposal to split up the steel-energy company. But Icahn's plan didn't stir up shareholders as much as management's proposal for its new stock incentive plan for employees. Shareholders who took the floor at the meeting _ including several retirees of USX subsidiaries _ angrily questioned why management was lining its own pockets at the expense of stockholders and pensioners. Results of the voting on Icahn's proposal, the stock plan and other issues were not expected until this coming week at the earliest. Icahn, however, has already conceded his idea _ which would have spun off the company's U.S. Steel subsidiary from its Marathon Oil Co. division _ was likely to fail. Time Warner executives found themselves answering the same question they were faced with a year ago: Why didn't Time Inc. accept a $200 a share buyout bid from Paramount Communications Inc. last year instead of buying Warner Communications Inc. and going heavily into debt? Several disgruntled shareholders criticized management because of the company's $10.8 billion debt load and losses attributed to the $14 billion Warner acquisition. They also were unhappy with a stock price that is now less than half the Paramount bid. But, like the USX meeting, the biggest expression of shareholder unhappiness was over the vote on management's stock incentive plan. The proposal passed, but one-quarter of the shares voted were against it. Grumbling at annual meetings is nothing new, although shareholders _ in particular the big institutions like pension funds _ have become more active in recent years. Dale Gerboth, a partner at the accounting and consulting firm Ernst & Young, said he's seen no overall increase in shareholder anger this season, although particular companies with particular problems may have more irate stockholders than other firms. Although large shareholders, including the institutions, are able to communicate with management at other times over the course of the year, the annual meeting is ``still an effective avenue for making a voice heard'' for stockholders, Gerboth said. In other business developments this past week: _Signs of an economic slowdown were evident in government reports of falling wholesale prices and a decline in retail sales. The numbers were greeted jubilantly on Wall Street, where stocks swept ahead, bond prices rallied and interest rates dropped. But the dollar tumbled. _President Bush and congressional leaders announced talks to cut up to $100 billion from the rapidly expanding federal deficit. Tax increases as well as spending cuts will be considered. _Southern California's aerospace industry took two big hits as McDonnell Douglas Corp. said it would lay off another 1,000 workers at its Long Beach aircraft unit and Lockheed Corp. said it would move its Burbank aeronautics operations to Georgia and Palmdale, Calif. The job losses reflected major cuts in defense spending resulting from the thaw in East-West relations.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions May 12-13

DOC.TEXT: The nation's top three banking regulators told bankers they weren't imposing a ``credit crunch'' through overly aggressive regulation. In an unprecedented meeting with the country's largest banking association, the regulators also urged banks to keep lending money to sound businesses. The officials, led by Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan, attended Thursday's board meeting of the American Bankers Association to respond to charges that over-regulation is making bank credit too difficult to get for real estate developers and other businesses.

Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan outlined plans to reform the nation's financial system, including charging banks with risky investments more for deposit insurance. In his first extensive remarks on deposit insurance reform, Greenspan told a Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago conference Thursday that the issue ``should be high on our agenda'' as the government considers permitting banks to expand into securities and insurance. He suggested varying insurance premiums according to the riskiness of a bank's investments, examining banks' books more frequently, seizing weak banks faster and requiring bank owners to risk more of their own money.

The Federal Aviation Administration's top security official has been removed and will be given a new job, an FAA spokesman said. The move announced Thursday move came as a presidential panel prepared a report said to be critical of FAA security operations. Raymond Salazar, whose resignation was demanded by relatives of Pan Am Flight 103 victims, will leave next month to direct the FAA's Center for Management Development in Palm Coast, Fla., said spokesman Fred Farrar.

Pan Am Corp. and ground victims from Lockerbie, Scotland, have settled claims arising from the terrorist bombing that sent Flight 103 crashing into the town, the carrier and the victims' attorneys said. ``We are very pleased that we have been able to reach an agreement, but beyond that we cannot give specifics,'' said Elizabeth Manners, spokeswoman for New York-based Pan Am. The Lockerbie lawsuits accused Pan Am of failing to provide adequate security for the flight.

Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in March as borrowing to buy automobiles rebounded from February, the government said. The Federal Reserve said Thursday that consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.4 percent, up from a revised 0.1 percent rise in February. Borrowing increased at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the first quarter, compared with 7.6 percent for all of 1989 and 8.5 percent for 1988, reflecting a dampening of economic growth.

Yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose at the latest auction to the highest level in a year as the government ended its record $30.5 billion quarterly refunding. The average yield at Thursday's sale was 8.84 percent, up from 8.50 percent at the last auction on Feb. 8. A total of $10 billion in bonds was sold out of bids totaling $19.9 billion.

Rebates are costing Ford Motor Co. about $4 billion a year, eroding the automaker's profits as it fights to hold its U.S. market share, executives said at the company's annual meeting. Ford President Philip Benton said after Thursday's shareholders' meeting that the average of about $1,000 in incentive costs for every car and light truck Ford sells is about double last year's rate.

A New York company said it will begin testing within two years a revolutionary, wireless ``personal'' telephone system in Houston and Orlando, Fla., designed to compete with wired and cellular systems. The lightweight, wallet-sized phones will use high-frequency microwave signals to connect the telephones with each other or to interchange calls with the local phone network. Plans for the new systems, known as personal communications networks or PCNs, were announced by a subsidiary of Millicom Inc.

Apparel stores, boosted by sales of Easter and spring merchandise, continued outperforming the rest of the retailing industry during April. Analysts said department stores, which have lagged the specialty retailers for some time, showed signs of improvement in figures released Thursday by several big store chains.

Stocks settled for a small gain Thursday, encouraged by a relatively good reception for the government's auction of 30-year bonds. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.63 to 2,738.51. Bond prices rose in response to the bond auction, but lower rates weakened the dollar. It fell to two-year lows against the Swiss franc and West German mark despite rising against most other currencies. Gold prices fell in New York after rising overseas. Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher; precious metals and copper were mixed; livestock, pork and energy futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Douglas Plans 1000 More Layoffs in Latest Blow to California
DOC.TEXT: tantial research work in California, including sinking $100 million into a new home in Palmdale for its secret ``Skunk Works,'' which designed the U-2 and SR-71 spy planes and the stealth fighter. Northrop Corp. invested $1.2 billion in its Pico Rivera facility to produce the B-2 stealth bomber. And Rockwell International Corp. is building the nation's most advanced hypersonic wind tunnel in Ventura County. In addition, the nation's six leading spacecraft producers are based in California, with its strength in high technology. Still, Hensley predicted that cuts in federal defense spending, which accounts for about 7 percent of the state's gross product, could send shock waves through the regional economy, just as layoffs in New York's securities industry have rippled through the Northeast. The Douglas layoffs are particularly disheartening because they involve mainly workers in civilian aviation. Big orders for jetliners _ Douglas has 875 orders and options for its mid-range MD-80s and 346 for its new MD-11 jumbo jets _ were seen as a way to offset the effects of less defense work. ``Everyone had been banking on Douglas, with their big backlog, to pick up slack,'' Hensley said. The cuts have left some workers bitter. ``It's a war zone in there,'' said Muriel Carr, 54, a shipping and receiving clerk from Los Angeles who is eligible to retire from Lockheed in October, but instead will be laid off in June. ``Who's going to hire a 54-year-old woman?''

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Nations Poised for Modest Recovery in 1991
DOC.TEXT: The United States' trade deficit is set to worsen significantly despite declining surpluses for Japan, South Korea and other Pacific nations, according to a new forecast. Countries around the Pacific rim also are poised for a modest rebound in growth next year after a self-imposed two-year slowdown designed to rein in inflation, said the report released Thursday by The Asia Foundation. Japan saw its trade surplus narrow in 1989 despite a sharp depreciation in the yen relative to the dollar, which makes its exports more competitive and imports more expensive. The country's trade surplus _ which declined to $57.3 billion last year from $78.8 billion in 1988 _ should drop to $42.7 billion this year before edging up to $45.5 billion in 1991, according to the foundation's Pacific Economic Outlook for 1990-91. Taiwan's balance of payments surplus in the region is forecast to drop to $10.4 billion this year and $9.2 billion in 1991 from $11.1 billion last year. Similarly, South Korea will see its surplus fall from $5.1 billion last year to $1 billion this year and $300 million next year, the report says. The United States, meanwhile, is expected to move the other way. After cutting its balance of payments deficit in the region from $118 billion in 1988 to $96.6 billion in 1989, the deficit is expected to rise to $105 billion this year and $116 billion in 1991. The United States can help itself by cutting its own budget deficit, says Lawrence B. Krause, an economics professor at the University of California-San Diego who helped produce the report. But Krause sees no likelihood of America regaining a trade surplus with Japan or the rest of the Pacific region in the next few years. The outlook, an important tool used by planners in the region, is based on analyses and predictions by economists from 15 countries affiliated with the Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference. The region's powerhouses all slowed their economies with tight monetary policies to curb inflation. Most countries in Latin America, Africa and Southern Europe would have been happy with the 1989 inflation rates of the Pacific's leading economies _ 2.3 percent in Japan, 4.4 percent in Taiwan, 5.7 percent in South Korea, and 4.9 percent in the United States, as measured by the consumer price indexes. Overall, the region's inflation rate was 6.5 percent, a figure bloated by rates of 17.6 percent in China, 10.1 percent in Hong Kong and 10.6 percent in the Philippines. The tight money policies are expected to bring inflation down in 1991 to 1.5 percent in Japan, 3.3 percent in Taiwan, 6.0 percent in South Korea and 4.8 percent in the United States. The region's overall inflation rate should drop to 5.5 percent next year with China cutting its rate to 9.5 percent, Hong Kong to 7.0 percent and the Philippines to 9.7 percent. Krause said the region's declining growth rate should moderate this year and pick up slightly in 1991. The forecast calls for growth of 5.0 percent this year, down from 5.3 percent in 1989 and 7.2 percent in 1988. ``The forecast has a modest recovery in 1991, up to 5.2 percent, so it will have taken two years to moderate the excesses and then have some recovery again,'' Krause said. One notable exception from that growth forecast is Japan, where growth is expected to decline from 5.1 percent in 1989 to 4.3 percent in 1990 and 3.1 percent in 1991. The United States is expected to remain stuck with one of the region's lowest growth rates _ 3.0 percent in 1989, 2.5 percent in 1990 and 2.8 percent in 1991. The region's growth leader, Thailand, should slow from a rate of 11 percent last year to 9.1 percent this year and 8.4 percent in 1991, with Singapore and Malaysia slightly behind. China's political crackdown last year hurt its economy and Hong Kong's, but did not have much impact on the rest of the region, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Traders' Defense Keyed To Market Confusion
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for three commodity traders facing federal fraud charges are keying their defense to the seeming bedlam of the futures markets. They say the government's main witness, an undercover FBI agent who observed and secretly tape-recorded evidence of alleged wrongdoing at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, was so befuddled by the frantic nature of commodity trading that he mistook the defendants' legitimate actions for attempts to defraud customers. ``It's been referred to as organized chaos,'' defense attorney Alan Blumenthal said of commodity trading during his opening statement Thursday to the U.S. District Court jury. ``It is within that confusion that you are going to question whether agent (Randall) Jannett had the opportunity to observe what he claims to have observed,'' Blumenthal said. Blumenthal is defending David Zatz, an independent trader of Swiss franc futures who along with Robert D. Mosky and Danny L. Scheck faces multiple counts of mail or wire fraud and violating federal futures-trading rules. Mosky also is charged with racketeering conspiracy. Mosky worked as a floor broker, filling customer orders from a number of brokerage firms, as well as trading for his own account. Scheck was strictly an independent trader, known as a local. Their trial before U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams is the first to result from an unprecedented FBI probe of trading fraud at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two largest commodity futures markets. Prosecutors have portrayed the three as common criminals who conspired along with at least two other traders to divert to their own accounts profits that rightfully belonged to brokerage customers. The government called its first witness Thursday, an investigator for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission who began the arduous task of educating the jury about commodity trading. A Swiss franc future is a contract to buy or sell a specified number of Swiss francs at a future date at a price agreed upon in advance. Like other commodity futures, Swiss franc contracts are traded in a designated arena, called a pit. There, traders stand shoulder to shoulder and strike deals through a rapid-fire combination of hand signals and shouted bids and offers. The government's case rests largely on conversations secretly recorded by Jannett while he posed as a corrupt trader in the Merc's Swiss franc pit during the last 11 months of 1988. Prosecutors also plan to call as witnesses two other Swiss franc traders, William Walsh and Mark Fuhrman, who have pleaded guilty to fraud charges. The defense lawyers discounted Walsh and Fuhrman as corrupt men who are seeking light sentences for their crimes. And they portrayed Jannett as determined to uncover trading fraud despite inadequate preparation for the frenzied, confounding environment into which he was placed. ``The FBI can send an agent into a trading pit but that won't make him a commodity trader,'' said Scheck's lawyer, Harvey Silets. The government contends the FBI tapes reveal a variety of fraud schemes. But Silets and Elliott Samuels, Mosky's lawyer, said the tapes portray their clients' proper attempts to verify trades they made with each other and Jannett amid the hubbub of the trading pit. Prosecutors have stressed that the conversations Jannett recorded were secretive, which the government says indicates the traders were trying to conceal their actions. But Samuels said exchange and federal rules require traders to verbally confirm their trades immediately after they make them. This trade-checking, ``by nature, has to be secret, private, one-on-one,'' Samuels said. ``That's what agent Jannett recorded,'' Samuels said. ``He recorded my client's compliance _ not violation of any rules.'' The three men are the first suspects to be tried out of 47 Chicago futures traders and a clerk indicted last year as the result of the FBI sting operation. Sixteen of those indicted have pleaded guilty to reduced charges in return for their cooperation.

DOC.HEAD: Investment Firms Seek Management of Nuclear Plant Decommissioning Funds
DOC.TEXT: Two investment firms have formed a joint venture to manage the money utilities are required to set aside to pay for the eventual dismantling of nuclear power plants. John Nuveen & Co. Inc. and Duff & Phelps Inc. have announced they have formed Nuveen-Duff & Phelps Investment to offer investment management services to nuclear utilities. Nuveen spokesman Jeff Kratz said estimates of the cost of decommissioning the nation's 110 nuclear power plants range from $100 billion to $1 trillion. ``The cost for an individual utility may not be very great,'' he said, ``but we are talking about a very substantial amount of money overall.'' Kratz said Nuveen-Duff & Phelps would advise the utilities on how to invest their decommissioning funds. He noted that Nuveen & Co. specializes in non-taxable investments such as municipal bonds and Duff & Phelps specializes in taxable fixed income and equity securities. The utilities will require both kinds of investments to finance the decommissionings, he said. ``We will appear at rate hearings to provide expert testimony on what rates of return the utilities are receiving,'' Kratz said. ``We will act as advisors to utilities, keeping them abreast (of the market) and in general be prepared to assist them to meet the decommission liabilities.'' The Nuclear Regulatory Commission only recently has required utilities to set up funds to pay for plant dismantling. The utilities have until July 26 to show how they will finance the shutdowns. NRC spokesman Jan Strasma in Chicago said the federal agency requires the utilities to either prepay the entire decommissioning cost into an independent fund, establish a sinking fund and pay into it gradually, or establish a surety bond that guarantees payment of decommissioning. Depending on the size and type of plant, the utility would have to set aside $105 million to $135 million for each reactor. Decommissioning involves taking the fuel out of the plant, decontaminating the unit and removing the reactor. ``The idea is to return the site to pristine condition for other uses,'' said Cathy Roche, spokeswoman for the U.S. Council of Energy Awareness, an industry group based in Washington, D.C. ``It is a fairly long-term process.'' ``Decommissioning is an expensive process, and we want the utilities to have sufficient funds to do it,'' Strasma said, adding the funds cannot be used by the utilities for operating expenses. He said laws vary from state to state on how funds can be invested. Under rules established by the Illinois Commerce Commission, Illinois-based Commonwealth Edison _ which operates 13 nuclear plants _ is limited to investing its decommissioning funds in U.S. Treasury bonds, bank certificates of deposits and tax-exempt bonds. ComEd official Debbie Vestal noted that in 1989, the utility put $66 million into the fund, which is handled by four investment firms, including Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. of New York. Before 1989, ComEd integrated its decommission funds into its operating fund, from which it received a higher rate of return. The new fund is covered by a different tax bracket, which lowers the rate of return, said Ms. Vestal. However, she said it is difficult to judge how well the investment firms are doing with the account because there is nothing to compare it with. Scott Peters, a spokesman for the U.S Council for Energy Awareness, said there are currently no nuclear plants up for decommissioning, although a number of plants are idle. But he said the technology exists that could extend the lifetime of the plants. ``Utilities may find that it is cheaper to refurbish plants than replace them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Apparel Stores Continue To Outperform Other Retailers
With BC-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Buoyed by the popularity of this year's Easter and spring merchandise, apparel retailers chalked up strong sales gains in April and continued to outperform the rest of the retailing industry, according to results released by several big store chains. Analysts said department stores, which have lagged specialty retailers for some time, showed signs of improvement in the figures released Thursday. Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, posted a 16 percent gain at stores open at least a year and an 18 percent overall increase. Gap Inc., another big apparel retailer, reported its comparable-store sales jumped 25 percent last month as overall sales gained 31 percent. Clothing is ``the key item that's continuing sales growth,'' said Karen Sack, a retail industry analyst with Standard & Poor's Corp. Results from stores open a year or longer _ known as same- or comparable-store sales _ give a more accurate reading of a retailer's performance. Retail sales are closely watched not only as a gauge of the health of the industry and individual companies, but also as an economic barometer. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product. Among the big department stores, Dayton Hudson Corp., whose holdings include Dayton's and Hudson's department stores and Target discount stores, said its comparable-stores sales rose 5.5 percent in April, while overall sales picked up 11.7 percent. May Department Stores Co. _ which owns Lord & Taylor, Foley's, Filene's and other chains _ said its comparable-store sales rose 8.8 percent as overall sales improved 14.3 percent. Many stores that had sluggish sales in March fared better in April as consumers shopped for Easter and spring clothing. K mart Corp., the nation's largest discount chain, recorded a 6.3 percent comparable-store gain, and a 15.9 percent rise overall. In March, K mart suffered a 1.1 percent drop in comparable-store sales. Calendar shifts _ such as Easter falling on a different date from one year to another _ can affect retail sales, inflating one month's figure and detracting from another. The industry tends to consider March and April together in assessing how well stores did. Kurt Barnard, a retailing consultant, said the stores that have done the best cater to consumers seeking higher-quality merchandise ``at a moderate price in a very attractive and exciting ambiance.'' He cited Limited and Gap as examples of such retailers. Analysts said consumers, burdened by high installment debt, continue to be conservative and wary about more expensive purchases like large appliances. Retailers dependent on such items have had lackluster sales gains compared with the improvement by apparel stores. Analysts predict the trend will continue until later this year. Several of the nation's biggest retailers _ including Sears, Roebuck & Co; Wal-Mart Stores Inc.; J.C. Penney Co. Inc.; and Woolworth Corp. _ reported their April results a week ago, and they also reflected the split between sales of apparel and more expensive items. The figures released Thursday differ from the federal government's monthly retail sales report. Besides stores, the government's figures include sales at a range of establishments from auto dealerships and supermarkets to restaurants and movie theaters.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Retail Sales Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the April domestic sales reported Thursday by some of the nation's largest retailers. Due to differing calendars, many of the major companies that in recent years issued monthly results on the first Thursday of each month now are reporting on the second Thursday. Several big chains, including Sears, Roebuck and Co. and Wal-Mart Stores Inc., issued their March results last week. Some top retailers do not report their sales monthly, including: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., the Campeau Corp. units; R.H. Macy & Co.; and Batus Inc. Montgomery Ward & Co., a privately held retailer, has stopped releasing its monthly sales. Not all retailers have the same fiscal year.
