DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release at 9 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Business Leaders Predict Slow Growth But No Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top business leaders, who just six months ago warned that a recession was a distinct threat, said today the economy will continue to grow moderately at least through 1991. The Business Council _ 100 chief executives of the country's largest corporations _ forecast the economy will grow at a 2 percent pace in 1990 and 2.6 percent in 1991. Last October, it had projected growth of only 1.8 percent for this year, the slowest pace since the recession year of 1981. ``There is remarkable unanimity among our consultants (who drew up the forecast),'' said Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J.P. Morgan Inc., the giant New York bank, and council vice chairman. ``Not a single one of the 19 is forecasting a recession to begin any time this year or next.'' ``The dominant belief is that the (Federal Reserve) has successfully guided the economy into a moderate growth pattern that has an excellent chance of being extended for a very long time,'' Preston said in presenting the forecast on the eve of the council's semiannual meeting at the Homestead resort. The council's forecast last October warned that an outright recession was possible unless the Federal Reserve cut interest rates, which it had boosted to slow the economy in its fight against inflation. Despite continuing high interest rates, the council increased its inflation forecast to 4.8 percent from 4.2 percent for this year because of weather factors and other ``aberrations'' that pushed prices up 8.1 percent at an annual rate during the first quarter. But the council said inflation, as measured by the government's Consumer Price Index, will drop to 3.9 percent during the second half of the year and average 4.4 percent during 1991. The CPI was up 4.6 percent in 1989. Preston said the council's economists also expect no change in Fed policy ``for an extended period ahead.'' He added, however, that ``a significant reduction of the federal budget deficit would certainly change the forecast.'' Congressional and White House negotiators on Tuesday are to start discussing ways to reduce the deficit for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. If they fail to reach an agreement, administration officials say the budget could be atomatically trimmed by $60 billion to $100 billion under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law. That would severely hurt the economy by taking funds away from corporations, members of the public and other beneficiaries of government programs. It also would lead to lower tax collections, causing the deficit to rise again, economists say. Today's forecast approximated the 1.9 percent consensus growth outlook in the latest survey of 51 top economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in Sedona, Ariz. The council projected economic growth to accelerate gradually from 1.9 percent in the first quarter to 2.3 percent in the second half of the year and 2.6 percent during 1991. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew 3 percent in 1989 after slowing to 1.1 percent in the final quarter. Contributing most to the growth, the forecast said, will be consumer spending, exports and business investments. The forecast also suggested an improvement in the manufacturing sector of the economy, saying industrial production will rise 2.1 percent this year and 2.8 percent in 1991. On the other hand, Preston said the forecast provides little hope that the sluggish housing industry will bounce back soon. ``The combination of mortgage rates ... and a very slow appreciation of housing prices is viewed as very constraining,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Honda Names New President, CEO
DOC.TEXT: Nobuhiko Kawamoto, who headed Honda Motor Co. Ltd.'s research and development for three years, has been named president and chief executive officer of Japan's No. 3 automaker. Kawamoto, currently senior managing director, succeeds Tadashi Kume, who has been at Honda's helm since October 1983 and is retiring. The company said Thursday that Kawamoto, 54, will assume his new post in seven weeks. Kume, 58, will remain on Honda's board of directors as an adviser after his June 28 departure, it said. Kawamoto was president of Honda Research & Development Co. Ltd. for three years before becoming the parent company's senior managing director in June last year. Kume's retirement age would be considered young if he were head of a U.S. automaker, but Honda officials say it was not unusual for Honda executives to retire before age 60. Honda is the third-largest Japanese automaker, behind Toyota Motor Corp. and Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. Honda was the first Japanese company to manufacture cars in the United States when it started production at its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, in November 1982. The company since has opened another carmaking plant in East Liberty, Ohio. The company also said Thursday that Shoichiro Irimajiri and Yoshihide Munekuni will become executive vice presidents effective June 28. Irimajiri and Munekuni have served in various jobs in Honda's North American operations.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Blasts Aetna for Pulling Out of Car-insurance Market
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Casualty and Surety Co. says it will stick with its decision to stop selling car insurance in Pennsylvania despite a written admonition from Gov. Robert P. Casey, who called the giant insurer ``arrogant and callous.'' On Thursday, Casey sent a strongly worded, three-paragraph letter to Aetna's president, David A. Kocher, criticizing the company's decision Wednesday to terminate business with its 200,000 Pennsylvania customers. Casey said the company's withdrawal violated Pennsylvania law and displayed ``an arrogant and callous disregard for our state and your policyholders.'' ``If you persist in your decision, I hereby put you on notice that Pennsylvania will use all remedies against your company which the law allows to protect the 200,000 Aetna policyholders in our state and the broad public interest of all our citizens,'' Casey said in the letter. Aetna, a Sears, Roebuck and Co. unit and the state's fifth-largest insurer, said Pennsylvania's new car-insurance law would cause it to lose $20 million during the next year. The law enacted in February lowers all motorists' rates by 10 percent July 1 or by 22 percent if they give up their rights to sue in most cases. Aetna also has asked the courts to block the state Insurance Department from trying to foil its exodus from the car-insurance market. The Insurance Department filed a cease-and-desist order on Thursday against Aetna to force it to stop sending out renewal notices and to reinstate customers who are dropped. Aetna then asked the U.S. District Court in Philadelphia to issue a temporary restraining order to block the department's order. John C. Hawkins, an Aetna spokesman, said in a statement that the company's action was within its rights. ``The company holds the position that its actions in Pennsylvania to withdraw from the personal auto insurance market and begin orderly non-renewal of its policyholders are legal,'' Hawkins said. ``There is nothing in Pennsylvania law that prohibits us from taking this action.'' At least two other companies, Harleysville Mutual Insurance Co. and Safeco Insurance Co. of America, said they were pulling out of the state. The Insurance Department is fighting both in court.

DOC.HEAD: Incentives Costs Double for Ford
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites first three grafs to CLARIFY that cost of incentives running $4 billion, not cost of doing business. Picks up 4th graf pvs, Benton said ...
DOC.TEXT: The cost of luring car buyers into Ford Motor Co.'s showrooms is running at an annual rate of about $4 billion, double last year's pace, the No. 2 automaker says. Ford President Philip Benton said after the company's annual meeting Thursday that the automaker hopes that incentive spending, which chews up profits, will taper off later this year. If the current pace continues Ford will spend $4 billion on rebates in 1990, he said. Benton said the cost of cash rebates and low-interest financing is rising. However, the company hopes the launch of its new Escort subcompact and Explorer sport-utility vehicle will hold down the spending. ``I would be hopeful with the reception of our new cars in the marketplace, it would be less,'' Chairman Harold Poling said at a news conference following a quick and quiet shareholders' meeting. The day before, General Motors Corp. President Robert Stempel, who takes over as chairman on Aug. 1, had the same message. ``The rebates have just about run out their string,'' he said. ``There's no question that the companies want to get off them.'' Chrysler Corp., which relies heavily on incentives to boost sales, also has said it would like to get away from them but doesn't see that happening soon. Ford's meeting was the first of the Big Three this year. Chrysler holds its annual meeting next week in Los Angeles and GM shareholders meet a week after that in Detroit. Ford, like GM and Chrysler, said last week that incentive costs were part of the reason for severely depressed first-quarter earnings. Ford said it was spending an average of $1,000 on every vehicle it sells now. The company earned $506.2 million during the first three months of this year, down 69 percent from last year's company-record first-quarter earnings. GM's quarterly earnings fell 54 percent and Chrysler's dropped 80 percent. ``We believe the increased marketing and product expenditures will continue to affect profits throughout the year,'' Poling told shareholders in the first annual meeting he has run. He succeeded Donald Petersen as chairman March 1. If incentives work, they boost a company's sales pace. But they cut directly into profits. Ford's share of the U.S. market for domestically built cars was 28.6 percent at the end of April, compared with GM's 46 percent and Chrysler's 11 percent. Also at Ford's annual meeting: _Benton said Ford spent about $1.2 billion on its worldwide advertising in 1989, about 9 percent more than it spent in the previous year. _A 17-member slate of directors nominated by the board was elected unopposed. _Executives fielded repeated questions about the location of next year's annual meeting. Ford Auditorium, where the company has held 27 shareholder meetings, will be torn down to make way for a bank office building if a proposal before the Detroit City Council is approved. Poling said the board would decide on a meeting site later.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Slumped 0.6 Percent in April
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to change slugline to avoid confusion with f0011, PM-Retail Sales. Also moved on general news wires as PM-Retail Sales.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales slumped 0.6 percent in April, posting the second consecutive monthly decline and the biggest setback in six months, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said sales fell by $907 million last month to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion. The April decrease was a disappointment to economists, who had been looking for a small rebound following a 0.2 percent decline in March and no change in February. Since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, continued weakness in the area of retail sales was likely to intensify concerns about the country's future economic prospects, especially in light of last week's report that unemployment climbed in April to 5.4 percent. Growing joblessness could promote worries among consumers about the future, causing them to shut off spending, especially for big-ticket items such as autos. The 0.6 percent April decline was the largest since a 1.4 percent plunge last October. The back-to-back declines in March and April marked the first time that has occurred in moe than three years. Originally, the government reported February posted a sales decline as well but sales activity during that month was revised upward in the current report to show no change. For April, the biggest drag on activity came from auto sales, which dropped 2.7 percent. It marked the sixth time in the last seven months that car sales have fallen. Without the big drop in auto sales, total retail sales would have been unchanged last month. Sales at general department stores were off 0.7 percent in April following an even bigger 1.2 percent drop in March. A survey focusing only on the country's largest chain department stores showed sales had generally rebounded in April, when compared to a year ago, boosted by late Easter shopping. Sales at hardware and building supply stores dropped 2.6 percent in April following an 0.8 percent decrease the previous month. There was basic weakness across the board. Sales at gasoline stations fell by 1 percent, restaurant sales were off by 0.2 percent while sales at speciality clothing stores were down 1.9 percent. Drug stores were the only retail establishments showing an increase, a gain of 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Unilever Posts 13 Percent Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch food and home products giant, reported Friday that its first quarter net income rose 13 percent over a year ago as growth in Europe countered declining profitability in North America. The company said its net profit for the three months ended March 31 totaled $362 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $321 million, or 72 cents, in 1989. Sales rose around 13 percent to $8.4 billion from $7.4 billion. Chairman Sir Michael Angus called the profit improvement ``satisfactory.'' On a regional level, operations in Europe were strong across the board, Unilever said. North America, however, saw lower profit in the food business, the company said. In other regions around the world, profit grew strongly, it said. The company provided the dollar figures.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Xerox's Lawsuit Against Apple
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit Xerox Corp. filed against Apple Computer Inc. after Xerox gave up its one remaining claim in the suit, which centered on rights to the popular display technology in the Macintosh computer. Xerox's decision will allow the company to appeal the case more quickly. U.S. District Judge Vaughn Walker dismissed the suit Wednesday. The lawsuit, which was filed in December, focused on technology known as a graphical user interface, which makes computers easier to use by replacing typed commands with pictures called icons on the screen and a pointer device called a mouse. The technology helped sell millions of Macintoshes and forced other manufacturers to offer similar systems for desktop computers. Xerox maintained that many features in the Macintosh originated at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center, about 30 miles south of San Francisco, in the 1970s. The suit sought $150 million in damages and asked to have Apple's copyrights on the Macintosh display technology cancelled. On March 23, Walker dismissed five of Xerox's six counts against Apple on procedural grounds. The remaining count sought a declaratory judgement stating that Xerox owns the copyright to its Star program, one of those it accused Apple of pirating. Xerox said it intends to appeal the dismissal.

The stock market ran up a broad gain in stepped-up trading today, spurred on by favorable inflation news and falling interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 13.97 to 2,752.48 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by nearly 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 822 up, 212 down and 427 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 34.88 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The government reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods dropped 0.3 percent in April, in contrast to Wall Street's expectations of a 0.1 percent-0.3 percent increase. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales fell 0.6 percent last month. Analysts said the figures provided the markets with a double dose of evidence that the pace of the economy remained slow and inflationary pressures were subdued. That served to allay whatever fears persisted on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to tighten credit. Interest rates fell in the bond and short-term money markets. Among actively traded blue chips, Merck rose | to 76\; International Business Machines 1[ to 113{; Philip Morris \ to 43|; American Express { to 28\, and American Telephone & Telegraph { to 41}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.19 to 189.33. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.07 at 349.99. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.63 to 2,738.51. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 4 to 3 on the NYSE, with 844 up, 611 down and 507 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 158.46 million shares, against 152.22 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Network Sues 22 Philadelphia Stores Over `Simpsons' Sales
DOC.TEXT: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp. has filed suit in federal court against 22 Philadelphia stores, claiming the retailers broke copyright law by selling products depicting its popular television series ``The Simpsons.'' The suit, filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, alleges the stores have illegally sold hundreds of counterfeit Simpsons merchandise. The animated show airs on the company's subsidiary, Fox Broadcasting Co. More than 50 additional businesses eventually could be named as defendants, according to an attorney for Fox, Zachary T. Wobensmith III. ``The only thing I can tell you is that Twentieth Century Fox is going to enforce its copyrights and prosecute anyone who is selling, distributing or manufacturing unlicensed Simpsons items,'' he said. Similar suits have been filed in Washington and Dallas, he said. ``The Simpsons'' was created in 1987 for use as 60-second segments in another Fox program, ``The Tracey Ullman Show.'' The cartoon then became a half-hour show in January and appears weekly on Fox television affiliates.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Budget Summit Wide Open But He Won't Show His Hand Yet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; edits throughout to tighten; no pickup. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he is willing to discuss everything at next week's budget summit but declared ``I'm not going to show you my hand'' in advance on new taxes. Bush, speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One on his way from Washington to Texas, insisted that nothing was off the bargaining table, despite comments from a senior aide suggesting he might rule out any proposed tax increase. ``Why don't you just listen to what I say and see what we do,'' Bush said. ``There are no conditions and that's the way it is, that's the way it's going to be and that's the way it must be.'' It was the first time Bush himself has spoken out on the subject since he appeared to open the door to a possible tax increase last Sunday by proposing a no-preconditions budget summit with Congress. The first negotiations will take place next Tuesday at the White House. Bush's comments came as administration and congressional leaders struggled to impose a verbal cease-fire on Democrats and Republicans who are bickering over whether next week's budget summit will consider new taxes. Top Democrats criticized White House Chief of Staf John Sununu for saying that Bush would never accept tax increases as part of a $1.2 trillion budget for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Asked if Sununu was in trouble for his remarks, Bush said: ``That's silly _ so stupid.'' And, in a reference to members of Congress who have joined in the fray, Bush said: ``None of these congressmen are in trouble, either.'' However, the president conceded that House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash, was concerned over Sununu's remarks. Bush called Foley on Thursday to assure him that he had no preconditions for the budget summit talks. ``Yes, he did express concern,'' Bush said. ``But I think he sees the need to go forward on the basis I have called for and I respect him for that.'' Pressed on whether he would consider tax increases if they were put on the table, Bush said: ``You can come at me all day long. It would not be dealing in good faith if I started going into these details. I'm not going to do it.'' ``I'm not going to show you my hand and I haven't seen a lot of hands being laid down up on the Hill,'' Bush said. ``But that's the way it ought to be. There are some tough decisions out there and we've got to do something.'' Still, Bush declined to characterize the widening deficit gap as a crisis. ``No, we're not dealing in a crisis mentality,'' he said. ``But, we've got a major deficit problem. ... We need cooperation because it isn't going to be easy; it's going to be very difficult.'' Could the budget be balanced without some form of tax hike? ``See what happens,'' the president said. ``We just go there and discuss everything. ...That's the only way you can get strong-willed people to the table _ in good faith, the way it will be.'' Bush spoke on his way to a Texas, where he was to deliver a commencement address at Texas A&I University at Kingsville. Although Democrats reacted angrily Thursday to Sununu's remarks, they stopped short of any action that could imperil the top-level bargaining, which is supposed to have no preconditions and is set to begin Tuesday. ``We view this incident as an extremely serious one because it could, if repeated, threaten the success of these talks,'' Foley said on Thursday. Acknowledging the intense political pressure ignited by a need for perhaps $100 billion in budget cuts next year, lawmakers of both parties begged for a truce. ``One way to make certain we don't succeed is to continue statements that might throw us off course,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``We just can't continue to have this kind of sniping and political warfare going on at the same time we're trying to deal with a serious problem,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Sununu said his controversial comments were ``designed to make sure that people did not misinterpret `no conditions' as implying that there was a condition for what had to be in the final agreement.'' White House budget chief Richard Darman has told lawmakers that there could be a need to slash next year's federal shortfall by $60 billion to $100 billion, an astronomical amount even by government standards. The goal is to obey the Gramm-Rudman law's requirement that the 1991 budget gap not exceed $64 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices in April Fall 0.3 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, Bond markets ..., with 3 New grafs to include stock market number and quote. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A second steep drop in vegetable costs helped push wholesale prices down 0.3 percent overall in April, the government said today. It was the sharpest decline since August and the third consecutive moderate report after a severe cold snap sent prices spiraling 1.8 percent in January, a 15-year record. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, one stop short of retail, had fallen 0.2 percent in March and showed no change in February. The monthly numbers are all adjusted for seasonal variations. For the first four months of the year, wholesale inflation was running at a 4.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989. In a separate report today, the Commerce Department said retail sales last month slumped 0.6 percent, the third consecutive month without an increase. Stock and bond markets rallied in response to both reports. Traders took them as a sign that the Federal Reserve Board, in the near term, would not need to push up interest rates to fight inflation. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks climbed 13.97 to 2,752.48 in the first half hour of trading. ``The numbers are increasingly ratifying the fact that we've dodged the inflationary bullet, at least for a while,'' said Dirk Van Dongen, president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. ``The bad news is that maybe the soft landing (economic slowdown) is a little softer than we would like.'' In April, food prices fell 0.6 percent after an identical 0.6 percent decline a month earlier. Prices rose for eggs, rice, pasta and pork. They fell for fruit, chicken, cooking oils and candy. Vegetable prices, which fell 25.5 percent in March after record increases the previous two months, fell another 31.1 percent last month. It was the biggest drop since the government began tracking those costs in 1967. Tomato prices fell 73.3 percent. ``They are no longer boxing tomatoes in Florida because the boxes are worth more than the tomatoes. ... Thus the winter freeze is nothing more ... than a bad memory,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. Energy prices dropped 1.7 percent after declining the two previous months. Gasoline prices, with the start of the warm weather driving season, climbed 2.2 percent. However fuel oil fell 1.9 percent while natural gas dropped 5.5 percent. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices rose a modest 0.2 percent after rising a moderate 0.3 percent in March. Economists said this ``core'' number is often a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy. Automobile prices fell 0.9 percent in April. Clothing price inflation recovered from increases a month earlier. Women's, men's and boys' clothing costs were unchanged. Girls' and infants' clothing fell 0.2 percent. Prices rose for medicines, soap, floor coverings and toys. They fell for alcoholic beverages, jewelry and magazines. The various changes put the index for all finished goods at 117.0 in April. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $117 last month, up from $113 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process were moderate in April. Intermediate goods rose a slight 0.1 percent while crude goods fell 3.1 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. Despite the moderate report for April prices at the wholesale level, economists are still concerned that inflation may be accelerating this year. Consumer prices, up at an annual rate of 8.5 percent in the first quarter, are rising at a steeper pace than wholesale costs. April consumer numbers are due out next week. Why the divergence between the two sets of prices? Producer prices reflect only the cost of goods, while consumer prices are heavily influenced by the cost of services, which have been less affected by the economic slowdown of recent months. Economic growth has slowed enough to soften demand and hold down goods prices, but not enough to greatly affect employment and thus the cost of services. The Federal Reserve Board, which aims its monetary policy at reducing inflation, meets Tuesday to consider interest rate policy for the next six weeks. With April wholesale inflation much better than the 0.2 percent rise forecast by most economists, the Fed may be less inclined to cool the economy by nudging interest rates higher, something it hasn't done since March 1989. However, financial markets in recent weeks had nevertheless anticipated Fed tightening by pushing up rates outside the central bank's direct control. In the government's quarterly auction of three-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds this week, interest rates were up about a third of a percentage point from three months ago.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 433.99 up 0.79 from the previous day's close.

The stock market chalked up a broad gain today, spurred on by favorable inflation news and falling interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 11.94 to 2,750.45 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 877 up, 361 down and 487 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 64.81 million shares at midmorning. The government reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods dropped 0.3 percent in April, in contrast to Wall Street's expectations of a 0.1 percent-0.3 percent increase. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales fell 0.6 percent last month. Analysts said the figures provided the markets with a double dose of evidence that the pace of the economy remained slow and inflationary pressures were subdued. That served to allay whatever fears persisted on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to tighten credit. Interest rates fell in the bond and short-term money markets. Among actively traded blue chips, Eli Lilly rose 1[ to 70}; International Business Machines ~ to 113\; Philip Morris ] to 43}, and American Telephone & Telegraph ] to 41|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.03 to 189.17. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.22 at 350.14.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Crop Report Push Wheat Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading is expected to be heavily influenced by the release Thursday of the Agriculture Department's crop report. The U.S.D.A. estimated winter wheat production at a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels. That is up 44 percent from last year's drought-reduced harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. This year's corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels and soybean production was pegged at 1.92 billion bushels. Analysts say the figures for wheat and soybeans are considered bearish, although soyoil interest could give some strength to the soybean complex. Corn is getting some support from commission house buying. In early trading, wheat was a { cent to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.81{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 3 cents higher with May at $2.91 a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to a \ cent higher with May at $1.64{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 2{ cents higher with May at $6.49 a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed and pork futures lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures were pressured by indications cash market prices have peaked and could turn lower. Pork price were hammered by aggressive selling of pork belly futures in followthrough to Thursday's weak close. Live cattle were .08 cent lower to .35 cent higher with June at 74.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .40 cent lower to .30 cent higher with May at 84.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .62 cent lower to .25 cent higher with June at 63.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.55 cent lower to .08 cent higher with May at 64.50 cents a pound. Livestock and pork futures settled lower in Thursday's trading.

DOC.NOTE: $adv14
For Release Monday May 14
DOC.HEAD: Index Funds Spread Their Wings
DOC.TEXT: A couple of decades after they first caught on in the world of professional money management, index funds are bidding to win a new generation of converts among individual investors. The recruitment drive is being led by such prominent mutual-fund sponsors as Dreyfus Corp. and Fidelity Investments, which lately have introduced funds based on stock-market indexes. Vanguard Group, a singular early success in the field with its Index Trust-500 Portfolio, is extending the idea to a series of new fund offerings. At the very least ``a mini-fad is developing,'' says Sheldon Jacobs, publisher of the monthly newsletter No-Load Fund Investor in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. If the strategy proves as popular with the public as it has among managers of pension funds and other institutional pools of money, it could turn out to be substantially more than a fad. Index funds are set up to duplicate the performance of some popular market yardstick such as Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index, by holding a portfolio of issues that closely matches the makeup of the index. This often strikes those who first encounter the concept as ``playing for a tie'' rather than shooting for all-out victory in the battle for investment profits. Indeed, indexing has never had a big fan club among securities analysts, economists and market forecasters, who compete to outguess each other. After all, the theory behind it pretty much dismisses their work as a waste of time and money. Regardless of who is right in this academic debate, however, indexed money-management strategies do appear to have benefited from the makeup of the modern marketplace. When institutions, by virtue of their increasingly dominant role, in effect become synonymous with the market, it stands to reason that they cannot as a group outperform that market. Also, says Jacobs, ``over the long run the costs of investing can offset managerial skill.'' Index funds gain an edge by minimizing or eliminating the costs of research and frequent trading. The Vanguard 500 Portfolio, which was started in 1976, has attracted assets approaching $2 billion. Even in today's $1 trillion fund industry, any fund over $1 billion still ranks as a big success. Whether you count the 500 Portfolio as a ``growth'' or ``growth and income'' fund, Jacobs says, its 16.5 percent average annual return over the past five years is good enough to rank it among the top 20 percent of its class. Damning as it may look to the managed competition, that showing may exaggerate the virtues of indexing to some degree. The big stocks that make up the S&P 500 have been outpacing their smaller counterparts in recent years, Jacobs notes, in part because of their popularity among foreign investors and because of the spreading use of indexing itself. Whether the blue-chip 500 will stay at the head of the pack in the 1990s remains an open question. Some analysts say smaller, secondary stocks _ some of which are now being grouped into new, specialized index funds _ are due for a comeback. ``While the odds favor a change in market leadership, it is very difficult to say just when this will occur,'' Jacobs observes. To investors shopping for an index-fund investment, Jacobs offers a couple of suggestions. First of all, he says, pay special attention to all costs, including management fees, operating expenses and any entrance or exit charges. ``The whole point of index fund investing is to minimize expenses,'' he says. Secondly, he recommends spreading your money among funds based on indexes of both large and small stocks. ``That way,'' he concludes, ``you really will be guaranteed a `market' return.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon May 14

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Chairman Bails Out With Golden Parachute
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Chairman William R. Laidig, who led the paper company's unsuccessful effort to fend off Georgia-Pacific Corp., left the company Friday with a lucrative severance package. A company spokesman said Laidig will qualify for a ``golden parachute'' package that will pay him three times his base salary plus his highest annual bonus of the past three years. The company's 1989 proxy statement listed Laidig's salary at $707,000 a year. The board sweetened the severance package after Georgia-Pacific launched a hostile takeover bid last fall. Great Northern's four-month effort to remain independent ended in February, when the company agreed to be acquired by Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific for $3.7 billion. Laidig's departure comes about a month before the companies are expected to merge. In a letter to employees, Laidig said ``he agreed to help during the transition and had done that to the point it was most productive,'' Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill said. Laidig, who had served as chairman, chief executive and president of Great Northern since 1984, was said to be in a meeting early Friday and unavailable for comment.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Fines Brokerage
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Securities Dealers has fined Stuart-James Co. more than $2 million for overcharging companies, one of the largest fines ever levied against a brokerage firm by NASD. The alleged overcharges involved more than 4,000 stock transactions in 1988, said NASD, which policies over-the-counter stock markets. Stuart-James is one of the nation's largest over-the-counter investment banking firms with 40 retail offices nationwide and over 1,000 brokers. NASD announced Thursday that as part of its settlement with the Englewood-based brokerage, NASD was fining Stuart-James $1.9 million; its president and owner James Padgett $105,000; its former chairman and co-owner Stuart Graff $25,000, and its head trader, Steven Pata, $30,000. Padget also was barred from being involved in a supervisory capacity in the company's markup area for six months, and Graff was suspended from acting as the company's principal for 60 days under the agreement. NASD also suspended Pata for 20 days. The parties agreed to the sanctions without admitting or denying guilt. NASD said the Stuart-James markups ranged from 6.9 percent to 153 percent over their cost, when the firm dominated and controlled the trading of the securities. In the settlement announced Thursday, the company and its officials consented to findings that NASD rules were violated in markups charged customers in four low-priced securities: Meadow Group Inc., a NASDAQ stock exchange-listed security, and three penny stocks _ Celerity Coputing Inc; 1992 warrants for International Design Group Inc., and National DataComputer Inc. As part of the settlement, Stuart-James also agreed to change certain business practices, some of which the company dropped more than a year ago. For instance, it agreed to stop making markets in penny stocks and to send customers written confirmation of the highest ask and bid prices in certain securities at the time of sale. The settlement also calls for an independent consultant to review the firm's trading practices and procedures, to prepare reports and to make recommendations to both the brokerage and NASD. Last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed excessive markup charges against the firm and also accused it of a number of other securities violations. Stuart-James, Padgett, Graff and other current and former executives of the firm now are on trial before an SEC administrative law judge.

DOC.HEAD: British Inflation Rate Up to 9.4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Britain's annual inflation rate reached an eight-year high of 9.4 percent in April, the government reported Friday. But the financial markets took the news well, with the pound and stock prices both firming, since many investors had expected an even higher 9.7 percent rate. Fighting inflation is Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's No. 1 economic priority and her Conservative government has increased interest rates to 15 percent to try an slow down demand. However, a new per-capita tax, increases in excise duties and higher utility charges combined to push the inflation rate to its highest level since May 1982 when it stood at 9.5 percent, the Central Statistical Office said. In March, the rate stood at 8.1 percent. The office said its retail price index rose 3 percent in April from March. The monthly rise was the largest since April 1980 when the index gained 3.4 percent. The index, which uses a January 1987 base of 100, stood at 125.1 in April, 121.4 in March, and 114.3 in April 1989. ``Everyone was sure it was going to double figures,'' said a trader at a major British bank, speaking anonymously. ``Now people are going to say, `that's not too bad.''' The Bank of England on Thursday forecast inflation at about 10 percent for the near-term, with a peak in the third quarter. British Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said there was ``nothing unexpected'' in the latest rise. Speaking in broadcast interviews after the figures were released, Major said the increase resulted directly from ``relatively artificial changes.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites thruout to UPDATE with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher Friday on London's Stock Exchange following the release of better-than-expected British inflation figures. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 18.9 points at 2,175.9. That was well above its session low of 2,155.6 and slightly off from a peak of 2,182.3. Volume totaled 510.1 million shares, up from 406.3 million Thursday. Shares began climbing after the release of the British inflation figures, which showed that the annual inflation rate rose to 9.4 percent in April, up from 8.1 percent in March but below the markets expectations. ``Anything less than 10 percent was going to rally the market,'' a market maker said.

Traders said they could find no reason for the dollar's drop. ``It's something we can find no explanation for,'' said a trader at a large U.S. bank in London. DOC.NOTE: $adv15
For Release AMs Tuesday, May 15
DOC.HEAD: The Money Is Plentiful Where The Rates Are High
DOC.TEXT: While banks in some areas might be pruning their lists of qualified borrowers, they are still shoveling out the money on credit cards. The latest Federal Reserve figures show that revolving credit, most of it run up at retail stores and through bank cards, rose at a 12.1 percent annual rate in March, a rather large figure for a sluggish economy. That increase means that in the first quarter of this year the amount of consumer debt outstanding was $706 billion, or roughly $24 billion more than existed a year earlier. Most of this credit, it is presumed, went to pay for new consumer items, although some cynics will tell you that a good many Americans these days have become accustomed to meeting ordinary expenses through borrowing. Meanwhile, business loans _ so-called commercial and industrial loans _ have been slowing. In the first 14 weeks of 1988, C&I loans rose $10.1 billion. In the same period of 1989, they rose $12 billion. In 1990, they rose just $5.4 billion. The Federal Reserve and other federal regulators leave no misimpressions about their goal, which is to keep the economy cool and collected. That is to say they seek to avoid inflation, avoid recession and get the bills paid. Because of this policy, the Fed concedes there are pockets of tight money, a rather odd turn of phrase for what are, in effect, empty pockets. But it declines to say that a general credit crunch exists. Nevertheless, complaints are rising in some areas from small businesses, especially developers, who claim their lines of credit are being withdrawn or reduced. Home mortgage applications also are being scrutinized more closely. While there might or might not be a credit crunch, the situation obviously concerns the Fed, which last week advised bankers to act like bankers, that is, to assume prudent risks rather than attempt to reduce risk to zero. Meanwhile, those bank cards seem to be an exception to the new conservatism of lenders. Banks continue to expand their bank card lists. And credit limits for customers who pay on time may even be raised, no questions asked. The explanation isn't complex: Bank cards are profitable. The major reason is that interest charges are often double those of home equity loans. When some home mortgages are in single digits, for example, many bank card rates are 19.5 percent, plus an annual fee. Moreover, while the total amount of credit extended on bank cards might be sizeable for any particular bank, the separate loans are relatively small. The bank's exposure on any one loan is limited. In contrast, a home equity loan can be large. Millions of Americans own homes that have doubled in value in the past decade or less, and they are tempted to use that equity. Home equity loans are the least expensive, and the expense is made still lower at tax time, when interest paid can be deducted. In lending to small businesses, meanwhile, bankers are confronted with this situation: Small-business loans often are risky; that risk is made even more so when the economy is sluggish; many such loans have gone bad in recent years. Confronted with regulatory restraints, poor business conditions and recent bad experience on loans to small businesses, many bankers seem to be retreating to the security, the limited risk and the high returns of bank card credit.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv AMs Tuesday, May 15.

DOC.HEAD: What the Dollar's Slide Means
With AM-Dollar-Gold Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The latest slide in dollar reflects a rebound in the value of the Japanese yen and a spreading belief that the U.S. economy is not overheating. A slower economy would mean lower interest rates, which reduces the dollar's allure to international investors. The dollar's value also is falling because of eased fears about a credit crunch affecting banks.
DOC.HEAD: Yen Surge
DOC.TEXT: The yen surged in value against the dollar in foreign exchange trading Friday after a long slide. Traders who buy and sell currencies for a profit said the yen had been oversold in the wake of this spring's decline in the Tokyo stock market. Traders were said to be looking for excuses to buy yen and sell dollars.
DOC.HEAD: The Economy
DOC.TEXT: U.S. economic reports are providing the needed excuse. Recent statistics have reported slumping home sales, rising unemployment and weak corporate profits. On Friday, economic reports showed a slowdown in retail sales and a drop in wholesale prices.
DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: A drop in interest rates would encourage borrowing, but also would make the dollar less attractive because investments denominated in dollars won't earn as much as before.
DOC.HEAD: The Impact
DOC.TEXT: The dollar's value is the most visible symbol of confidence in the health of the U.S. economy. The dollar's worth relative to other currencies also is an important barometer of international economic currents. While short-term rises or drops in the dollar's worth don't necessarily signal profound economic changes, they are nonetheless monitored closely by economists and governments. Over the longer term, a weaker dollar is thought to help U.S. trade by making exports relatively less expensive, and therefore more competitive, in world markets.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders Say Recession Unlikely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs, `The group's ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with inflation forecast for 1990; picks up picks up 14th graf, `The administration's ...' A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economy Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of top U.S. businesses said Friday the economy will grow only moderately this year and next but will manage to stave off a recession. Inflation is on the way down, they say, predicting that the first-quarter annual inflation rate of 8.1 percent will be cut nearly in half. Economic growth will total about 2 percent in 1990 as it accelerates gradually from 1.9 percent in the first half of the year to 2.3 percent in the second, according to the Business Council, 100 chief executives of the nation's largest corporations. It will rise to 2.6 percent in 1991. The Bush administration forecast in January that the economy would grow 2.4 percent in 1990, although many economists expect that to be lowered in the July review. It projects 3.2 percent growth in 1991. The council's latest forecast, presented at its semiannual meeting at this mountain resort, contrasted with a report released at its October meeting that predicted a meager 1.8 percent growth rate in 1990 and warned of an outright recession if the Federal Reserve failed to cut interest rates. The Fed, which had boosted rates to slow the economy in its fight against inflation, did permit rates to drop several times after the October meeting. But it has kept a firm hand on credit since December despite calls for easing by administration officials and some economists to allow stronger economic growth. Lewis T. Preston, Business Council vice chairman and chairman of J.P. Morgan Inc., the giant New York bank, said the 19 council economists who drew up the report expected no change in Fed policy ``for an extended period of ahead.'' Nevertheless, Preston said ``not a single one of the 19 is forecasting a recession to begin any time this year or next.'' ``The dominant belief is that the Fed has successfully guided the economy into a moderate growth pattern that has an excellent chance of being extended for a very long time,'' Preston told reporters. The Business Council forecast mirrored the 2 percent consensus growth rate in a May survey of 51 leading economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in Sedona, Ariz. The economy grew 3 percent last year, but had slowed to 1.1 percent rate during the fourth quarter. It grew at a 1.9 percent clip in the first quarter of 1990. Looking at the steep price increases early this year, the council said ``the disappointingly high inflation readings in the first quarter are generally viewed as an aberration by the consultants.'' They now expect the 8.1 percent annual rate in the first quarter to slow to 3.3 percent in the second. ``The group's CPI inflation forecast for the second half of the year has been slightly lowered from 4.1 percent at the time of the last survey to 3.9 percent in the current survey,'' the council said. Despite the slowdown, inflation for the full year is projected to be 4.8 percent. That's up from a 4.2 percent rate the council forecast in October. Inflation should moderate next year to a rate of 4.4 percent, the council said. The adminstration's January forecast calls for inflation to rise 3.9 percent this year and 4 percent in 1991. It was 4.6 percent in 1989. Preston said the economy is fragile and the growth forecast could be skewed by special factors and by federal deficit-reduction talks beginning Tuesday between congressional and White House negotiators. The administration contends that if the deficit is not cut to the $64 billion limit set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law, it could mean automatic spending cuts of between $60 billion and $100 billion in fiscal 1991 that begins Oct. 1. Such huge cuts would severely hurt the economy, economists say. Nevertheless, the council is forecasting 1990 growth based on continued consumer spending, exports and business investment. It also said the manufacturing sector would pick up, with industrial production rising 2.1 percent this year and 2.8 percent during 1991. The optimism didn't extend to housing, however. ``Our advisory group has little hope that housing will show any buoyancy any time soon,'' Preston said. ``The combination of mortgage rates ... and a very slow appreciation of housing prices is viewed as very constraining.''

DOC.HEAD: Perrier's Profit Plunges
DOC.TEXT: Source Perrier SA said Friday that the costs associated with the recent recall of its popular bottled sparkling water were assessed to last year's account, resulting in a 75 percent plunge in earnings for 1989. The company said net profit totaled $47 million for the year, compared with $185 million in 1988. Perrier recalled its bottled water worldwide in February after tests showed traces of benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, in its product in several countries. The contamination came from improper infiltration of carbon dioxide gas added to the water, according to the company. Perrier put the cost of the recall at $78 million. The company said it put aside part of its 1989 profit to cover the recall expense, which is permitted under French law. Perrier said it had expected to cover most of the recall costs with non-recurring gains from the sale of assets, but these totaled only $45 million for 1989. In addition, Perrier's 1988 results were swelled by much more substantial non-recurring gains of $154 million, reflecting the sale of assets that included television, confectionary and milk interests. Perrier recently began resupplying its distributorss with bottles marked ``New Production.'' Perrier officials said they were optimistic about 1990 results. ``Perrier is again present on all markets and the current pace of production should allow us to meet the enormous worldwide demand for Perrier relatively quickly,'' the company said in a statement. It said sales of mineral water were up 12 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier, but didn't provide a specific figure.

DOC.HEAD: Printer's Mistake Makes Trips to Germany a Bargain
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of central Florida newspaper readers knew they spotted a bargain when they saw the Pan Am ad offering a one-way flight to Nuremberg, West Germany, for $109. Oops. The advertisement should have said $409. But never mind, Pan Am went ahead and honored the erroneously advertised price for about 75 people who wanted tickets Wednesday and Thursday. After all, the ad promised ``A lot of Europe for not a lot of money.'' Pan Am ticket agents discovered the error Wednesday morning when the first bargain hunters appeared. ``It was very embarrassing,'' said Fergus Kelly, Pan Am's general manager in Orlando. ``We said, `That'll be $409,' and the customer said, `Uh-uh.''' The deal on the fare, made possible by the mistake of a New York printing company, ended at noon Thursday. Company officials said the error appeared only in the ad that ran in The Orlando Sentinel. At the local office of the law firm of Holland & Knight, secretary Julie McDaniels' husband Dave called her Wednesday to tell her about the fare and ask her if she wanted to go to Germany. She thought about it ``for about two seconds,'' she said. Mrs. McDaniels asked her boss for the time off. Her boss asked about the fare. ``When I told him, he jumped for it,'' she said. ``My boss is going too.'' Officials at Florida's Department of Agriculture and Consumer Affairs said the company wasn't under any legal obligation to honor the lower fare since it was a typographical error. But Pamela Hanlon, a New York spokeswoman for Pan Am, said Friday the airline decided it was only fair to do so, particularly since it won't be out any money. ``The printers ... have acknowledged it was their error and will pick up the cost to Pan Am,'' Ms. Hanlon said.

DOC.HEAD: Flight Attendants Sue American Airlines Over Who Gets Eastern Work
DOC.TEXT: The union representing American Airlines' flight attendants has filed suit over the company's plan to use foreign nationals on Latin American routes newly acquired from Eastern Airlines. In a lawsuit filed Thursday in Miami, the Association of Professional Flight Attendants claims the plan violates American's contract with the 14,500-member union. Earlier this week, American asked a Fort Worth federal judge to rule that the Railway Labor Act does not apply to flight attendants outside the United States and international flights to and from U.S. gateway cities. American, the nation's largest airline, has agreed to pay Eastern $335 million for its routes between Miami and 15 Latin American nations. The sale is a key part of Eastern's reorganization plan. American plans to hire all of Eastern's employees outside the United States, including flight attendants who are not U.S. citizens and who apparently will not be members of the airline's independent flight attendants' union. The union also sought a preliminary injunction barring American from going ahead with its plans until the matter is put to arbitration. The Fort Worth-based airline is to begin serving some of the routes by July 1 and to serve them all by late August. ``What is at stake here is not only international flying in and out of Latin America to U.S. cities such as Miami, but international flying throughout the world,'' said Cheryle Leon, president of the flight attendants union. Ms. Leon said the union had made an offer that would have allowed American to employ temporarily the foreign flight attendants coming from Eastern, but American rejected the offer. Maureen Moore, an American attorney, said the airline has no choice but to hire those Latin American attendants now flying with Eastern because it agreed to do so as part of the acquisition. Eastern had been held to the same obligation when it acquired those routes from the old Braniff International Airways in 1982, shortly before Braniff filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition and ceased operating for nearly two years. Ms. Moore said the flight attendants' union does not have a clause in its contract defining the extent of union coverage. And since American contends that the Railway Labor Act does not apply outside the United States, the airline believes the APFA has no right to represent citizens of foreign nations who work only on American international flights. ``Besides, some of these people are in their own unions,'' Ms. Moore said.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Asks Creditors for Help in Stocking Shelves
DOC.TEXT: The new head of Ames Department Stores Inc. has appealed to creditors to help the discount retail chain restock its shelves, especially in time for back-to-school sales at the end of summer. Nearly 400 of the company's creditors gathered Thursday in New York to discuss Ames' Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing and how the company plans to dig out of its problems. Stephen L. Pistner, Ames' new chief executive officer, had little to say about the decisions that led the 680-store retailer into U.S. Bankruptcy Court last month. But he asked for cooperation. ``I expect no favoritism from you, but I expect your honest effort to get us back in business quickly,'' he said. Ames has sought protection from creditors while it files a plan to reorganize. Thursday's meeting was called by the U.S. Trustee's office, an arm of the bankruptcy court, to choose a committee of creditors to participate in the case. Michael Cook, a bankruptcy attorney representing Ames, said the company owes an estimated $528 million to 33 banks, $355 million to bondholders and an estimated $350 million to suppliers. Antonio Alvarez, a financial consultant, said the company has $45 million in cash available. Ames also has received court approval to borrow $25 million from Chemical Bank in New York. Chemical has agreed to lend Ames up to $250 million. A hearing to approve that financing is scheduled for next Tuesday in New York, Alvarez said. Pistner said Ames intends to use the money to restock its stores. Company President George Granoff said the shelves are bare because many manufacturers stopped shipping merchandise in March when they feared the company could not pay its bills. Pistner said he and Granoff are studying the chain's merchandise to determine which items the company will continue to sell. He said they also will decide how many stores to close. Pistner also said he is evaluating Ames' managers. ``Very quickly I'll be changing key members of the team,'' he told creditors. ``You'll see quite a few changes and you'll recognize some of the names. I've had literally hundreds of calls from people asking to join up.''

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Nekoosa Chairman Bails Out With Golden Parachute
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Chairman William R. Laidig, who failed in his effort to thwart Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s takeover, resigned Friday, the company said. The company said it anticipates Laidig's successor will be Ronald P. Hogan, who currently is vice chairman of Great Northern and president and chief operating officer of Georgia-Pacific. Laidig's departure comes roughly a month before Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific plans to complete its $65.75-a-share merger. ``He put out a letter to employees saying that he agreed to help during the transition and had done that to the point it was most productive,'' Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill said. Hill referred questions on Laidig's future plans to the departing executive. Laidig did not immediately return telephone calls. Laidig will leave with a ``golden handshake'' worth millions of dollars. After Georgia-Pacific initiated its unsolicited takeover attempt last fall, the Great Northern board approved a sweetened package that calls for Laidig to get three times his base salary plus his highest annual bonus of the past three years. The company's 1989 proxy statement listed Laidig's salary at $707,000 a year. Laidig had been chairman since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Weekly Production Rises
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 229,305 cars and light trucks this week, up from 223,556 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. The production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 247,776 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 138,863 cars this week, compared with 133,262 a week ago and 159,730 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 90,442, compared with last week's 90,294 and last year's 88,046. Canadian automakers were to build 28,825 cars this week, up from 26,971 a week ago and last year's 19,451. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 21,555, compared with 21,254 a week ago and 21,794 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Crop Estimate Sends Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders reacted negatively to U.S. Agriculture Department crop figures. The USDA on Thursday estimated winter wheat production at a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels. That was up 44 percent from last year's drought-reduced harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. This year's corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels and soybean production was pegged at 1.92 billion bushels. Wheat prices were pressured by the larger-than-expected winter wheat production estimate, analysts said. Losses built as the price loss triggered commission house sell stops. Soybean prices were pressured by heavy professional selling, although soyoil offered some support due to the Agriculture Department's forecast of a drop in soyoil inventory. The decline of soybean futures spilled into corn, although new-crop corn was boosted by positive figures in USDA's supply and demand report. At the close, wheat was a { cent to 5{ cents lower with the contract for May delivery at $3.81{ a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to 3 cents higher with May at $2.87} a bushel; oats were 4} cents to 6 cents lower with May at $1.60 a bushel; soybeans were 13{ cents to 17 cents lower with May at $6.31 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Recommends Formation Of Regional Bank
DOC.TEXT: A federal commission studying the nation's poverty-blighted Mississipi Delta has recommended development of a regional bank to get capital to the area's small and minority-owned businesses. It's one of many recommendations in the final report of the Lower Mississippi Delta Development Commission, formed by Congress in 1988 to determine why the resource-rich delta is the poorest in the United States. The report is to be presented to Congress Monday. Section III of the four-section report deals with the problems of private enterprise and how best to develop business in the region, which covers 219 counties in the states of Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Illinois, Tennessee and Kentucky. ``The delta region as a whole has substantial assets in its banking system, and these assets currently total about $78 billion,'' the report noted. But that money isn't getting to the entrepreneurs who need it, according to the report. Bank deposits in the region totalled $59.92 billion for 1989, while loans totalled $44.2 billion for a loan-deposit ratio of 73.6 percent, the report said. Improving that ratio to the national level of 79.5 percent would spur $3.5 billion in additional investment, the report said. ``In each of the Commission's public hearings, Delta business persons addressed the need for greater access to capital and encouraged the Delta Commission to recommend the establishment of a regional funding entity to work with banks to increase the amount of capital available for regional investment,'' the report said. A regional bank could guarantee local bank loans, provide equity loans and various other types of financing to help small and minority-owned businesses get started and help existing businesses expand, the report said. The report encourages state and federal governments, universities, chambers of commerce and others to share knowledge, resources and technology. And it says too few delta business managers ``recognize the need for or have access to the kind of technology, training and resources that will strengthen their skills and expertise as managers.'' The report decries the lack of black business people in the delta. ``Approximately 40 percent of the total population is African American; yet, the involvement of African Americans in the business sector is far less substantial'' the report said. The report also noted that industries in the delta rely too heavily on harvesting its rich agricultural and mineral resources and too little on making products out of them. The report notes Arkansas' success in developing retirement communities and suggests other parts of the delta region could do the same. It also touts tourism for the region, suggesting development of a ``tourism entity'' that could promote the cultural diversity and natural beauty of the area and work with Amtrak to develop a major passenger train corridor through the delta.

DOC.HEAD: Rates on Fixed-Rate Mortgages Slip; Adjustables Up
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.54 percent this week, down from 10.67 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. said Friday. One-year adjustable rate mortgages averaged 8.63 percent this week, up from 8.62 percent last week. The rates, compiled from a national survey, do not include add-on fees known as points.

The stock market climbed to near-record heights in heavy trading today, spurred on by favorable inflation news and falling interest rates. The government reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods dropped 0.3 percent in April, in contrast to Wall Street's expectations of a 0.1 percent-0.3 percent increase. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales fell 0.6 percent last month. Analysts said the figures provided the markets with a double dose of evidence that the pace of the economy remained slow and inflationary pressures were subdued. That served to allay whatever fears persisted on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to tighten credit. Interest rates fell in the bond and short-term money markets.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Says Casino Not For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump said Friday his Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay is not for sale despite comments from the chairman of Hilton Hotels that he is looking into buying the gaming hall. ``It's not for sale at any price,'' Trump said in a telephone interview. Trump refused to say if Hilton Chairman Barron Hilton had approached him about selling the property. ``I have great respect for Barron Hilton,'' Trump said. ``I can't comment on that.'' Hilton said after the company's stockholders meeting Thursday that he might be interested in buying the casino. Hilton Hotels built the casino in 1985 for $320 million but had to sell it after the state Casino Control Commission denied them a license because of ties to reputed organized crime attorney Sidney Korshak. The two commissioners who voted against Hilton are no longer on the panel. Trump Castle placed eighth among the city's 12 casinos in gross gaming revenues last month. Trump has said he wants to sell some of his assets to raise cash, but has added he does not plan to sell any of his three casinos.

DOC.HEAD: Image of Traders Concern of Group
DOC.TEXT: As the trial of three commodities brokers charged in a wide-ranging probe of corruption commenced in a Chicago courtroom, a group of floor traders in New York engaged in an effort to redeem the tainted image of their profession. The Floor Brokers and Traders Association, formed a year after the futures industry came under intense scrutiny for suspected trading abuses, wants to administer its own ethics pledge to traders. In addition, the organization wants to encourage members to attend ethics classes tailored to the moral choices and challenges of trading, in which fortunes can be made and lost in a few minutes' time. Although image is a major concern, the group's president Michael Wilner says the organization will address other issues, such as the controversial practice of dual trading _ which it favors _ and working conditions on the floor of New York's commodity exchanges. The association has attracted about 520 members in the past two months _ among them traders at the New York Mercantile Exchange, the Commodity Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange. Wilner, president of Hilltop Trading Co., said they all have one thing in common _ they are hardworking, down to earth guys. ``Our belief is that the majority of traders are above-board professionals,'' Wilner said. ``And we don't want our image hammered by the misdeeds of a few.'' In Chicago, Danny L. Scheck, Robert D. Mosky and David Zatz are on trial in U.S. District Court on charges stemming from an FBI probe of trading fraud at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade. The government's case rests partly on tapes made by an FBI agent who secretly recorded conversations while posing in 1988 as a corrupt trader in the Swiss franc futures trading pit at the Mercantile Exchange. The government contends the tape recordings reveal a variety of schemes employed by the trio to divert customer profits to their own accounts. But defense lawyers say the tapes portray their clients' proper attempts to verify trades they made with each other and the agent amid the hubbub that is typical of a futures trading pit. Wilner said the association wants to change the image of floor traders from the public perception of them as brash rich gamblers who bet on the future prices of basics ranging from soybeans to pork bellies. The association plans a newsletter to keep traders educated about regulatory issues, to assure they are in compliance with the rules, Wilner said. But image is only one concern of the association. Wilner said the group plans to defend dual trading _ in which floor traders execute customer orders and trade for themselves at the same time. Critics say the practice creates enormous opportunities for cheating and enables traders to executive profitable dealers for themselves before they take care of clients. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the federal agency responsible for policing the futures pits, has proposed phasing in a dual-trading ban. ``Dual trading is appropriate,'' Wilner said, adding that he has found that most customers are comfortable with it. ``The reason it is an advantage is it ensures a high caliber of experience. And compensation comes not only from salary and commission, but from one's own trading account.'' Quality of life issues are also a concern for the group. The Comex, NYMEX, Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange as well as the New York Futures Exchange and the Cotton Exchange all share the same floor space in the World Trade Center. The cramped floor space stunts the growth of the exchanges, and makes the traders' jobs more difficult. The association hopes to have input in the search for larger quarters, as well as find affordable health insurance for traders, Wilner said.

DOC.HEAD: Auction Investors Bet Rates Have Peaked
DOC.TEXT: Investors showed by their vigorous bidding for the Treasury's auction of $30.5 billion in new notes and bonds this past week that they think interest rates have peaked. Moreover, new evidence of moderating inflation and slow economic growth on Friday helped the market end the week with an impressive rally that drove yields on 30-year Treasury bonds toward 8.65 percent. That is a huge move from the 9.05 percent yields that prevailed only two weeks earlier. Market watchers remained divided, however, on whether rates are going to continue to fall, and how soon the decline will be reflected in rates for mortghage and consumer loans. ``Mortgage rates tend to follow Treasury rates with a lag,'' said Lincoln Anderson, economist for Bear Stearns & Co. ``There is a connection, but the linkage is not tight.'' Anderson, who thinks long-term Treasury rates are going to fall by another percentage point or more by the end of the year, said those making mortgage and other consumer loans are going to wait to make sure rates don't bounce higher before they adjust their own lending rate schedules. Mickey Levy, chief economist for First Fidelity Bancorporation of Newark, N.J., said he thinks Treasury rates have peaked and mortgage rates will decline modestly within a month. But other analysts said yields ran up so quickly in April after the government's March consumer price report indicated inflation was accelerating that mortgage lenders did not fully reflect the increase in their rates. As a result, they said, there may be less room for mortgage rates to fall. Chief Economist Lyle E. Gramley of the Mortgage Bankers Association said the potential for further increases in bond prices and rate declines ``is rather limited.'' The former Federal Reserve Board governor said the effective rate on mortgage loans including special charges was close to 11 percent two weeks ago and may have fallen to 10.75 percent in recent days with the potential to drop to 10.50 percent. ``We're not likely to see much better than that,'' he said. Aubrey H. Zaffuto, economist of IBJ Schroder Bank & Trust, said she expects there will be only minimal impact on consumer rates as a result of the drop in Treasury yields. She said the government's borrowing needs are likely to accelerate this summer while credit demands from Eastern Europe will grow, both putting more pressure on interest rates. ``I can't see that we have a clear shot at lower rates. I think they are going to stay where they are now in a trading range,'' she said. The sharp declines in interest rates cut the government's potential borrowing costs considerably from what they had been 10 days earlier. Yields on 30-year bonds had risen as high as 9.05 percent in late April, mainly because reports on March consumer prices indicated to some traders that the economy and inflation were accelerating to the detriment of bond prices. But the government caught a break on May 4 when the employmnet report for April indicated the economy ands inflation were weaker than expected. Bond prices staged one of the biggest rallies of the year that day, dropping yields as low as 8.81 percent on 30-year Treasury bonds. The backdrop for the Treasury refunding auction could not have been better. On Tuesday, investors snapped up $10.5 billion in three-year notes at an average yield of 8.74 percent and turned in more than $3.53 in bids for each $1 in notes sold, the biggest imbalance of that sort since August 1985. There was similarly strong demand for $10 billion in 10-year notes which were sold on Wednesday at an average yield of 8.88 percent. The ratio of $3 in bids for every $1 in notes sold was the second largest on record for a 10-year note auction, according to the investment firm Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The auction concluded Thursday, as $10 billion in 30-year bonds were sold for an average yield of 8.84 percent, lower than the yield commanded by the 10-year notes and another indication of healthy demand. The government's reports on Friday that its producer price index fell 0.3 percent in April as retail sales fell 0.6 percent touched off a rousing rally. By midafternoon, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds were as low as 8.66 percent, or nearly four-tenths of a percentage point below their peaks two weeks earlier. That is an extraordinary move in that time frame. ``They indicated moderating inflation and moderate, maybe slowing, economic activity. That is music to a bond investor's ears,'' said Elliott Platt, who follows the credit markets for Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. ``We were off to the races... It was incredible,'' he said.

Energy Futures Decline As Gasoline Rally Ends
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices declined and carried the rest of the energy market lower as supply concerns abated Friday. The contract for June delivery of unleaded regular gasoline fell 1.79 cents to 61.89 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Earlier in the week, gasoline rose sharply as traders worried that supplies would run tight in the Gulf of Mexico. A pipeline that serves 36 drilling platforms and handles 95,000 barrels of oil a day was shut down, raising the possibility of disruptions to refineries just as they were preparing to process large quantities of crude for the summer driving season. However, concerns eased as fuel cargoes destined for the Atlantic Coast were diverted to the Gulf Coast, and traders consequently sold gasoline lower, said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. The slide in gasoline brought other futures down. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, declined 7 cents to $18.95 a 42-gallon barrel. Heating oil for June delivery dropped 0.79 cent to 50.92 cents a gallon. Natural gas for June delivery fell to $1.565 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.574 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: TBS Net Income $4.3 Million for First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said its had first quarter net income of $4.3 million, compared with a loss of $421,000 in the same three months last year. After payment of preferred stock dividends, however, the company posted a loss of 15 cents for each share of common stock. That compared with a loss of 25 cents a share a year earlier. Revenues rose 25 percent to $291 million from $232 million. The company said it made large expenditures to establish a new investigative reporting unit at Cable News Network and begin original movie productions for the Turner Network Television channel. Such investments, said TBS Chairman Ted Turner, ``are essential to our plans for continued growth.''
