DOC.HEAD: Capture Ban, Growing Demand Sends Dolphin Prices Soaring
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: One of the most valuable investments these days may be a Flipper lookalike. Dolphin prices are soaring. One reason is an unexplained Dolphin illness in the Gulf of Mexico, a prime frolicking ground for the intelligent mammals, which has forced a ban on dolphin captures there. Moreover, demand for flipper lookalikes has jumped markedly from tourist businesses, which range from swim-with-the-dolphin theme park attractions to aquariums and even a casino. Federal officials say they've recently heard of offers made for top performing dolphins from $50,000 to $100,000 apiece, but exact figures are guarded industry secrets. ``So long as they are captured and cared for under the law, I don't care how much money they make,'' said Chuck Oravetz, protected species coordinator for the National Marine Fisheries Service branch in St. Petersburg. ``Economics is not something we delve into.'' But the stakes could keep climbing because the Gulf of Mexico, where nearly all dolphins for display are captured, is off limits until scientists can determine what has caused the 237 known dolphin deaths so far this year. A 90-day federal moratorium on captures was scheduled to last through mid-June but may be extended if the dolphin deaths continue. Even when captures are resumed, new quotas will be in effect to further restrict how many dolphins can be taken from the wild. That will make those in captivity much more valuable. ``It's a matter of the laws of supply and demand,'' said Nick Brown, director of the non-profit National Aquarium in Baltimore, which plans to open a $35 million marine mammal facility by this fall. ``We're having a hard time keeping up.'' In the past year, the National Aquarium's budget to procure dolphins has jumped from $300,000 to more than $1 million because of increased demand, Brown said. Nine facilities, which also include Disney World and the Indianapolis Zoo, have permits to capture a total of 36 dolphins from the Gulf this year. Those plans are on hold. But it's the latest entry into the business that is causing the most controversy _ dolphins will soon compete with showgirls and slot machines at the Mirage hotel and casino on the shimmering Las Vegas strip. ``Whenever a facility has never held dolphins before, there's controversy, especially when it has a lot of money to spend,'' said Ann Terbush, chief of the fisheries service's permit division in Silver Spring, Md. ``I think the Mirage has had an effect on increasing the price of dolphins.'' Behind the Mirage swimming pool, workers are putting the finishing touches on a 1.5 million gallon display that is set to open with six dolphins in September. ``We have a 20,000-gallon tropical fish tank, a rain forest and a display of tigers _ now we'll have a state-of-the art facility for dolphins,'' said Mirage spokesman Alan Feldman. ``It's another attraction that makes the Mirage a special place.'' He emphasized there are no plans for the dolphins to perform tricks and it will not be a swim-with-the-dolphins attraction. ``The primary purpose is to help educate the public about dolphins.'' As a new dolphin display, the Mirage has a federal permit restricting its acquisition to animals already in captivity. Although Feldman would not elaborate on the bids the Mirage is making for dolphins, he said money wasn't the prime concern. ``It's not like something you walk into Sears and buy,'' Feldman said. ``Yes, it's expensive to the extent we are willing to buy dolphins that have been well cared for and that are healthy.'' In April, the Mirage purchased its first dolphin, an 8-year-old female performer named Sigma, from the recently closed SeaArama in Galveston, Texas, fisheries service officials said. ``Price is confidential,'' said SeaArama dolphin supervisor John Dellanera, adding that it was less than the rumored $100,000. ``It was a more than fair price.'' The trading of dolphins as just another marketable commodity galls activists such as Richard O'Barry, a former trainer for the Flipper television series who now runs the Miami-based Dolphin Project, an organization dedicated to protecting dolphins. ``It's a very sleazy business,'' said O'Barry, who has protested the Mirage facility. ``A casino is no place for dolphins,'' he said. ``It's going to be `Dolphins for the Rich and Famous.''' The Dolphin Project follows the activities of known dolphin trappers and attempts to track the prices paid for dolphins. O'Barry said some marine veterinarians routinely charge approved facilities $20,000 to capture dolphins from the wild, while dolphin stars trained to leap for fish and jump through hoops command prices up to $100,000. Jay Sweeney, a San Diego marine mammal veterinarian who has trapped dolphins for several facilities, said the price he charges for the service varies, but it is around $10,000 plus expenses for his boats and crew of eight. Opponents of Dolphin trading say regulation is not tight enough because of the inherent conflict of interest in the Marine Mammal Protection Act. The Commerce Department and the National Marine Fisheries Service, empowered to protect the interests of business, are also in charge of protecting dolphins. But the fisheries service contends there is a misperception about how many dolphins are actually captured and in captivity. Of the estimated 45,000 dolphins in the Gulf of Mexico, the fisheries service reported only 25 captured last year. The quota allowed to be taken this year, if the capture ban is lifted, will be lowered from 91 to 35. There are 351 dolphins in captivity in the United States, fisheries service figures show. Those numbers pale in comparison to the estimated 100,000 dolphins that have died annually in the nets of tuna fleets fishing in the eastern tropical Pacific. Tuna companies selling brands such as Starkist, Chicken of the Sea and Bumble Bee have recently announced they've switched to fishing methods that won't kill the dolphins. Regardless of the emphasis on commercialization, the National Aquarium's Brown says dolphin displays not only satisfy the national fascination for the creatures, but also promote understanding. ``I don't see the silent majority out there jumping on this bandwagon that targets dolphin displays as an issue like the homeless or abortion,'' he said. ``Being able to go some place and see dolphins goes a long way toward making people aware of their environment and conservation efforts.''

DOC.HEAD: Strengthening Yen Sends Dollar Into Tailspin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS West German mark value to 1.6378 in 20th graf
DOC.TEXT: The dollar went into a tailspin against the Japanese yen Friday as investors reassessed the health of the Japanese and U.S. economies. The yen's dramatic advance began overnight in Tokyo, where record-setting trading volume in the Japanese currency signaled that investor confidence in Japan's economy was being renewed. The move was hastened later in the United States on fresh government reports indicating the economy is weakening and inflation is being curbed. But by the close of domestic trading, the dollar had recovered against all currencies except the yen and the British pound. Nearly $22 billion worth of yen changed hands Friday in Tokyo, more than double an average day's volume of around $8 billion to $9 billion, said James McGroarty, senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Greenwich, Conn. As the yen soared, the dollar spiraled down. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 154.15 yen, off 2.60 yen from Thursday. It fell further in London, where it settled at 153.75 yen, and later closed at 152.70 yen in New York, off sharply from late Thursday's 156.50 yen. Friday's trading in New York represented a roughly 3.5 percent drop from a week earlier, when the dollar traded at about 158.30 yen in New York. Traders were ``quite surprised by the significant drop in the value of the dollar overnight, which precipitated further selling'' when trading shifted to U.S. markets, McGroarty said. A Labor Department report showing an unexpected 0.3 percent decline in April wholesale prices, coupled with a 0.6 decline in retail sales during the month, accelerated the dollar's fall. The reports fueled the notion that the Federal Reserve will not need to raise interest rates to cool the economy. Higher interest rates increase the relative attractiveness of returns on dollar-denominated securities. That helped spark rallies in other U.S. markets. Stock prices shot higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing up more than 63 points, and bond prices rising more than $17.50 per $1,000 in face value. But despite the speculation of lower U.S. interest rates, the day's foreign exchange activity was ``more of a yen story than a dollar story,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. He said investors were beginning to react to the Group of Seven's contention that Japan's economic fundamentals do not justify such a low yen. Earlier this month in Washington, finance ministers of the seven leading industrialized nations agreed to support a higher yen to prevent ``undesirable consequences'' for the world economy. While there has not been any evidence of central bank intervention to push the yen higher, heavy yen-buying ``implies major investors have had another reassessment (and said) maybe things aren't that bad in Japan,'' McGroarty said. Analysts note the Japanese stock market, which had lost 30 percent in value since January, is beginning to recover and Japan's bond market remains strong. On the surface, the dollar's decline against the yen appeared to be a logical progression, because the U.S. currency traded at two-year lows against the Swiss franc and the West German mark this week. But some market observers are bearish on dollar's near-term future as well. ``The market is losing its enthusiasm for speculating in favor of the dollar,'' Brusca said. ``Over the past few days (investors) have been acutely aware of ... the pressure on the Fed to ease rates and the potential for a tax hike to occur.'' In London, the British pound rose to $1.6817 from $1.6770 late Thursday. In New York the dollar rose to $1.6790 from Thursday's $1.6775. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6378 West German marks, up from 1.6325; 1.3995 Swiss francs, up from 1.3915; 5.5295 French francs, up from 5.5115; 1,207.75 Italian lire, up from 1,202.75, and 1.1758 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1703. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6300 West German marks, down from 1.6368; 1.3955 Swiss francs, up from 1.3950; 5.5096 French francs, down from 5.5235; 1.8330 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8407; 1,200.40 Italian lire, down from 1,205.75, and 1.1783 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1650. Gold prices fell worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $1.30 a troy ounce to settle at $368.80 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted bullion at $368.50 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, down $2 from late Thursday. In London gold fell to a late bid of $369.05 a troy ounce from $371.35; in Zurich, gold fell to a closing $368.80 an ounce from $371.25. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.12 to close at a bid of $369.10 a troy ounce. Silver prices also fell. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery slipped to $5.043 a troy ounce from $5.088 on Thursday. In London, silver fell to a late bid of $5.06 a troy ounce from $5.08.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Lower on Bearish USDA Crop Figures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders reacted negatively to U.S. Agriculture Department crop figures. On other markets, precious metals futures were lower, livestock prices were mostly higher, pork was mixed and energy prices fell. Wheat settled a { cent to 5{ cents lower with the contract for May delivery at $3.81{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents lower to 3{ cents higher with May at $2.87{ a bushel; oats were 5{ cents to 6\ cents lower with May at $1.60 a bushel; soybeans were 14{ cents to 17{ cents lower with May at $6.32 a bushel. Traders gave a bearish interpretation to the figures released Thursday by the Agriculture Department. The USDA estimated winter wheat production at a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels. That was up 44 percent from last year's drought-reduced harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. This year's corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels and soybean production was pegged at 1.92 billion bushels. The size of the projected wheat harvest was larger than expected, triggering Friday's selloff. Thoughts that the large crop could spur export sales gave some support to the market, though, analysts said. Soybean prices were pressured by heavy professional selling, although soyoil offered some support because of the Agriculture Department's forecast of a drop in soyoil inventory. The decline of soybean futures spilled into corn, although new-crop corn was boosted by positive figures in USDA's supply and demand report. Precious metals prices were lower on the New York Commodity Exchange. Selling of gold was a continuation of selling on the overnight markets, said Peter Caudillo, an analyst with Josephthal & Co. in New York. The market also was pressured by the release of figures from the Labor Department that showed inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989. Wholesale prices actually fell in April. Investors usually buy gold as a hedge against inflation. ``The malaise in the market also is due to the heavy producer selling by Australia and South Africa and the threat of gold sales by the Soviet Union'' to finance grain purchases, Caudillo said. Gold was $1.40 to $1.70 lower with June at $370.50 a troy ounce; silver was 4.5 cents to 5 cents lower with May at $5.065 a troy ounce. Energy futures were mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange. There was little news to influence the market, said Robert Baker, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. However, crude oil gained support during its fall from a report Kuwait was cutting back on spot sales, an indication it was complying with OPEC efforts to cut back production. Gasoline prices plunged as the market realized the tightness in gasoline stocks was not as severe as first believed, Baker said. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 1 cent to 14 cents lower with June at $18.95 a barrel; heating oil was .27 cent to .92 cent lower with June at 50.92 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .55 cent to 1.79 cents lower with June at 61.89 cents a gallon. Livestock futures were mostly higher and pork futures mixed in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle prices received support from expectations the number of cattle going into feed lots in coming months will decline, said Tom Morgan of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington, Ill. Pork prices were pressured by lower cash prices and the belief the market is overbought after a run up in prices in recent weeks, Morgan said. Live cattle were .13 cent lower to .22 cent higher with June at 74.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent lower to .22 cent higher with May at 84.82 cents a pound; hogs were .67 cent lower to .10 cent higher with June at 63.65 cent a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to .75 cent higher with May at 64 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Market Exults as Wholesale Prices, Retail Sales Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf, `Financial markets ...' to UPDATE with closing stocks, bonds and dollar; picks up 8th graf, `The reports ...'
DOC.TEXT: A record drop in vegetable costs contributed to a second straight decline in wholesale prices last month, the government said Friday, sparking rallies in the stock and bond markets. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, one stop short of retail, fell a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent last month. It was the sharpest decline since August and the third consecutive moderate report after a severe cold snap sent prices spiraling 1.8 percent in January. The index fell 0.2 percent in March and was unchanged in February. ``The inflation scare is over,'' declared economist Lawrence A. Hunter of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. For the first four months of the year, inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales unexpectedly slumped 0.6 percent in April, the third month without an increase. Financial markets rallied and interest rates fell in response to the reports. Traders said the figures provided a double dose of evidence that economic growth and inflation remain subdued. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks climbed 63.07 to 2,801.58, its third highest closing ever. The price of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond surged 1} points, driving the yield down more than an eighth of a percentage point to 8.66 percent. Lower rates knocked the dollar, however. It dropped to 152.70 Japanese yen, off 3.80 yen from Thursday. The reports, along with one last week showing the April unemployment rate rising to 5.4 percent, likely will convince Federal Reserve monetary policy makers to leave interest rates unchanged when they meet Tuesday, economists said. Prior to the April figures, many economists believed the Fed would nudge interest rates higher out of concern that growth was rebounding too strongly and inflation was reigniting. ``We started the year worrying about a recession, then we worried about inflation and now there's worry about a recession again. People are zigzagging on this,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. A panel of 19 economists employed by the nation's largest corporations on Friday predicted slow but sustained economic growth through 1991. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, will grow 2 percent in 1990 and 2.6 percent in 1991, down from 3 percent in 1989, they said. The forecast was released in Hot Springs, Va., where the nation's top corporate executives are gathering for a meeting of The Business Council. The Labor Department said food prices fell 0.6 percent in April after an identical decline a month earlier. Prices rose for eggs, rice, pasta and pork. They fell for fruit, chicken, cooking oils and candy. Vegetable prices, which fell 25.5 percent in March after record increases in the preceding two months, fell an additional 31.1 percent last month. It was the biggest drop since the government began tracking those costs in 1967. Tomato prices fell 73.3 percent. Energy prices dropped 1.7 percent after declining in the two previous months. Gasoline prices, with the start of the warm weather driving season, climbed 2.2 percent. Fuel oil prices, however, fell 1.9 percent while natural gas costs dropped 5.5 percent. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices rose a modest 0.2 percent after rising a 0.3 percent advance in March. Economists said this ``core'' number is often a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy than the calculation that includes food and energy expenses. Automobile prices fell 0.9 percent in April. Clothing price inflation recovered from increases a month earlier. Women's, men's and boys' clothing costs were unchanged. Girls' and infants' clothing prices fell 0.2 percent. Prices rose for medicines, soap, floor coverings and toys. They fell for alcoholic beverages, jewelry and magazines. The various changes put the index for all finished goods at 117.0 in April. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 would have cost $117 last month, up from $113 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process were moderate in April. Prices for intermediate goods rose a slight 0.1 percent. Crude good prices fell 3.1 percent, pulled down by a 12 percent drop for crude oil, the largest in four years. An example of the three processing stages _ finished, intermediate and crude _ would be clothing, cloth and cotton. Despite the moderate report for wholesale prices last month, some economists remain concerned that inflation may accelerate this year. Consumer prices, up at an annual rate of 8.5 percent in the first quarter, are rising at a steeper pace than wholesale costs. Why the divergence between the two sets of prices? Wholesale prices reflect only the cost of goods, while consumer prices are heavily influenced by the cost of services, which have been less affected by the economic slowdown of recent months. Economic growth has slowed enough to soften demand and hold down goods prices, but not enough to greatly affect employment and thus the cost of services. ``Whatever inflationary pressures there are in the economy are stemming from the relative scarcity of labor,'' said economist Sandra Shaber of The Futures Group, a Washington consulting firm.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that close was third highest
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rose sharply to near-record heights Friday in an exuberant reaction to favorable inflation news and falling interest rates. Trading volume picked up to its heaviest pace of the year as the market extended a two-week old rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 63.07 points to 2,801.58, its third-highest close ever and less than nine points below the peak of 2,810.15 reached on Jan. 2. Over the past 10 sessions the average has risen 156.53 points, or 5.9 percent. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 7 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,282 up, 339 down and 384 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 234.04 million shares, up from 158.46 million Friday and the largest total since a 240.39 million-share day on Dec. 15. The government reported Friday morning that the producer price index of finished goods dropped 0.3 percent in April, in contrast to Wall Street's expectations of a 0.1 percent-0.3 percent increase. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales fell 0.6 percent last month. Analysts said the figures provided the markets with a double dose of evidence that the pace of the economy remained slow and inflationary pressures were subdued. That served to allay whatever fears persisted on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to tighten credit. Interest rates fell in the bond and short-term money markets. Prices of long-term government bonds rose about $17.50 for each $1,000 in face value, reducing their yields to the 8.66 percent-8.73 percent range. Among actively traded blue chips, American Express rose 1 to 28}; International Business Machines 1| to 114; Exxon 1\ to 47~; Philip Morris ~ to 44\, and American Telephone & Telegraph 1 to 42\. Bank and other financial issues drew some particular benefit from increasing hopes that a ``credit crunch'' could be avoided with interest rates headed down. Citicorp gained 1\ to 24; Chase Manhattan 1[ to 25[; J.P. Morgan 1\ to 36}, and BankAmerica { to 29]. Among the mortgage issues, Federal Home Loan Mortgage jumped 3\ to 70[ and Federal National Mortgage was up 2 at 38}. Securities-industry stocks also got a lift. Merrill Lynch climbed 2 to 23{; Salomon 1] to 22~; PaineWebber 1 to 17|, and Charles Schwab } to 16{. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 273.78 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $68.90 billion, or 2.10 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 4.10 to 192.24. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 9.24 to 409.45, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 8.18 at 352.00. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 4.90 to 438.10. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 352.50, up 3.58.

DOC.HEAD: Douglas Plans 1000 More Layoffs in Latest Blow to California Aerospace
DOC.TEXT: At McDonnell Douglas Corp. in Long Beach, at Lockheed Corp. in Burbank, at companies that employ a quarter-million workers in Los Angeles County alone, the question is the same. How much worse can the aerospace business get in California? Aerospace, for decades one of the biggest cogs in the state's $700 billion economy, is now threatened on one side by defense cuts, on the other by the high costs of living and doing business in California. Layoffs are suddenly a near-daily event. On Friday, Gencorp Inc.'s Aerojet division said it would merge two rocket propulsion units in Sacramento, cutting 200 jobs. A week earlier, Aerojet announced more than 200 layoffs at its Chino and Downey plants after losing a key contract. Total Aerojet employment was 7,977 at the end of 1988, 7,237 at the end of 1989, and 7,028 at the end of April, before the latest cuts. On Thursday, McDonnell Douglas increased its estimate of layoffs this summer at its loss-plagued Long Beach aircraft unit from 3,000 to 4,000. Also during the week, Lockheed said it would close its historic Burbank operations by mid-1990. It will move much of the work to an Atlanta suburb to save $75 million a year and make the company a leaner competitor for dwindling government contract work. Lockheed's ``Skunk Works,'' where top-secret researchers dreamed up the U-2 and SR-71 spy planes and the stealth fighter, will stay in Southern California, in the desert city of Palmdale, but a total of 4,500 Lockheed jobs are expected to be lost. Most business analysts say the economies of the state and of the greater Los Angeles area, where aerospace is centered, are far more diversified than during the last big round of defense cuts in 1970-71. That means the aerospace woes won't trigger an all-out regional recession like the one in the late 1980s in the oil states, they say. The latest data available to the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce showed that in the first quarter of 1990, aerospace jobs in the county totaled 270,000, down 14,800 from the first quarter of 1989. Yet in the same year, the total non-farm jobs in the county rose by 99,000 to 4.3 million. ``So that to me indicates that, yes, we've been having some major hits from aerospace, but the economy has a little more resilience that the nay-sayers would lead you to believe,'' said Jack Kyser, the chamber's chief economist. Kyser acknowledged, though, that many of the aerospace job losses came in a category that's hard to replace: high-paying blue-collar jobs at a time when the cost of housing has skyrocketed. David Hensley of the UCLA Business Forecasting Project expects that in the next few years California's economy will grow at only about the national rate of 2 percent, down from the 7 percent yearly clip of the mid-1980s. The latest UCLA forecast, released in March, predicted California aerospace employment would fall from 361,000 in 1989 to 316,000 in 1992. Hensley says he'd put the number even lower today. Not only is the aerospace pie shrinking, but bigger pieces of it are being carved up out of state, where land and labor costs are cheaper. ``In the 1980s we opened a lot of facilities out of state,'' said Richard H. Dore, a spokesman for General Motors Corp.'s Hughes Aircraft Co. unit in El Segundo, still the biggest employer in Southern California. Hughes employment, which peaked at 80,000 in 1985, has now stabilized at about 68,000 after 9,000 layoffs last year. The loss of jobs in Southern California, though, is greater than 12,000 because of the growth in out-of-state employment.

DOC.HEAD: China's Favored Nation Status Looms As Next Crisis in US-Chinese Ties
Graphic planned
DOC.TEXT: Disastrous and catastrophic are the words most frequently used to describe the possible U.S. suspension of China's trade status as a most-favored nation _ and that's just American businessmen talking. One senior Chinese executive, Wei Mingyi of the state-run China International Trust and Investment Corp., said it would set relations back 20 years. In 1970, the two countries did not even have diplomatic ties. The issue may not be decided for weeks. President Bush must decide by June 3 whether to renew China's MFN status for another year, and he is expected to act in China's favor. But critics in Congress may try to overrrule him as part of their attempt to ostracize China for its suppression of political dissenters, symbolized by the army attack on student protestors last June 4. The critics argue economic retaliation is an important weapon to pressure China into reform. This means the battle over China's trade status with the United States, a crucial part of their relationship, could be prolonged. China and its allies on this issue in the American business community have begun readying for the fray _ only the latest round in Washington's debate over whether sanctions help or hurt the cause of democracy in China. The United States imposed limited economic sanctions last year, but Bush has eased several, such as a ban on high-tech exports. Signaling how seriously China takes the threat to MFN, in the past two weeks it lifted martial law in the Tibetan city of Lhasa and announced the release of 211 pro-democracy protesters. Both moves were widely seen as an effort to counter criticism of its human rights record. It also disclosed that authorities allowed 238,000 people go abroad on private business last year, which it said was up 11 percent from the previous year. U.S. law bars giving MFN status to any country that denies residents freedom of emigration. American businessmen in Beijing and Hong Kong, meanwhile, have begun a letter-writing campaign to their congressmen urging that MFN be extended. The American Chamber of Commerce in Beijing issued a nine-page position paper arguing that revoking MFN would be ``catastrophic to American business interests in China and American consumers of Chinese products.'' The chamber's Hong Kong branch, worried because most U.S.-China trade passes through the territory, sent a delegation to testify on Capitol Hill this past week. ``To revoke MFN would be an act of economic warfare, and it's an act on the Chinese people, not the Chinese government,'' said an American businessmen who has lived in Beijing for several years. ``I was here last June. It's been a sad time to be here in China,'' he said. ``But ... let's not slam the door on them. I know many Chinese people and I have yet to find one who thinks it would be helpful to lift MFN.'' Most-favored-nation status, which the United States grants to all but a few nations, substantially reduces tariffs on goods exported to the United States. Without it, the U.S. tariff on Chinese-made sweaters would rise from the current 6 percent to 60 percent. The duty on Chinese toys would go from less than 7 percent to 70 percent, the Washington-based U.S.-China Business Council has estimated. Toys, sweaters and other garments accounted for most of China's $12 billion in exports to the United States last year, which in turn comprised nearly one-third of China's total exports. With higher tariffs, Chinese sales to the United States would drop at least 50 percent, the council predicted. Most U.S. toy and clothing merchandisers could find alternate suppliers, but for Chinese manufacturers, ``there really isn't another market,'' said a Western economist in Beijing, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Their exports to Japan and the European Community are growing very slowly. They're just not going to sell much of this stuff to South Korea and Indonesia,'' he said. The impact on the Chinese economy could be serious, especially in the export-driven coastal areas, analysts agree. China has not said how it would retaliate, but at a minimum it likely would suspend reciprocal preferential tariffs. That could affect U.S. wheat farmers and fertilizer and airplane manufacturers, leaders in the United States' $5.7 billion worth of exports to China. U.S. joint ventures in China fear suspending MFN could create so much hostility that they would be unable to operate. The American Chamber of Commerce predicted problems in getting Chinese government cooperation essential to obtain loans, contracts, raw materials and even electricity. Recent commentaries in China's official media have warned that political relations would suffer as well. The U.S. business community's outcry over the prospect of losing the China market comes in sharp contrast to its usual complaints about the slowness and expense of doing business in China. ``China's always been a difficult place to do business,'' acknowledged a representative for a major American sportswear importer. ``You have to make a lot of trips to the factories to guarantee quality. You really have to do a high volume to make a profit.'' But he added, ``China has one-fourth of the world's people. Even if you have to go through a lot of hassles _ no other place can replace China.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday May 14

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Soar On Signs Of Calm Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd grafs, The Treasury's ... to UPDATE with closing yield of 8.66 percent.
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rocketed higher Friday, swept up by new evidence that the economy is not overheating and by relief that the Treasury successfully has completed its quarterly auctions of new securities. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond climbed 1} points, or about $17.50 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield tumbled to 8.66 percent from 8.83 percent late Thursday. The big rally reflected a marked change in market psychology. Only two weeks ago, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds were pushed over 9 percent because of worries that the econonmy and inflation were moving at such a rapid clip that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates higher. But over the past six sessions, a series of new government reports have convinced many traders that the economy is growing only moderately and inflationary pressures are subsiding. ``The markets have had a fairly remarkable six days,'' said Steven A. Wood, economist for BankAmerica Capital Markets Group in San Francisco. Friday's rally came a day after the completion of the government's three-day quarterly refunding, in which a record $30.5 billion in new notes and bonds were auctioned to finance government operations. In when-issued trading, the yield on the Treasury's new 30-year bond tumbled to 8.64 percent from an average yield of 8.84 percent at auction on Thursday. Trading was described as fairly active on Friday after the government released a pair of economic reports that indicated the Federal Reserve will not be inclined to raise interest rates, which would erode the value of bonds. The Labor Department reported wholesale prices edged down 0.3 percent, while many analysts had expected a 0.2 percent increase. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales fell a steep 0.6 percent in April. The reports appeared to verify the conclusions about the economy that traders drew from last Friday's April employment report showing lower than expected job creation and wage inflation. Over the past three days, the Treasury found investors enthusiastic about buying new three-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds, evidently in an effort to lock in current yields because they expected rates to fall. Wood said he thinks there is room for further rate declines next week when the government reports on industrial production and consumer prices for April. ``I think the market has room to do little better, and even if those reports are wore, I don't think it will give all of these gains back,'' he said. But other analysts warn that the market has gained so much ground so quickly a reversal could lie ahead. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose by \ point to { point, intermediate maturities gained by between | point and 1 3-32 points and long-term issues rose as much as 1} points, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 8.61 to 1,149.32. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 27-32 to 91 1-16. The average yield to maturity tumbled to 7.54 percent from 7.62 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.86 percent as the discount lost 10 basis points to 7.61 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.05 percent as the discount fell 7 basis points to 7.64 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.20 percent as the discount fell 10 basis points to 7.63 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: States Reportedly Approve Plan to Restrict Insurers' Holdings of Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Regulators in 11 states on Thursday approved recommendations aimed at limiting insurance companies' holdings of junk bonds, a newspaper reported. The restrictions on the high-yield, high-risk bonds are expected to be approved by regulators from all 50 states next month and would be binding on insurers, The New York Times said in an early edition of Friday's paper. ``Our motivation is to prevent companies from concentrating their investments in these bonds,'' the Times quoted Terence Lennon, assistant deputy superintendent of the New York State Insurance Department, as saying. Lennon headed the subcommittee of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners that issued the recommendations. Regulators are proposing to phase in the guidelines over five years beginning in 1991 in an effort to prevent a selloff in the distressed junk bond market. Lennon said that schedule shouldn't force insurers to dump their holdings. ``I believe we're taking a very rational position,'' he was quoted as saying. The recommendations would require insurers to set aside higher reserves against some of their junk bond holdings to cover the risk of possible losses. It also would shorten the length of time companies can take to accumulate reserves. The Times said it wasn't clear if insurance companies would set aside higher reserves to meet the guidelines or sell their holdings. It estimated insurance company holdings at $50 billion to $60 billion, or about a quarter of the $225 billion market. The junk bond market has been depressed in recent months in part because of federal rules last year that required savings and loans to sell their holdings by 1994. Defaults by several major issuers and the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which dominated the issuing and trading of junk bonds, also have hurt the market.

DOC.HEAD: Recap of Economic Reports and How Financial Markets Reacted
DOC.TEXT: Government reports released Friday suggesting a weak U.S. economy had an enormous impact on the financial markets, driving up stocks and bonds but depressing the dollar. Here is a glance at what happened:
DOC.HEAD: Wholesale prices down
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department reported the sharpest drop in wholesale prices since last August and economists decreed the inflation scare over. The 0.3 percent drop was the second straight monthly decrease in wholesale prices, which could translate into retail price declines.
DOC.HEAD: Retail sales down
DOC.TEXT: The Commerce Department said retail sales, a closely watched statistic that reflects consumer confidence in the economy, fell 0.6 percent in April, the biggest setback in six months. Economists said this raised the prospect of a further slowdown in months to come and growing inventories of unsold goods.
DOC.HEAD: Stocks and bonds soar
DOC.TEXT: Investors reacted gleefully to the economic news, snapping up stocks and bonds on the theory that interest rates won't rise and may even decline if the Federal Reserve believes it must loosen credit to thwart a recession. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip stocks jumped 63.07 points, the biggest one-day advance of 1990, putting the well-known barometer at 2,801.58, just short of its 2,810.15 all-time high. Broader indexes also jumped in heavy trading volume. In the bond market, a key barometer of the economy and interest rates, the 30-year Treasury bond jumped nearly $17.50 per $1,000 in face amount and its yield fell to 8.66 percent, vs. more than 9 percent just two weeks ago.
DOC.HEAD: Dollar tumbles
DOC.TEXT: Money brokers dumped dollars on the belief that a weak U.S. economy will translate into lower interest rates, which means investments priced in dollars will be worth less. Instead they snapped up Japanese yen and other foreign currencies. By the time currency trading concluded late Friday in New York, the dollar had partly recovered but remained sharply lower against the yen and British pound.

A record drop in vegetable costs contributed to a second straight decline in wholesale prices last month, the government said. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index for finished goods fell a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent last month, the sharpest decline since August and the third consecutive moderate report. For the first four months of the year, inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.2 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989.

Stock prices rocketed to near record-heights as favorable inflation news and falling interest rates drew investors to Wall Street. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks finished up 63.07 at 2,801.58 on Friday, short of the record high close of 2,810.15 reached on Jan. 2. It was the biggest one-day advance for the Dow average this year.

Another big drop in auto demand contributed to a 0.6 percent decline in retail sales in April, the biggest setback in six months. The Commerce Department said Friday that sales fell to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion last month after a 0.2 percent decline in March. Private economists warned that the lackluster sales likely would translate into slower economic growth in the months ahead as businesses face growing inventories of unsold products.

Leaders of top U.S. businesses said the economy will grow only moderately this year and next but will manage to stave off a recession. Inflation is on the way down, they said Friday, predicting that the first-quarter annual inflation rate of 8.1 percent will be cut nearly in half. Economic growth will total about 2 percent in 1990 as it accelerates gradually from 1.9 percent in the first half of the year to 2.3 percent in the second, according to the Business Council, 100 chief executives of the nation's largest corporations. Growth will rise to 2.6 percent in 1991.

Amax Inc., the nation's third-largest coal producer, has offered $1.25 billion to acquire industry leader Peabody Holding Co., raising the possibility of a bidding war with a major Peabody investor. The bid on Friday was rejected immediately by Hanson Industries, which owns 45 percent of Peabody and is attempting to buy the rest. Hanson responded by raising its offer for the Peabody shares it doesn't own. The remaining 55 percent of St. Louis-based Peabody is owned by Newmont Mining Corp. of Denver. Hanson, in turn, owns 49 percent of Newmont.

Stroh Brewery Co. wants to buy Heileman Brewing Co. and form a new No. 3 beer maker, Stroh senior vice president and chief legal officer George Kuehn says. But Heileman President Murray Cutbush replied Friday that he was skeptical about joining with a company ``that has an absence of strong senior management, an uncertain direction ... and an eroding distributor network.'' Stroh President Roger Fridholm told a business strategists' group on Wednesday that Stroh still wanted to buy Heileman, according to a story in The Detroit News that Kuehn confirmed Friday.

Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Chairman William R. Laidig, who failed in his effort to thwart Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s takeover, has resigned. Great Northern said Friday it anticipates Laidig's successor will be Ronald P. Hogan, who is vice chairman of Great Northern and president and chief operating officer of Georgia-Pacific, which expects to complete its $65.75-a-share merger next month.

Donald Trump said his Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay is not for sale despite comments from the chairman of Hilton Hotels that he is looking into buying the gaming hall. Trump said Friday Trump Castel is ``not for sale at any price.'' He refused to say if Hilton Chairman Barron Hilton had approached him about selling the casino. Hilton said after the company's stockholders meeting Thursday that he might be interested in buying the casino.

A former executive of United Technologies Corp. was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $5,000 for conspiring to obtain inside information about Pentagon competition for a lucrative Navy contract. Roger K. Engel, 49, who was vice president of the company's Norden Systems division in Norwalk, Conn., was sentenced Friday by U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va.

Bond prices staged a huge rally in repsonse to evidence of moderation in the economy and inflation. The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen but finished higher against most other major currencies. Grain, soybean and precious metals futures prices closed mostly lower; livestock prices were mostly higher; pork was mixed and energy prices fell.

DOC.HEAD: Bolt Maker, Two Former Employees Plead Guilty In Inspection Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest manufacturer of aircraft bolts and fasteners pleaded guilty Friday to charges of conspiring to falsify test reports on the parts and agreed to pay $18 million in penalties and costs. Two former employees of the company, VSI Corp., also pleaded guilty to one count each of conspiracy. The case, part of a continuing investigation into wrongdoing in the aerospace industry, recovered the most money of any action stemming from information received under the federal whistleblower law, U.S. Attorney Mike McKay said. Under the law, three former VSI employees who complained about the phony tests will be entitled to share at least $2.1 million, McKay said. ``For at least 14 years, VSI intentionally deceived its customers, including the U.S. government,'' McKay told a news conference. ``VSI did this to cut corners and line its pockets.'' Parts manufactured by VSI are used throughout the civilian and military aircraft industry, with about half the company's products sold to the government or defense contractors. McKay said the falsified reports covered millions of fasteners, including some bought for the B-2, B-1 and B-52 bombers, C-5B transport plane and F-18, F-15 and F-16 fighters. Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said the fasterners are used on virtually every Boeing product, including civilian airliners. No accidents have been traced to faulty fasteners, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Bruce Carter, who prosecuted the case. Before U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein, VSI pleaded guilty to three counts of mail fraud and one count of conspiracy to commit mail fraud, provide false statements to the government and defraud the United States. The pleas were entered by company Vice President Donald S. Parker. James E. Ryan, a former quality assurance manager at VSI's Voi-Shan plant in Chatsworth, Calif., and Aram Marderian, a former metallurgical laboratory supervisor for Voi-Shan, also pleaded guilty to one count each of conspiracy. Rothstein set sentencing for Aug. 17. Ryan and Marderian, both of whom have agreed to cooperate in further government investigations, each face up to five years in prison and up to $250,000 in fines. As part of the plea agreement, VSI agreed to pay a fine of $2.5 million and the estimated $1 million for the costs of the investigation. To resolve a separate civil whistleblower case, VSI will make an additional payment of $14.5 million. The three whistleblowers will share 15 percent to 25 percent of that, McKay said. VSI, a subsidiary of Fairchild Industries Inc., and Ryan and Marderian were charged Wednesday. The government alleged that from 1975 or earlier to February 1989, some required tests were omitted, test results were altered, parts were reworked in violation of specifications and falsified reports were given by VSI to Boeing, Northrop, McDonnell Douglas, Lockheed, General Electric, Pratt & Whitney, the Defense Department and other customers. The stamp of a fictitious ``Inspector 11'' was used to indicate that some tests had been completed successfully, the complaint said. Some bolts that failed tests were delivered with documents indicating they met specifications, and other required tests weren't performed, the complaint said. In other instances, tests were performed on fewer parts than required. The mail fraud charges involved phony test results provided to Boeing at Seattle and Wichita, Kan., General Dynamics in Fort Worth, Texas, and Northrop in Los Angeles, Carter said. VSI will cooperate fully with the government and wants ``to put all this behind it,'' Parker said. ``If anyone out there is not identified as a wrongdoer, we're going to cooperate to bring them to justice,'' he said. Parker said senior management at the company didn't find out about the fraud until February 1989, when federal agents raided the Voi-Shan plant. But Lawrence Finegold, an attorney for Ryan, said his client had been following an ``inherited practice'' that had gone on for years. Carter said evidence in the case indicated ``quality control fraud really was a way of life'' at the Chatsworth plant. The probe was triggered by a complaint from whistleblower Tom Runion shortly after he left his job in the metallurgical laboratory at the Chatsworth facility, Carter said. Runion and two others are plaintiffs in the whistleblower suit that was unsealed Friday in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles, Carter said. He said inadequate Voi-Shan parts were found during aircraft assembly and installation and were returned to the manufacturer but investigators do not know whether there have been any imminent safety threats. Investigators learned that of the government and civilian buyers of Voi-Shan fasteners, Boeing and Northrop Corp. especially had been rejecting substantial deliveries after doing their own tests. Boeing said it has inspected and tested the fasteners, and retested certain lots of materials. It said Voi-Shan materials met all Boeing specifications and requirements and use of them ``has not compromised the integrity of Boeing products.''

DOC.HEAD: Amax Bids For Peabody Coal; Hanson Increases Offer In Response
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT to Amax sted Amex.
DOC.TEXT: Amax Inc., the nation's third-largest coal producer, made a $1.25 billion offer Friday for industry leader Peabody Holding Co., raising the possibility of a bidding war with a major Peabody investor. he bid was rejected immediately by Hanson Industries, which owns 45 percent of Peabody and is attempting to buy the rest. Hanson responded by raising its offer for the Peabody shares it doesn't own. The remaining 55 percent of St. Louis-based Peabody is owned by Newmont Mining Corp. of Denver. Hanson, in turn, owns 49 percent of Newmont. Hanson in March offered to buy Newmont's stake in Peabody for $715 million. But under terms of the sale agreement between Hanson and Newmont, the companies agreed to consider outside bids for all of Peabody until the deal with Hanson closed. Closing tentatively was scheduled for sometime next month, said Newmont spokesman James Hill. After New York-based Amax disclosed its bid Friday, Hanson immediately increased its offer for Newmont's Peabody stake to $725.6 million. That tops the $718.5 million that Newmont's stake is worth under the Amax offer, Hanson said. Hill said Newmont's agreement to sell its Peabody stake to Hanson remained in effect but that the Amax bid started an auction process for Peabody. ``It is to ensure that the highest bidder gets it,'' he said. Hanson, the U.S. arm of Britain's Hanson PLC conglomerate, acquired its Peabody stake in February for about $504 million from Boeing Co., Bechtel Investments Inc. and the energy company Eastern Enterprises. ``Although their (Amax's) bid would benefit Hanson by providing a premium for the stake which we already own, we are determined to complete our acquisition of Peabody,'' said Sir Gordon White, chairman of Hanson Industries. Hanson Industries acquired its 49 percent stake in Newmont through its purchase of Consolidated Gold Fields PLC, the British gold mining company, in 1989. Amax, which also is a major aluminum producer, has said for some time that it plans to increase its coal holdings, said spokesman Mitchell Badler. He said Peabody would help boost Amax's already substantial reserves in low-sulfur coal, which is in demand because it pollutes less than high-sulfur varieties. ``We thought it was a good fit,'' he said. He said Amax envisioned no antitrust concerns in its bid because of the fragmented nature of the coal industry. An Amax-Peabody combination would control less than 12 percent of the nation's coal production, he said. Badler said he did not know whether Amax would increase its bid in light of Hanson raising its offer. Newmont decided to put Peabody up for sale after it failed to carry out a restructuring of the coal company, Hill said. Newmont took on a heavy debt load in 1987 after it paid out a special $2.2 billion dividend to shareholders to avoid a takeover from T. Boone Pickens. It has been selling assets to reduce the debt, and also planned to have Peabody issue junk bonds and pass along some of the proceeds to Newmont, Hill said. But that plan fell through when the junk bond market went sour last year, he said. In consolidated trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, Hanson PLC's American Depositary Receipts rose 62{ cents to $18.87{, Newmont shares rose 62{ cents to $46 and Amax shares fell 12{ cents to $25.25.
